plants.culturalInformation: Abelmoschus manihot (sunset muskmallow), perennial, 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with large, deeply lobed, dark green leaves and large, pale yellow, bowl-shaped flowers with maroon centers in late summer and fall. Native to tropical southeastern Asia south to eastern Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Cut to the ground in midwinter to renew. Sunset: N/A

Abies pinsapo (Spanish fir), evergreen tree, slow growing to 50-75 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with short, stiff, aromatic, needlelike, bluish green leaves and cylindrical cones that stand upright at ends of branches. Native to rocky soils on dry mountain slopes in southern Spain and northern Morocco. Sun to light shade, slightly acidic, well-drained soils. Accepts more heat and dryness than many other firs. Sunset: N/A

Abronia latifolia (yellow sand verbena), perennial, low mat, 4-6 inches tall and 2-5 feet wide, with succulent, round, green leaves and small, rounded clusters of bright yellow flowers from spring to fall or almost year round. Native to sand dunes and sandy soils along the immediate coastline from Santa Barbara County to southwestern British Columbia. Sun to part shade, fast-draining, sandy soils. Prefers saline water. Not easy outside its native range and habitat. Sunset: N/A

Abronia maritima (red sand verbena), perennial, low mat, 4-6 inches tall and 2-5 feet wide, with succulent, oval, green leaves and rounded clusters of pink or purplish flowers from early spring to fall or almost year round. Native to sand dunes and sandy soils along the immediate coastline from southern California and the Channel Islands to Baja California. Sun to part shade, fast-draining, sandy soils. Prefers saline water. Not easy outside its native range and habitat. Sunset: N/A

Abutilon palmeri (Indian mallow), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with velvety, heart-shaped, gray-green leaves and golden yellow to orange, bell-shaped flowers in spring and summer. Native to dry, rocky soils in mountains of southern California, Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 8-9,11-13

Acacia aneura (mulga), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk or low branching, 15-20 feet tall and 12-15 feet wide, with linear, silvery gray-green, leaflike structures (phyllodes) and a rounded or spreading habit. Short, cylindrical clusters of bright yellow flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by brown, beanlike seedpods. Native to dry grasslands and shrublands in inland areas of much of Australia where limited rainfall is distributed throughout the year. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia baileyana (Bailey acacia), evergreen tree, usually multitrunk, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with fine-textured leaves divided into many small, silvery blue-gray leaflets and smooth or furrowed, pale to dark gray bark.  Small, spherical clusters of tiny, bright yellow, lightly fragrant, flowers in late winter to early spring are followed by long, beanlike seedpods. Native to southern New South Wales, Australia. Short lived. Can be weedy. Considered high risk for invasiveness in parts of California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,13-24

Acacia berlandieri (guajillo), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 5-15 feet tall and wide, with gray-green leaves divided into feathery leaflets, similar to A. greggii but branches lack thorns. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, creamy yellow flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to southern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Senegalia. Sunset: 10-24

Acacia boormanii (Snowy River wattle), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with narrow, gray-green leaflike structures (phyllodes) and silvery gray bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in mid-winter or early spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Suckers and may form thickets. Native to the mountains of southeastern Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia cognata (bower wattle), evergreen tree, fast growing to 15-30 feet tall and wide, with narrow, drooping, bright green leaflike structures (phyllodes) on pendulous branches. Small, spherical clusters of tiny, pale yellow flowers in late winter or spring are followed by small, beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal southeastern Australia. May be offered as A. subporosa var. linearis. 'Cousin Itt' is 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide; may be offered as 'Mini-Cog'. May not be reliably winter hardy when grown on exposed sites in Region 2, in this region spring planting may be preferable to fall planting. Sun to light shade, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-24

Acacia constricta (whitethorn acacia), deciduous shrub to small tree, usually multitrunk or low branching, 10-20 feet tall and wide, with medium green leaves divided into feathery leaflets on usually spiny branches. Small, spherical clusters of tiny, bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to desert grasslands and shrublands from western Arizona to western Texas and south to central Mexico. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. May be offered as Vachellia. Sunset: 8-24

Acacia covenyi (blue bush), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide, with fine-textured, silvery blue, narrowly elliptical  leaflike structures (phyllodes) and dark gray-brown to almost black bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in late winter or spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal mountains of southeastern Australia. Short lived. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia craspedocarpa (leatherleaf acacia), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 6-12 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with leathery, oval, silvery gray-green, leaflike structures (phyllodes), new growth coppery. Short, cylindrical clusters of bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by bright yellow-green seedpods. Native to inland south-central Western Australia, often along streams or in seasonally flooded areas. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia cultriformis (knifeleaf wattle), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with small, silvery gray-green, triangular  leaflike structures (phyllodes) on arching stems and dark brown to greenish gray bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in early spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-24

Acacia dealbata (silver wattle), evergreen tree, fast growing to 40-50 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, gray-green to bluish gray leaves divided into many feathery leaflets and gray bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, pale to bright yellow flowers in late winter to early spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to open forest and woodlands in much of southeastern Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Acacia decurrens (green wattle), evergreen shrub or tree, fast growing to 15-50 feet tall and 10-25 feet wide, with dark gray-green leaves divided into many feathery leaflets. Small, spherical clusters of bright yellow flowers at branch ends are followed by large, brown seedpods. Spreads by suckers to form thickets. Native to rocky soils in foothills and valleys of southeastern Australia. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Acacia erioloba (camelthorn), deciduous tree, broadly flat-topped and low branching, slow growing to 20-35 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with leaves divided into feathery, bluish green leaflets on thorny branches. Small, spherical clusters of yellow flowers in early spring are followed by large, curved, semi-woody seedpods. Native to sandy or rocky soils in semi-arid savannas and desert grasslands of southern Africa, often along streams. May form thickets by suckering roots. Sun, fast drainage. May be offered as Vachellia. Sunset: N/A

Acacia glaucoptera (clay wattle), evergreen shrub, prostrate and 4-6 feet wide or upright to 4-6 feet tall, with overlapping, bluish gray-green, triangular, leaflike structures(cladodes), new growth tinged purplish red. Small, spherical clusters of yellow flowers in late winter to late spring followed by shiny, black, beanlike seedpods. Native to southwestern Western Australia. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. May need occasional pruning to remove dead wood. Prostrate forms drape over walls. Sunset: N/A

Acacia greggii (catclaw acacia), deciduous shrub or small tree, fast growing to 15-20 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, gray-green leaves divided into narrow, feathery leaflets on branches armed with substantial spines. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, creamy yellow flowers in spring and summer are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to desert slopes and washes from southern Utah to southeastern California and from Baja California east to western Texas and northern Mexico. May form thickets. Long lived. Sun, fast drainage. May be offered as Senegalia. Sunset: 10-24

Acacia iteaphylla (willow wattle), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-12 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with a rounded, somewhat weeping habit and long, narrowly linear, bluish gray-green leaflike structures (phyllodes), new growth tinged pinkish red. Small, spherical clusters of pale yellow flowers in late winter are followed by light brown, beanlike seedpods. Native to sandy or rocky soils in mountains of southeastern South Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Accepts saline soils. Good seaside plant. Can be weedy or invasive. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia linearifolia (golden wattle), evergreen tree, fast growing to 10-30 feet tall and 6-15 feet wide, with narrow, gray-green, lance-shaped to linear leaflike structures (phyllodes) and smooth, gray-brown bark. Small, round clusters of golden yellow flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by reddish bown, beanlike seedpods. Native to dry, exposed slopes and woodland openings on rocky or sandy soils in foothills of southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Acacia longifolia (Sydney golden wattle), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with light green, lance-shaped leaflike structures (phyllodes) and smooth, gray bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in late winter to mid-spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal southeastern Australia. Self-sows readily and can be weedy or invasive. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as A. latifolia. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Acacia melanoxylon (blackwood acacia), evergreen tree, fast growing to 40-50 feet tall and 20 feet wide, with medium green, lance-shaped leaflike structures (phyllodes) with pinnate leaves at the tips and rough, dark gray bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, pale yellow to creamy white flowers in late winter to early spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal southeastern Australia. Self-sows readily and sprouts from spreading roots. Roots can lift pavement. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: N/A

Acacia merinthophora (zig-zag wattle), evergreen shrub, 8-12 feet tall and wide, with long, thin, gray-green leaflike structures (phyllodes) on weeping branches. Short, cylindrical clusters of yellow flowers from late fall to early spring are followed by narrow, curved, beanlike seedpods. Native to sandy or rocky soils inland in central and southern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 13-17,19-24

Acacia pendula (weeping acacia), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with narrowly elliptic, silvery blue-gray leaflike structures (phyllodes) on weeping branches. Small, spherical clusters of pale yellow flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by curved, brown, beanlike seedpods. Native to sandy soils inland in southeastern Australia.  Sun to part shade, most soils. Accepts periodic flooding. Sunset: 13-24

Acacia pennatula (pennatula acacia), semi-deciduous tree, fast growing to 15-25 feet tall and wide, flat-topped and wide spreading, with spiny branches bearing pendulous, feathery, green to grayish green leaves divided into many leaflets. Spherical clusters of yellow-orange flowers in early spring are followed by linear, beanlike seedpods. Native to hot, dry woodlands and grasslands in much of central to southern Mexico and Central America. Can be weedy or invasive. May be offered as Vachellia. Sunset: N/A

Acacia podalyriifolia (pearl acacia), evergreen tree, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with small, oval, silvery blue-gray leaflike structures (phyllodes) and small, spherical clusters of golden yellow flowers in late winter or early spring followed by large, brown, beanlike seedpods. Native to rocky slopes and ridges in southeastern Queensland and northeastern New South Wales, Australia. Sun, excellent drainage. Can be weedy or invasive. Sunset: 8-9,13-24

Acacia pravissima (Ovens wattle), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 15-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with small, triangular, bluish gray-green leaflike structures (phyllodes) on pendulous branches and smooth, gray bark. Small, round clusters of lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in winter and spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to the mountains of southeastern Australia, often near streams. 'Golden Carpet' is 2-4 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-24

Acacia redolens (prostrate acacia), evergreen shrub, 1-4 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaflike structures (phyllodes) and small, spherical clusters of tiny, pale yellow flowers in late winter or spring followed by narrow, beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal and inland areas of southern Western Australia. 'Desert Carpet' and 'Low Boy' are 1-2 feet tall. Needs ample room to spread. Weedy and potentially invasive in parts of southern California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia rigidula (rigidula acacia), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, multitrunk, slow growing to 8-15 feet tall and wide, with oval to rounded, dark green leaflike structures (phyllodes) on stiff, thorny branches. Short, cylindrical spikes of pale yellow flowers in spring are followed by reddish brown, beanlike seedpods. Suckers and may form thickets. Native from western Texas through central Mexico. Part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Vachellia. Sunset: 10-13

Acacia saligna (blueleaf wattle), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 8-20 feet tall and wide, with dark bluish green, lance-shaped leaflike structures (phyllodes) on weeping branches. Small, spherical clusters of bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by long, narrow, beanlike seedpods. Native near the coast and inland in western and southwestern Western Australia. Suckers and may form thickets. Self-sows and can be invasive. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Acacia schaffneri (twisted acacia), deciduous or semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, multitrunk or low branching, 15-20 feet tall and 20-25 feet wide, with mid-green leaves finely divided into feathery leaflets and short, sharp thorns on dark brown, almost black, branches. Spherical clusters of tiny, bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to deserts of northeastern Mexico and southwestern Texas. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Vachellia. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia stenophylla (shoestring acacia), evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-40 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with long, narrow, drooping, grayish green leaflike structures (phyllodes) on pendulous branchlets. Small, spherical clusters of pale yellow flowers in late winter or spring are followed by long, beanlike seedpods prominently constricted between each seed. Native to eastern Australia, usually along streams or seasonal watercourses. Sun to part shade, most soils. Accepts periodic flooding. Adaptable. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Acacia subporosa (subporosa acacia), evergreen tree, 20-30 feet tall and wide, with pendant, bright green, narrowly linear, leaflike structures (phyllodes) on pendulous branches. Spherical clusters of tiny, pale yellow flowers in spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to sandy soils along the coast of New South Wales, Australia, often along streams. Sun, most well-drained soils. A. cognata, with even narrower phyllodes, is closely related and sometimes offered as A. subporosa var. linearis. Sunset: N/A

Acacia triptera (spur wing wattle), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, upright and open or low and spreading, with spine-tipped, oval, blue-green leaflike structures (phyllodes) with broadened bases that encircle long, curving stems. Short, cylindrical clusters of tiny, bright yellow flowers from coppery buds in spring are followed by curved, beanlike seedpods. Native to rocky soils in mountains of eastern Australia. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Acacia vestita (hairy wattle), evergreen shrub or small tree, 10-15 feet tall and wide, with oval, gray-green leaflike structures (phyllodes) with pointed tips densely covering pendulous branches. Spherical clusters of tiny, bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to west-facing mountain slopes in New South Wales, Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Good along the coast or inland. Trim lightly as needed to shape. Sunset: 13,15-17,19-24

Acacia willardiana (palo blanco), deciduous or semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with long, narrowly linear, leaflike structures (phyllodes) that terminate in two small, mid-green, pinnately compound leaves. Drops leaves in winter but phyllodes remain. Papery white bark peels to reveal silvery white underbark. Cylindrical, brush-like spikes of pale yellow flowers in winter to late spring are followed by long, bean-like seedpods. High canopy, few branches, and willowy foliage cast little shade. Native to dry, rocky slopes and desert washes in northwestern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Mariosousa. Sunset: 12-24

Acalypha californica (copperleaf), evergreen shrub, 3 feet tall and wide, with light green, broadly oval to almost heart-shaped, rough-textured leaves with serrated edges that take on coppery red tones in summer and short spikes of tiny, pinkish red flowers in winter and spring. Native to dry, rocky slopes and flats in foothills and deserts of southern California, southern Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Acanthus mollis (shade in the desert) (dormant in summer in CV)
Acanthus spinosus (dormant in summer in CV, perennial in shade on coast)

plants.culturalInformation: Acca sellowiana (pineapple guava), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-20 feet tall and wide, with dark green, oval leaves, silvery gray beneath, and showy, spring or early summer, white and pink flowers with brilliant red stamens. Flowers are followed by rounded to pear-shaped, gray-green fruit. Fruit and leaf drop can be messy.  Native to the highlands of southern Brazil to Paraguay, northern Argentina, and Uruguay. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Feijoa. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Achillea ageratifolia (Greek yarrow), perennial, 4-8 inches tall and 12-18 inches wide, with small, linear to lance-shaped, silvery gray-green, aromatic leaves and loose clusters of small, bright white flowers on short stems in late spring. Native to rocky or sandy soils in northern Greece and the Balkans. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Achillea clavennae (silvery yarrow), perennial, 4-6 inches tall and 10-12 inches wide, with deeply cut, silvery gray, aromatic leaves and flat-topped clusters of small, white flowers on short stems in early summer to fall. Native to the mountains of central and southeastern Europe. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Achillea filipendulina (fernleaf yarrow), perennial, low basal clump 2-3 feet wide, with soft, aromatic, bright green, finely divided leaves and broad, flat-topped clusters of tiny, golden yellow summer flowers on 3- to 4-foot, leafy stems. Native to rocky or sandy soils from Iran and Afghanistan north to the Caucasus and east to central Asia. Spreads by rhizomes and by seed. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24,A1-3

Achillea millefolium (yarrow), perennial, upright to mat-forming and 2-3 feet wide, with finely divided, aromatic, green to gray-green leaves and broad, flat-topped clusters of tiny, white to yellowish white flowers on leafy, 2- to 3-foot stems. Spreads by rhizomes and by seed, sometimes aggressively. Native to a wide range of habitats in temperate regions of Asia, Europe, and much of North America. ‘ Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24,A1-A3

Achillea millefolium native cultivars (yarrow), perennials, variable, from upright to mat-forming, with dark green to gray-green or silvery gray, aromatic leaves and clusters of small, white to yellowish or pinkish white flowers on 1- to 3-foot leafy stems in spring and summer. Spread, sometimes aggressively. Species is native to a wide range of soils, temperatures, elevations, and moisture regimes in temperate regions of Asia, Europe, and much of North America. 'Island Pink', a vigorous spreader from the Channel Islands in southern California, has dark green leaves and bright pink flowers. 'Calistoga', from the North Coast Ranges in northern California, has silvery gray leaves and creamy white flowers. 'Sonoma Coast', from coastal central California, has green leaves and white flowers. 'King Range', from coastal Humboldt County in northern California, has large clusters of creamy white flowers. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-24,A1-3

Achillea tomentosa (woolly yarrow), perennial, dense mat, 3-6 inches tall and 12-18 inches wide, with aromatic, woolly, gray-green, finely divided leaves and small, flat-topped clusters of yellow flowers on short stems. Native to southern Europe and western Asia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24,A1-3

Achillea x kellereri (Keller's yarrow), perennial, 6-10 inches tall and 1 foot wide, with silvery gray, finely divided, aromatic leaves and flat-topped clusters of tiny, bright white flowers with yellow centers in summer. Natural hybrid of uncertain parentage found in Bulgaria, believed to involve A. clypeolata and A. ageratifolia or A. depressa, three species from the Balkan region. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 1-24,A1-3

Acmispon glaber (deer weed), perennial, mounding 2-3 feet tall and 3 feet wide, with tiny green leaves on wiry, green stems. Small clusters bright yellow flowers in spring through summer age to orange and are followed by slightly upcurved and tapered seedpods. May drop some leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to dry slopes in California, Arizona, and northern Mexico. Full sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Lotus scoparius. Sunset: N/A

Acmispon rigidus (rock pea), perennial or subshrub, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with upright stems bearing leaves divided into several narrowly oval, green leaflets and small clusters of yellow pea flowers in spring that age to red-orange. Native to desert slopes and washes from southeastern California and Arizona south into Baja California and northwestern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Lotus. Sunset: N/A

Adenanthos cuneatus 'Coral Drift' (flame bush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with scalloped, wedge-shaped, silvery gray-green leaves, new growth bright coral pink, and small, red flowers in spring and summer. 'Coral Carpet' is similar but 6-10 inches tall. Species is native to sandy soils along the southern coast of Western Australia. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Adenanthos detmoldii 'Metallica' (yellow jugflower), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, grayish green leaves on upright branches and yellow to orange, tubular flowers in winter and spring. Species is native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Adenanthos drummondii (woolly bush), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and 4-7 feet wide, with soft, silvery gray-green leaves deeply divided into flattened, lance-shaped leaflets and red, tubular flowers from spring through fall. Natural hybrid between A. sericeus subsp. sericeus and A. cuneatus, two species native to the south coast of Western Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as A. x cunninghamii. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Adenanthos meisneri (woolly bush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with soft, silvery gray-green leaves deeply divided into linear leaflets and clusters of purplish pink, tubular flowers in summer and intermittently year round. Native to sandy soils in coastal southwestern Western Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Adenanthos sericeus (coastal woolly bush), evergreen shrub, upright to 8-12 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, needlelike but soft and silky, silvery gray-green leaves, new growth bright green, and dark pink to bright red flowers in spring and summer. Native right along the coast in southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Adenanthos cunninghamii (Albany woollybush), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 4-7 feet wide, with silvery bluish gray-green leaves divided into flattened, linear segments and small, pinkish red, tubular, spring flowers mostly hidden among the leaves. Natural hybrid between A. sericeus and A. cuneatus, both native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Best near the coast, but fine inland with afternoon shade. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Adenostoma fasciculatum (chamise), evergreen shrub, variable, 3-12 feet tall and 1-8 feet wide, with small clusters of bright green, resinous, needlelike leaves and showy clusters of tiny, creamy white, tubular flowers at branch ends in spring and summer. Native to dry slopes and flats, coastal and inland, in California and Baja California. The variety prostratum is a low-growing plant from the northern Channel Islands. 'Black Diamond' and 'Nicholas' are low-growing cultivars. Sun, most well-drained soils. Can be cut back hard to renew. Sunset: N/A

Adenostoma sparsifolium (red shanks), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk, 6-18 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with narrow, resinous, light green, aromatic leaves, shaggy, reddish brown, exfoliating bark, and small, fragrant, white flowers in summer and fall. Native to dry inland slopes in mountains and valleys from southern San Luis Obispo County to northern Baja California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Adiantum spp. (shade) CA native and non-native

plants.culturalInformation: Aechmea recurvata var. recurvata (false tillandsia), succulent, compact rosette of stiff, yellowish green, spiny-edged leaves with centers that turn red when the plant is in flower. Spreads by offsets to form a tight clump 1-2 feet tall and wide. Purple flowers surrounded by showy magenta bracts are produced in the center of the rosette in mid-spring to early summer. Native to shaded forests in southern Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, and northeastern Argentina. Prefers shade to part shade, but best color is in cool sun. Can be grown as an epiphyte or in well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Aeonium species (tree houseleek), succulents, rosettes a few inches to 3 feet tall and a few inches to 1 foot wide, long-stemmed, short-stemmed, or stemless, with waxy green or purple, spoon-shaped leaves and conical or triangular clusters of white, yellow, pink, or red flowers in winter followed by papery seedpods. Rosettes die after flowering. Some stemless and short-stemmed plants reproduce by offsets, and branched long-stemmed plants continue to grow on after individual rosettes die. Native to rocky soils in the Canary Islands, coastal Morocco, and Madeira. Many cultivars. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 15-17,20-24

Aesculus californica (California buckeye), deciduous tree or large shrub, 15-40 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with silvery gray bark, medium green leaves consisting of five large leaflets, upturned clusters of fragrant, creamy white flowers at branch ends in spring, and large, shiny, brown seeds from pear-shaped pods in fall. Leaves tend to turn yellow and drop in mid-summer. Native to coastal mountains and Sierra Nevada foothills from southwestern Oregon to southern California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Agastache barberi (pink hyssop), perennial, 2 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with aromatic, rough-textured, narrowly oval to lance-shaped, gray-green leaves with serrated margins and tall spikes of bright pink to magenta flowers on stems a foot above the leaves in summer and fall. Native to Arizona and New Mexico. Sun to part shade, good drainage. May be offered as A. pallida. Sunset: 2-24

Agastache cana (mosquito plant), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with aromatic, pointed oval, bluish gray-green leaves and upright spikes of tubular, reddish to purplish pink flowers in late summer. Native to dry, rocky slopes in mountains of New Mexico, western Texas, and northern Mexico. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 2-24

Agastache rupestris (licorice mint), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, aromatic, silvery gray-green, linear leaves and upright spikes of tubular, reddish orange flowers with purplish sepals. Native to cool mountain slopes at mid-elevations in Arizona, New Mexico, and northern Mexico. 'Apache Sunset' has orange flowers with pink sepals. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Sunset: 1-24

plants.botanicalName: Agave americana (and thick-leaved relatives)(CA native and non-native)
plants.culturalInformation: Agave americana and thick-leaved relatives (agave), succulents, 1-4 feet tall and wide, with rosettes of thick, stiff, green to blue-green or blue-gray leaves with sharp marginal teeth and a terminal spine. Yellow or creamy white flowers on a 10- to 30-foot stalk after many years. Flowering occurs only once, at maturity, after which the rosette dies and is replaced by few to many offsets that form a slowly expanding colony. Native to arid and semi-arid regions of North, Central, and South America. Among many other thick-leaved agaves are A. havardiana, A. palmeri, A. parryi, and A. victoriae-reginae. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, excellent drainage, especially where winter rainfall is substantial. Usually more tolerant of hot sun and frost than soft-leaved agaves. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Agave attenuata (and thin-leaved relatives) (Ca native and non-native)
plants.culturalInformation: Agave attenuata and thin- or soft-leaved relatives (agave), succulents, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with rosettes of flexible, green to grayish green or bluish green leaves lacking marginal teeth or spines, although some have sharp points or spines at leaf tips. Greenish yellow or creamy white flowers on tall, arching stalks at maturity. Rosettes die after flowering, in some species replaced by offsets at the base, in others by plantlets that form on the decaying stalk. A. attenuata is native to rocky outcrops on the west-facing side of the mountains of central Mexico. Other soft-leaved agaves, all native to central western, northeastern, or eastern Mexico, are A. attenuata subsp. dentata (A. pedunculifera), A. bracteosa, A. desmetiana, A. geminiflora, and A. vilmoriniana. Cool sun to light shade, good drainage. Most need protection from both hot sun and frost. Best near the coast. Sunset: 13,20-24

Agonis flexuosa (peppermint tree), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-35 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with narrow, lance-shaped, gray-green, aromatic leaves on pendulous branches, deeply fissured, gray-brown bark, and clusters of small, white flowers in spring or summer. Leaf drop can be messy. Native to sandy soils, a few miles inland from the coast, in southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 15-17,20-24

Ailanthus altissima (tree-of-heaven), deciduous tree, fast growing to 40-60 feet tall and wide, with long, medium to dark green, aromatic leaves divided into many lance-shaped leaflets. Branched sprays of pale yellow flowers in spring are followed by winged fruits. Spreads by seed and by suckering roots and can form dense, widespreading colonies. Native to northern and central China, Taiwan, and northern Korea. Naturalized and invasive in temperate climates throughout the world. Sun to light shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Albizia distachya (plume albizia), deciduous shrub or small tree, fast growing to 12-25 feet tall and wide, with feathery leaves divided into tiny, bright green leaflets. Brushlike spikes of greenish yellow flowers with prominent stamens in spring and summer are followed by large, beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Spreads readily by seed and can be weedy or invasive. Dropping of leaves, flowers, and fruit can be messy. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Paraserianthes lophantha. Sunset: N/A

Albizia julibrissin (silk tree), deciduous tree, fast growing to 20-40 feet tall and 20-50 feet wide, low branching and wide spreading, with large, feathery, dark green leaves divided into many finely divided, oblong leaflets. Clusters of fluffy, fragrant, pink flowers in summer are followed by beanlike seedpods. Spreads by seed. Fallen leaves, flowers, and seedpods can be messy. Native to Asia from Iran to Japan. Needs summer heat. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be short lived. Sunset: 4-23

Albuca juncifolia (rush-leaved albuca), perennial from bulb, 6-12 inches tall and wide, with a few narrow, upright, grasslike or rushlike, mid-green leaves and pendant, green-striped, yellow flowers in spring. Native to sandy soils in Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Alcea rosea cultivars (hollyhock), perennial, narrowly upright to 6-8 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with a stout, central, mostly unbranched stem, large, rounded and lobed, rough-textured, mid-green leaves with scalloped margins, and large, bowl-shaped, white, pink, or purplish red flowers on upright stems in mid-summer to fall. Origin unknown, possibly southeastern Europe or western Asia. Many cultivars offer smaller size and double or semi-double flowers in a wider range of colors. Short lived. May self-sow. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Althaea. Sunset: 1-24

Alchemilla alpina (mountain lady's mantle), perennial, a few inches tall and 8-12 inches wide, with glossy, green leaves leaves divided into lance-shaped leaflets with silvery white margins and dense clusters of tiny, yellowish green flowers on 6- to 8-inch stems in summer. Native to mountain meadows, streambanks, and open woodlands in northern and western Europe. Cool sun or light shade, well-drained soils. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: 1-9,14-17

Alchemilla mollis (lady's mantle), perennial, mounding 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with rounded, softly hairy, shallowly lobed and scalloped, light green leaves and loose clusters of tiny, star-shaped, greenish yellow flowers in early summer. Native to the mountains of southeastern Europe and western Asia from the eastern Carpathians to the Caucasus. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Self-sows prolifically. Sunset: 1-9,14-24,A2-3

Allium species native to California and the Mediterranean (allium), perennials from bulbs with one to several narrow, grasslike leaves and flat-topped to spherical clusters of tiny, star-shaped or cup-shaped flowers on leafless stalks in spring. Strong onion odor from all parts of the plant. Leaves of most die back with peak bloom. May self-sow. Dormant or partially dormant in summer. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Allium spp. mostly from CA or Mediterranean
plants.culturalInformation: Allium spp. native to California and the Mediterranean (allium), perennials from bulbs with one to several narrow, grasslike leaves and flat-topped to spherical clusters of tiny, star-shaped or cup-shaped flowers on leafless stalks in spring. Strong onion odor from all parts of the plant. Leaves of most die back with peak bloom. May self-sow. Dormant or partially dormant in summer. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Allocasuarina torulosa (forest oak), evergreen tree, narrowly upright to 25-45 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with pendulous, green, needlelike branchlets (cladodes) that turn coppery brown in winter and deeply fissured, corklike, gray-brown bark. Inconspicuous, reddish brown flowers in fall or winter are followed by rounded, woody, conelike fruits. Native along the coast and on east-facing mountain slopes in New South Wales and Queensland, Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Casuarina. Sunset: N/A

Allocasuarina verticillata (coast beefwood), evergreen tree, 15-35 feet tall and wide, with long, drooping, gray-green, needlelike branchlets, grayish brown, furrowed bark, and small, brown, conelike fruits. Small winter flowers are orange-yellow on male trees and red on female trees. Native to a variety of habitats, both coastal and inland, in southeastern Australia. Full sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Casuarina stricta. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Alluaudia procera (Madascan ocotillo), deciduous shrub, 15-25 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, succulent, green leaves and sharp, gray spines alternating along mostly upright, unbranched, gray-white stems and occasional tiny, greenish yellow flowers at stem ends. Native to semi-arid southwestern Madagascar. Sun, fast drainage, good air circulation. Best with a dry winter dormancy. Sunset: N/A

Aloe species (aloe), succulents with rosettes of broadly or narrowly lance-shaped, sword-shaped, or roughly triangular leaves, often with soft or sharp marginal teeth, and red, orange, or yellow tubular or bell-shaped flowers on leafless stalks, usually in winter or early spring. Native to many habitats in southern and eastern Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Hundreds of cultivars. Sun to light shade or afternoon shade, excellent drainage. Plant on an angle to allow water to drain rapidly away. Sunset: zones vary

Aloysia macrostachya (aloysia), semi-evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with soft, broadly oval, woolly, aromatic, mid-green leaves, paler and felted beneath, and spikes of tiny, fragrant, lavender flowers from early spring into fall. Native to dry, rocky slopes and gravelly washes in southern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. May be offered as a variety of A. wrightii. Sunset: N/A

Aloysia triphylla (lemon verbena), evergreen shrub, upright and fast growing to 6-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, bright green, aromatic leaves and loose clusters of tiny, white or pale lilac flowers in summer and fall. Native to much of South America from Peru to Brazil and from Chile to Uruguay. Deciduous in cold-winter climates. Full sun, most soils. Best along the coast. May be offered as A. citriodora, A. citrodora, or Verbena triphylla. Sunset: 9-10,12-21

Aloysia wrightii (oreganillo), deciduous or semi-evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with small, oval to rounded, aromatic, green leaves, hairy beneath, and short spikes of small, fragrant, greenish white flowers from spring to fall. Native to rocky slopes and canyons in deserts from California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, good drainage. Sunset: 8-13,19-24

Alstroemeria ligtu hybrids and cultivars (alstroemeria), perennials from tubers, 2-5 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with broadly lance-shaped, bluish green leaves, twisted on their stalks so that the undersides face upward. Flowers are solitary or in loose clusters and come in many shades of orange, red, and near white with intricate markings in darker shades. Leaves appear in late winter and flowers in early to mid-summer. Plants are dormant after flowering. Self-sow and can be weedy or invasive. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as A. chilensis. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Alstroemeria species, hybrids, and cultivars (Peruvian lily), perennials from tubers, 6 inches to 3 feet tall and 6 inches to 2 feet wide, with broadly lance-shaped, bluish green leaves, twisted on their stalks so that the undersides face upward. Loose clusters of flowers in colors ranging from creamy white to yellow, orange, red, pink, purple, or multicolored, many with intricate markings in darker shades. Most species are native to central or northern Chile or to eastern Brazil. Some species are summer dormant, others are dormant in winter, and a few grow and flower almost year round. Most plants in the nursery trade are cultivars that flower in late spring and summer. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Self-sow and can be weedy or invasive. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Alyogyne hakeifolia (red-centered hibiscus), evergreen shrub, fast growing and upright to 6-10 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with fine-textured, dark green leaves divided into narowly linear, threadlike lobes and creamy yellow, lavender, or pink, cup-shaped flowers in summer to fall. Flowers last only a day or two but new flowers continue to open over a long period. Native to coastal South Australia and southeastern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Alyogyne huegelii (blue hibiscus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with deeply lobed, rough-textured, dark green leaves and large, pale blue to purple flowers almost year round. Native to sandy or rocky soils near the coast in Western Australia. 'White Swan' has purple-tinged, white flowers. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Tip prune for a more compact plant. Sunset: 13-17,20-24

Amaryllis belladonna (naked lady), perennial from bulb, 1 foot tall and 2 feet wide, with several medium green, strap-shaped leaves and large, pale pink, trumpet-shaped flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems. Leaves emerge in late fall or winter and die back in spring. Flowers on leafless stems follow in late summer or fall. Native to rocky soils in Western Cape Province, South Africa. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Ambrosia chamissonis (sand bur), perennial, a few inches to 1 foot tall and spreading 6-12 feet wide, with deeply toothed to shallowly lobed or divided, silvery gray-green, woolly leaves and upright spikes of tiny, yellowish green flowers in summer followed by spiny, round burs. Native to sand dunes and sandy soils along the coast of western North America from Alaska to Baja California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ambrosia deltoidea (triangle-leaf bursage), evergreen shrub or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, triangular, gray-green leaves, gray-white beneath, and spikes of tiny, greenish yellow flowers in winter or spring followed by spiny, round burs. Native to dry, gravelly ridges and sandy washes in deserts of southwestern Arizona, Baja California, and Sonora, Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Ambrosia dumosa (white bursage), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, deeply divided, softly hairy, gray-green leaves on stiff, brittle branches and spikes of small, creamy yellow flowers with green bracts that mature to purple and harden to enclose the spiny, spherical fruits. Native to washes, slopes, and dunes in deserts of southeastern California, southern Nevada, western Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ambrosia monogyra (burrow bush), evergreen shrub, upright or spreading to 3-8 feet tall and 3-12 feet wide, with narrowly linear, threadlike, green leaves, often divided into threadlike leaflets, and greenish white flowers in fall followed by winged burs. Native to desert washes and ravines in the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. May be offered as Hymenoclea. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ambrosia pumila (San Diego ragweed), perennial, 4-18 inches tall and spreading widely by branching rhizomes, with lacy, aromatic, softly hairy, bluish gray leaves divided and subdivided into many small leaflets and upright spikes of tiny, yellow flowers in summer and fall. Native to river drainages and grassy edges of vernal pools in foothills, valleys, and coastal mountains of Riverside and San Diego counties and northern Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. Deciduous and dormant in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Amelanchier utahensis (Utah serviceberry), deciduous shrub to small tree, usually multitrunk, 6-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with gray-green, oval to rounded, partially serrated leaves that turn bright yellow in fall and pale gray bark. Clusters of white flowers in late spring and early summer are followed by dark purple fruit. Native to dry, rocky slopes, shady woodlands, and streambanks from southeastern Oregon and southwestern Montana south to northern Baja California and western Texas. Part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Amorpha californica (California false indigo bush), deciduous shrub, 3-8 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with fine-textured, aromatic leaves divided into oval, green leaflets and short, narrow spikes of small, spring and early summer flowers with a single purple petal and prominent stamens topped with bright yellow or orange anthers. Native to dry, wooded slopes or shrublands in foothills and mountains of central and southern California, Arizona, and northern Baja California. Not easy in cultivation. Part shade to shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Amorpha fruticosa (false indigo bush), deciduous shrub, 3-12 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, aromatic leaves divided into oval, green leaflets and narrow spikes of small, spring and early summer flowers with a single purple petal and prominent stamens topped with bright yellow or orange anthers. Native to southern California and northern Baja California east to the Atlantic states and eastern Canadian provinces. Self-sows and may form thickets in moist locations. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Amsonia grandiflora (large-flowered blue star), perennial, variable, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with narrowly lance-shaped to linear or threadlike, mid-green leaves and clusters of small, lavender-tinged or bluish white flowers in spring. Native to mountain canyons in southern Arizona and northern Mexico. Sun to afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Anacyclus pyrethrum var. depressus (Mount Atlas daisy), low mat 4-6 inches tall and 8-18 inches wide, with aromatic, finely dissected, silvery gray-green leaves and bright white daisy flowers with yellow centers on short stems in spring and early summer. Native to rocky soils in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco and Algeria. Self-sows but not aggressively. Good rock garden plant. Sun, fast-draining soils. May be short-lived. May be offered simply as A. pyrethrum. Sunset: 2-24

Anaphalis margaritacea (pearly everlasting), perennial from rhizomes, upright to 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped to linear, mid-green leaves, white-woolly beneath, and 2- to 3-foot stems bearing tiny, yellow flowers surrounded by papery white bracts in late summer. Native to dry, sandy or gravelly soils in mountain meadows, woodland and forest openings, and prairies throughout much of North America. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Andropogon gerardii (big bluestem), warm-season bunchgrass, narrowly upright to 3-5 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with bluish green leaves that turn coppery red in fall and purplish red, late-summer flowers on 5- to 7-foot stems. Spreads by rhizomes and may form a rough sod in moist locations. Native to grasslands and open woodlands in much of midwestern and eastern North America. Sun to part shade, most soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 1-9,14-24

Andropogon scoparius (little bluestem), warm-season bunchgrass, variable, 2-4 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with fine-textured, bluish green leaves and pinkish orange flowers on 3- to 5-foot stems in summer followed by silvery white seedheads. Leaves take on a coppery orange or reddish tinge in fall. Native to the prairies of the midwestern United States and much of the rest of North America. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Self-sows. Can be cut back in early spring. May be offered as Schizachyrium scoparium. Sunset: 1-24

Anemanthele lessoniana (New Zealand wind grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with arching, fine-textured, dark olive green leaves that take on coppery orange tones in fall. Airy, purple-tinged summer flowers. Native to New Zealand, usually along streams or in partly shaded forest openings. Cool sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. May be offered as Agrostis or as Stipa arundinacea. Sunset: 14-24

Anemone coronaria (poppy-flowered anemone), short-lived perennial from tuber, less than 1 foot tall and wide, with finely divided, medium green leaves and red, sometimes white or blue, poppylike, single or double flowers with black centers in spring. Native to the Mediterranean region, most commonly along the coast from Greece to Israel. Many cultivars, some with double flowers. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Angelica pachycarpa (shiny-leaf angelica), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into high-gloss, bright green leaflets with serrated margins and broad, flat-topped clusters of tiny, fragrant, creamy to greenish white flowers on upright stems in spring and early summer. Native to forest openings and grasslands, often along streams, in northwestern Spain and Portugal and naturalized in New Zealand. Self-sows and can be weedy. Short-lived. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Angophora costata (gum myrtle), evergreen tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 30-60 feet wide, with long, lance-shaped, bright green leaves, juvenile leaves more rounded and new growth coppery red. Pinkish or creamy white, peeling bark ages to gray. Showy clusters of white flowers with prominent stamens in late spring to early summer are followed by small, oval seed capsules. Native to sandy soils along the coast and in foothills of southeastern Australia. Sun, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Anigozanthos bicolor (two-colored kangaroo paw), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and  wide, with fans of narrowly strap-shaped, green leaves and hairy, green and red, tubular flowers with pointed lobes on leafless, unbranched, 1- to 2-foot stems in spring. Native to rocky outcrops and open forests inland and along the coast in southwestern Western Australia. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Short lived. Cut flowering stems to the ground after flowering. Best where winters are mild and dry. Sunset: 15-24

Anigozanthos flavidus (kangaroo paw), perennial from rhizomes, 2-3 feet tall and 2-6 feet wide, with fans of narrowly strap-shaped, medium to dark green leaves and loose clusters of hairy, tubular, yellow, pink, orange, or purple flowers with pointed lobes on leafless, branched, 5- to 6-foot stems in spring and summer. Native to river banks and open forests in southwestern Western Australia. Many cultivars. Sun to light shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. Long lived. Cut flowering stems to the ground after flowering. Sunset: 15-24

Anigozanthos hybrids and cultivars (kangaroo paw), perennials from rhizomes, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with green to grayish green, strap-shaped leaves and softly hairy, upright, tubular summer flowers on leafless stems, usually well above the leaves. Species are native to dry, sandy soils in southwestern Western Australia. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Some are dormant and deciduous in summer. All need protection from heavy winter rains. Sunset: 15-24

photos.filename: Anigozanthos manglesii (red and green kangaroo paw)
photos.caption: Anigozanthos manglesii (red and green kangaroo paw)

plants.culturalInformation: Anigozanthos manglesii (red and green kangaroo paw), perennial from rhizomes, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with fans of narrowly strap-shaped, gray-green leaves and loose clusters of hairy, tubular, green flowers with bright red bases and pointed lobes on reddish, sometimes branched, 2- to 3-foot stems in late winter and spring. Native to sandy soils in woodlands and forests of western and southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils, good air circulation. Short lived. Cut flowering stems to the ground after flowering. Sunset: 15-24

Anigozanthos rufus (red kangaroo paw), 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with fans of narrowly strap-shaped, silvery gray-green leaves and loose clusters of hairy, tubular, bright red flowers with pointed lobes on branched, 2- to 3-foot stems in late spring and early summer. Native to sandy soils, both coastal and inland, in southern Western Australia. Cultivars are available that range in flower color from rusty red-orange to maroon. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Cut flowering stems to the ground after flowering. Sunset: 15-24

Anigozanthos viridis (green kangaroo paw), 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with fans of narrowly strap-shaped, gray-green leaves and loose clusters of hairy, tubular, green flowers with pointed lobes on unbranched, 2- to 3-foot stems in late winter to summer. Native to coastal southwestern Western Australia, often in places that are waterlogged in winter. Short lived. Sun to light shade, most soils, including poorly drained. Cut flowering stems to the ground after flowering. Sunset: 15-24

Anisacanthus species (desert honeysuckle), evergreen or deciduous shrubs, upright with small, lance-shaped to narrowly oval, green leaves and tubular, upfacing, red-orange flowers in spring and summer. A. quadrifidus var. wrightii, 3-5 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, is deciduous and native to deserts of southwestern Texas and northeastern Mexico. A. thurberi, 4-7 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, is evergreen and native to deserts of southern Arizona, southwestern New Mexico, and northern Mexico. Sun, most well-drained soils. Need summer heat. Cut back hard in spring to renew. Sunset: 8-13,18-23

Anisodontea hybrids and cultivars (mallow), evergreen shrubs, 3-8 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, rough-textured, lobed, light green leaves and pink to purplish flowers with darker or lighter veins and centers in summer or much of the year in mild climates. Species are native to coastal South Africa. A. x hypomandarum, 6 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with pale pink flowers streaked with magenta, is a hybrid of garden origin commonly offered as A. capensis. 'Tara's Pink', a garden hybrid of A. x hypomandarum and A. scabrosa, is 6-8 feet tall, with larger leaves and flowers. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 14-24

Anthemis carpatica 'Karpatenschnee' (dwarf chamomile), perennial, 6-8 inches tall and 10-12 inches wide, with deeply divided, gray-green leaves and bright white daisy flowers with yellow centers in late spring and summer. Species is native to sandy or rocky soils in the mountains of southeastern Europe. Good rock garden plant. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 3b-10,14-24

Antigonon leptopus (coral vine), evergreen vine from tubers, fast growing to 15-30 feet, with large, often wavy-edged, heart-shaped to triangular, light to dark green leaves and sprays of bright pink or white flowers in late summer and fall. Climbs by twining tendrils. Spreads by seed and vegetatively by stems and tubers and considered a noxious weed in many tropical parts of the world. Native to Mexico. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-13,18-24

Antirrhinum hispanicum (Spanish snapdragon), evergreen subshrub or shrubby perennial, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with small, oval to rounded, felted, gray-green leaves and short, upright spikes of pink, white, or pink-tinged white flowers in spring and again in fall. Native to rocky soils in southeastern Spain and northern Morocco. Cool sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Antirrhinum multiflorum (multiflowered snapdragon), evergreen subshrub or shrubby perennial, 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with upright stems bearing small, lance-shaped to linear, pointed, green leaves and topped with tall spikes of pink and creamy yellow flowers in late spring and summer. Native to gravelly or sandy soils in central Sierra Nevada foothills and coastal mountains from the southern San Francisco Bay Area to northern Los Angeles County. Fast growing and short-lived. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Antirrhinum sempervirens (silver snapdragon), evergreen subshrub or shrubby perennial, 6-8 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with small, broadly oval, lightly hairy, grayish green leaves and creamy white flowers with pale lavender stripes and yellow throats in summer. Native to rocky soils in the mountains of northern Spain. Cool sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: N/A

Apocynum cannabinum (Indian hemp), perennial, upright to 2-6 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes, with lance-shaped, green leaves and flat-topped clusters of tiny, greenish white flowers from spring into fall followed by long, narrow seedpods. Native to both damp and dry habitats throughout much of North America. Forms colonies and can be weedy or invasive. An important pollinator plant. Sunset: N/A

Aptenia 'Red Apple' (iceplant), succulent, dense mat, spreading widely on rooting 2-foot stems, with oval, bright green leaves and bright red flowers in spring and summer. May spread aggressively but easy to pull. Can be invasive in wildlands. Believed to be a hybrid between A. cordifolia and A. haeckeliana (Platythyra haeckeliana), a yellow-flowered species with elliptical leaves. Both species are native to coastal South Africa. Cool sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Mesembryanthemum. Sunset: 12-13,15-17,21-24

Aptenia cordifolia (iceplant), succulent, dense mat, spreading widely on rooting 2-foot stems, with small, heart-shaped, bright green leaves and purplish pink flowers in spring and summer. Can be weedy or invasive. Native to coastal Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. Cool sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Mesembryanthemum. Sunset: 12-13,15-17,21-24

plants.botanicalName: Aquilegia spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Aquilegia species (columbine), perennials, a few inches to 3 feet tall and less than 1 foot to 2 feet wide, with leaves finely divided into lobed, green, gray-green, or bluish green leaflets and upright or nodding, trumpet-shaped, late spring and early summer flowers, most with short or long, backward-pointing, nectar tubes (spurs). Native to partly shaded woodlands and rocky mountain slopes in temperate regions of the northern hemisphere. Dozens of species and many hybrids of varying sizes, shapes, and colors. Short-lived but self-sow, some quite prolifically. Part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Arabis species (rockcress), annuals and perennials, less than 1 foot to almost 3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, mat-forming or mounding, with green to gray-green, oval to broadly lance-shaped leaves and small, white, pink, or purplish flowers in spring. Native to rocky slopes throughout much of the northern hemisphere. Most but not all North American species have been moved to the genus Boechera but are still often offered as Arabis. A. alpina and A. caucasica (sometimes considered a subspecies of A. alpina) are alpine species with white flowers native to southern Europe and western Asia. A. blepharophylla, with rose-purple flowers, is native to coastal California. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Araucaria araucana (monkey puzzle tree), evergreen tree, 60-80 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with horizontal branches and stiff, sharply pointed, lance-shaped to almost triangular, tightly packed, dark green leaves that completely cover the upcurving branchlets. Mature trees bear spherical cones containing nutlike seeds. Native to foothills of the Andes Mountains in central and southern Chile and western Argentina. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Araucaria bidwillii (bunya-bunya), evergreen tree, 80-130 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with sharply pointed, lance-shaped to almost triangular, glossy, dark green leaves. Mature trees bear large, heavy cones containing nut-like seeds. Native to rainforests in coastal mountains of southeastern Queensland, Australia. Sun or shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Arbutus 'Marina' (Marina arbutus), evergreen tree, 25-40 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, colorful peeling bark, clusters of rose pink, urn-shaped flowers in spring, and red, berrylike fruit in fall.  Believed to be either a selection of A. x andrachnoides, a naturally occurring hybrid of A. unedo and A. andrachne, or a hybrid between A. x andrachnoides and A. canariensis. Year-round shedding of bark, leaves, flowers, and fruit can be messy. Sun to light shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Arbutus andrachne (Greek strawberry tree), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-30 feet tall and wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, colorful peeling bark, clusters of white to yellowish green, urn-shaped flowers in spring, and red  fruit. Native to the eastern Mediterranean region, mostly near the coast, from Croatia and Greece to Turkey and Cyprus. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Adaptable but best in acidic soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Arbutus menziesii (madrone), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-80 feet tall and 15-40 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, dark green leaves, paler beneath, and red-orange bark that peels to reveal smooth, greenish underbark. Clusters of white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in spring are followed by red-orange, berry-like fruit in fall. Year-round shedding of bark, leaves, and fruit can be messy. Native from coastal southwestern British Columbia to the western slopes of the northern Sierra Nevada and the coastal mountains of northern San Diego County. Sun to light shade or afternoon shade, perfect drainage, good air circulation. Not easy in cultivation. Best near the coast. Sunset: 4-7,14-19

Arbutus texana (Texas madrone), evergreen tree, usually multitrunk, slow growing to 20-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with large, leathery, oval to elliptic, dark green leaves with red-tinged margins and dark gray-brown bark that peels to reveal shiny, red, white, or tan new bark. Showy clusters of urn-shaped, white flowers in spring are followed by red, berrylike fruits. Native to woodlands and shrublands from western Texas and southeastern New Mexico south through Mexico to Guatemala. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as A. xalapensis or as a variety or subspecies of A. xalapensis. Sunset: N/A

Arbutus unedo (strawberry tree), evergreen shrub or multitrunk tree, 10-20 feet tall and wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, reddish brown, peeling bark, clusters of white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in spring, and berrylike fruit in fall. Red fruit from the previous year persist on the tree along with new orange fruit and pinkish white flowers. Native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Israel and from coastal northern Morocco to Tunisia. Dropping of leaves, flowers, and fruit can be messy. Sun to light shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. 'Compacta' is 6-8 feet tall and wide. Sunset: 4-24

Arctostaphylos 'Austin Griffiths' (Austin Griffiths manzanita), evergreen shrub, upright to 8-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with medium green, oval leaves, and colorful, peeling bark. Pendant clusters of urn-shaped, pink-tinged white flowers in late winter are followed by small, found, berrylike fruit. Hybrid of garden origin from coastal central California believed to be a cross between A. densiflora 'Sentinel' and A. 'Dr. Hurd'. Best with some afternoon shade, good to excellent drainage, and good air circulation. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos 'John Dourley' (John Dourley manzanita), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leathery, gray-green to bluish gray leaves, new growth red-orange, and reddish brown bark.  Clusters of small, pink, urn-shaped flowers in late winter are followed by purplish red, berrylike fruit. Garden hybrid of uncertain parentage, possibly involving A. pajaroensis and A. bakeri. Sun, good drainage. Adaptable. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos 'Lester Rowntree' (Lester Rowntree manzanita), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-10 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with blue-gray leaves, new growth tipped with red-orange. Pendant clusters of urn-shaped, deep pink flowers in winter are followed by small, round, berrylike fruit. Natural hybrid involving A. pajaroensis, a gray-leaved, pink-flowered plant native to Monterey County, and possibly A. obispoensis, a gray-leaved, white-flowered plant from the mountains of San Luis Obispo County. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos 'Pacific Mist' (Pacific Mist manzanita), fast growing to 2-3 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with gray-green, narrowly oval to lance-shaped leaves, pink-tinged new growth, purplish brown stems upturned at the ends, and a few urn-shaped, white flowers. Hybrid of garden origin, believed to involve A. silvicola, a gray-leaved plant from the mountains of coastal central California. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Good for dryish shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos 'Sunset' (Sunset manzanita), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with glossy, green leaves, coppery red when new, and peeling, shaggy, mahogany bark mostly hidden by the dense foliage. Pendant clusters of pinkish white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Natural hybrid of A. pajaroensis and A. hookeri from northern Monterey County. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos bakeri 'Louis Edmunds' (Louis Edmunds manzanita), evergreen shrub, upright to 6-10 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with rounded, leathery, gray-green leaves and dark purplish brown, peeling bark. Pendant clusters of small, pink, urn-shaped flowers in late winter are followed by red-orange, berrylike fruit. Selection of a species native to the Coast Ranges of Sonoma County. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage, good air circulation. Best near the coast. Afternoon shade inland. Sunset: 4-9,14-17

Arctostaphylos canescens (hoary manzanita), evergreen shrub, variable, from low mats to 4-6 feet tall and spreading, with lightly hairy to rough and glossy, oval, grayish blue-green leaves, woolly when new. Clusters of urn-shaped, pinkish white flowers in winter and early spring are followed by reddish brown, berrylike fruit. Native to sandy or rocky soils on slopes and ridges of coastal mountains of southwestern Oregon and northern California. Best near the coast. Sun, excellent drainage, afternoon shade inland. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos catalinae (Catalina manzanita), evergreen shrub, upright to 6-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with gray-green, oval leaves and dark red-brown bark. Large clusters of urn-shaped, white or pink-tinged white flowers in winter are followed by small, berrylike fruit. Native to rocky outcrops and canyons on Catalina Island in southern California. Best along the coast. Cool sun or part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.commonName: manzanita cvs. e.g. Howard McMinn, Sentinel
plants.culturalInformation: Arctostaphylos densiflora cultivars (manzanita), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 5-7 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, broadly lance-shaped leaves, pendant clusters of small, white or pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in winter or early spring, and small, round, red, berrylikefruit. Native to sandy soils in chaparral in Sonoma County, California. Species is not often available, but several natural hybrids are widely grown. 'Howard McMinn', 6-10 feet tall and wider than tall, is exceptionally adaptable. 'Sentinel' is similar but more upright. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Sunset: 7-9,14-21

Arctostaphylos edmundsii 'Bert Johnson' (Bert Johnson manzanita), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, leathery, dark green leaves, bronzy when new, and mahogany bark. Pendant clusters of small, pinkish white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter are followed by red-brown, berrylike fruit. Selection of a species native to coastal bluffs of northern Monterey County. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos edmundsii 'Big Sur' (Big Sur manzanita), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with leathery, oval, dark green leaves and reddish brown bark. Pendant clusters of clear white to pinkish white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter are followed by reddish brown,  berrylike fruit. Selection of a species native to coastal bluffs of northern Monterey County. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos edmundsii 'Rosy Dawn' (Rosy Dawn manzanita), evergreen shrub, 1 foot tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, leathery, gray-green leaves, new growth tinged red, and mahogany bark. Pendant clusters of small, urn-shaped, pale pink to white flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by small, round, berrylike fruit. Species is native to coastal bluffs of northern Monterey County. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos edmundsii cultivars, prostrate to mounding evergreen shrubs with leathery, dark green to gray-green leaves and pendant clusters of small, pink to pinkish white or clear white flowers in late winter to early spring followed by reddish brown, berrylike fruit. Species is native to coastal bluffs of northern Monterey County. 'Carmel Sur' is 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide with gray-green leaves and occasional pink flowers. 'Little Sur' is less than 1 foot tall and 4-5 feet wide with green leaves with red margins and pink flowers. 'Big Sur' is 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide with dark green leaves and white to pinkish white flowers. 'Bert Johnson' is 1-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide with dark green leaves and white or pinkish white flowers. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos glandulosa (Eastwood's manzanita), evergreen shrub, variable, sprawling or upright to 3-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with erect, bright green to gray-green, sticky, oval leaves on bristly stems and reddish brown, peeling bark. Clusters of urn-shaped, white or sometimes pale pink flowers in winter or early spring are followed by small, berrylike fruit. Native to dry, rocky slopes in coastal mountains from southwestern Oregon to southern California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos glauca (bigberry manzanita), evergreen shrub or small tree, 8-15 feet tall and 12-15 feet wide, with pale gray-green to bluish green, oval leaves and clusters of white, urn-shaped flowers in winter followed by reddish brown, berrylike fruit. Native to dry, rocky slopes in coastal mountains of central and southern California and Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos hookeri 'Buxifolia' (Buxifolia manzanita), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with small, leathery, dark green leaves densely set on short, red stems. Clusters of small, white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Species is native along the Big Sur coast from San Luis Obispo County north to the San Francisco Bay Area. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Part shade or afternoon shade inland. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos hookeri 'Ken Taylor' (Ken Taylor manzanita), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, dark green leaves and maroon bark. Pendant clusters of small, pink-tinted white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Species is native along the coast from San Luis Obispo County to the San Francisco Bay Area. 'Ken Taylor' is a selection from the Monterey Bay area. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos hookeri 'Monterey Carpet' (Monterey Carpet manzanita), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, leathery, glossy, dark green to gray-green leaves with finely serrated margins on purplish red stems. Clusters of small, white to pinkish white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter to early spring are followed by bright red, berrylike fruit. Species is native along the coast from San Luis Obispo County to the San Francisco Bay Area. Cool sun, fast drainage. Best along the coast. Part shade or afternoon shade inland. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos hookeri 'Wayside' (Wayside manzanita), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leathery, red-tinged, bright green leaves on upright stems and dark reddish brown bark. Pendant clusters of small, white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in late winter are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Species is native along the coast from San Luis Obispo County to the San Francisco Bay Area. Cool sun, good drainage. Part shade or afternoon shade inland. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos hookeri cultivars (manzanita), evergreen shrubs, variable, 2-8 feet tall and 3-12 feet wide, with small, glossy, green to grayish green leaves and reddish brown bark. Pendant clusters of small, white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in winter or spring are followed by bright red, berrylike fruit. Species is native along the coast from San Luis Obispo County north to the San Francisco Bay Area. 'Buxifolia', 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, has small, dark green leaves and white flowers. 'Monterey Carpet', 1-3 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, has dark green to grayish green leaves with serrated margins and white flowers. 'Wayside', 2-4 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, has bright green leaves and white flowers. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained, slightly acidic soils. Best near the coast. Part shade or afternoon shade inland. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos insularis (island manzanita), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and wide, with glossy, green, oval leaves and clusters of white or pinkish white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter to early spring followed by orange-brown, berrylike fruits. Native to Santa Cruz Island in southern California. Best along the coast. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-24

Arctostaphylos manzanita (common manzanita), evergreen shrub, upright to 10-15 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, bright green, wedge-shaped leaves and dark, purplish red bark. Pendant clusters of small, white or pink, urn-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by reddish brown, berrylike fruit. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the inner North Coast Ranges and the northern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best away from the immediate coast. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

plants.commonName: manzanita cvs. e.g., Dr Hurd, St. Helena
plants.culturalInformation: Arctostaphylos manzanita cultivars, evergreen shrubs, 10-15 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with light green to gray-green leaves and purplish red bark. Pendant clusters of small, white or pink, urn-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by reddish brown, berrylike fruit. Species is native to the inner North Coast Ranges and northern Sierra Nevada foothills. 'Dr Hurd', a garden hybrid possibly involving A. stanfordiana, is 12-15 feet tall and wide with light green leaves, mahogany red bark, and white flowers. 'St Helena', from Napa County, is 10-12 feet tall and wide with large, rounded, bluish gray-green leaves and white flowers. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Arctostaphylos morroensis (Morro manzanita), evergreen shrub, variable, 4-12 feet tall and usually wider than tall, with gray-green, oval leaves, new growth reddish, and clusters of white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in late winter followed by red, berrylike fruit. Native to coastal cliffs and dunes around Morro Bay in San Luis Obispo County, California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best along the coast. Afternoon shade inland. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos otayensis (Otay manzanita), evergreen shrub, 4-10 feet tall and wide, with gray-green, oval leaves and clusters of white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in winter followed by red, berrylike fruit. Native to rocky slopes and outcrops in the mountains of southern San Diego County. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos pajaroensis cultivars (Pajaro manzanita), evergreen shrubs, 3-6 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with green to gray-green or blue-green leaves, new growth bronzy red, and fibrous, reddish gray bark. Clusters of small, pale to dark pink or white, urn-shaped flowers in winter are followed by berrylike fruit. Species is native to coastal Santa Cruz and Monterey counties. 'Paradise' has dark green to bluish green leaves and pink to nearly white flowers. 'Myrtle Wolf' has blue-green leaves and bright pink flowers. 'Warren Roberts' has bluer leaves and pink-tinged white flowers. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 14-24

Arctostaphylos pringlei (pink bract manzanita), evergreen shrub, variable, 5-15 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with oval, finely hairy, gray-green leaves and reddish brown, peeling bark. Clusters of urn-shaped white or pinkish white flowers in winter or spring are followed by small, berrylike fruit. Native to rocky slopes and open woodlands in mountains of southern California, Arizona, and southwestern Utah. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos pungens (Mexican manzanita), evergreen shrub, variable, upright to 3-10 feet tall and wide, with narrowly oval to broadly lance-shaped, finely hairy, gray-green leaves and reddish brown bark. Clusters of urn-shaped white or pinkish white flowers in spring are followed by small, berrylike fruit.
