Native to sandy or gravelly soils in coastal and inland mountains from central California to northern Baja California and east to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos purissima 'Vandenberg' (Vandenberg manzanita), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with broadly oval to rounded, glossy, green leaves and clusters of white, urn-shaped flowers in winter and spring followed by red berrylike fruit. Species is native to sandy soils near the coast in western Santa Barbara County. Sun to light shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos refugioensis (Refugio manzanita), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, with broadly oval, gray-green leaves, new growth reddish, and clusters of white, urn-shaped flowers in winter followed by red, berrylike fruit. Native to sandy or rocky soils, but not beach sand, near and along the coastline west of Santa Barbara. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good coastal or inland. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos rudis cultivars (Mexican manzanita), mounding 3-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with oval to rounded, glossy green leaves and grayish brown, shredding bark. Clusters of urn-shaped, white or pale pink flowers in winter are followed by small, berrylike fruit. Native to sandy soils along the central California coast. Cool sun, fast drainage. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos silvicola (ghostly manzanita), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with gray-green to silvery gray-white, oval leaves and clusters of white, urn-shaped flowers in winter followed by orange, berrylike fruit. Native to sandy soils on coastal slopes in the southern Santa Cruz Mountains. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: N/A

Artostaphylos uva-ursi 'Point Reyes' (Point Reyes manzanita), evergreen shrub, 12-18 inches tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leathery, rounded, dark green leaves turning reddish purple as weather cools and reddish purple bark mostly hidden by dense foliage. Clusters of small, pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in winter are followed by bright red, berrylike fruit. Species is native to northern regions of Europe, Asia, and North America. 'Point Reyes' is a selection from coastal northern California. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Part shade or afternoon shade inland. Sunset: 1-9,14-24,A1-3

Arctostaphylos uva-ursi 'Radiant' (Radiant manzanita), evergreen shrub, 6-10 inches tall and 6-10 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, bright green leaves, tinged red in winter, and reddish purple bark mostly hidden by dense foliage. Clusters of small, pale pink to pinkish white, urn-shaped flowers in winter and spring are followed by bright red, berrylike fruit. Species is native to northern regions of Europe, Asia, and North America. 'Radiant' is a garden selection from coastal northern California. Cool sun, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Part shade or afternoon shade inland. Sunset: 1-9,14-24,A1-3

Arctostaphylos uva-ursi 'San Bruno Mountain' (San Bruno Mountain manzanita), 6-10 inches tall and 6-8 feet wide, with large, leathery, glossy green leaves and reddish brown bark mostly hidden by the dense foliage. Clusters of small, pale pink to white, urn-shaped winter flowers are followed by large, red, berrylike fruits. Selection from San Mateo County of a species native to northern regions of Europe, Asia, and North America as far south as northern California. Cool sun to light shade, part shade inland, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. San Bruno Mountain manzanita is also the common name of A. imbricata, a species native only to San Bruno Mountain in San Mateo County. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos uva-ursi 'Tom's Point' (Tom's Point manzanita), 6-12 inches tall and 5-10 feet wide, with small, leathery, glossy, dark green leaves and reddish brown bark mostly hidden by dense foliage. Clusters of pink-tinged white, urn-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring followed by large, red, berrylike fruit. Northern California selection of a species native to northern regions of Europe, Asia, and North America as far south as northern California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos uva-ursi 'Wood's Compact' (Wood's Compact manzanita), 6-12 inches tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, rounded, glossy green leaves and reddish brown bark mostly hidden by dense foliage. Clusters of small, urn-shaped, pinkish white flowers in late winter are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Selection from coastal Oregon of a species native to northern regions of Europe, Asia, and North America as far south as northern California. Possibly a natural hybrid. Cool sun to light shade, part shade or afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Good for dry shade. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos viridissima 'White Cloud' (White Cloud manzanita), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with glossy, oval to rounded, dark green leaves on hairy stems, new growth tinged red. Clusters of white, urn-shaped flowers in winter or early spring are followed by berrylike fruits. Species is native to rocky soils on eastern Santa Cruz Island and can be a widely spreading shrub mounding 2-4 feet tall or treelike to 8-10 feet tall. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Arctostaphylos viscida (whiteleaf manzanita), evergreen shrub, 3-12 feet tall and 3-8 feet wide, with broadly oval to rounded, matte grayish green leaves and dense clusters of white to pale pink, urn-shaped flowers in winter or early spring followed by shiny red to reddish brown, berrylike fruit. Native to rocky slopes and forest openings in coastal mountains of southwestern Oregon and northwestern California and in foothills of the Sierra Nevada. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Arctotis hybrids (African daisy), perennials, 1 foot tall and wide, with basal clumps of lobed, hairy or felted, gray-green to silvery green leaves and large, brightly colored daisy flowers with contrasting centers on 12- to 18-inch stems from early summer to fall. Flowers close at night and plants may stop blooming in hot summers. Species are native to dry, rocky or sandy slopes in southern Africa. Cultivars are mostly hybrids with flowers in shades of white, pink, red, purple, yellow, or orange. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. May need replacing every few years. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Argemone corymbosa (prickly poppy), perennial, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with shallowly or deeply lobed, leathery, gray-green leaves with spiny margins and undersides on spiny stems. Large flowers with crinkled white petals and bright yellow stamens in spring are followed by prickly, oval seed capsules. Native to sandy or rocky soils in the eastern Mojave Desert. Self sows. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Argemone munita (prickly poppy), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, low rosette of long, deeply lobed, silvery blue-gray, spiny leaves and large flowers with crinkled, white petals and bright yellow stamens on spiny 3- to 4-foot stems in summer. Flowers are followed by spiny, bluish white seed capsules. Native to rocky soils in the central Coast Ranges from San Luis Obispo to Baja California and in deserts from southeastern Oregon and Utah to southern California and Arizona. Short lived. Self-sows and can be weedy. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Argemone pleiacantha (southwestern prickly poppy), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, low rosette of long, deeply lobed, silvery blue-gray, spiny leaves and large flowers with crinkled, white petals and bright yellow stamens on spiny 4- to 5-foot stems in summer. Flowers are followed by spiny, bluish white seed capsules. Native to dry slopes in foothills and mountains of Arizona, New Mexico, and northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Argyranthemum frutescens  & cvs. (Chrysanthemum frutescens)(shade in desert)

photos.filename: Argyranthemum gracile cultivars, perennials or subshrubs
photos.caption: Argyranthemum gracile cultivars, perennials or subshrubs

plants.culturalInformation: Argyranthemum gracile cultivars, perennials or subshrubs, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with fine-textured, pale gray-green leaves divided into threadlike lobes and white daisy flowers with yellow centers in summer. Species is native to mountains of the Canary Islands and Madeira. Dozens of cultivars, many of them hybrids with other species, are available with semi-double and double flowers in various shades of pink, red, purple, yellow, and orange as well as white. Sun, well-drained soils. Best if protected from heavy winter rains. May be offered as Chrysanthemum. Sunset: N/A

Aristida purpurea (purple three-awn), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, green to blue-green leaves and erect and arching, purple-tinted stems with reddish purple flowers in late summer or fall. Self-sows. Native to dry, rocky or sandy soils in the western United States, southern Canada, and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 3B-24

Aristolochia californica (California pipevine), deciduous vine, to 12-20 feet, with bright green, heart-shaped leaves and distinctive pipe-shaped, purple-striped, creamy white flowers on bare stems in late winter to early spring. Leaves are food for pipevine swallowtail butterfly larvae. A few old brown leaves and seedpods hang on into the following growing season. Native to foothills and valleys of central and northern California, often along streams. Part shade, or with roots in shade, most soils. Sunset: 5-10,14-24

Armeria maritima (sea thrift), perennial, 4-6 inches tall and spreading slowly to 12-18 inches wide, with short, grasslike, bright green leaves and dense, spherical clusters of tiny, bright pink or white flowers on leafless stems in spring or summer. Native to coastal dunes and bluffs from central California north to southeastern Alaska, as well as in coastal areas of Europe and the Mediterranean region. Best along the immediate coast, where it thrives in cool sun with fast drainage. Sunset: 1-9,14-24,A2,A3

Aronia arbutifolia 'Brilliantissima' (red chokecherry), deciduous shrub, upright and narrow to 6-8 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with oval to elliptic, glossy, dark green leaves, gray-green beneath, that turn bright red in fall. Clusters of white to pale pink flowers in spring are followed by persistent, glossy, red fruits. Slowly spreads by suckering roots to form colonies. Species is native to both wet and dry habitats in eastern North America. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-7

Artemisia 'Powis Castle' (Powis Castle sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with flat sprays of finely divided, aromatic leaves, green when new, maturing to silvery gray. Rarely flowers; grown for its foliage. Hybrid of garden origin, believed to be a cross between A. arborescens, native to the western Mediterranean region, and A. absinthium, more widely native to Europe, Asia, and northern Africa. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: 2-24

Artemisia arborescens (large wormwood), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with finely divided, aromatic, silvery white to gray-green leaves and short sprays of small, rounded, pale yellow flowers in late spring or early summer. Native to rocky slopes along the coast from Portugal to Greece. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Artemisia californica (California sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green leaves, finely divided into threadlike lobes, and small, yellowish white flowers in summer. Grown for foliage. Native along the coast from central California, including the Channel Islands, to Baja California. 'Canyon Gray', from San Miguel Island, is less than 2 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide. Best near the coast in sun but fine inland with good drainage and a little afternoon shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Artemisia californica 'Canyon Gray' (Canyon Gray sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with feathery, aromatic, gray-green leaves finely divided into threadlike lobes and inconspicuous greenish yellow summer flowers. Species is native along the coast from central California to Baja California. 'Canyon Gray' is a selection from San Miguel Island. Cool sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast but fine inland with a little shade. Good seaside. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Artemisia californica 'Montara' (Montara sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 1 foot tall and 3-6 feet wide, with feathery, aromatic, pale gray-green leaves finely divided into threadlike lobes and inconspicuous greenish yellow summer flowers. Species is native along the coast from central California to Baja California. 'Montara' is a selection from San Mateo County. May be a natural hybrid with A. pycnocephala. Cool sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast but fine inland with a little shade. Good seaside. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Artemisia douglasiana (California mugwort), perennial, upright stems 2-5 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes, with aromatic, lance-shaped, narrowly lobed, gray-green leaves, silvery white beneath, and spikes of tiny, tightly clustered, creamy yellow flowers in summer. Native to western North America from Oregon and Idaho to northwestern Baja California, often along streams. Sun or shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Artemisia filifolia (sand sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with narrow, almost threadlike, aromatic, silvery blue-gray leaves and small, inconspicuous, pale yellow flowers in spring. Native to rocky or sandy soils in grasslands and shrublands from Nevada and Utah east to Wyoming and south to Arizona, Texas, and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Not recommended for low-desert landscapes. Sunset: 2-11,14-24

Artemisia tridentata (big sagebrush), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with strongly aromatic, blue-gray, wedge-shaped leaves covered with fine, silvery hairs and inconspicuous, greenish yellow summer flowers. Native to dry mountain habitats from British Columbia south to eastern and southern California and Baja California and east to Texas. Sun, excellent drainage. May be offered as Seriphidium. Sunset: 1-3,6-11,14-24

Arum italicum (Italian arum), perennial from tubers, 12-18 inches tall and wide, with long, wavy-edged, glossy, grayish green leaves with paler veining that emerge in fall or early winter. Upright spikes of minute, tightly packed, greenish or yellowish white flowers partially enclosed within a large, white bract appear in spring and early summer and are followed by bright, red-orange berries. Native to woodland openings and grasslands from northern France to the north coast of Morocco and from Portugal to the Caucasus. Summer dormant. Spreads by offsetting tubers and by seed; listed as a noxious weed in some states. Shade to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 2-24

Arundinaria gigantea (cane weed), evergreen grass, variable, 6-20 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes, with lance-shaped, mid-green, drooping leaves on branches of hollow, woody, upright stems. Plants flower rarely and sporadically. Native to floodplains, river banks, and other seasonally flooded sites from southern New York to central Florida and west to Illinois and eastern Texas. Forms thickets. Sun or shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Asarina antirrhiniflora (snapdragon vine), deciduous vine, 3-8 feet, triangular, bright green leaves and lavender, blue, red, or pink, pendant, trumpet-shaped flowers in mid-spring or early summer. Native to rocky or sandy soils in dry habitats from southeastern California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Climbs by twining. May self-sow. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. May be offered as Maurandella or Maurandya. Sunset: N/A

Asclepias natives (milkweed), perennials with loose clusters of star-shaped, summer flowers followed by large, inflated pods containing seeds with silky hairs that aid in wind dispersal. A. californica, with woolly, gray-white leaves and pink to purplish flowers, is native from central California to Baja California. A. cordifolia, with heart-shaped, bluish green leaves and creamy white and purple flowers, is native from Oregon to central California and western Nevada. A. fascicularis, with narrow green leaves and creamy white flowers, is native from southeastern Washington to Baja California. A. speciosa, with large, gray-green leaves and pinkish purple flowers, is native to much of western North America. Milkweeds spread, sometimes aggressively, by rhizomes and by seed. Leaves are larval food for butterflies. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Asclepias curassavica (scarlet milkweed), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, lance-shaped, medium green leaves and showy clusters of star-shaped, red and orange or red and yellow flowers in summer or nearly year round. Long, narrow pods contain seeds with white, silky hairs that aid in wind dispersal. Native to Central and South America. Self-sows readily and can be weedy. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Asclepias subulata (desert milkweed), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with rushlike clusters of upright, leafless, silvery gray-green stems and loose clusters of creamy white or yellowish flowers at stem ends intermittently from spring to fall. Pendulous, narrow seedpods split to release seeds with silky hairs that aid in dispersal by wind. Small, narrowly linear, gray-green leaves appear only after rains or when soil moisture is adequate. Native to sandy or rocky soils on dry slopes and flats in deserts from California and Nevada to Arizona and northern Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 11-13

Asphodeline lutea (king's spear), perennial, to 1 foot tall and wide, with narrow, bluish gray-green, grasslike leaves and spikes of fragrant, bright yellow, star-shaped flowers on 3- to 4-foot, unbranched, leafy stems in late spring. Flowers are followed by round, green seedpods that age to brown. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Native to the eastern Mediterranean region from Greece and the Caucasus to Jordan, Israel, and northern Africa. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b-24

Asphodeline taurica (asphodel), perennial, to 1 foot tall and wide, with narrow, bluish gray-green, grasslike leaves and spikes of fragrant, star-shaped, white or pink-tinged white flowers on 2- to 3-foot, unbranched, leafy stems in late spring. Flowers are followed by round, green seedpods that age to brown. Native to rocky soils in the mountains of Greece, Turkey, and the Caucasus. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Asphodelus aestivus (white asphodel), perennial, 12-18 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with bluish gray-green, strap-shaped basal leaves and spikes of star-shaped, white flowers on 3- to 5-foot, branched stems in late spring. Flowers are followed by round, green seedpods that age to brown. Dormant and deciduous in summer. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Native to Portugal and Spain. Similar to and often confused with A. ramosus, which is native from North Africa and the Canary Islands across southern Europe to Iran. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Aspidistra elatior (cast iron plant), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with arching, broadly lance-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves and inconspicuous creamy white and purplish flowers in spring. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Native to several islands off the south coast of Japan. Cultivars with variegated leaves are available. Shade to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-10,12-24

plants.botanicalName: Asplenium bulbiferum (shade in the low desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Asplenium scolopendrium (Hart's tongue fern), fern, slow growing to 1-2 feet tall and 2 feet wide, with undivided, wavy-edged, lance-shaped, bright green leaves. Native to central and southern Europe and northern Africa, with one rare variety native to parts of eastern North America. Part shade to shade, excellent drainage. Best in humusy, alkaline soils. Sunset: 2b-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Aster spp., cvs. and hybrids (genus now split to many!)

plants.culturalInformation: Atriplex species California natives (saltbush), evergreen or semi-deciduous shrubs, perennials, and annuals with gray or silvery gray-green leaves and clusters or spikes of tiny, usually creamy white or yellow flowers in summer. Native to desert, coastal, and riparian habitats in much of western North America, including California. A. canescens, 2-6 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, A. confertifolia, 1-3 feet tall and wide, and A. lentiformis, 3-10 feet tall and wide, are evergreen shrubs that may drop leaves in summer if grown dry. Many natural hybrids between both native and introduced species. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Aubrieta deltoidea (rock cress), perennial, mat-forming, 2-6 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with oval, sometimes lobed, gray-green leaves and small, lavender to purplish pink flowers from spring to early summer. Native to rocky or sandy soils in mountains of the eastern Mediterranean region from Italy to the Balkan Peninsula and around the Aegean Sea to Iran. Many cultivars. Self-sows. Drapes over walls. Cut back after flowering to renew. Cool sun to light shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, excellent drainage. Sunset: 1-9,14-21

Aurinia saxatilis (basket-of-gold), perennial, 6 inches to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with oval, gray-green leaves and dense clusters of small, bright yellow flowers in spring. Native to rocky soils in mountains of central and southeastern Europe to Turkey. Many cultivars with flowers in various shades of yellow and creamy white. Drapes over walls. Self-sows. Cut back after flowering to renew. Sun, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, excellent drainage. May be offered as Alyssum. Sunset: 1-24

Babiana species and hybrids (baboon flower), perennials from corms, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with upright fans of sword-shaped, green leaves emerging in mid-winter and short spikes of upfacing cup-shaped flowers in spring. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Most are native to clay soils in southern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Most plants in the trade are hybrids, usually involving B. stricta. The species B. rubrocyanea, with rich purple flowers with bright red centers, and B. villosa, with red flowers, are sometimes available. Full sun, good air circulation, good drainage. Lift and store where winters are cold. Sunset: 4-24

Baccharis 'Centennial' (Centennial baccharis), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with small, resinous, glossy, green leaves and masses of tiny, white, spring flowers, sticky in bud and messily fluffy in seed. Hybrid between B. pilularis, native to coastal dunes and woodland openings in the Coast Ranges from Oregon to Baja California, and B. sarothroides, native to deserts of California and the southwestern United States. Sun, well-drained soils. Cut back annually or every few years to renew. Sunset: 7-24

Baccharis 'Starn' (Starn coyote brush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with small, resinous, glossy green, oval to wedge-shaped leaves and inconspicuous pale yellow flowers in spring. Hybrid between B. pilularis, a coastal species, and B. sarothroides, a species native to deserts of California and the Southwest. Better adapted to hot inland climates than some other cultivars and, as a male plant, does not produce the messy, white flowerheads or the seedlings associated with female cultivars. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back every few years to renew. May be offered as Thompson™. Sunset: 7-24

Baccharis pilularis ssp. consanguinea (coyote brush), evergreen shrub, upright and rounded to 4-10 feet tall, with small, resinous, glossy green, oval to wedge-shaped leaves and small, creamy white flowers in spring.  Native to the Coast Ranges from Oregon to Baja California and to the Central Valley and Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back every few years to renew. Sunset: N/A

Baccharis pilularis cultivars (dwarf coyote brush), evergreen shrubs with small, resinous, glossy, green leaves and small, creamy white flowers in spring. Species is native to coastal dunes and woodland openings in the Coast Ranges from Oregon to Baja California. 'Pigeon Point' and 'Twin Peaks 2', 1-3 feet tall and 8 feet wide, are coastal selections that need some shade inland. 'Centennial' and 'Starn' (Thompson™), 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, are hybrids involving B. sarothroides, a species native to deserts of California and the southwestern United States; both are adapted to hot, inland climates. All need sun and good drainage. Cut back every few years to renew. Sunset: zones vary

Baccharis salicifolia (mule fat), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with lance-shaped, dark green, sticky, resinous leaves and flat-topped clusters of small, creamy white flowers intermittently year round. Native to desert washes from California east to Colorado and south to Texas and northern Mexico. Self-sows and can be weedy. Drops some leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun, most well-drained soils. Can be cut back hard to renew. Sunset: N/A

Baccharis sarothroides (desert broom), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with fine-textured, narrowly linear, medium green leaves on narrow, green stems and masses of small, creamy white flowers in winter. Self-sows. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to desert washes from southern California and Nevada to Texas and northern Mexico. Species is not often available but is one parent of commonly planted hybrids. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back annually or every few years to renew. Sunset: 7-24

Baeckea virgata (tall baeckea), evergreen shrub, upright and rounded to 5-8 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with soft, fine-textured, almost needlelike, dark green leaves, new growth bronzy, and showy clusters of tiny, bright white, lightly fragrant flowers in late spring and summer. Native to New Caledonia and eastern Australia. Tip prune or cut back hard after flowering to maintain compact form. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as Sannantha or as Babingtonia bidwillii. Sunset: N/A

Baeometra uniflora (beetle lily), perennial from corms, to 1 foot tall and wide, with a fan of glossy, green, strap-shaped leaves and an upright stem bearing several bright yellow or orange, cup-shaped flowers with dark brown centers in spring. Flowers close at dusk or in cloudy weather. Summer dormant. Native to rocky slopes in the mountains of southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Spreads by offsets. Sun, fast drainage. Accepts seasonal flooding and needs a dry summer dormancy. Sunset: N/A

Bahiopsis deltoidea (golden eye), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with hairy, triangular, mid-green to gray-green leaves with toothed margins on upright stems and yellow daisy flowers with dark brown centers intermittently in spring and summer. Native to deserts of California, Nevada, western Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Viguiera. Sunset: 10-24

Bahiopsis laciniata (San Diego County viguiera), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with hairy, resinous, lance-shaped, light green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers in spring and summer or almost year round. Native to dry slopes and canyons in coastal southern California and Baja California. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as Viguiera. Sunset: N/A

Baileya multiradiata (desert marigold), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with silvery white-woolly, lobed, basal leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers on 2-foot, unbranched stems in spring and summer. Self-sows where content. Native to sandy soils in inland valleys and desert washes from southern California and Nevada east to Texas and northern Mexico. Full sun, fast-draining soils. Sunset: 1-3,7-23

Ballota pseudodictamnus (Grecian horehound), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with aromatic, felted, gray-green leaves on upright, greenish white stems and inconspicuous white flowers in summer. Native to rocky soils in western Turkey and the Aegean Islands. 'All Hallows Green', long offered as Ballota, is now considered a selection of Marrubium bourgaei. Sun, most well-drained soils. Accepts coastal winds and salt spray. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Sunset: N/A

Bambusa species (bamboo), evergreen grasses, fast growing clumping bamboos to 30-50 feet tall and slowly expanding to form a colony 3-10 feet wide, with multiple branches on hollow, upright stems bearing linear to lance-shaped leaves in various shades of green. Native to China, southeastern Asia, and tropical northern Australia. Cultivars with variegated leaves and dwarf varieties are available. Sun to part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: N/A

Banksia baxteri (bird's nest banksia), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-12 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with stiff, dark gray-green leaves divided into deeply triangular lobes and tiny, greenish yellow flowers in large, cylindrical, dome-shaped heads in mid-summer and fall. Native to sandy soils and sand dunes along the south coast of Western Australia. Sun, excellent drainage. Prune only lightly as needed to shape. Sunset: 15-24

Banksia ericifolia (heath banksia), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-12 feet tall and wide, with needlelike, dark green leaves and tiny, red-orange flowers in large, cylindrical, conelike spikes in fall and winter. Native to sandy soils in coastal southeastern Australia. Compact forms, 4-6 feet tall, are often available. Accepts salt spray. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 15-24

Banksia integrifolia (coast banksia), evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-45 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with dark green, broadly lance-shaped leaves, silvery gray beneath, and upright, cylindrical, conelike heads of tubular, pale yellow to greenish yellow flowers from fall to spring. Native to coastal dunes and mountains of eastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 15-24

Banksia menziesii (firewood banksia), evergreen shrub or small tree, variable, 6-25 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide, with oblong, wavy-edged, gray-green leaves with toothed margins, rusty brown beneath, and cylindrical, conelike heads of tiny, reddish pink, red-orange, or sometimes golden yellow flowers at branch ends in fall and winter. Native to sandy soils in woodlands and shrublands along the west coast of Western Australia. Dwarf forms are often available. Good seaside plant. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Banksia praemorsa (cutleaf banksia), evergreen shrub, dense and upright to 6-12 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with stiff, oblong, dark green leaves with toothed margins, grayish white beneath, and cylindrical, conelike heads of tiny, burgundy red to yellow flowers in winter and spring. Native to sandy soils and dunes along the south coast of Western Australia. Good choice for windy, seaside sites. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils.  Sunset: 15-24

Banksia speciosa (showy banksia), evergreen shrub or small tree, 12-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with long, deeply serrated, dark olive green leaves, gray-white beneath, and upright, conelike heads of tubular, creamy yellow flowers in summer and fall or almost year round. Native to sandy soils in coastal southern Western Australia. Sun, good drainage. Sunset: 15-24

Baptisia australis (false indigo), perennial, 3-5 feet tall and 4 feet wide, with bluish green leaves and tapering spikes of dark blue-purple pea flowers on 4- to 6-foot stems in late spring or early summer. Lower stems are leafless. Dark brownish black, inflated seedpods are ornamental. Long lived but slow to establish. Native to prairies and open woodlands, often along streambanks, in central and eastern North America. Plants die back to the ground in late fall. In spring new stems rise from the soil already topped with flower buds, and leaves and flowers develop together as stems elongate. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Not for alkaline soils. Sunset: 1-24

Barleria obtusa (bush violet), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with small, rounded, dark green leaves and tubular, purplish blue flowers in fall and winter. Native to summer-rainfall northeastern South Africa and Zimbabwe. Self sows. Sun or part shade, good drainage. Can be cut back hard after flowering. Sunset: N/A

Barleria repens (coral creeper), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 1-2 feet tall and spreading by rooting stems, with small, rounded, glossy, green leaves and tubular, pinkish red flowers from midsummer through fall. Native to KwaZulu-Natal in northeastern South Africa. Cascades over walls. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Bauera rubioides (dog rose), evergreen shrub, mounding 2-4 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with glossy, light green leaves divided into small, lance-shaped leaflets with serrated margins and masses of downward-facing, cup-shaped, white or purplish pink flowers in spring and summer or almost year round. Native to woodlands and shrublands in coastal southeastern Australia and the mountains of Tasmania, often along shaded stream banks. Cool sun to shade, part shade, or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. May be short lived in cultivation. Sunset: N/A

Bauhinia galpinii (red orchid bush), evergreen or semi-evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-10 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with deeply two-lobed, bluish green leaves. Showy, bright red or red-orange, unscented or lightly scented flowers in summer and fall are followed by large, beanlike seedpods. Native to grasslands and shrublands of northeastern South Africa, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique. Can be trained as a small tree or espalier. Drops some leaves in spring and new leaves appear by midsummer. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as B. punctata. Sunset: 13,15-16,18-24

Bauhinia lunarioides (Texas plume), deciduous shrub or small tree, evergreen in mild-winter climates, slow growing to 10-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with deeply two-lobed, wavy-edged, mid-green leaves. Dense clusters of fragrant, bright white or pink flowers in late spring and early summer are followed by papery, beanlike seedpods. Native to rocky soils in desert washes and canyons of southwestern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 10-13,18-23

Bauhinia macrantha (Kalihari bauhinia), evergreen shrub, 3-8 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with deeply two-lobed, green leaves and fragrant, bright white flowers with crinkled petals in summer followed by woody, beanlike seedpods. Native to sandy soils in woodlands and shrublands of southwestern Africa from Angola and Zambia to northwestern South Africa. May be offered as a subspecies of B. petersiana. Name is often confused with B. macranthera (Chihuahuan orchid tree), a 10- to 15-foot shrub or small tree with purplish or pink flowers native to northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Beaucarnea guatemalensis (red ponytail palm), succulent, slow growing to 12-15 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with a rosette of pendulous, strap-shaped, glossy green leaves, slowly forming a palmlike trunk that becomes noticeably enlarged at the base. With age, the trunk may form branches, each with its own rosette, and upright spikes of small, creamy white or greenish flowers may appear in spring but not every year. Native to seasonally dry forests of Guatemala and Honduras. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Nolina. Sunset: N/A

Beaucarnea recurvata (ponytail palm), evergreen tree, slow growing to 15-20 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with a rosette of long, narrowly strap-shaped or grasslike, leathery, green leaves with finely serrated margins at the top of a palmlike trunk. Trunk stores water and is noticeably enlarged at the base. With age, trunk forms branches, and upright, pyramidal clusters of small, creamy white, greenish, or sometimes pink flowers may appear in spring but not every year. Flowers are followed by reddish fruit. Native to rocky soils in deciduous forests of summer-rainfall southeastern Mexico. Not a true palm; closely related to and may be offered as Nolina or as Dasylirion. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Prefers dryish winters. Sunset: 13,16-24

Beaucarnea stricta (bottle palm), succulent, slow growing to 15-25 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with a rosette of stiffly upright, narrow, grasslike, bluish green leaves, slowly forming a palmlike trunk that becomes noticeably enlarged at the base. With age, the trunk may form branches, each with its own rosette, and branched spikes of creamy white or greenish yellow flowers. Old, brown leaves hang down on the trunk unless removed. Native to southwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Nolina. Sunset: N/A

Bebbia juncea (sweet bush), evergreen shrub, 2-5 feet tall and wide, with barely noticeable, narrowly linear, aromatic, green leaves and small, upright heads of tiny, tightly clustered, yellow-orange disc flowers with no petals in spring or summer. Native to rocky slopes and desert washes in southern California and Nevada east to Texas and south to northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Berberis 'Golden Abundance' (Golden Abundance mahonia), evergreen shrub, upright to 6-8 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes to 8-10 feet wide, with glossy green leaves divided into spiny-edged leaflets. Large sprays of bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by deep blue-purple, berries. Natural hybrid involving B. aquifolium, B. piperiana, and B. amplectens, three species native to western North America. Cool sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as Mahonia. Sunset: 2b-12,14-24

Berberis aquifolium 'Compacta' (compact Oregon grape), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and spreading slowly by rhizomes, with glossy, dark green leaves divided into spiny-edged leaflets, new growth coppery and winter accents bright red and purple. Bright yellow, early spring flowers are followed by dark blue-purple berries. Native to woodland openings from the mountains of southern California north to British Columbia and east to Idaho. Cool sun to part shade, full shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained, humusy soils. Best in cool-summer, mild-winter climates. May be offered as Mahonia. Sunset: 2-12,14-24

Berberis aquifolium var. repens (creeping mahonia), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes, with leaves divided into spiny-edged, leathery, dark blue-green leaflets that turn reddish in winter. Bright yellow flowers in late spring are followed by dark bluish purple fruits. Native to woodlands and forests from British Columbia south to northern Baja California and east to the Rocky Mountains. Cool sun to part shade, full shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained, humusy soils. May be offered as B. repens. Sunset: 2b-9,14-24

Berberis eurybracteata 'Soft Caress' (Soft Caress mahonia), evergreen shrub, smaller than the species, reaching 3 feet high and 3.5 feet wide with long leaves pinnately compound into long, thin leaflets. Branches create a spiral around the plant yielding a unique accent in the shade garden. Yellow blooms arise late fall into winter, brightening up the shade. May be headed to create more branching and denser habit. Part shade to shade, most soils. Sunset zones:6-9, 14-24.

Berberis haematocarpa (red barberry), evergreen shrub, upright to 6-8 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into spiny-edged, leathery, matte gray-green, narrowly oval to lance-shaped leaflets. Loose clusters of bright yellow flowers in late winter to spring are followed by purplish red berries. Native to dry, rocky mountain slopes, canyons, and mesas, often near springs or in washes, from southeastern California and southwestern Nevada to western Texas and northern Mexico. May be offered as a variety of B. nevinii or as Mahonia. Sunset: N/A

Berberis nevinii (Nevin's mahonia), evergreen shrub, 5-8 feet tall and wide, with matte blue-green to dark gray-green leaves divided into spiny-edged leaflets, new growth tinged pink, clusters of golden-yellow flowers in late winter to mid-spring, and bright red-orange berries in fall. Native to sandy or gravelly soils along the coast or in inland canyons and foothills of southern California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Mahonia. Sunset: N/A

Berberis pinnata and cultivars (California holly grape), slow growing to 6-8 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with leaves divided into oval to lance-shaped, glossy green, wavy-edged leaflets with spiny margins, new growth bronzy red or orange. Upright clusters of small, yellow flowers in early spring are followed by dark purple berries. Species is native to coastal mountains, often near seeps or springs, on north-facing slopes, and in the fog belt, from Oregon to Baja California. 'Ken Hartman' is a selection from the San Gabriel Mountains. 'Shnilemoon' is a selection of subspecies insularis, an endangered plant native to the Channel Islands. Cool sun to part or full shade, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. May be offered as Mahonia. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Berberis thunbergii cultivars (Japanese barberry), deciduous shrubs with small, rounded leaves on arching, spiny branches and yellow spring flowers followed by bright red berries. Species is 3-6 feet tall with dark green leaves that turn red, orange, and yellow in fall. Species is native to Japan and eastern Asia and is invasive in parts of eastern North America. Many cultivars, some of which may have invasive potential. 'Aurea' is 3-5 feet tall with golden yellow leaves. 'Bogozam' (Bananza Gold™) is similar but only 1-2 feet tall. Crimson Pygmy' and 'Bagatelle' are 1-2 feet tall with deep red leaves. 'Helmond Pillar', with red leaves, is 6-8 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2b-24

Berberis trifoliolata (currant of Texas), evergreen shrub, 2-6 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into spiny-edged, gray-green to bluish green leaflets and clusters of small, yellow flowers in late winter and early spring followed by red berries. Spreads by suckering roots. Native to rocky soils in grasslands, shrublands, and open woodlands from Arizona to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Mahonia. Sunset: N/A

Bergenia crassifolia (winter-blooming bergenia), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, spreading slowly by rhizomes, with large, leathery, dark green leaves and small, pink flowers on short stems in late winter or early spring. Native to rocky soils at mid-elevations from Siberia south through northwestern China. Many cultivars with flowers from red to pink or white. Cool sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-9,12-24,A1-A3

Berlandiera lyrata (chocolate-scented daisy), perennial, 1-3 feet tall and 2 feet wide, with gray-green leaves and chocolate-scented, night-blooming, yellow daisy flowers most fragrant in the early morning. Dies back to the ground in winter. May self-sow. Native to dry, gravelly or sandy soils from Colorado and Kansas south to Arizona, Texas, and northern Mexico. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Best in warm-summer climates. Sunset: 10-13,18-23

Beschorneria albiflora (trunking beschorneria), succulent, 3-4 feet tall and wide, rosette of mid-green, strap-shaped leaves, gradually forming a trunklike stem to 6 feet tall. Pendulous, pinkish to greenish white, tubular flowers are borne on the branches of an arching, 4- to 5-foot magenta stalk that arises from the center of the rosette. Clumps gradually expand by offsets at the base. Native to semi-arid parts of Mexico and Central America. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Beschorneria yuccoides (Mexican lily), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with succulent, gray-green, strap-shaped leaves and tubular, bright green, late spring or summer flowers with prominent red bracts on bright red, 3- to 6-foot stalks. Clumps gradually expand by offsets at the base. Native to rocky slopes in coastal southeastern Mexico. Full sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 13,16-17,19-24

Bidens ferulifolia (Apache beggarticks), perennial, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with finely dissected, dark green leaves and masses of bright yellow daisy flowers almost year-round in mild climates. Grown as an annual where winters are cold. May self-sow. Native to Arizona and New Mexico south through northern Mexico. Many cultivars. Full sun, well drained soils. Sunset: 16-24

Bidens nudata (yellow laguna bur marigold), perennial, mounding 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with fine-textured, mid-green leaves divided into threadlike leaflets and bright yellow daisy flowers from late fall into early summer. Native to grasslands and forest edges in Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Bidens triplinervia (tickseed), perennial, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with dark green leaves divided into small, linear or lance-shaped leaflets and bright yellow daisy flowers with dark brown centers in summer and fall. Native to the mountains of northern Mexico to Bolivia. Cultivars with red, orange, and bicolored flowers are sometimes available. Self-sows and can be weedy. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Blechnum spicant (shade in the low desert)
plants.culturalInformation: Blechnum spicant (deer fern), fern, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, spreading slowly by rhizomes, with a rosette of arching or spreading, glossy, dark green, sterile leaves divided into wavy-edged leaflets and taller, stiffly upright, fertile leaves divided into narrower leaflets in the center of the rosette. Native to damp forests of Europe, northern Asia, and coastal western North America from Alaska to northern California. Part shade to shade, well-drained, humusy soils. May be offered as Struthiopteris. Sunset: 2b-7,14-19,24

Bloomeria crocea (goldenstar), perennial from corm, 1 foot tall, with a single, green, grasslike leaf and a loose cluster of yellow, star-shaped flowers on a tall stem in spring. Native to grasslands and open woodlands in southern California and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Boltonia asteroides cultivars (false chamomile), perennials, 3-6 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with linear to lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and masses of small, white, lavender, or purplish pink daisy flowers with yellow centers in late summer and fall. Species is native to sandy or gravelly soils in seasonally wet meadows and along stream banks and pond edges in central and eastern North America. Compact cultivars are available. Spread slowly by rhizomes. Self-sow and can be weedy. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Boophone disticha (oxbane), perennial from bulb, 1 foot tall and wide, with a fan of stiffly upright, grayish green, strap-shaped, wavy-edged leaves atop a large, partially exposed bulb. A large, round head of fragrant, funnel-shaped, red or pink flowers in late winter and spring, usually before new leaves appear, is followed by a dried seedhead that detaches from the bulb and rolls like a tumbleweed, dispersing seed as it rolls. Native to sandy or rocky soils on slopes and in dry grasslands in eastern and southern Africa, including South Africa, usually but not always in areas of summer rainfall. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Bothriochloa barbinodis (cane bluestem), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with pale green leaves that take on red and orange tints in fall and silvery white flowers in spring and summer. Native to dry slopes in southern California east to Oklahoma and south to Central and South America. Full sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Andropogon. Sunset: N/A

Bougainvillea (bougainvillea), evergreen or deciduous vine or vining shrub, 15-30 feet tall, with heart-shaped to elliptical, matte green leaves on arching, thorny branches and inconspicuous, tiny, white flowers surrounded by brightly colored, papery bracts. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to tropical and subtropical Central and South America. Many named cultivars, the origins of which are often obscure. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-17,19, 21-24

Bouteloua curtipendula (sideoats grama), warm-season grass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, clump-forming, with narrow, bluish green leaves aging to reddish brown or tan and distinctive 2- to 3-foot flowering stalks bearing purplish flowers on only one side of the stalk. Native to rocky, open slopes throughout much of North America. Sun to light shade, most well drained soils. Good for hot sites and for erosion control. Sunset: 1-3,7-11,14,18-21

Bouteloua gracilis and cultivars (blue grama), warm-season grasses, 6-12 inches tall, clumping or sod-forming, with fine-textured, bluish gray-green leaves that age to purplish golden brown and feathery, purple-tinged flowers held horizontally on 18-inch stalks. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Native to the Great Plains region from Canada to the southwestern United States. 'Blonde Ambition' is 12-18 inches tall and has chartreuse flowers. Can be mowed as rough turf. May be offered as Chondrosum. Sunset: 1-3,7-11,14,18-21

Brachychiton acerifolius (flame tree), semi-deciduous tree, 30-50 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with a broad, tapering trunk, large, lobed, glossy green leaves, and pendant clusters of bright red, waxy, bell-shaped to tubular flowers in late spring. Flowers appear soon after the tree has dropped all or some of its leaves and are followed by long, dark brown seedpods. Young trees may not bloom for several years. Native to coastal forests of summer-rainfall southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good coastal and inland. Sunset: 15-24

Brachychiton discolor (Queensland lacebark), semi-deciduous tree, slow growing to 30-40 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with a broad, tapering trunk, large, lobed, dark bluish green leaves, and clusters of felted, bell-shaped, pink flowers with darker pink centers in summer. Flowers appear soon after the tree has dropped all or some of its leaves and are followed by long, brown seedpods. Native to coastal forests of summer-rainfall southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 15-24

Brachychiton populneus (bottle tree), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 30-50 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with a moisture-storing trunk, broad at the base and tapering toward the top, and oval to lance-shaped, sometimes lobed, glossy green leaves, new growth tinged pink. Clusters of bell-shaped, creamy white to pale pink flowers in spring are followed by dark brown seedpods. Native to a range of habitats, from wet coastal to dry inland southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good shade tree for hot-summer climates. Sunset: 12-24

Brachychiton rupestris (Queensland bottle tree), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20 feet tall and 15 feet wide, with a moisture-storing trunk, swollen at the base, and pointed, oval, dark green leaves, deeply lobed on young trees. May drop some or all leaves before flowering or in prolonged drought. Small, yellowish, bell-shaped flowers on older trees are followed by small, leathery, dark brown seedpods. Native to rocky soils in semi-arid, inland parts of eastern Australia. Sun, most soils. Coastal or inland. Adaptable. Sunset: 13,21,23-24

Brachyglottis greyi (groundsel), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 4-5 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with lightly felted, oval, gray-green leaves narrowly edged in white, white-woolly beneath, and loose clusters of bright yellow daisy flowers in summer to fall. Native to rocky, exposed bluffs in southern North Island, New Zealand, where rainfall is spread throughout the year. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Senecio. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Bracteantha cultivars (strawflower), annuals and perennials, a few inches to 3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and yellow central disk flowers surrounded by papery, rigid, glossy bracts that resemble petals from late spring to fall. Species are native to many habitats, both moist and dry and from sea level to alpine, throughout much of Australia. Many cultivars, mostly short-lived perennials with varying flower colors. 'Dargan Hill Monarch' has gray-green leaves and large yellow flowers. 'White Monarch' is similar but with white flowers. 'Diamond Head' forms a flat mat of green leaves and has orange flowers with yellow bracts. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Helichrysum or as Xerochrysum. Sunset: N/A

photos.filename: Brahea armata (blue hesper or Mexican blue palm)
photos.caption: Brahea armata (blue hesper or Mexican blue palm)

plants.culturalInformation: Brahea armata (blue hesper or Mexican blue palm), slow growing to 25-50 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with stiff, flattened, fan-shaped, silvery gray-green leaves, bluish white when young. Leaf petioles are sharply toothed. Long, pendulous clusters of small, white or yellowish flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by shiny, round, dark brown fruits. Fruit and leaf drop can be messy. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Crown must be kept dry in summer. Sunset: 12-17,19-24

Brahea brandegeei (San Jose hesper palm), palm, slow growing to 40-60 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with gray-green, fan-shaped leaves on a narrow trunk and long clusters of creamy white flowers in spring followed by black fruit, mostly hidden among the leaves. Native to Baja California. Sun, good drainage. Sunset: 13,19,21-24

Brahea edulis (Guadalupe palm), palm, slow growing to 20-30 feet tall and 12-15 feet wide, with stiff, medium green leaves consisting of radiating leaflets and long, pendant clusters of small, creamy white flowers in late winter or early spring followed by golden yellow fruit. Drops old leaves and fruit. Native to dry, open woodlands on Guadalupe Island, off the coast of Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 12-24

Brickellia californica (brickelbush), perennial, 2-6 feet tall and wide, with oval to almost triangular, hairy, green leaves with serrated margins and small, narrow, cylindrical heads of intensely fragrant but otherwise insignificant, creamy white or pale yellow flowers in late summer and fall. Native to woodlands and shrublands, grasslands and deserts from Oregon and California east to Wyoming and western Texas and south to northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Briza media (quaking grass), cool-season grass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, spreading slowly by rhizomes, with upright, fine-textured, dark green leaves and purple-tinted green flowers on branched, threadlike, 2- to 3-foot stems in late spring or early summer followed by tan seedheads. Native to Europe and Asia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Brodiaea species (brodiaea), perennials from corms, with one to a few narrow, grasslike, basal leaves and a cluster of tubular to funnel-shaped flowers on a leafless stem in late spring or early summer. Deciduous and dormant after flowering. Spread slowly by offsets. B. californica, with lavender, white or sometimes pink flowers, and B. elegans, with purple flowers, are native to valley grasslands and foothill woodlands from southwestern Oregon to central California. B. coronaria, with dark blue flowers, is native to mountains and foothills from British Columbia to northern California. Several other brodiaeas, including B. laxa, B. grandiflora, B. hyacinthina, and B. ixioides, have been reclassified as Triteleia. Sun to part shade, well-drained, moisture-retentive soil. Need moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: zones vary

Bromelia balansae (heart of fire), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with a rosette of dark green, strap-shaped leaves with sharply spiny margins. Small, fragrant, magenta and white, late-spring flowers on an upright, central stalk are followed by spherical to egg-shaped, orange fruits. Inner leaves turn bright red-orange just before and during bloom. May spread by underground stems to produce large colonies. Native to South America from Colombia and Brazil to northeastern Argentina. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 13,19-24

Buddleja alternifolia (fountain butterfly bush), deciduous shrub, 8-15 feet tall and wide, with arching branches bearing lance-shaped, dark gray-green leaves, pale gray and felted beneath, and showy, pendulous sprays of tiny, tubular, fragrant, lavender flowers in spring. Native to arid or semi-arid north-central China. 'Argentea' has leaves covered with fine hairs, giving plants a silvery appearance. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2b-24

Buddleja lindleyana (weeping butterfly bush), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with glossy green, oval leaves on weeping branches and long, pendulous sprays of tiny, tubular, unscented, purple flowers from lavender buds in summer. May spread by runners to form thickets. Native to forest edges, often along streams, in much of western and central China. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Buddleja marrubiifolia (woolly butterfly bush), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, densely covered with elliptic, silvery gray-green, woolly leaves with serrated margins and small, spherical clusters of orange flowers in spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils in deserts of western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

Bulbine frutescens (stalked bulbine), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, rosette of narrow, cylindrical, succulent, light gray-green leaves and conical clusters of bright yellow, star-shaped flowers on tall stems in spring. Cultivars include ‘Hallmark’ with orange flowers, and 'Tiny Tangerine', a shorter cultivar with orange flowers that thrives in full sun. Native to the southern coast of South Africa north to Mozambique. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, most soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Bulbine latifolia (rooiwortel), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with a rosette of succulent, lance-shaped to triangular, light green leaves resembling an aloe but without marginal teeth. Upright spikes of star-shaped, yellow flowers in late winter and spring. Native to rocky or sandy soils in summer-rainfall Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Bulbinella elegans (cat's tail lily), perennial, rosette, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, of narrow, bright green, somewhat fleshy, linear leaves and conical clusters of small, bright yellow or creamy white, star-shaped flowers on upright, 2-foot stems in late winter to spring. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils in mountains of Northern Cape Province, South Africa. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Bulbinella floribunda (yellow cat's tail), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, grasslike, green leaves and cylindrical clusters of small, star-shaped, yellow flowers on tall stems in winter and spring. Native to winter-rainfall climates of Western Cape Province, South Africa. Dormant and deciduous in summer. Sun to light shade, most soils. Adaptable. May be offered as B. robusta. Sunset: 14-24

Bulbinella hookeri (Maori onion), perennial from rhizomes, rosette of narrow, lance-shaped, somewhat fleshy, dark green leaves, 1 foot tall, spreading to form colonies 2-3 feet wide, and conical clusters of small, star-shaped, yellow flowers on 2-foot stems in late spring into summer. Native to shaded slopes, along streams, or in damp grasslands in the mountains of southern New Zealand. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Bulbinella nutans (bulbinella), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with rosettes of narrow, bright green, grasslike or strap-shaped, somewhat fleshy but not succulent leaves and cylindrical clusters of small, star-shaped, yellow flowers on tall stems in spring. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Native to winter-rainfall climates of Western Cape Province, South Africa. May be offered as B. robusta. Sunset: 14-24

Bulbinella robusta (bulbinella), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, grasslike, green leaves and cylindrical clusters of small, star-shaped, yellow flowers on tall stems in winter and spring. Native to winter-rainfall climates of Western Cape Province, South Africa. Dormant and deciduous in summer. Sun to light shade, most soils. Adaptable. May be offered as B. floribunda or as B. nutans subsp. nutans. Sunset: 14-24

Bupleurum fruticosum (shrubby hare's ear), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with leathery, oval, dark blue-green leaves, pale gray beneath, grayish white stems, and loose, flat-topped to rounded clusters of chartreuse flowers in late spring and early summer. Native to the Mediterranean region. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Good choice for exposed coastal sites. Sunset: N/A

Bursera fagaroides (fragrant bursera), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, slow growing to 12-25 feet tall and wide, with a thick, short trunk, whitish tan, peeling bark, smooth and gray-green beneath, and widespreading main branches. Trunk and main branches are succulent and noticeably swollen. Smaller branches are more upright and bear resinous leaves divided into small, oval, gray-green leaflets with toothed margins. Tiny, greenish white flowers in spring are followed by small, green fruits. Slowly developing pods split to reveal a single bright red or yellow seed. Bark, leaves, and fruits are aromatic. Native to central and northwestern Mexico, including Baja California, and southwestern Arizona. Sun, well-drained soil. Needs summer heat. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Bursera hindsiana (bursera), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, slow growing to 12-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with a thick, short, noticeably swollen trunk or trunks, reddish brown bark, and dark green leaves divided into lightly hairy, oval to broadly lance-shaped leaflets with scalloped margins. Inconspicuous white flowers in late summer or fall are followed by small, green and red fruits. All parts of the plant are aromatic. Native to dry, rocky slopes and washes in coastal western Mexico, including northern and southern Baja California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Bursera microphylla (little elephant tree), semi-evergreen shrub, slow growing to 10-18 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with a semi-succulent, noticeably swollen trunk and main branches, tan-white, papery, peeling bark, and leaves divided into small, glossy, dark green linear to elliptic or almost oval leaflets. Tiny, creamy white to greenish flowers in summer are followed by small, reddish purple fruits. All parts of the plant are aromatic. Native to deserts of southern California, southern Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun, most well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Butia odorata (pindo palm), palm, slow growing to 12-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with long, feathery, arching, gray-green to bluish gray leaves on spiny stalks, a stout trunk, and long clusters of yellow spring flowers followed by yellow to orange fruit. Native to dry woodlands and grasslands in northern Argentina, southern Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as B. capitata. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Caesalpinia cacalaco (cascalote), evergreen tree or large shrub, fast growingto 15-20 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into oval to almost round, gray-green leaflets on thorny branches. Showy spikes of bright yellow flowers in late fall and winter are followed by coppery, beanlike seedpods. Native to dry slopes and desert washes in southern Mexico. Thornless cultivars are available. Sun, well-drained soils. May drop leaves in cold winters. Sunset: 12-13,21-24

Caesalpinia californica (vara prieta), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-10 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leaves divided into gray-green, linear to oval leaflets on thornless branches. Showy spikes of yellow flowers in summer are followed by reddish brown, beanlike seedpods. Native to deserts of northwestern Mexico and Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as a variety of C. mexicana or as C. pannosa. Sunset: N/A

Caesalpinia gilliesii (desert bird of paradise), evergreen or semi-evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-10 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leaves divided into small, linear, grayish green leaflets on thornless branches. Spikes of yellow flowers with long, red stamens in spring and summer are followed by large, beanlike seedpods. Native to Argentina and Uruguay. Sun, well-drained soils. May drop leaves in cold winters. May be offered as Erythrostemon. Sunset: 8-16,18-24

Caesalpinia mexicana (Mexican bird of paradise), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into small, dark green, oval leaflets on thornless branches. Upright spikes of bright yellow flowers from spring to fall and sporadically at other times of year are followed by large, beanlike seedpods. Native from southwestern Texas to central Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-16,18-24

Caesalpinia pulcherrima (dwarf poinciana), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 8-15 feet tall and wide, with mid-green leaves divided into small, linear to oval leaflets on thorny branches. Upright spikes of red and orange flowers from spring to fall or almost year round are followed by beanlike seedpods. Origin uncertain, believed to be native to Central America and the Caribbean. Cultivars with yellow flowers are available. Sun, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in cold winters. Sunset: 12-16,18-23

plants.botanicalName: Calamagrostis x acutiflora cvs. e.g. 'Karl Foerster'

photos.caption: Calamagrostis x acutiflora cvs. e.g. 'Karl Foerster'

plants.culturalInformation: Calamagrostis x acutiflora cultivars (feather reed grass), cool-season bunchgrass with fine-textured green leaves and tall stalks of pale pink to purplish pink flowers that age to tawny gold. Hybrid of garden origin between C. arundinacea, native to moist woodlands of eastern Asia, and C. epigejos, native to moist and dry habitats in central Europe. 'Karl Foerster' is 2-3 feet tall and wide with purplish flowers. 'Overdam' is less than 2 feet tall with variegated leaves and pale pink flowers. Full sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 2b-24

plants.botanicalName: Calandrinia spp. and cvs. (some spp. changed to Cistanthe sp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Calandrinia species and cultivars (purslane), annuals and short-lived perennials, most less than 1 foot tall, with succulent, linear or lance-shaped leaves and small, bright pink, red, or sometimes white flowers in summer. Native to western North and South America, Central America, and Australia. C. menziesii, redmaids, with magenta flowers, is native from British Columbia to Baja California and east to New Mexico; may be offered as C. ciliata, by which name it was long known. C. spectabilis or C. grandiflora, native to Chile, is now Cistanthe grandiflora but is still often offered as Calandrinia. Full sun, fast-draining soils. Sunset: zones vary

Calibanus hookeri (calibanus), succulent, slow growing to 1-2 feet tall and wide, with multiple tufts of narrow, gray-green, grasslike leaves that emerge from a partially aboveground, swollen, woody base (caudex) with a fissured, corky surface. Tiny, greenish or sometimes purplish white, summer flowers on branched stems are mostly hidden among the leaves. Flowers on female plants are followed by small, red fruits. Native to dry, rocky slopes in northeastern and central Mexico. May be offered as Beaucarnea. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Callaeum macropterum (yellow orchid vine), evergreen vine, fast growing to 15-20 feet, with oval to elliptic, mid-green leaves and clusters of ruffled, yellow flowers in late spring and sporadically in summer. Flowers are followed by papery, winged seedpods. Native to much of Mexico, including Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Mascagnia. Sunset: 12-24

Calliandra Sierra StarTM (fairy duster), evergreen shrub, 4-5 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into small, oval to oblong, gray-green leaflets and flowers with prominent, bright red, bristlelike stamens and inconspicuous petals almost year round. Hybrid between C. eriophylla, native to deserts from southeastern California to western Texas, and C. californica native to desert washes of Baja California Sur. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 10-24

Calliandra californica (Baja fairy duster), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with small, finely divided, dark gray-green leaves and bright red flowers with bristle-like stamens and inconspicuous petals in spring and fall or almost year-round. Native to gravelly slopes and desert washes in Baja California and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 10-24

Calliandra eriophylla (fairy duster), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with dark green leaves divided into tiny, linear leaflets and pale to dark pink flowers with prominent, bristlelike stamens and inconspicuous petals in late winter and spring. Native to gravelly slopes and desert washes from southern California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 11-24

Calliandra peninsularis (Baja fairy duster), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves divided into tiny, linear leaflets and bright red flowers with prominent, bristlelike stamens and inconspicuous petals in spring. Native to dry washes and rocky slopes in the Cape region of Baja California Sur. Sun, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Calliandra surinamensis (Surinam flame bush), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 8-15 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into small, lance-shaped to oblong, pale green leaflets, coppery when new, and flowers with prominent, pink and white, bristlelike stamens and inconspicuous petals in mid-summer or almost year round. Native to forest openings and edges in much of northern South America. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Calliandra tweedii (Trinidad flame bush), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into small, linear to oblong, bright green leaflets and flowers with prominent, bright red, bristlelike stamens and inconspicuous petals in spring and fall. Native to southeastern Brazil and Uruguay. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 22-24

Callirhoe involucrata (wine cups), perennial, low mound, 6-10 inches tall and 3 feet wide, with deeply lobed, dark green leaves and cup-shaped, magenta or wine red flowers with white centers in late spring and early summer. Cascades over walls. Native to dry, rocky soils in prairies, grasslands, and open woodlands from southern Canada south to Texas and New Mexico. Full sun, most well drained soils. Sunset: 1-3,7-14,18-24

Callistemon 'Cane's Hybrid' (Cane's hybrid bottlebrush), evergreen shrub or small tree, 10-15 feet tall and wide, with small, aromatic, lance-shaped, grayish green leaves, new growth tinged pink, and cylindrical flowerheads with bristly, pale pink stamens in spring and early summer. Hybrid involving C. sieberi or C. pityoides, both native to the mountains of southeastern Australia, usually in moist habitats. Sun to part shade, almost any soils. Adaptable. May be offered as 'Pink Ice', 'Pink Stiletto' or as Melaleuca. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Callistemon 'Jeffers' (Jeffers bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with narrow, lance-shaped, green leaves, new growth coppery, and cylindrical flowerheads with bristly, reddish purple stamens that age to lavender almost year round. Possibly a cultivar of C. citrinus or a hybrid involving that species, which is native along the coast of southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as C. 'Violaceus' or as Melaleuca. Sunset: 8-9, 12-24

Callistemon 'Little John' (Little John bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves and cylindrical flowerheads with bristly, bright red stamens from spring through fall. Seedling of garden origin, believed to be a hybrid involving C. viminalis, a native of southeastern Australia. Sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as a selection of C. viminalis or as Melaleuca. Sunset: 6-9,12-24

Callistemon 'Violaceus' (purple bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with narrow, lance-shaped, green leaves, new growth coppery, and cylindrical flowerheads with bristly, reddish purple stamens that age to lavender almost year round. Possibly a cultivar of C. citrinus or a hybrid involving that species, which is native along the coast of southeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as C. 'Jeffers', C. rugulosus 'Violaceus', or Melaleuca. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Callistemon citrinus (lemon bottlebrush), evergreen shrub to small tree, 8-20 feet tall and 6-15 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped to narrowly oval, green leaves, new growth coppery, and cylindrical spikes of bristly, bright red stamens almost year round. Native along the coast of southeastern Australia from Queensland to Victoria. Dwarf and compact cultivars are often available. Sun to part shade, almost any soils. May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Callistemon pinifolius (pine-leaved bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with stiff, aromatic, dark green, needlelike leaves and cylindrical spikes of bristly, pale greenish yellow or red stamens in spring and early summer. Native to damp woodlands in eastern New South Wales, Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Melaleuca linearis. Sunset: N/A

Callistemon rigidus (erect bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, stiffly upright to 8-18 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with aromatic, narrowly lance-shaped, dark gray-green leaves and cylindrical flowerheads with bristly, bright red stamens in late spring and summer or intermittently almost year round. Native to coastal Queensland and New South Wales, Australia, often along streams or in seasonally damp locations. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Callistemon salignus (white bottlebrush), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 20-25 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with pendulous, aromatic, lance-shaped, mid-green leaves, new growth pink to red, and showy, cylindrical spikes of bristly, creamy white or pale yellow stamens in late spring to mid-summer. Native to southeasten Australia, usually in damp places. Cultivars with pink or red flowers are sometimes available. Sun to part shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. May be offered as Melaleuca salicina. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Callistemon subulatus (callistemon), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with arching branches densely covered with aromatic, small, linear, almost needle-like, grayish green leaves and cylindrical flowerheads of bright red stamens in early spring and intermittently into late summer. Native to coastal southeastern Australia, often along streams. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: N/A

Callistemon viminalis (weeping bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 15-20 feet tall and 15 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, light green leaves on pendulous branches and cylindrical flowerheads with bristly, bright red stamens in spring and summer. Native along the coast and in foothills of eastern Australia. C. 'Little John', a hybrid involving C. viminalis, is 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide. Sun to part shade, almost any soils. May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: 6-9,12-24

photos.filename: Calochortus albus (mariposa lily, globe lily, star tulip)
photos.caption: Calochortus albus (mariposa lily, globe lily, star tulip)

plants.culturalInformation: Calochortus species (mariposa lily, globe lily, star tulip), perennials from bulbs that develop a few linear or lance-shaped leaves in winter, flower in spring, and are dormant and deciduous in summer. Flowers can be purple, white, yellow, or pink, often with contrasting markings. Mariposas are tall plants with upward-facing, bowl-shaped flowers. Globe lilies, or fairy lanterns, have almost spherical, nodding flowers usually several to a stem. Star tulips, or cat's ears, are small plants with upward-facing, bell-shaped flowers. Native to many summer-dry habitats in much of western North America. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Must be kept dry in summer. Sunset: N/A

Calodendrum capense (cape chestnut), semi-evergreen tree, 20-40 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with oval to elliptic, mid-green leaves and fragrant, pale pink to lavender flowers in spring or summer. Native to eastern and southern Africa from Kenya to Cape Town. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Calostemma purpureum (garland lily), perennial from bulb, 1-2 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with narrowly strap-shaped, green leaves and loose clusters of purplish red, sometimes creamy yellow or yellow and pink, tubular or funnel-shaped flowers on leafless stems in summer. Spreads slowly by offsets to form colonies. Native to both rocky ridges and floodplains mostly inland in southeastern Australia. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Calothamnus gracilis 'Spring Torch' (slender net bush), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with rigidly upright, narrowly linear, gray-green leaves, new growth red-orange, and brush-like clusters of dark red flowers on one side of the stem intermittently year round. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in coastal southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, May be offered as Melaleuca. Sunset: N/A

Calothamnus quadrifidus (one-sided bottlebrush), evergreen shrub, 5-8 feet tall and wide, with needlelike, green to gray-green leaves and brushlike bundles of red stamens on one side of a terminal spike in late winter and spring. Native to a wide variety of habitats in southwestern Western Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Calothamnus villosus (silky net bush), evergreen shrub, upright to 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with needlelike but soft, green to gray-green leaves and one-sided, brushlike spikes of red flowers in winter and spring and often into summer.
