Native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: N/A

Calycanthus occidentalis (western spice bush), deciduous shrub, 6-12 feet tall and wide, with oval, bright green, aromatic leaves that turn yellow in fall and small, fragrant, red flowers in late spring to early summer. Spreads by suckering roots to form thickets. Native to damp, shady woodlands or along streams in the California Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills. Part shade to shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Calylophus berlandieri (sundrops), perennial or subshrub, 8-12 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrow, fine-textured, dark green leaves and bright yellow, bowl-shaped flowers in spring and summer. Cascades over walls. Native to dry, sandy or rocky soils from New Mexico and Oklahoma to Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as a variety or subspecies of C. drummondianus. Sunset: 1-3,6-16,18-24

Calylophus drummondianus (Texas primrose), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrow, fine-textured, dark green leaves and bright yellow, bowl-shaped flowers in spring and summer. Native to open grasslands from eastern New Mexico to western Texas and south into northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 1-3,6-16,18-24

Calylophus hartwegii (Sierra sundrops), perennial, 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped to linear, shiny, wavy-edged, green leaves and bright yellow, bowl-shaped, summer flowers that age to pink. Flowers open late afternoon, wilting the following day. Native to sunny slopes and flats from Colorado and Kansas south to northern Mexico. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-3,6-16,18-24

Calystegia macrostegia (island morning glory), evergreen vine, fast growing to 15-30 feet, with large, triangular, dark green leaves and white to pale pink, trumpet-shaped flowers from late spring through summer. Climbs by twining. May drop leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to dry, rocky soils on the Channel Islands and mainland California from coastal Monterey County south to Baja California. Best along the coast. Cool sun, good drainage. Cut back annually in winter to control spread. Sunset: N/A

photos.filename: Calystegia purpurata subsp. purpurata (coast morning glory)
photos.caption: Calystegia purpurata subsp. purpurata (coast morning glory)

plants.culturalInformation: Calystegia purpurata subsp. purpurata (coast morning glory), deciduous vine, to 10 feet tall and wide, with deeply lobed, heart-shaped to triangular, grayish green leaves and small clusters of large, white, pink, purple, or purple-striped white flowers in late spring and summer. Climbs with support and drapes over rocks and walls. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains and valleys of California. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Camissoniopsis cheiranthifolia (beach evening primrose), perennial or subshrub, 6-12 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with oval, silvery gray-green leaves and bright yellow flowers that age to red-orange from early spring to fall. Native to dunes and sand hills from southwestern Oregon to southern California. Drapes over walls. Self-sows freely. Sun, sandy or gravelly soils. Cut back in late fall to renew. May be offered as Oenothera californica. Sunset: N/A

Campsis species (trumpet creeper), deciduous vines, fast growing to 25-40 feet tall, with leaves divided into pairs of dark green, oval leaflets with serrated margins. Clusters of large, orange to red-orange or sometimes yellow, trumpet-shaped flowers in summer are followed by long, curved, beanlike seedpods. C. radicans, native to eastern and southeastern North America, self-sows freely, spreads rapidly by underground runners, and can be highly invasive. C. grandiflora, native to eastern and southeastern China, is slightly smaller and somewhat less aggressive. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back hard in late winter or early spring. May be offered as Bignonia. Sunset: zones vary

Capparis spinosa (caper bush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with thick, semi-succulent, rounded to oval, mid-green leaves with sharp spines at the base of each leaf. Large, fragrant, white flowers with purple stamens in summer are followed by oblong, multi-seeded fruit. Origin uncertain, possibly arid parts of western and central Asia, but long found growing wild in coastal areas bordering the Mediterranean Sea. Spineless cultivars are available. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Carex divulsa (European gray sedge), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, clump-forming, with glossy, dark green, grasslike, arching leaves and small, inconspicuous, green flowers from late winter through spring that age to brown. Native from Europe and North Africa east to central Asia. Self-sows freely and should not be planted near wildlands. Mow before seed set to contain spread. Cool sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. May be offered as Berkeley sedge or as C. tumulicola, which is a smaller, less vigorous plant. Sunset: 2b-9, 11-24

Carex flacca (blue sedge), perennial, clump-forming, less than 1 foot tall and spreading vigorously by rhizomes to 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly linear, grasslike, blue-green leaves. Native to grasslands, sand dunes, and marshes of southern Europe and North Africa. Cool sun to light shade or afternoon shade, almost any soils. Accepts periodic flooding. May be offered as C. glauca. Sunset: 3-9,14-24

Carex oshimensis cultivars (Japanese sedge), perennials, 8-16 inches tall and 12-18 inches wide, with fine-textured, arching, grasslike leaves and spikes of inconspicuous brownish flowers in spring. Species is native to rocky slopes and woodlands throughout much of the island of Honshu, Japan. Most commonly available are variegated cultivars in the Evercolor Series*. Evergold has green leaves with a creamy white center stripe. Everest, a mutation of Evergold, has leaves with a green center stripe and white margins. Everlime has dark green leaves with lime green margins. Cool sun to part shade, most soils. Cut back lightly in late winter to renew. May be offered as C. hachijoensis. Sunset: 3-9,14-24

Carex spissa (San Diego sedge), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, loosely clumping and spreading slowly by rhizomes, with coarse-textured, silvery gray-green to bluish gray, grasslike leaves and spikes of greenish yellow spring or summer flowers that age to dark reddish brown. Native to streamsides and seasonally wet places in southern California, Arizona, and northern Mexico. Accepts periodic flooding. Sun to light shade, moisture-retentive soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-17,19-24

Carex subfusca (rusty sedge), perennial, 12-18 inches tall and spreading by rhizomes to form dense stands, with fine-textured, dark green, grasslike leaves and spikes of small, greenish flowers in spring that age to dark brown. Native to seasonally flooded grasslands and creek beds from southern British Columbia east to Montana and south to northern Baja California and New Mexico. Sun to part shade, most soils, including poorly drained. Dormant and deciduous in summer if grown dry. Can be mowed as rough turf. Sunset: N/A

Carex texensis (Catlin sedge), perennial, 4-6 inches tall and 1 foot wide, clumping and spreading slowly by rhizomes, with narrow, fine-textured, medium green leaves and small spikes of greenish spring flowers that age to brown. Native to sandy soils in woodland edges and openings from New York to Georgia and west to Nebraska and Texas. Can be grown as a rough turf. Part shade to shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as a variety of C. retroflexa. Sunset: 7-9,11-24

Carex tumulicola (foothill sedge), perennial, 8-12 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, spreading slowly by rhizomes, with glossy, dark green, grasslike leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers in spring. Native to meadows and open woodlands in the Coast Ranges from southern California north to British Columbia. A smaller plant with narrower leaves than C. divulsa, which may be offered under the same name. Cool sun or part shade, most soils. Best right along the coast. Sunset: N/A

Carissa macrocarpa cultivars (Natal plum), evergreen shrub, 5-8 feet tall and wide, with leathery, oval, glossy green leaves on spiny branches. Fragrant, star-shaped, white flowers in summer or almost year round are followed by fleshy, red fruits. Native to coastal KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Low-growing, thornless, and variegated cultivars are available. 'Green Carpet' is 12-18 inches tall and 4-5 feet wide. 'Tomlinson' is 2-3 feet tall and thornless. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Good seaside plants. May be offered as C. grandiflora. Sunset: 22-24

Carissa species and cultivars (Natal plum), evergreen shrubs with leathery, glossy, dark green, oval leaves on thorny branches and fragrant, usually bright white, star-shaped flowers in spring and summer or intermittently year round. Flowers are followed by oval, green fruits that mature to bright red. C. macrocarpa, 6-10 feet tall and wide, is native along the coast from Eastern Cape Province, South Africa, north to Mozambique. 'Green Carpet' is 1-2 feet tall. 'Boxwood Beauty' has smaller, tightly stacked leaves. 'Tomlinson' has smaller, less prominent thorns. 'Jen's Beauty' has variegated green and creamy white leaves. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Good seaside plant. May be offered as C. grandiflora. C. bispinosa, native to much of southern Africa north to Kenya, is similar to C. macrocarpa but with much smaller fruit. C. spinarum, from tropical regions of Africa, southern Asia, and Australia, is a vining shrub, variable, 3-15 feet tall and bearing white, red, or pink flowers. May be offered as C. edulis. Sunset: 22-24

Carnegiea gigantea (saguaro), succulent, slow growing to 15-40 feet tall and 2-10 feet wide, columnar, with a prominently ribbed, spiny trunk and one to several or sometimes many stiffly upright branches. Large, fragrant, white, spring flowers at tops of trunk and branches are followed by oval to oblong, red fruits. Flowers open at night and close the next day. Native to sandy, alluvial flats and steep, rocky slopes in deserts of southwestern Arizona, northwestern Mexico, and a small part of southeastern California. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 12-13,18-21

Carpenteria californica (bush anemone), evergreen shrub,  6-8 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, lance-shaped leaves and clusters of fragrant, white flowers in late spring and early summer. Native to dry woodlands, often along seasonal streams, in the Sierra Nevada foothills of Fresno County, California. 'Elizabeth' is more compact. Sun along the coast, part shade or afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Carpobrotus species (ice plant), succulents, fast growing, mat forming, and spreading widely in all directions, with fleshy, upright, gray-green leaves and brightly colored daisy flowers that open in the morning and close at night. Native to sandy coastal habitats in mild-winter, summer-dry parts of South Africa, Australia, and Chile. C. edulis, native to the Cape provinces of South Africa, can cover an area more than 150 feet wide and has large, light pink or yellow flowers. C. chilensis, with magenta flowers, is similar but has shorter leaves and is less aggressive. Its origins are uncertain, possibly also South Africa. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Mesembryanthemum. Sunset: 12-24

Carya illinoinensis (pecan), deciduous tree, 75-100 feet tall and 40-70 feet wide, with long, compound leaves divided into pointed, oblong, mid-green leaflets. Inconspicuous greenish yellow flowers in spring are followed by oval to oblong nuts enclosed in husks that often persist into winter. Native to the Mississippi Valley from Iowa to Ohio and south to Texas and northern Mexico. Many cultivars. Sun, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 6-10,12-14,18-20

Caryopteris incana (common bluebeard), deciduous shrub, mounding 2-4 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with aromatic, oval to broadly lance-shaped, grayish green leaves with scalloped edges and dense whorls of tiny, violet-blue, sometimes white or pink, flowers at intervals along upright spikes in late summer. Native to dryish mountain slopes in eastern Asia from Mongolia and China to Japan. Hybrids with C. mongholica known as C. x clandonensis are most often available. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back hard in late winter or early spring to renew. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Cassia leptophylla (gold medallion tree), semi-evergreen tree, 20-25 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with compound leaves divided into long, linear, glossy green leaflets and large, showy clusters of bright yellow flowers in early to mid-summer followed by long, green, beanlike seedpods that age to dark brown. Native to tropical southeastern Brazil. Sun, most well-drained soils. Good along the coast or inland in mild-winter climates. Sunset: 15-16,20-24

Castanopsis cuspidata (copper false chestnut), evergreen tree, 30-45 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with leathery, oval to oblong, sometimes irregularly toothed, glossy, dark green leaves on pendulous branches. Spikes of white, star-shaped flowers in spring are followed by hard-shelled nuts resembling pointed acorns. Native to broadleaved evergreen woodlands and forests in South Korea and southern Japan. Cultivars with variegated green and creamy white leaves are sometimes available. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Sunset: N/A

Castanospermum australe (Moreton Bay chestnut), evergreen tree, slow growing to 25-80 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with leathery leaves divided into large, glossy, dark green, narrowly oval to oblong leaflets. Dense clusters of red and yellow pea flowers in summer are followed by large, beanlike seedpods. Native to coastal rainforests, beaches, and mountains in eastern Australia, often along rivers and streams. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Casuarina cunninghamiana (river she-oak), evergreen tree, fast growing to 50-60 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with long, needlelike, grayish green twigs bearing minute, scalelike leaves and long clusters of tiny, reddish brown flowers in spring followed by small, brown, conelike fruits. Native to eastern Australia.  Sun, most soils. Accepts periodic flooding. Self-sows prolifically and spreads vegetatively to form thickets. May be invasive in coastal subtropical climates such as southern California. May be offered as C. equisetifolia, a species less resistant to cold and more accepting of salt spray. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Catalpa bungei (umbrella catalpa), deciduous tree, 25-30 feet tall and wide, dense and widespreading, with large, mid-green, overlapping, heart-shaped leaves. Showy, upright clusters of fragrant, trumpet-shaped, pink or white flowers with yellow and violet markings in summer are followed by long, narrow, beanlike seedpods. Native to central and eastern China. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Catalpa speciosa (western catalpa), deciduous tree, 40-70 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with large, heart-shaped, mid-green leaves, hairy beneath. Showy spikes of ruffled, trumpet-shaped, white flowers with yellow and purple markings in late spring are followed by long, narrow, beanlike seedpods. Native from western Tennessee and northeastern Arkansas to southwestern Indiana and eastern Missouri. Dropping of flowers, leaves, and fruit can be messy. Sun to part shade, most soils. Accepts seasonal flooding. Adaptable. Sunset: 2-24

Ceanothus 'Blue Jeans' (Blue Jeans ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with stiff, arching branches and small, shiny, dark olive green leaves with serrated margins and a flattened tip. Clusters of purplish blue flowers cover the plant in late winter or early spring. Garden hybrid originally assumed to be a seedling of C. purpureus but now considered a hybrid of uncertain parentage. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Best near the coast. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Centennial' (Centennial ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 1 foot tall and 4-8 feet wide, with small, glossy, dark green leaves and tight clusters of deep blue flowers in spring. Natural hybrid between C. foliosus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus discovered on seaside bluffs in coastal Sonoma County. Cascades over walls. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best near the coast but fine inland with afternoon shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Concha' (Concha ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with narrow, glossy, rough-textured, dark green leaves on arching branches and dark blue flowers from magenta buds in spring. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between C. impressus and C. papillosus var. roweanus. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Best near the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Cynthia Postan' (Cynthia Postan ceanothus), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 6-8 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, glossy, rough-textured, dark green leaves on upright branches and blue-violet flowers from magenta buds in late spring. Similar to C. 'Concha'. Hybrid of garden origin between C. papillosus var. roweanus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus from seeds collected in Berkeley and grown in England. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Dark Star' (Dark Star ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with small, glossy, rough-textured, dark green leaves on arching branches and dark blue flowers from magenta buds in spring. Similar to 'Julia Phelps' but not as wide spreading. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between C. impressus and C. papillosus var. roweanus. Best near the coast. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be short lived. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Frosty Blue' (Frosty Blue ceanothus), evergreen shrub, upright and fast growing to 8-12 feet tall and 12-15 feet wide, with glossy, textured, bright green leaves and small clusters of blue flowers from buds with pale bracts that give the plant a frosted appearance. Hybrid of uncertain parentage, believed to involve C. impressus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus. Can be espaliered or trained as a small tree. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Joan Mirov' (Joan Mirov ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with small, glossy, dark green leaves and clusters of deep blue flowers in early spring. Natural hybrid between C. foliosus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus discovered in coastal Sonoma County. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Best along the coast or in mild-summer climates. Short lived in southern California. Good bank cover. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus 'Joyce Coulter' (Joyce Coulter ceanothus), evergreen shrub, mounding 2-3 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with narrowly oval to elliptic, glossy, dark green leaves and clusters of medium blue flowers in late winter and spring. Hybrid of garden origin, believed to be between C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus and C. papillosus, both native to coastal central and northern California. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Good bank cover. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Julia Phelps' (Julia Phelps ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with small, rough-textured, dark green leaves and clusters of deep cobalt blue flowers in spring. Believed to be a hybrid of C. impressus and C. papillosus var. roweanus. Similar to 'Dark Star' but wider and with even darker green leaves. Best near the coast in full sun and well-drained soils. May be short lived. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Louis Edmunds' (Louis Edmunds ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 5-6 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, oval leaves with slightly serrated margins, pale gray-green beneath, and small clusters of bright blue flowers in spring. Garden selection of C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus, which is native to dunes, bluffs, and canyon slopes in coastal central and northern California. Best along the coast. Sun, good to excellent drainage. Good large-scale groundcover. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Ray Hartman' (Ray Hartman ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with large, rounded, dark green leaves and showy clusters of medium blue flowers in late winter to spring. Hybrid of C. arboreus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus. Good small tree. Best near the coast in cool sun but fine inland with light shade. Accepts clay soils with good drainage. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Sierra Blue' (Sierra Blue ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with large, glossy, medium green leaves and long, spikelike clusters of violet-blue flowers in spring. Seedling of C. 'La Primavera', a garden hybrid involving C. cyaneus, which is native to the mountains of San Diego County. Succeeds both along the coast and inland in southern California. Sun, good to excellent drainage. Good small tree. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus 'Tassajara Blue' (Tassajara Blue ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with small, glossy, dark green, oval to rounded leaves and clusters of medium blue flowers in spring. Garden hybrid believed to be between C. arboreus and C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus 'Tilden Park' (Tilden Park ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-5 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with glossy, finely serrated, dark green leaves on arching branches and dark purplish blue flowers in late spring. Garden hybrid likely involving C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus, a species native to dunes, bluffs, and canyon slopes in coastal central and northern California. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus 'Wheeler Canyon' (Wheeler Canyon ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with narrow, coarsely textured, glossy, dark green leaves and long clusters of medium blue flowers from pinkish purple buds in early spring. Natural hybrid believed to involve a compact form of C. papillosus native to coastal mountains of Santa Barbara County. Similar to C. 'Concha' but shorter and with lighter blue flowers. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast, but adaptable. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus arboreus and cultivars (island ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 12-25 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with large, glossy, dark green leaves, felted and gray-white beneath, and showy clusters of pale blue flowers in late winter to early spring. Native to exposed, rocky slopes on the Channel Islands in southern California and Guadalupe Island off the coast of Baja California. 'Powder Blue', from Santa Cruz Island, is 8-12 feet tall with light blue flowers. 'Trewithen Blue', a garden selection from England, is 20-25 feet tall with darker blue flowers. Good small tree or tall, informal screen. Sun, excellent drainage. Best along the coast but fine inland with afternoon shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus cuneatus (buckbrush), evergreen shrub, variable, rounded or sprawling, 5-12 feet tall and wide, with small, leathery, wedge-shaped, dark green to olive green leaves and small clusters of fragrant, white to lavender or pale blue flowers in spring. Native to coastal and interior mountains from north-central Oregon to northern Baja California. 'Rodeo Lagoon', selected in coastal southern Marin County, is 1-2 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus cyaneus (San Diego ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 10-15 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with glossy, light green, oval leaves, sometimes serrated or toothed, and long, showy spikes of bright blue to deep bluish purple flowers with protruding yellow anthers in spring. Native to rocky or gravelly soils in the foothills of San Diego County and northern Baja California. Sun to light shade, or roots in shade, excellent drainage. Best near the coast. Not always easy in cultivation. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus foliosus and cultivars (wavy-leaf mountain lilac), evergreen shrub, variable, upright or mat-forming, 2-6 feet tall and wide, with small, aromatic, dark green leaves with toothed and wavy margins and small, round clusters of dark blue or purplish blue flowers with prominent yellow anthers in spring. Native to rocky or sandy soils in coastal foothills from northern to southern California. 'Berryhill', a selection from Sonoma County, is 2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide. 'Centennial', a hybrid with C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus, is 1-2 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus gloriosus 'Anchor Bay' (Anchor Bay ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leathery, dark green, hollylike leaves densely set on spreading branches and small clusters of blue-violet flowers in spring. Selection of the variety gloriosus, native to seaside bluffs and dunes in coastal central California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus gloriosus 'Heart's Desire' (Heart's Desire ceanothus), evergreen shrub, less than 1 foot tall and 3-5 feet wide, with small, leathery, dark green, hollylike leaves and lavender-blue flowers in early spring. Selection of the variety gloriosus, native to seaside bluffs and dunes in coastal central California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus gloriosus 'Emily Brown' (Emily Brown ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with dark green, hollylike leaves and clusters of dark blue-violet flowers in late winter to early spring. Selection of the variety exaltatus, native to sandy or rocky soils in coastal northern California. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: N/A

photos.filename: Ceanothus gloriosus var. porrectus (Mt. Vision ceanothus)
photos.caption: Ceanothus gloriosus var. porrectus (Mt. Vision ceanothus)

plants.culturalInformation: Ceanothus gloriosus var. porrectus (Mt. Vision ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with small, rounded, dark green leaves with toothed, sometimes spiny margins and bright blue flowers in early spring. Native to bluffs and ridges of Mt. Vision in Pt. Reyes National Seashore. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, fast-draining soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus greggii (desert ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with small, oval, dark grayish green leaves, toothed or smooth, on gray stems and small, tight clusters of pure white to creamy white flowers, sometimes tinged pink or blue, in spring. Native to shrublands and woodlands in desert mountains from Utah to Colorado and south to southern California and northern Mexico and east to Texas. Sun, excellent drainage. May be offered as C. vestitus or as C. pauciflorus. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus hearstiorum (San Simeon ceanothus), evergreen shrub, loose, low mat less than 1 foot tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, rough-textured, dark green leaves and rounded clusters of pale lavender-blue flowers in spring. Native to sandy or rocky clay soils on coastal hills and bluffs in central California. Cool sun to light shade, part shade inland, good drainage. Not always easy in cultivation.  Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus impressus 'Puget Blue' (Puget Blue ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with small, rough-textured, dark green leaves on arching branches and bright lavender-blue flowers in spring. Selection made from the Washington Park Arboretum in Seattle and now believed to be a seedling of C. papillosus var. roweanus. Said to be especially cold hardy and accepting of garden conditions. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus impressus 'Vandenberg' (Vandenberg ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with small, rough-textured, glossy, exceptionally dark green leaves and clusters of bright blue flowers in mid-spring. Selection of the variety impressus from northern Santa Barbara County. Similar to 'Dark Star' and 'Julia Phelps' but with lighter blue flowers. Best near the coast in full sun and well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus integerrimus (deer brush), deciduous, evergreen, or semi-evergreen shrub, variable, upright or mounding 3-10 feet tall and wide, with lance-shaped to oblong or broadly oval, glossy, bright green leaves and large clusters of bright white or blue, rarely pink, flowers in late spring. Native to rocky slopes and forest openings from southern Washington south to northern Baja California and east to western New Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Not always easy in cultivation. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus leucodermis (whitebark ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and wide, with oval, gray-green leaves on grayish white branches with rigid, thornlike twigs and dense clusters of pale blue or sometimes white flowers in spring or early summer. Native to dry, rocky slopes in coastal mountains and inland foothills of central and southern California and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best in hot, dry, inland climates. Not a good choice for coastal climates. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus maritimus 'Frosty Dawn' (Frosty Dawn ceanothus), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 1-2 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with gray-green leaves on spreading branches and clusters of lavender-blue flowers in late winter. Selection from the coastal bluffs of northern San Luis Obispo County. Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Best along the coast but fine inland with some shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus maritimus 'Popcorn' (Popcorn ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, oval, leathery, dark olive green leaves and tight, rounded clusters of white flowers in late winter or early spring. Species is native to coastal bluffs in northern San Luis Obispo County. Cool sun to light shade, afternoon shade inland, good drainage. Best along the coast. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Ceanothus maritimus 'Point Sierra' (Point Sierra ceanothus), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, oval to rounded, leathery, glossy, gray-green leaves on stiff, arching branches and small, rounded clusters of blue-violet flowers from grayish white buds in winter. Species is native to coastal bluffs in northern San Luis Obispo County. Cool sun, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Ceanothus maritimus 'Valley Violet' (Valley Violet ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with small, leathery, dark green leaves and dark lavender-blue flowers in late winter to spring. Species has medium blue or blue and white flowers and is native to coastal bluffs in northern San Luis Obispo County. 'Valley Violet' was selected for its good performance in the Sacramento Valley as well as along the coast. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus megacarpus (bigpod ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 10-12 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with broadly oval to elliptic, medium green leaves and small but showy clusters of white to pale lavender flowers with darker centers in winter and spring. Flowers are followed by round, red-tinged green fruits. Native to dry, rocky slopes near the coast from Santa Barbara County to San Diego County and the Channel Islands. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus rigidus 'Snowball' (Snowball ceanothus), evergreen shrub, mounding 4-6 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, leathery, wedge-shaped to rounded, dark olive green leaves on stiffly arching branches and small, tight clusters of pure white flowers in winter. Species is native primarily to coastal central California. May be offered as a selection of C. cuneatus var. rigidus. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast or in other mild climates. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus spinosus (greenbark ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with oval, green leaves on olive green branches with thornlike twigs and long clusters of white or pale blue flowers in late winter or early spring. Native to coastal mountains south of San Luis Obispo and south into northern Baja California. Sun, well-drained, moisture-retentive soils. May drop some leaves in summer if grown dry. Best near the coast. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus 'Arroyo de la Cruz', (Arroyo de la Cruz ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with glossy, bright green leaves and clusters of medium blue flowers in spring. Selection from San Luis Obispo County of a variable species native along the coast from Santa Barbara to Lane County, Oregon. Sun near the coast, part shade or afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus 'Oregon Mist' (Oregon Mist ceanothus), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 8-15 feet tall and wide, with small, dark green leaves and pale but bright blue flowers in late spring. Selection from Coos County, Oregon, of a variable species native along the coast from southern Oregon to Santa Barbara. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus 'Skylark' (Skylark ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 4 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with glossy, dark green leaves and bright blue flowers in late spring to early summer. Believed to be a hybrid of C. thyrsiflorus var. thyrsiflorus and C. velutinus and also thought to be the same plant as C. thyrsiflorus 'Victoria'.  Accepting of garden conditions and adaptable both along the coast and inland. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus 'Snow Flurry' (Snow Flurry ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 15-20 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with large, glossy, bright green leaves on arching branches and masses of bright white flowers in spring. Selection of the variety thyrsiflorus from the Big Sur coast in central California. Adaptable and accepting of garden conditions along the coast or inland. Can be espaliered or grown as a small tree. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus var. griseus "Carmel Creeper" (Carmel creeper ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 2-3 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with glossy, oval, dark green leaves and clusters of light blue flowers in late winter or early spring. Variety griseus is native to exposed, rocky bluffs overlooking the ocean in coastal Monterey County. Carmel creeper is the common name for several cultivars, including 'Yankee Point' and 'Diamond Heights'. 'Centennial', from coastal Sonoma County, is a natural hybrid between C. thyrsiflorus var. griseus and C. foliosus. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best along the coast but adaptable inland with part shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-17,19-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus var. griseus 'Diamond Heights' (Diamond Heights ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-12 inches tall and 3-5 feet wide, with variegated green leaves with yellow margins and pale blue flowers. Garden selection made in San Francisco. May be offered as a selection of  C. griseus var. horizontalis.  Part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus thyrsiflorus var. griseus 'Yankee Point' (Yankee Point ceanothus), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with glossy, dark green leaves and bright blue flowers in spring. Selection from exposed rocky bluffs overlooking the ocean in coastal Monterey County. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best along the coast but adaptable inland with part shade. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Ceanothus tomentosus var. olivaceus (woollyleaf ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with olive green leaves with marginal teeth, pale gray-green beneath, and light to bright blue or sometimes white flowers in winter or early spring. Native to sandy or rocky soils in coastal mountains and foothills of southern California and northern Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ceanothus verrucosus (warty stem ceanothus), evergreen shrub, 5-8 feet tall and wide, with small, heart-shaped, dark green leaves, gray-green beneath, and clusters of white flowers in winter or early spring. Native to coastal San Diego County and northwestern Baja California. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Cedrus deodara (deodar cedar), evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with grayish to bluish green needles on horizontal branches that droop slightly at the tips. Native to the western Himalayas from eastern Afghanistan and northern Pakistan to north-central India. Many named cultivars from prostrate to dwarf and mid-sized. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b-10,14-24

Cedrus libani (cedar of Lebanon), evergreen tree, slow growing and low branching to 40-70 feet tall and 30-60 feet wide, much larger with great age, with short, dark green needles on nearly horizontal branches, dark gray, furrowed bark, and yellowish or purplish cones that age to reddish brown. Native to mountains of the northeastern Mediterranean region from Turkey to Syria and Lebanon. Weeping, dwarf, and blue-needled cultivars are available. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Ceiba insignis (white floss silk tree), semi-deciduous tree, 40-60 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with large, green leaves divided into serrated, oblong leaflets and a swollen trunk covered with sharp, cone-shaped spines. Large, creamy white or pale yellow flowers in winter are followed by large, pear-shaped seed capsules. Native to western South America from Colombia to northern Argentina. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Chorisia. Sunset: 12-13,15-24

Ceiba speciosa (floss silk tree), evergreen to semi-deciduous tree, fast growing to 40-60 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with compound leaves divided into light green leaflets, some or all of which may drop before flowering, and a green to light gray trunk with sharp, rigid, thornlike prickles. Large, showy, reddish or purplish pink flowers in late summer or fall are followed by large, oval capsules that split open in spring to release white, cottony floss and seeds. Native to tropical and subtropical summer-rainfall parts of southern Brazil, northeastern Argentina, and Paraguay. Thornless cultivars are sometimes available. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Chorisya. Sunset: 12-24

Celtis australis (European hackberry), deciduous tree, fast growing to 40-60 feet tall and wide, with smooth, gray bark and oval to broadly lance-shaped, bright green leaves with serrated margins that turn pale yellow in fall. Inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in spring are followed by dark purple, berrylike fruits. Native to rocky soils from southern Spain and northwestern Africa to the Caucasus, Turkey, and Syria. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Celtis occidentalis (common hackberry), deciduous tree, 30-50 feet tall and wide, with asymetrically oval, bright green leaves with serrated margins and pointed tips. Inconspicuous, greenish, spring flowers are followed by dark purple, berrylike fruit. Native to eastern and midwestern North America from southern Ontario and Quebec to North Carolina and Oklahoma, usually along streams and often on seasonally flooded sites. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 1-24

Celtis pallida (desert hackberry), semi-evergreen shrub, 8-15 feet tall and wide, with small, oval to elliptic, leathery, dark green leaves on spiny branches. Inconspicuous, greenish flowers in spring are followed by orange, sometimes red or yellow, berrylike fruit. Native to mid-elevation foothills and canyons from southern Arizona to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Needs summer heat. May drop leaves in summer if grown dry. May be offered as a variety of C. spinosa. Sunset: 10-13

Celtis reticulata (western hackberry), deciduous tree, slow growing to 25-30 feet tall and wide, with oval to almost triangular, dark green leaves with serrated margins and inconspicuous, greenish flowers in spring followed by red-orange, berrylike fruit. Native to dry slopes and seasonal watercourses from eastern Washington to the mountains of southern California and Arizona. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as a variety of C. laevigata. Sunset: 2-24

Celtis sinensis (Chinese hackberry), deciduous to semi-evergreen tree, fast growing to 40-60 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with a low and widespreading canopy and oval, medium green, finely serrated leaves that turn yellow in fall. Inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in spring are followed by small, round, orange to reddish brown fruits. Native to eastern China, Japan, and Korea. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 8-16,18-20

Centaurea cineraria (dusty miller), perennial or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with densely felted, deeply cut, gray-green leaves that appear silvery white and small, pinkish purple, thistlelike flowers in late spring and summer. Native to coastal cliffs in southwestern Italy. Sun to part shade, most soils. Good seaside plant. Senecio cineraria, often offered as C. cineraria and also known as dusty miller, has similar leaves and yellow flowers. C. cineraria may be offered as C. gymnocarpa, a rare plant from the island of Capraia off the western coast of central Italy. Sunset: 8-24

Centaurea gymnocarpa (Capraian cornflower), perennial or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with fine-textured, deeply cut, silvery gray-white leaves and pinkish purple, thistlelike flowers in late spring and summer. Native to rocky cliffs and mountain peaks on Capraia, an island between the north coast of Corsica and the western coast of central Italy. Plants commonly offered as C. gymnocarpa may instead be a variety of C. cineraria or a hybrid involving that species. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 8-24

Centaurea montana (perennial cornflower), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaves and purplish blue flowers with fringed, outer petals and thistlelike, reddish purple centers in late spring and early summer. Self-sows readily and spreads by rooting stems, especially in moist soils. Native to mountains of southern Europe. Cultivars with pink or white flowers are available. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back after flowering to renew. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

Centranthus ruber (red valerian), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with fleshy, oval to lance-shaped, bluish green leaves and rounded clusters of tiny, star-shaped, purplish pink or sometimes white flowers from late spring to summer or into fall where summers are mild. Native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Turkey and Morocco to Tunisia. Self-sows freely and can be invasive, especially in coastal habitats. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Can be cut back hard to renew. Sunset: 2-9,12-24

Cephalocereus species (old man cactus), succulents, slow growing to 15-30 feet tall and 2-5 feet wide, upright and columnar, sometimes branched, usually bluish dark green, with sharply spiny ribs and long, soft, white hairs that in some species almost completely cover the plant. Tubular to bell-shaped, nocturnal, bat-pollinated, summer flowers on mature plants are followed by oval, scaly fruit. Most slowly form colonies. All five species are native to specific types of rocky soil in mountains of southern Mexico. C. similis is readily available; other are uncommon in the trade or available only from specialty suppliers. Many plants formerly considered Cephalocereus species are now classified as Pilocereus. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage. Sunset: 13,21-24

Cephalophyllum species (ice plant), succulents, a few inches tall and either clumping or spreading, with fleshy, green to gray-green, upright, cylindrical to almost triangular leaves and bright red, purplish pink, orange, or yellow flowers in winter or early spring. Flowers close in the evening and open on sunny days. Native to winter-rainfall western South Africa north to southwestern Namibia. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 8-9,11-24

Ceratonia siliqua (carob), evergreen tree, slow growing to 30-45 feet tall and wide, with large, compound leaves divided into glossy, almost round, leathery, dark green leaflets that cast dense shade. Small, red flowers in spring are followed by long, dark brown, beanlike seedpods on female trees. Believed to be native originally to southwestern Asia but cultivated and distributed many centuries ago throughout much of the coastal Mediterranean region. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 9,13-16,18-24

Ceratostigma abyssinicum (African plumbago), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with oval to elliptic, lightly hairy, mid-green leaves with bristly margins that turn bronzy red in fall and clusters of small, tubular, bright blue flowers in summer. Native to northeastern Africa, from Sudan and Eritrea to Kenya. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Ceratostigma griffithii (Burmese plumbago), evergreen shrub, mounding 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with wiry stems bearing thick-textured, bluish green leaves with purplish margins that turn red in fall and bright blue flowers in summer and fall. Native to the Himalayas. Sun to part shade, most soils. Can be cut back hard to renew. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Ceratostigma plumbaginoides (dwarf plumbago), perennial, 6-12 inches tall and spreading by rhizomes, with glossy, medium green leaves that turn reddish in cold weather and deep blue flowers from late summer to fall. Native to rocky slopes in western China. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, some afternoon shade is recommended for best performance inland, most well drained soils. May spread aggressively in moist locations. Sunset: 2b-10,14-24

Cercis mexicana (Mexican redbud), deciduous tree, 10-15 feet tall and wide, multitrunk or low branching, with glossy green, leathery, heart-shaped, wavy-edged leaves, bright reddish pink flowers in spring before leaves appear, and pendulous, purplish brown seedpods that persist into winter. Native to desert washes in southwestern Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as C. canadensis var. mexicana. Sunset: 4-24

Cercis occidentalis (western redbud), deciduous shrub or multitrunk tree, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with bluish green, heart-shaped leaves that turn yellow in fall, bright magenta flowers that appear before leaves, and long, purplish brown seedpods. Native to the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills from northern to southern California and east to Utah and Arizona. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Flowers best with some winter chill. Sunset: 2-24

Cercis reniformis (southwest or Texas redbud), deciduous tree, slow growing to 15-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, usually multitrunk and low branching, with glossy, leathery, wavy-edged, heart-shaped to rounded, dark green leaves, bright reddish pink flowers in spring before leaves appear, and pendulous, purplish brown seedpods that persist into winter. Native to mountains of southern Oklahoma south through Texas and northeastern Mexico. 'Texas White' has white flowers. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as C. canadensis var. texensis. Sunset: 3-24

Cercocarpus betuloides (mountain ironwood), evergreen shrub or small tree, slow growing to 10-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, deeply veined, oval to rounded, dark green leaves and small clusters of inconspicuous, fragrant, creamy white flowers in spring. Seeds have decorative, silvery white plumes that aid in dispersal by wind. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the mountains of southwestern Oregon to Baja California and east to central Arizona. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as C. montanus var. glaber. Sunset: 3,5,7-10,13-24

Cercocarpus ledifolius (curl-leaf mountain mahogany), evergreen shrub or small tree, variable, slow growing to 6-25 feet tall and 5-15 feet wide, narrowly upright and usually multitrunk, with leathery, resinous, dark green, narrowly oval to nearly linear leaves, grayish white beneath, and small clusters of inconspicuous, creamy white to tan flowers in spring. Seeds have decorative, silvery white plumes that aid in wind dispersal. Native to steep, rocky slopes from southeastern Washington to Baja California and from southern Montana to northwestern New Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-3,7-10,14-21

Cercocarpus minutiflorus (San Diego mountain mahogany), evergreen shrub or small tree, 8-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, oval, serrated, dark green leaves, bright green when new. Small clusters of creamy yellow flowers in spring are followed by seeds with long, feathery, white plumes that aid in dispersal by wind. Native to coastal mountains of San Diego County and northwestern Baja California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as a variety of C. montanus. Sunset: N/A

Cercocarpus montanus (mountain mahogany), deciduous or semi-evergreen shrub, variable, slow growing and long lived, 8-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with leathery, oval to oblong, dark green leaves that turn deep yellow in fall. Small clusters of inconspicuous, fragrant, creamy white to pale yellow flowers in spring or early summer are followed by seeds with long, feathery, silvery white plumes that aid in dispersal by wind. Native to dry, rocky slopes and mesas from southwestern Oregon to Baja California and from southern Montana to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-3,7-10

Cereus hildmannianus (night-blooming cereus), succulent, slow growing to 30 feet tall, with ribbed, usually spineless, dark blue-green, columnar branches spreading to form a clump up to 15 feet wide. Large, nocturnal, bat-pollinated, trumpet-shaped, white flowers in spring and summer are followed by large, pear-shaped, red fruit. Origin uncertain but believed to be native from southern Brazil and Paraguay to northern Argentina and Uruguay. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Cereus peruvianus (Peruvian apple cactus), succulent, slow growing to 15-30 feet tall, with ribbed, sharply spiny, pale gray-green to bluish green, columnar branches spreading to form a clump up to 15 feet wide. Large, nocturnal, bat-pollinated, trumpet-shaped, white flowers in spring and summer are followed by large, oval to rounded, red-orange fruit. The form offered as monstrosa has ribs with exaggerated undulations. Native to Venezuela, Grenada, and the Netherlands Antilles. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. May be offered as C. repandus. Sunset: N/A

Chaenomeles cultivars (flowering quince), deciduous shrubs, 3-10 feet tall and wide, with oval to oblong, glossy, dark green, finely serrated leaves on spiny branches and pink, white, red, or orange flowers in late winter or early spring. Flowers usually appear before the leaves and are followed by small, round, yellowish green fruit. May spread by suckering roots to form thickets. Species are native to China, Japan, Korea, and Myanmar. Hundreds of cultivars with single, double, or semi-double flowers vary also in mature size and cold hardiness. Dwarf and thornless cultivars are available. Sun, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 2-23

Chamaebatia australis (southern mountain misery), evergreen shrub, 3-8 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, resinous, fernlike leaves divided into many small, soft-textured, sticky, light green leaflets and small, white flowers with yellow centers in winter and early spring. May form thickets. Native to dry slopes and ridges in foothills of San Diego County and adjacent northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Chamaecyparis spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Chamaemelum nobile (chamomile), perennial, 3-6 inches tall and spreading by rooting stems to 6-12 inches wide, with aromatic, fernlike leaves divided into bright green leaflets and small, white daisy flowers with yellow centers in summer. Native to western and southern Europe. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Anthemis. Sunset: 2-24

Chamaerops humilis (Mediterranean fan palm), palm, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with green to bluish green leaves consisting of radiating leaflets on 3- to 4-foot, spiny stalks. Bright yellow flowers and orange fruits are mostly hidden among the leaves. Native to Mediterranean coasts from Spain to Italy and from Morocco to Tunisia. 'Vulcano' has no spines. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Chamelaucium cultivars (waxflower), evergreen shrubs, 3-10 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, bright green, needlelike leaves and small pink, purplish, or white flowers in late winter and spring. Species are native to sandy soils in southwestern Western Australia. 'Dancing Queen', a hybrid involving C. uncinatum, is 4-6 feet tall and wide, with pale lilac, double flowers. 'Matilda', a hybrid involving several species, is 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with pure white flowers maturing to dark pink. Sun to light shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Chamelaucium uncinatum (Geraldton waxflower), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, needlelike, green leaves and small pink, purplish, or white flowers in late winter and spring. Native to sandy soils in southwestern Western Australia. 'Purple Pride' has dark pinkish purple flowers. 'Dancing Queen' has pale lilac, double flowers. Sun to part shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Chasmanthe aethiopica (cobra lily), perennial from corm, 2 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with a fan-shaped rosette of upright, irislike, lance-shaped, pale green leaves and a 3- to 4-foot, unbranched spike of orange, tubular flowers in fall and winter. Flowers are followed by large, swollen capsules containing bright orange seeds. Native to coastal southern and southwestern Western Cape Province and winter-rainfall parts of the Eastern Cape, South Africa. Can be weedy; spreads by offsets and by seeds. Needs a dry summer dormancy. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 13,15-24

Chasmanthium latifolium (sea oats), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with lance-shaped, blue-green leaves spread out along upright stems and drooping, pale green, oatlike seedheads that age to tan. Native to streambanks and edges of moist woodlands from Pennsylvania to Florida west and south to Wisconsin and New Mexico. Self-sows and spreads by rhizomes, especially in moist soils. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Cut to the ground in early spring to renew. Sunset: 2-10,14-24

Cheilanthes argentea (silver cloak fern), fern, 6-10 inches tall and slowly spreading, with deeply dissected, triangular, matte green fronds, waxy and silvery white beneath, on dark reddish purple stems. Native to rocky outcrops in mainland China and Taiwan. Cool sun to shade, excellent drainage. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Cheilanthes covillei (Coville's lip fern), deciduous fern, to 1 foot tall and wide, stiffly upright with dark gray-green fronds on dark brown stems. Native to rocky cliffs and crevices in coastal and inland mountains from California east to Utah and Arizona and south to northern Baja California. Cool sun to shade or part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Myriopteris. Sunset: N/A

Cheilanthes lanosa (hairy lip fern), fern, 6-12 inches tall and 12-15 inches wide, with deeply dissected, olive green, lance-shaped, lightly hairy fronds. Native to rocky slopes and open woodlands in the eastern and midwestern United States from Connecticut west and south to Missouri and Oklahoma. Part shade, excellent drainage. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Good rock garden plant. May be offered as Myriopteris. Sunset: N/A

Cheilanthes sinuata (wavy cloak fern), fern, upright to 1-2 feet tall and 12-18 inches wide, with narrow, arching, deeply dissected, matte gray-green fronds, grayish tan and felted beneath. Native to rocky cliffs and crevices from Arizona to western Texas and south through Mexico to parts of Central and South America. Cool sun to part shade, or fronds in sun and roots shaded, excellent drainage. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Not always easy in cultivation, especially where winters are wet. May be offered as Astrolepis or as Notholaena. Sunset: N/A

Chilopsis linearis (desert willow), deciduous shrub to small tree, often multitrunk, fast-growing to 15-30 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with long, narrow, green to gray-green leaves and clusters of fragrant, trumpet-shaped, pink to white or purplish flowers from spring to fall. Long, narrow seedpods hang from the tree into winter. Native to sandy or rocky soils in deserts of southern California to northern Mexico and east to western Texas. 'Burgundy' has gray-green leaves and deep purple flowers. Best in hot-summer, mild-winter climates. Full sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b,7-14,18-23

Chimonanthus praecox (wintersweet), deciduous shrub, 10-15 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with large, glossy green, oval to broadly lance-shaped leaves and fragrant, bowl-shaped, pale yellow flowers with purplish centers on leafless branches in winter or early spring. Native to forested areas in the mountains of central and southeastern China. Sun to part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. May be offered as C. fragrans. Sunset: 4-9,14-21

Chimonobambusa marmorea (marbled bamboo), grass, 6-10 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes to form dense thickets, with bright green, closely spaced leaves on dark reddish brown stems (culms), marbled with creamy white and purple when new. Native to southern China, Myanmar, and Vietnam. Variegated cultivars with white-striped leaves are available. Shade to part shade, good drainage. Can be invasive if not controlled. May be offered as Arundinaria. Sunset: N/A

Chimonobambusa quadrangularis (square-stemmed bamboo), grass, 12-20 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes to form dense thickets, with pendant, dark green to dark gray-green leaves on arching branches and rough-textured, dark gray-green stems (culms) with prominent nodes. Native to forested areas of southeastern China and Taiwan. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Can be highly invasive if not controlled. Sunset: N/A

Chiranthodendron pentadactylon (monkey's hand tree), evergreen tree, fast growing to 40-60 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with large, drooping, shallowly lobed, green leaves, woolly, brown hairs beneath, and unusual flowers consisting of a hand-shaped grouping of five dark red stamens emerging from a cup of dark red sepals in late spring and early summer. Flowers are followed by large, woody seed capsules. Native to southern Mexico and Guatemala. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Chlorogalum pomeridianum (soap plant), perennial from bulb, 1 foot tall and 18 inches wide, with wavy-edged, strap-shaped, medium green leaves and airy displays of small, white, night-blooming flowers on thin, 4- to 6-foot, branched stalks in late spring or early summer. Deciduous and dormant after flowering. Native to grasslands and woodlands in southwestern Oregon and much of California. Sun to light shade, almost any soils. Sunset: N/A

Chlorophytum comosum (spider plant), perennial from tuber, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with a rosette of strap-shaped to linear, bright green leaves and clusters of greenish white, star-shaped flowers at intervals along a long stalk that extends outward and bends toward the ground. Small plants produced at the tips of flowering stems take root where they touch the soil. Native to forested river valleys and mountains of South Africa from the Western Cape to Limpopo. Most plants offered are cultivars with variegated green and white leaves.Part shade or shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 15-17,19-24

Choisya dumosa var. arizonica (Arizona mock orange), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with glossy, bright green leaves divided into narrowly lance-shaped or linear leaflets and showy clusters of star-shaped, fragrant, white flowers with yellow stamens in late spring or early summer. Native to rocky or gravelly slopes in mountains of southern Arizona and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as C. arizonica. Sunset: N/A

Chondropetalum elephantinum (Cape rush), perennial from rhizomes, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, grasslike stems, small, brownish, papery bracts at nodes along the stems, and clusters of tiny, dark brown flowers at stem ends. Initially upright and then relaxing on all sides to create a graceful mound. New stems arise from the center. Native to Western Cape and Eastern Cape provinces, South Africa, near the coast and often in marshes or seeps. Sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Elegia. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Chondropetalum tectorum (Cape rush), perennial from rhizomes, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, grasslike stems, small, brownish, papery bracts at nodes along the stems, and clusters of tiny, dark brown flowers at stem ends. Initially upright and then relaxing on all sides to create a graceful mound. New stems arise from the center. Native to Western Cape and Eastern Cape provinces, South Africa, near the coast and often in marshes or seeps. Sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Elegia. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Chorizema 'Bush Flame' (Bush Flame pea), evergreen shrub , 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with bright green, heart-shaped leaves with toothed margins and bright orange and pink pea flowers in winter and spring. Hybrid between C. cordatum, native to forests of southern Western Australia, and C. varium, an endangered plant native to coastal hills in southwestern Western Australia. Cool sun or part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 15-17,19-24

Chorizema cordatum (flame pea), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with heart-shaped, green leaves with wavy-edged margins and loose clusters of red-orange or yellow pea flowers from fall through early spring. Cascades over rocks and walls. Native to forests of southern Western Australia. Part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 15-17,19-24

Chorizema dicksonii (yellow-eyed flame pea), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with small, narrowly oval, mid-green leaves and loose clusters of orange, red, and yellow pea flowers in winter and spring. Drapes over walls. Native to sandy or gravelly soils on rocky slopes in southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Chorizema diversifolia (climbing flame pea), evergreen vining shrub, to 3-5 feet, with bright green, heart-shaped to elliptical leaves and bright pink and orange pea flowers in winter and spring or almost year round. Drapes over rocks and walls. Native to southwestern Western Australia. Part shade or cool sun, well-drained soils. Sunset:N/A

Chrysactinia mexicana (damianita daisy), evergreen shrub or subshrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, dark green, needlelike leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers from spring to fall. Native to rocky or sandy soils in desert mountains of northern Mexico, New Mexico, and western Texas. Sun, excellent drainage. Tip prune only; does not respond well to hard cutting back. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

Chrysocephalum apiculatum (everlasting), perennial, variable, from decumbent to 2-3 feet tall and wide, with gray-green leaves and stems covered in silky hairs that give plants an overall silvery appearance. Tight clusters of small, buttonlike, golden yellow, flowers with papery, yellow bracts from late winter to fall or almost year round. Drapes over rocks and walls. Native to a variety of habitats in southern Australia from Western Australia to Queensland. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Helichrysum. Sunset: N/A

Chrysolepis chrysophylla (giant chinquapin), evergreen tree or shrub, variable, shrub 8-15 feet tall and wide to tree 60-90 feet tall, with leathery, broadly lance-shaped to narrowly oval, dark green leaves, golden brown and felted beneath. Creamy white flowers in upright catkins in spring or early summer are followed by nuts contained in spiny, yellowish green burs. Native to both damp forests (tree forms) and dry, rocky slopes (shrub forms) in the mountains of northwestern California and western Oregon. C. sempervirens, bush chinquapin, is similar to shrub forms of C. chrysophylla. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Chrysopogon zizanioides (vetiver), warm-season bunchgrass, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with long, narrow, stiffly upright, light green leaves that turn bronzy in cool weather and purplish brown flowers in fall. Plants have long, vertical roots and tolerate a variety of heavy metals and are used for erosion control and soil remediation. Native to streambanks and other moist places from Pakistan south and east to Thailand. 'Sunshine' is a sterile selection. Sun to part shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. May be offered as Vetiveria. Sunset: N/A

Chrysothamnus nauseosus (rabbitbrush), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with aromatic, narrowly linear, green or silvery gray-green, felted leaves and small but showy clusters of bright yellow, tubular flowers in late summer and fall. Native to semi-arid regions from southeastern British Columbia south through the prairies and plains to northern Mexico and west to both coastal and inland mountains of California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back after flowering to renew. May be offered as Ericameria. Sunset: 1-3,10-11

Cirsium occidentale (Venus thistle), biennial, variable, from 2-foot clumps to 5-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with large, upright, sharply spiny, gray-white leaves and tall stems topped in summer with pinkish red flowers surrounded by spiny, gray-white bracts. Leaves, stems, and bracts are covered with white, woolly, matted hairs. Native to sunny, open slopes from southern Oregon south through California and Nevada into northern Baja California. Sunset: N/A

Cissus antarctica (kangaroo vine), evergreen vine, fast growing to 15-20 feet, with glossy, mid-green, broadly oval to heart-shaped leaves with serrated margins, new growth coppery. Small clusters of inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in spring are followed by small, round, dark blue fruits. Climbs by twining tendrils. Native to rainforests of southeastern Australia. Part shade to shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-24

Cistus incanus subsp. creticus (pink rockrose), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with resinous, oval, gray-green leaves with wavy margins and pink flowers with orange stamens in late spring and intermittently in summer. Flowers drop petals in late afternoon and new buds open the following day. Native to rocky soils throughout much of the Mediterranean region. Considered invasive in parts of California. Good seaside plant. Tip prune only as needed; rockroses do not respond well to hard cutting back. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage. May be offered as as C. creticus or as a variety of C. villosus. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Cistus species and cultivars (rock rose), evergreen shrubs, low growing to tall, with rough-surfaced, dark green to gray-green, often aromatic leaves and showy, white or pink flowers with bright yellow stamens in spring to mid-summer. Flowers drop petals in late afternoon and new buds open the following day. Native to rocky soils throughout the Mediterranean region from the Canary Islands to the Caucasus and from Morocco to Israel and Jordan. Dozens of cultivars. Some rockroses (e.g., C. creticus, C. ladanifer, C. monspeliensis) are invasive or potentially so, and all should be watched for any tendency to spread. Full sun to part afternoon shade, fast drainage. Tip prune only as needed; rockroses do not respond well to hard cutting back. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Clematis lasiantha (pipestem clematis), deciduous vine, to 15 feet, with medium green leaves divided into several lobed leaflets and fragrant, white flowers with prominent yellow stamens in winter and spring. Showy seedheads with long, feathery tails. Native to partly shaded, rocky slopes in coastal mountains and west-facing Sierra Nevada foothills from the San Francisco Bay Area to Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Clematis ligusticifolia (western virgin's bower), deciduous vine, to 15-30 feet, with medium green leaves divided into several leaflets and clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in mid- to late summer. Showy seedheads with long, feathery tails. Native to woodlands and forest openings, usually along streams, in western North America from British Columbia to northwestern Mexico. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Clematis pauciflora (small-flowered clematis), evergreen vine, fast growing to 10-15 feet, with dark green leaves divided into toothed, three-lobed leaflets. Small clusters of flowers with many pale yellow stamens and several creamy white sepals resembling petals in winter and spring. Seeds have long, feathery plumes that aid in dispersal by wind. Climbs by twining. Native to high deserts and dry, rocky foothills of southern California and Baja California, usually shaded by other plants. Summer dormant. Part shade, most well-drained soils, including periodically flooded. Sunset: N/A

Clematis viticella (Italian clematis), deciduous vine, fast growing to 15-20 feet, with mid-green leaves divided into broadly oval, usually lobed leaflets and bell-shaped flowers with flaring, blue-violet or purplish sepals from midsummer to fall. Climbs by twining. Native to southern Europe. Many cultivars with flowers in shades of blue and purple as well as white. Part shade or full sun with roots shaded, well-drained, humusy soils. Adaptable. Cut back hard in winter or early spring to promote flowering. Sunset: A2-3,2-11,14-24

Cleome isomeris (bladderpod), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, gray-green leaves divided into oval leaflets with pointed tips and clusters of bright yellow, tubular flowers with prominent stamens in late winter to spring and intermittently year round. Flowers are followed by pendant, inflated seedpods. Native to coastal bluffs, inland foothills, and desert washes in southern California, southwestern Arizona, and northern Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. Self-sows. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. May be offered as Isomeris arborea or as Peritoma arborea. Sunset: N/A

Clerodendrum bungei (cashmere bouquet), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 3-6 feet tall and wide, with large, broadly oval to heart-shaped, aromatic, dark green leaves with toothed margins and broad, domed clusters of small, fragrant, pink flowers from red buds in mid- to late summer and fall. Native to China and northern India. Spreads aggressively by suckering roots to form a dense colony, especially in moist locations. Invasive in parts of the southeastern United States. Part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

Clianthus puniceus (parrot's beak), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with arching branches bearing long, fine-textured, green to gray-green, fernlike leaves divided into many paired, linear leaflets. Dense clusters of pendant, bright pinkish red or white, sickle-shaped, clawlike flowers that taper to a long, curved tip appear mostly in spring. Flowers are followed by beanlike seedpods. Can be trained to climb with support. Native to loose, rocky soils at the base of eroding cliffs on North Island, New Zealand. Sun, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Clinopodium chandleri (San Miguel savory), perennial or subshrub, a few inches to 1 foot tall and 3 feet wide, with small, aromatic, wavy-edged, rounded, mid-green, lightly hairy leaves and small, fragrant, white to pale lavender, tubular flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky slopes in foothills of coastal mountains in southern California and northern Baja California. Part shade or cool sun, fast drainage. May be offered as Satureja or as Calamintha. Sunset: N/A

Clinopodium douglasii (yerba buena), 3-6 inches tall and spreading by rooting stems to 3 feet wide, with tiny, aromatic, rounded oval to nearly triangular, green leaves and fragrant, white to pale lavender flowers in spring. Native to shady woodlands in the coastal fog zone from northern and central California north to British Columbia. Part shade to shade or cool sun, most soils. May be offered as Satureja. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Clivia miniata (clivia), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with dark green, strap-shaped leaves and upright spikes of bright orange, funnel-shaped flowers in winter to early spring followed by red-orange fruit. Native to coastal or high-altitude woodlands in summer-rainfall parts of eastern South Africa. Many cultivars with flowers in various shades of peach, pink, and creamy white as well as orange, dwarf plants, and plants with especially broad or variegated leaves. Part shade to shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 12-17,19-24

Cneorum tricoccon (spurge olive), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with leathery, lance-shaped, glossy, grayish green leaves and clusters of tiny, bright yellow flowers in late spring. Flowers are followed by small, red-orange, berrylike fruits that age to black. Native to rocky slopes from southwestern Spain and the Balearic Islands to northwestern Italy and Sardinia. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Good for dry shade. Sunset: N/A

Colchicum x agrippinum (autumn crocus), perennial from corm, 4-6 inches tall and 3-4 inches wide, with strap-shaped, bluish green leaves in spring that are dormant by summer. Tubular, flaring, pinkish purple and white, stemless flowers emerge directly from the ground in fall. Believed to be a hybrid between C. autumnale, native from Portugal to Ukraine, and C. variegatum, native to southern Greece and southwestern Turkey. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-10,14-24

Comarostaphylis diversifolia (summer holly), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-20 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with shredding, gray bark exposing reddish brown underbark and glossy, leathery, dark green leaves with finely serrated margins. Pendant clusters of small, urn-shaped, white flowers in spring followed by bright red berrylike fruit. Native to shaded, dry slopes, often near seasonal streams, in coastal southern California and northern Baja California. Part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Arctostaphylos. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Condea emoryi (desert lavender), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with aromatic, rounded, silvery gray, woolly leaves with scalloped margins and short spikes of lavender flowers at branch ends in winter or early spring. Native to sandy soils on hot, dry slopes from southeastern California to Arizona and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Needs summer heat. May be offered as Hyptis. Sunset: 8-14,18-24

Constancea nevinii (Nevin's woolly sunflower), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with finely divided, silvery gray-white leaves and tight clusters of tiny, golden yellow, early summer flowers that age to dark brown. Native to rocky coastal bluffs on the southern Channel Islands. Full sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Cut back in late fall or winter to maintain dense form. May be offered as Eriophyllum. Sunset: 15-17,19-24

Convolvulus cneorum (bush morning glory), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with silvery green, lance-shaped leaves and funnel-shaped, white flowers from pink buds in late spring to fall. Native to rocky soils along the coast from Spain to Albania. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Afternoon shade in hot-summer climates. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be short lived. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Convolvulus mauritanicus (ground morning glory), perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with rounded to oval, grayish green leaves and lavender-blue flowers from spring to fall. Native to coastal Morocco and Algeria. Cascades over walls. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as C. sabatius. Sunset: 4-9,12-24

Coprosma x kirkii (creeping coprosma), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, glossy, narrowly oval to linear, mid-green leaves and usually inconspicuous, greenish white flowers in spring. Natural hybrid between C. acerosa and C. repens, both native to coastal New Zealand. Prostrate and variegated cultivars are often available. Cool sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Good bank cover. Cascades over walls. Sunset: 14-24

Cordia boissieri (Texas olive), evergreen shrub or small tree, 12-20 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide, with thick, oval, gray-green leaves, paler beneath, and clusters of funnel-shaped, crinkled, white flowers with yellow centers in spring and summer or nearly year round. Flowers are followed by yellowish green, oval fruit. Native to southwestern Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Cordyline australis (New Zealand cabbage tree), evergreen tree or shrub, dense, rounded rosette of upright and arching, sword-shaped, gray-green leaves, 2-3 feet tall and wide, gradually forming one to several trunks, each topped by a rosette of leaves. Mature plants may be 15-30 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide. Long, pendulous clusters of fragrant, white flowers appear in late spring to early summer, but not reliably every year, and are followed by small, hard berries. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive, especially in cool, foggy, coastal habitats. Native to forest edges, riverbanks, marshes, and sunny, open places on North and South islands, New Zealand. Red-leaved and variegated cultivars are often available. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Dracaena. Sunset: 5,8-11,14-24

Cordyline indivisa (blue dracaena palm), evergreen shrub or small tree, rosette of arching, glossy, bluish gray-green, broadly sword-shaped leaves, 4-8 feet long and 6-8 inches wide, slowly forming a single trunk. Mature plants may be 15-25 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide. Pendulous clusters of small, fragrant, greenish white to purplish flowers on a branched stalk appear below the leaves in late spring or early summer. Native to cool, damp forests in the mountains of southern North Island and western South Island, New Zealand. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Dracaena. Sunset: 16-17,20-24
