Coreopsis auriculata 'Nana', dwarf coreopsis, perennial, 5-6 inches tall and 2 feet wide, with dark green, hairy, mostly basal, oval to elliptic, lobed leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers on tall stems well above the leaves in late spring and summer. Compact selection of a species native to open woodlands in the southeastern United States. Spreads slowly by rooting stems. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Coreopsis lanceolata (lanceleaf tickseed), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, sometimes hairy, mostly basal, mid-green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers in late spring and summer. Native to eastern and midwestern North America. Many cultivars. Self-sows readily and spreads by rhizomes; can be weedy. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back hard in late summer to renew. Sunset: 1-24

Coreopsis rosea (pink tickseed), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with small, linear, almost needlelike, light green leaves and pink daisy flowers with yellow centers in summer. Self-sows and spreads slowly by rhizomes. Native discontinuously from Nova Scotia to South Carolina, usually in damp, sandy soils along water margins. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2b-24

Coreopsis verticillata cultivars (threadleaf coreopsis), perennials with dark green leaves divided into threadlike leaflets and loose clusters of daisy flowers from late spring to late summer. Species is 2-3 feet tall and wide with yellow flowers; it is native to sandy or rocky soils in eastern North America. Self-sows and spreads by rhizomes. 'Golden Showers' is 2-3 feet tall with dark yellow flowers. 'Heaven's Gate' is 18 inches to 2 feet tall with pink flowers with red centers. 'Rosea', with pink flowers, 'Zagreb', with small, yellow flowers, and 'Moonbeam', with creamy yellow flowers, are 12-18 inches tall. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

photos.filename: Correa pulchella 'Pink Eyre' (Pink Eyre Australian fuchsia)
photos.caption: Correa pulchella 'Pink Eyre' (Pink Eyre Australian fuchsia)

photos.filename: Correa pulchella 'Pink Eyre' (Pink Eyre Australian fuchsia)
photos.caption: Correa pulchella 'Pink Eyre' (Pink Eyre Australian fuchsia)

plants.culturalInformation: Correa species and cultivars (Australian fuchsia), evergreen shrubs, 2-6 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with small, oval to rounded, dark green to gray-green leaves, paler beneath, and creamy white to red or pink, tubular flowers with flared tips, usually in fall or winter to spring. Native to southeastern Australia. Most plants offered are cultivars. Correa pulchella ‘Pink Eyre’ is a compact cultivar reaching 2-3 tall and wide with pink blooms from late fall to late winter. Cool sun to part shade, fast drainage. Best near the coast. Sunset: 14-24

Corylus colurna (Turkish hazel), deciduous tree, slow growing to 40-60 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, pyramidal and low branching, lower branches nearly horizontal, with large, broadly oval, glossy, bright green leaves with prominently serrated margins that cast dense shade. Male and female flowers on the same tree in winter, male flowers in pendulous catkins, female flowers inconspicuous, followed by small, hard-shelled, spherical nuts in fall. Native to southeastern Europe and southwestern Asia from the Balkans to northern Iran. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 2b-9,14-20

Corylus cornuta subsp. californica (California hazelnut), deciduous shrub, 12-20 feet tall and wide, with rounded oval, coarsely toothed, mid-green leaves that turn yellow in fall and pendulous, yellow catkins in late winter followed by small, hard-shelled, spherical nuts. Native to moist, rocky slopes and forest edges in coastal mountains from southwestern British Columbia to central California and the northern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun or shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 2-9,14-20

Corymbia citriodora (lemon-scented gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 60-90 feet tall and 25-40 feet wide, with smooth, grayish white, peeling bark, aromatic, yellowish green, lance-shaped leaves, and small, white flowers in mid- to late winter, followed by woody seed capsules. Native to dryish woodlands in the mountains and along the coast of northeastern Australia. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good coastal tree. May be offered as Eucalyptus. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Corymbia ficifolia (red-flowering gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-40 feet tall and wide, with rough, fissured, black-brown bark, dark green leaves on somewhat pendulous branches, and showy clusters of red or sometimes pink flowers in late summer, followed by woody seed capsules. Native to open forest on the southwestern coast of Western Australia. Good coastal tree. May be offered as Eucalyptus. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Cotinus coggygria (smoke tree), deciduous shrub or small tree, 12-15 feet tall and wide, with large, broadly oval, bluish green leaves that turn yellow, orange, or red in fall. Clusters of tiny, creamy white flowers in spring are followed by a haze of showy, pale pink to deep purple, silky hairs as the flowers age. Native from southern Europe across central Asia to northern China. 'Royal Purple' and 'Velvet Cloak' have purple leaves. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Cotoneaster coriaceous (red clusterberry), evergreen shrub, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with small, gray-green, oval leaves and clusters of small, white flowers in spring followed by bright red berrylike fruit. Native to south-central China. Self-sows readily and can be highly invasive. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as C. lacteus or C. parneyi. Sunset: N/A

Cotoneaster dammeri 'Coral Beauty' (bearberry cotoneaster), evergreen shrub, 6-8 inches tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, leathery, glossy, dark green leaves, gray-green beneath, on stiff branches that root where they touch the ground. Leaves take on reddish or bronzy tones in winter. Small, white flowers in late spring are followed by bright red, berrylike fruit. Cascades over walls. Species is native to rocky slopes and open forests in mountains of central and southern China. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Cotoneaster dammeri 'Lowfast' (bearberry cotoneaster), to 1 foot tall and 8-10 feet wide, with small, leathery, glossy, dark green leaves, gray-green beneath, on stiff branches that root where they touch the ground. Leaves take on reddish or bronzy tones in winter. Small, white flowers in late spring are followed by bright red, berrylike fruit. Somewhat taller and more widely spreading than 'Coral Beauty' and with brighter red fruit. Species is native to rocky slopes and open forests in mountains of central and southern China. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Cotoneaster horizontalis (rock cotoneaster), semi-evergreen or deciduous shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with small, glossy, broadly elliptic, dark green leaves on stiff, flat, horizontally spreading branches. Leaves turn purplish to red-orange in fall. Small, pale pink flowers in spring are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Native to rocky slopes and dry mountain areas of central and western China. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2b-11,14-24

Cotoneaster species (cotoneaster), deciduous or evergreen shrubs or small trees, from less than 1 foot to 10 feet tall, with small, green or gray-green, oval to elliptic leaves and small but showy, white or pink flowers in spring followed by red or purplish black, berrylike fruit. C. horizontalis is 2-3 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide. C. dammeri is less than 1 foot tall and 8-10 feet wide. C. lacteus is 6-8 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide. C. franchetii is 6-8 feet tall and wide. Some species, especially C. lacteus, self-sow prolifically and can be weedy or invasive. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Cotyledon species (cotyledon), succulents, variable in size, shape, and color, with green, gray-green, or almost white pairs of fleshy leaves oriented at 90 degrees to the previous pair and usually with pendulous, orange or pink, tubular to bell-shaped flowers with triangular, recurved petal tips. Some bloom in summer, others in winter. Most are native to dry, rocky slopes and cliffs in eastern and northeastern South Africa. C. orbiculata is shrubby and 2-3 feet tall with rounded, gray-green to almost white leaves. C. velutina is similar, 2-5 feet tall with red-margined, gray-green, lightly hairy leaves. C. papillaris is low, almost prostrate, with spreading branches that drape over rocks and root where they touch the ground. C. tomentosa is 1-2 feet tall with hairy, bright green or gray-green, rounded leaves with soft, reddish brown marginal teeth. Sun to light shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Crassula species (crassula), succulents, variable, from a few inches tall and mat-forming to 6 feet tall and shrubby, with clusters of tiny, star-shaped, white or pale pink flowers in late winter or spring. Shrubby plants, commonly known as jade plants (e.g., C. ovata, C. arborescens), have fleshy, rounded or spoon-shaped leaves on branching stems. Stacked or necklace crassulas (e.g., C. perforata, C. rupestris) have densely packed leaves in opposite pairs on upright or trailing stems. Some crassulas grow as solitary rosettes or form clusters of rosettes (e.g., C. ciliata, C. dubia, C. orbicularis). Most plants in cultivation are native to southern or eastern Africa in habitats ranging from coastal to inland, winter to summer rainfall, full sun to light shade, and arid to semitropical. Hundreds of species and cultivars in an enormous variety of sizes, shapes, and colors. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Crocosmia hybrids (montbretia), perennials from corms, 2-3 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with narrow, strap-shaped, basal, green leaves and clusters of funnel-shaped, red, yellow, or orange flowers on one side of stiff, arching, branched, 3- to 4-foot stems in summer. Spread by offsets and can be invasive. Species are native to streambanks, grasslands, and forest openings in summer-rainfall southern and eastern Africa. Hundreds of cultivars. Sun, part shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. May be offered as Tritonia. Sunset: zones vary

Cupressus sempervirens (Italian cypress), evergreen coniferous tree, densely upright or more open and spreading, 40-60 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with dark green, aromatic, scalelike leaves on upright branches and small, round cones. Native to mountains from Greece to Turkey and from Libya to Lebanon. 'Glauca' has blue-green leaves. 'Totem Pole' and Tiny Tower™ ('Monshel') are dwarf selections. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Cussonia paniculata (little cabbage tree), evergreen tree, slow growing to 10-15 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with a thick, short trunk with a swollen base, fissured, corky, gray bark, and large, fan-shaped, blue-green leaves divided into long, deeply lobed leaflets. Short, dense spikes of small, greenish yellow flowers in summer are followed by purplish red, berrylike fruit. Subspecies sinuata, the plant most common in cultivation, is native to rocky slopes in the mountains of southeastern Africa from Eastern Cape Province to northern Gauteng, South Africa, and southern Botswana. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Cyclamen coum (hardy cyclamen), perennial from tubers, 2-3 inches tall and 6 inches wide, with rounded to heart-shaped, dark green leaves that appear in fall, sometimes patterned with silver or gray, and nodding, white or pink to magenta flowers on leafless stems in winter or early spring. Summer dormant. Spreads slowly by seed. Native to open woodlands from Turkey to Israel and around the Black Sea. Part shade, humusy, fast-draining soils. Prefers some winter chill. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

Cyclamen hederifolium (ivy-leaved cyclamen), perennial from tuber, 4-6 inches tall, with lobed, ivy-like, dark green leaves patterned with pale green or silvery gray and small pink or sometimes white flowers on short, leafless stems. Flowers appear with fall rains, followed by leaves that persist through winter and die back in spring. Summer dormant. Native to the Mediterranean region from southern France to Turkey. Part shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

photos.filename: Cyclamen persicum and hybrids (Persian or florists' cyclamen)
photos.caption: Cyclamen persicum and hybrids (Persian or florists' cyclamen)

plants.culturalInformation: Cyclamen persicum and hybrids (Persian or florists' cyclamen), perennials from tubers, 4-6 inches tall, with heart-shaped, dark green leaves, often with white or silvery gray markings, and nodding, white to pale pink, purple, or red flowers on 6- to 8-inch stems from late fall to spring. Summer dormant if grown dry. Species is native to rocky slopes from southwestern Turkey to Israel and from eastern Algeria to Tunisia. Part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 15-24

Cydonia oblonga, quince, deciduous shrub or small tree, 12-20 feet tall and 9-12 feet wide, with oval to broadly elliptic, pale green leaves, gray and hairy beneath. Pale pink to white flowers in late spring are followed by round to pear-shaped, green fruits that mature to bright yellow. Native to rocky slopes and open woodlands in western Asia from Turkmenistan and Iran to Armenia and Azerbaijan. Suckers and may form colonies. Needs a cool winter and summer heat to flower well and for fruit to ripen. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Cyperus spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Cyphostemma juttae (tree grape), succulent, deciduous, slow growing to 4-6 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with papery, peeling, gray-white bark and swollen stems bearing large, fleshy, oval, blue-green leaves with toothed margins and curled upward along the midrib. Inconspicuous flowers are followed by showy clusters of pinkish red berries in fall that age to purple. Native to rocky soils in South Africa and southern Namibia. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Cyrtanthus obliquus (Knysna lily), perennial from bulb, 1-2 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with strap-shaped, sometimes twisted, green to gray-green leaves and a 2-foot stem topped by a cluster of pendulous, tubular, red-orange flowers with pale green or yellow, slightly flared petal tips in late spring and summer. May offset to form a small clump. Native to dry, rocky slopes in open grasslands of coastal South Africa from KwaZulu-Natal to Eastern Cape Province. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Cytisus species (broom), evergreen and deciduous shrubs with tiny, green or gray-green leaves in groups of three and clusters of yellow or sometimes creamy white pea flowers in spring. Flowers are followed by brownish black pods that split in late summer and expel seeds explosively. Species are native to North Africa, central and southern Europe, and western Asia. C. scoparius, 3-10 feet tall with masses of bright yellow flowers, and C. striatus, a similar but slightly smaller plant, both self-sow aggressively, often forming dense, impenetrable stands. C. x praecox 'Warminster', a fertile hybrid of garden origin believed to be a cross between C. purgans and the white-flowered C. multiflorus, is 4-6 feet tall and wide with yellow flowers. Seedlings of this hybrid, including 'Allred', 'Gold Spear', and 'Albus', also belong to the C. x praecox group. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Dalea bicolor (dalea), deciduous or semi-evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-8 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with fine-textured leaves divided into small, green or silvery gray-green leaflets and spikes of small, bicolored, blue to purplish blue and white flowers in late summer or fall. Native to dry, rocky desert soils from Arizona to Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 10-13

Dalea capitata (dalea), evergreen or semi-deciduous shrub, 8-12 inches tall and 3-4 feet wide, with fine-textured, aromatic leaves divided into small, light green leaflets and spikes of small, yellow flowers in spring and fall. Native to deserts of northeastern Mexico and southwestern Texas. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 10-13

Dalea frutescens (black dalea), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-4 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured leaves divided into silvery gray-green leaflets and spikes of small, purple flowers in winter and spring. Native to dry, rocky slopes in deserts of New Mexico, Texas, and northern Mexico. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 10-13

Dalea greggii (trailing indigo bush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 1 foot tall and 4-6 feet wide, dense and mounding, with fine-textured leaves divided into small, silvery blue-green leaflets and clusters of tiny, purple flowers in spring and summer. Cascades over walls. Native to New Mexico, Texas, and northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 10-13

Dalea versicolor (dalea), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with fine-textured, gray-green leaves divided into small, hairy, broadly linear to oval leaflets and cylindrical spikes of lavender pea flowers intermittently from fall to spring. Native to foothills and mountains of southeastern Arizona and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Danthonia californica (California oatgrass), cool-season bunchgrass, to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with short, narrow, green leaves and tan flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems in spring and early summer. Can be mowed as a rough turf. Native to dry, rocky slopes and forest edges as well as moist meadows and seasonally flooded wetlands from British Columbia to California, east to Saskatchewan, and south through the Rocky Mountains to New Mexico. Sun to light shade, most soils, including poorly drained. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Daphne odora (winter daphne), evergreen shrub, 3-8 feet tall and 6 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, oblong to elliptic, dark green leaves and clusters of fragrant, deep pink or pale pink and white, tubular flowers in winter or early spring. Flowers are sometimes followed by red, berrylike fruit. Native to China. 'Aureomarginata' has green leaves with creamy white margins. Part shade, shade, or cool sun with afternoon shade, excellent drainage. Prune only lightly if needed. Not always easy in cultivation. Sunset: 4-10,12,14-24

Dasylirion species (desert spoon), succulent, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, grasslike leaves, some with sharp marginal teeth and some slowly forming a short or tall trunk. All eventually develop a flowering stalk, 10-15 feet tall, with creamy white to yellowish green or pale pink flowers. Plants flower repeatedly but not every year. Native to northeastern Mexico, with three species extending into the southwestern United States. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Delosperma species (ice plant), succulents, 1-4 inches tall and spreading 1-3 feet wide, with small, cylindrical, rounded, or narrowly oval, green or grayish green leaves and purple, yellow, pink, or sometimes white daisy flowers in spring and summer. Flowers close in the evening and may remain closed on cloudy days. Most species are native to summer-rainfall parts of southern and eastern Africa from South Africa to Zimbabwe. Many hybrids. Some are flat enough to follow contours and drape over rocks and walls. D. nubigenum has yellow flowers. D. sutherlandii has large, bright pink flowers. D. lavisiae is similar but with smaller pink flowers. Sun, some afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, most well-drained soils. Prefer dryish winters. May be offered as Mesembryanthemum. Sunset: zones vary

Dendromecon harfordii (island bush poppy), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-15 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with thick, oval, bluish gray-green leaves and bright yellow flowers in spring and early summer followed by long, narrow seedpods. Native to dry slopes on the Channel Islands in southern California. Best near the coast. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. May be offered as a subspecies of D. rigida. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Dendromecon rigida (tree poppy), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with lance-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves and bright yellow flowers in spring followed by long, narrow seedpods. Native to dry slopes in the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills from central California to northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 4-12,14-24

Deschampsia cespitosa and cultivars (tufted hairgrass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1 foot to 18 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, arching, dark green leaves and a haze of purplish green flowers on 2- to 4-foot stems in summer. Native to streambanks, wetlands, and seasonally damp meadows in arctic and temperate regions of Europe, Asia, and much of western and parts of eastern North America. 'Schottland' is larger than the species and has creamy white flowers. 'Northern Lights' has variegated leaves. 'Goldtau' has chartreuse flowers that age to bronzy gold. Part shade, most soils, including seasonally flooded. Cut to the ground in late winter to renew. Sunset: 2-24

Dianella caerulea cvs. (blue flax lily), clumping rhizomatous perennial, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide with strappy wide leaves. Flowers with bright yellow stamens and reflexed blue petals are borne above the foliage in summer, followed by bright violet-blue berries. Native to eastern Australia. Cultivars include ‘DBB03’ marketed as Cassa Blue, with blue-grey foliage, and ‘John316’ marketed as King Alfred with narrower, more grass-like leaves. Full sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset Zones: 8, 9, 14-24.

Dianella revoluta cultivars, flax lily, perennials from rhizomes, clump-forming, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with upright fans of narrowly strap-shaped to grasslike, bluish gray-green leaves and delicate, branched sprays of small, bluish purple flowers in spring and summer. Flowers may be followed by small, blue berries. Species is native to a variety of habitats in coastal southern and eastern Australia. May spread slowly by rhizomes to form large colonies. Smaller cultivars include 'Little Rev', 'Baby Bliss', 'Revelation', and 'Prestige'. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Cut back hard in winter to renew. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Dicentra spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Dichelostemma species (blue dicks), perennials from corms, with several grasslike leaves in late winter or early spring, followed by dense, rounded clusters of tubular to bell-shaped, pink, red, white, or purplish blue flowers on tall stems. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Spread slowly by offsets and by seed. Native from British Columbia south to northwestern Mexico and east to New Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Dicliptera suberecta (hummingbird plant), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with velvety, bluish gray stems and leaves and clusters of upright, bright red-orange, tubular flowers in summer and fall. Dormant and may die back to the ground in winter. Native to Uruguay, Paraguay, and parts of Brazil with year-round distribution of rainfall. Sun, most soils. May be offered as D. sericea. Sunset: 12-13,15-17,19,21-24

Dietes bicolor and cvs. (fortnight lily), perennial, are rhizomatous, clump forming plants 2-3 feet tall and wide with strap-like leaves emerging from central rhizomes. Species and older cultivars have 3 pale yellow sepals and 3 pale yellow petals with an orange-brown “eye,” individual flowers last for 24 hours, with a flowering season lasting from late spring to fall. ‘African Gold’ marketed as Pure Gold, has vivid yellow flowers with intense coloration. ‘Liz’s Selection’ was selected by Liz Kimmel of Sperling Nursery for its larger flowers. Dietes bicolor is native to South Africa. Cut back to 6-12 inches in late fall to remove spent flower heads and brown stems and leaves. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 8, 9, 12-24; H1, H2.

Dietes grandiflora and cultivars (fairy iris), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with fans of upright, narrowly sword-shaped, dark green leaves and large, white and lavender flowers with yellowish brown markings in summer or almost year round in mild climates. Each flower lasts only a few days, but new flowers continue to open at approximately two-week intervals. Self-sows readily and spreads by rhizomes; can be weedy. Native to South Africa from summer-rainfall coastal Eastern Cape Province to southern KwaZulu-Natal. Cultivars with variegated leaves are available. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as D. vegeta or as a selection of D. iridioides.  Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Dietes iridioides and cultivars (fortnight lily), perennial from rhizomes, 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with fans of stiff, strap-shaped, dark green leaves and 3-foot, branched, arching to almost horizontal stems carrying large, white flowers with bright yellow and lavender markings from spring to fall. Flowers last only a day but are quickly replaced as other buds open. Stems produce flowers for more than one year. Spreads both by seed and by rhizomes and can be weedy. Native to eastern and southern Africa from Ethiopia to Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. 'John's Runner' is a compact selection. Often offered as varieties of D. iridioides and differing only in small details, 'Orange Drops' and 'Lemon Drops' are hybrids with D. bicolor and 'Johnsonii' is a selection of D. grandiflora. Sun to light shade, most soils, including poorly drained. May be offered as Moraea. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Diospyros kaki (Japanese persimmon), deciduous tree, 20-30 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with large, oval, glossy, dark green leaves, new leaves yellowish green and fall colors yellow, orange, and red. Inconspicuous, creamy white flowers in late spring or early summer are followed by bright orange, round to oval fruit that persists into winter. Native to eastern China. Most cultivars are self-fertile so only one tree is needed for a good fruit crop. 'Fuyu', with round fruit, and 'Saijo', with oval to egg-shaped fruit, are popular varieties. 'Fire Crystal' is a compact selection and 'Pendula' has weeping branches. Sun, most well-drained soils. Fruit drop can be messy. Sunset: N/A

Diospyros virginiana (American persimmon), deciduous tree, slow growing and low branching to 35-60 feet tall and 25-35 feet wide, with oval to elliptic, glossy, dark green leaves that turn yellowish green or pinkish purple in fall. Fragrant, inconspicuous, white to greenish yellow flowers in late spring are followed by round to oval, yellow-orange to reddish purple fruit. Fruit drop can be messy. Native to the eastern and midwestern United States from southern Connecticut west to Kansas and south to Florida and Texas. Female trees of the species need a male tree to set fruit. 'Meader' sets seedless fruit without pollination. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 3-9,14-16,18-23

Dodecatheon species (shooting stars), perennials, low rosettes of linear to oval or broadly lance-shaped, bright green to grayish green leaves in early spring followed in late spring by tall, leafless stems topped with clusters of nodding, lavender, pink, or white flowers with protruding stamens and upward-pointing reflexed petals. Summer dormant. May spread slowly by offsets. Native to seasonally wet meadows and open woodlands in much of North America. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Need moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: zones vary

Dodonaea viscosa (hop bush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with long, narrow, green to purplish green leaves, inconspicuous flowers, and showy, long-lasting winged seedpods. Native to much of Australia, New Zealand, and parts of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. 'Purpurea' has bronzy green leaves that turn deep purple in cooler weather. Full sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-24

Dodonaea viscosa 'Purpurea' (purple hopseed bush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with long, narrow, bronzy green leaves that turn deep purple in cooler weather. Leaves can revert to green. Inconspicuous flowers are followed by showy, long-lasting, winged seed capsules. Species is native to a wide range of climates and soils in much of Australia, New Zealand, and parts of southwestern North America. This cultivar was originally found in New Zealand. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-24

Doryanthes palmeri (spear lily), perennial, 8-10 feet tall and wide, stemless rosette of long, flexible, broadly sword-shaped, green leaves and, at maturity, large, heavy clusters of upfacing, cup-shaped, bright red or red-orange flowers on an 8- to 12-foot, arching stalk. Flowers in spring and early summer are followed by egg-shaped fruit. Rosette dies after flowering and is replaced by offsets at the base. Native to the mountains of coastal eastern Australia. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast or where summer nights are cool. Sunset: N/A

Dorycnium hirsutum (hairy canary clover), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with softly hairy, gray-green leaves and small, white flowers from pink buds in summer to fall. Native to grasslands of the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Turkey. Sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. May be short-lived. Sunset: N/A

Dracaena draco (dragon tree), succulent, slow growing to 15-25 feet tall and wide, gradually forming a single, tall stem with multiple branches, each topped with a rosette of flexible, sword-shaped, 2- to 3-foot long, bluish gray-green leaves. Mature plants bear loose, branching clusters of greenish white flowers in summer followed by small, red-orange berries. Native to the Canary Islands, Madeira, and the west coast of Morocco. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Long lived. Sunset: N/A

Dracunculus vulgaris (voodoo lily), perennial from tuber, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with clusters of large, fan-shaped leaves divided into wavy-edged, dark green leaflets streaked with white at the top of tall stems. Inconspicuous flowers are hidden within the base of an upright, narrowly conical, dark purple spike surrounded by a large, purple, leaflike bract. Flowers appear in spring and are followed by small, green fruits that age to red-orange. Native to rocky slopes in Greece, the Balkans, western Turkey, and islands in the Aegean Sea. Sun to part shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Drepanostachyum falcatum (blue bamboo), clumping grass, 12-18 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with dense sprays of pendulous, narrowly lance-shaped, mid-green leaves on weeping branchlets and yellowish green stems (culms), blue when new and purplish red in sun. Blue color is retained at the base of the stems as plants age. Native to the Himalayas from eastern Nepal to Bhutan. Cool sun or light shade, most soils. May be offered as Himalayacalamus hookerianus. Sunset: N/A

Drepanostachyum hookerianum (bamboo), clumping grass, 15-20 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, mid-green leaves on long, slender branchlets and green stems (culms) striped with yellow and pink. Native to foothills of the Himalayas from northwestern India and Tibet to Bhutan. Cool sun to light shade, most soils. Best along the coast. May be offered as Himalayacalamus falconeri. Sunset: N/A

Drosanthemum species (ice plant), succulents, ground-hugging mats a few inches tall and spreading by rooting stems or subshrubs mounding 2-3 feet tall, with short, fleshy, cylindrical or linear, green or gray-green leaves and masses of iridescent, bright pink, purple, red, or yellow daisy flowers in late winter and spring. Flowers close in the evening and may remain closed on cloudy days. Mat-forming species (e.g., D. hispidum, D. floribundum) follow contours and drape over rocks and walls. Shrubby species (e.g., D. micans, D. speciosum, D. bicolor) tend to form dense mounds of erect stems. Native to rocky or sandy soils in summer-dry, winter-rainfall parts of South Africa. Best near the coast. Sun, good drainage. Sunset: 14-24

Dryopteris arguta (coastal wood fern), fern, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with erect, dark green, finely cut fronds. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Native to north-facing slopes and shady woodlands along the coast from southwestern British Columbia to southern California. Deciduous and dormant in summer if grown dry. Shade to part shade, humusy soils. Sunset: N/A

Dudleya species (dudleya), succulents with rosettes of silvery gray-green, gray-white, or green, spatulate or tubular leaves, often tinged with pink or red. Clusters of small, tubular or cup-shaped flowers on tall, upright to leaning, sometimes leafy stems in spring or summer. Some offset to form a small colony, others remain solitary. Native to rocky, fast-draining soils on coastal bluffs and coastal or inland hills from southwestern Oregon to northern Baja California. Dormant but not deciduous in late summer. Cool sun, afternoon shade inland, perfect drainage. Plant tilted to allow water to drain rapidly away. Best along the coast. Some may be offered as Echeveria. Sunset: zones vary by species

Dyckia species (dyckia), perennials, 3-24 inches tall and wide, rosettes of stiff, long, strap-shaped, green, red, tan, or silvery gray leaves usually but not always with sharp, spiny margins. Mature plants produce small, white, pink, orange, or red, tubular flowers on tall stems in spring. Most form offsets. Native to dry, gritty soils and rocky crevices in the mountains of Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Bolivia. Many species and hybrids in a wide variety of shapes, sizes, and colors. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage. Most prefer a dryish winter. Sunset: N/A

Dymondia margaretae (silver carpet), perennial, dense, tight mat 1-3 inches tall and slowly spreading to 2-3 feet wide, with small, narrow, dark gray-green leaves, silvery white beneath, and small, bright yellow, daisy flowers in summer. Native to coastal Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 15-24

Ebenopsis ebano (Texas ebony), evergreen tree, slow growing to 25-40 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk or low branching, with glossy, dark green leaves divided into small, oval to oblong leaflets on thorny branches and spikes of small, fragrant, creamy yellow flowers in early summer. Flowers are followed by large, persistent, dark brown seedpods. Native to dry woodlands and desert washes in coastal southern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun, most well-drained soils. May drop leaves briefly in spring if grown dry. May be offered as Pithecellobium flexicaule. Sunset: 12-13

Echeveria species (hen and chicks), succulents with rosettes of green to gray-green or bluish gray leaves and nodding, bell-shaped flowers on tall stems in spring or early summer. Some offset to form a small colony; others remain solitary. Native to rocky outcrops in semi-arid parts of Mexico, Central America, and northwestern South America, often at mid- to high elevations. Hundreds of cultivars. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, good air circulation, excellent drainage. Plant tilted to allow water to drain rapidly away. Best where summers and winters are mild. Sunset: zones vary by species

plants.botanicalName: Echinocactus spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Echinocactus species, barrel cactus, succulents, slow growing to 2-10 feet tall, bright green to bluish gray-green, spherical, short cylindrical, or barrel-shaped stem with well-defined ribs bearing rigid, sharp spines. Mature plants produce white, yellow, or pink, funnel-shaped flowers at the flat top of the stem in spring. Flowers are followed by woolly fruits. E. grusonii, from the mountains of eastern Mexico, has a bright green stem, spherical when young, slowly elongating into a 3- to 4-foot column with star-shaped clusters of golden yellow spines and yellow flowers. E. polycephalus, native to deserts from California and Nevada to Arizona and northern Mexico, slowly forms mounds of many spherical to short columnar stems completely covered in tight clusters of thick, curved spines; flowers are yellow and fruits are densely woolly. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 12-24

Echinopsis species, (torch cactus), succulents, variable, from round globes a few inches tall to 15- to 20-foot columns, with ribs often densely covered in spines and large, widely flaring, funnel-shaped, white, yellow, pink, or red flowers in spring. Some offset freely, gradually forming small or large colonies. Native to a wide range of habitats in the mountains of South America. Many species, selections, and hybrids, often of unknown or uncertain parentage. Sun, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, excellent drainage. Most prefer a dryish winter dormancy. Larger, columnar species and their cultivars may be offered as Trichocereus. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Echium candicans (pride of Madeira), evergreen shrub, 5-6 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with lance-shaped, hairy, gray-green leaves and showy, upright spikes of purplish blue flowers in spring. Native to rocky cliffs on the island of Madeira. Self-sows prolifically and can be weedy. Old leaves create a dense mulch that suppresses growth of plants beneath. Sun, most soils. Sunset: 14-24

Echium gentianoides 'Tajinaste' (Tajinaste tower of jewels), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with lightly hairy, bluish gray-green, linear leaves on upright stems and loose, terminal spikes of bright blue, tubular flowers from pink buds from spring to fall. Self sows. Native to volcanic soils on the island of La Palma, Canary Islands. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as E. thyrsiflorum. Sunset: N/A

Echium pininana (pride of Tenerife), biennial or short-lived perennial, rosette of long, lance-shaped, lightly hairy, silvery gray-green leaves in the first year and an upright spike of small, funnel-shaped, blue or white flowers atop a 10- to 15-foot leafy stem in the summer of the second year. Dies after flowering but self sows readily. Native to rocky soils on the island of La Palma, Canary Islands. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-17,22-24

Elaeagnus angustifolia (Russian olive), deciduous tree, fast growing to 12-20 feet tall and wide, with exfoliating, dark brown bark and narrowly lance-shaped to elliptic, dark green leaves, silvery gray beneath, on sometimes thorny branches. Small, fragrant, greenish yellow flowers in late spring are followed by small, oval, green fruits. Spreads by seed and by suckering roots and considered invasive in many parts of western North America, especially in riparian areas. Native to a wide range of habitats in temperate climates from central Europe to Asia. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-3,7-14,18-19,A2-3

Elaeagnus pungens (silverberry), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with dark olive green, leathery, wavy-edged leaves with rusty brown dots on upright, spiny branches. Clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in fall are followed by small, red-brown fruit. Native to coastal areas of China and Japan. 'Fruitlandii' has silvery new leaves. May spread by suckering or by seed. Sun or shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Elaeagnus x ebbingei (Ebbing's silverberry), evergreen shrub, 8-12 feet tall and wide, with leathery, dark green leaves with tiny silver spots and clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in fall. Hybrid of garden origin between E. macrophylla, native to coastal areas of Korea and Japan, and E. pungens, native to coastal China and Japan. 'Gilt Edge' has dark green leaves with golden yellow margins. May be offered as E. x submacrophylla. Sun or shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

plants.botanicalName: Eleocharis spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Elymus cinereus (Basin wild rye), cool-season bunchgrass, 3-6 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, coarse-textured, with broad, stiffly erect, green or blue-green leaves and flowers on tall stems above the leaves in summer. Native to dry, moist, or seasonally moist grasslands and woodland openings from British Columbia south to California, Arizona, and New Mexico and east to South Dakota. May spread by rhizomes. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as Leymus. Sunset: N/A

Elymus condensatus (giant wild rye), cool-season bunchgrass, 3-6 feet tall and widely spreading, with bluish green leaves and tan flowers on stems well above the foliage in summer. Native to coastal southern California and Baja California. 'Canyon Prince', a selection from the Channel Islands, is 2-3 feet tall with powdery blue-gray leaves. Cut to the ground in late winter to maintain upright form; new leaves are green and mature quickly to blue-gray. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as Leymus. Sunset: 7-12,14-24

Elymus triticoides (creeping wild rye), cool-season grass, sod forming, 1-3 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes, with narrow, green to bluish green leaves and narrow spikes of flowers on tall stems in late spring or summer. Native to dry or moist, often saline soils from southern British Columbia to northern Baja California and east to western Texas. Sun to part shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. May be offered as Leymus. Sunset: N/A

Encelia californica (coast sunflower), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with medium green, oval to broadly lance-shaped leaves and bright yellow, daisylike flowers from late winter to early summer. Self-sows freely. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to sunny slopes along the immediate coast and on the coastal side of inland foothills in southern California and northwestern Baja California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Cut back in late summer to renew. Sunset: 7-16,18-24

Encelia farinosa (brittlebush), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with oval to lance-shaped, silvery greenish gray, woolly leaves and yellow daisy flowers with darker centers in spring. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. Drops leaves in late summer if grown dry. Reseeds and may become invasive. Sun, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Cut back in late summer to renew. Sunset: 8-16,18-24

Encephalartos species, bread cycad, succulents, slow growing to 6-25 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, variable, with upright or arching, dark green, blue-green, or blue-gray, sometimes twisted, palmlike leaves and long, woody cones resembling those of a conifer. Leaves are divided into many pairs of rigid, lance-shaped, linear, or needlelike leaflets with spiny or smooth margins. Most gradually form a short or tall, sometimes mostly underground, water-storing stem or trunk. Some offset to form a small grouping or colony. Species are native to varied habitats, humid or dry, sunny or partly shady, in southern, eastern, and central Africa. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Engelmannia pinnatifida (Englemann daisy), perennial, 1-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with a basal rosette of deeply lobed, coarsely hairy, mid-green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers from mid-spring to fall. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in open areas from South Dakota south through Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas to northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Self-sows and can be weedy. May be offered as E. peristenia. Sunset: N/A

Epilobium species (Zauschneria) and cultivars (California fuchsia), perennials, a few inches tall to upright and spreading, with silvery gray, gray-green, or green leaves and bright red-orange, tubular flowers in mid- to late summer and fall. Species are native to coastal cliffs and dry, rocky slopes in western and southwestern North America, especially California. Plants spread by rhizomes and by seed. Sun near the coast, afternoon shade inland, most well-drained soils. Once plants are well established, cut back before new growth appears in spring. May be offered as Zauschneria. Sunset: 2-11,14-24

Eragrostis chloromelas (blue love grass), warm-season grass, clump-forming, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with narrow, fine-textured, blue-green leaves and an airy mass of golden brown flowers on 3- to 4-foot stems in mid- to late spring or early summer. Self-sows readily and spreads slowly by rhizomes. Native to grasslands and rocky outcrops in eastern and southern Africa and widely naturalized in the southwestern United States. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as E. curvula. Sunset: 4-24

Eragrostis spectabilis (purple love grass), warm-season bunchgrass, to 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with coarse, blue-green leaves that age to bronzy red and reddish purple flowers on 2-foot stems in summer. Self-sows. Native to North America from Maine to Florida, west to North Dakota, and south to Arizona, Texas, and Mexico. Sun, well-drained, sandy or gravelly soils. Sunset: 1-24

Eremophila glabra (emu bush), evergreen shrub, variable, from prostrate and 6-8 feet wide to upright and 6-8 feet tall, with linear, lance-shaped, or oval, green or gray-green, sometimes hairy leaves and tubular, red, yellow, orange, or yellowish green flowers from early spring through summer. Native to dry areas of central and southern Australia. 'Kalgoorlie' is 2-3 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide with gray-green leaves and orange flowers. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,13-24

Eremophila maculata (spotted emu bush), evergreen shrub, variable, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with lance-shaped to linear, oval, or almost threadlike, green or gray-green leaves and tubular, red, orange, pink, or yellow flowers in mid-winter to early spring. Native to dry, mostly inland parts of mainland Australia, often in periodically flooded areas. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils, good air circulation. Cut back after flowering to renew. Sunset: 8-9,13-24

Eremophila racemosa (Easter egg bush), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, bright green leaves on stiffly upright branches. Tubular, yellow flowers from orange buds mature to purplish pink, giving a multicolored effect from late winter to early summer. Native to an inland area of dry hills and plains in southwestern Western Australia. Sun, well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-9,13-24

Ericameria arborescens (golden fleece), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-10 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with fine-textured, needlelike to narrowly linear, bright green leaves on upright branches and clusters of bright yellow daisy flowers in summer and early fall. Self-sows. Native to open woodlands and shrublands in mountains and foothills of southwestern Oregon and northern California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Ericameria ericoides (California goldenbush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with fanlike clusters of tiny, cylindrical, pale green leaves. Small, yellow daisy flowers in late summer and fall are followed by feathery seedheads. Native to sand dunes and coastal hillsides from the northern San Francisco Bay Area to Los Angeles. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Haplopappus. Sunset: N/A

Ericameria laricifolia (turpentine bush), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with small, aromatic, needlelike, mid-green leaves and small clusters of yellow daisy flowers in fall followed by tan seedheads. Native to high-desert mountains and canyons from southeastern California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Erigeron 'Wayne Roderick' (Wayne Roderick daisy), perennial, 1 foot tall and 2 feet wide, with spoon-shaped, green to blue-green leaves and large, lavender daisy flowers with yellow centers in summer. Believed to be a hybrid involving  E. glaucus. Good performance coastal and inland. May be offered as E. 'W.R.' Sunset: 4-6,15-17,22-24

Erigeron glaucus (beach aster), perennial, to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with spoon-shaped, green to blue-green leaves and lavender to nearly white daisy flowers with yellow centers  from spring to summer or almost year round. Native to coastal bluffs and dunes from Oregon to southern California. 'Bountiful', a selection from southern California, has especially large flowers. 'Cape Sebastian', a selection from the southern Oregon coast, is especially dense and compact. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cool sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: 4-6,15-17,22-24

Erigeron karvinskianus (seaside daisy), perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 3-5 feet wide, with small, lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and small, white daisy flowers with yellow centers almost year round. Native to much of Mexico and parts of Central and South America. Self-sows and spreads by rhizomes, sometimes aggressively. Cascades over walls. Cool sun, most well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

photos.filename: Erigeron x moerheimii (pink Santa Barbara daisy)
photos.caption: Erigeron x moerheimii (pink Santa Barbara daisy)

plants.culturalInformation: Erigeron x moerheimii (pink Santa Barbara daisy), 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, narrow, green leaves and pale pinkish lavender flowers with yellow centers from spring to fall. Garden hybrid of uncertain origin, possibly involving  E. karvinskianus. Similar to E. karvinskianus but does not reseed. May be offered as E. karvinskianus 'Moerheimii'. Sunset: N/A

Eriobotrya japonica (loquat), evergreen tree or large shrub, 15-25 feet tall and wide, with large, leathery, elliptic to broadly lance-shaped, deeply veined, glossy, dark green leaves and clusters of fragrant, white flowers in fall or early winter followed by oval to rounded, orange or yellow fruit. Native from low to mid-elevations in subtropical southeastern China. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast or in other mild climates. Sunset: 6-24

Eriogonum arborescens (Santa Cruz Island buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with narrow, woolly, pale green to gray-green leaves and flat-topped clusters of tiny, creamy white to pale pink flowers in late spring through summer. Flowers age to a reddish brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Native to sandy or rocky soils on the Channel Islands in southern California. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 5,7-9,14-24

Eriogonum cinereum (ashyleaf buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with woolly, silvery gray-green leaves and rounded clusters of tiny, pinkish white flowers from late spring through summer. Flowers age to a rusty brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Native to exposed bluffs and coastal foothills from Monterey County to Los Angeles. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Best along the coast. Sunset: 5,14-17,19-24

Eriogonum crocatum (saffron buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with woolly, silvery gray-white leaves and stems and flat-topped clusters of tiny, saffron yellow flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to reddish brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the northwestern Santa Monica Mountains in Ventura County. Cool sun to light shade, good drainage. Best along the coast in southern California. Sunset: 14-24

Eriogonum fasciculatum 'Bruce Dickinson' (Bruce Dickinson buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, narrowly linear, leathery, green leaves and dense clusters of tiny, creamy white to pink flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving the plant a multicolored effect in late summer and fall. Species is native to dry slopes and washes in coastal central and southern California, the southern Sierra Nevada, and southern California desert foothills east to Arizona and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Eriogonum fasciculatum 'Theodore Payne' (Theodore Payne buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, narrow, dark green leaves with reddish tints and clusters of pink-tinted, creamy white flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Eriogonum fasciculatum 'Warriner Lytle' (Warriner Lytle buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, narrow, dark green leaves, silvery gray beneath, and tight clusters of pink-tinted creamy white flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Sun, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Eriogonum fasciculatum and cultivars (California buckwheat), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, leathery, green or gray leaves and rounded clusters of tiny, pink and creamy white flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Self sows. Native to coastal central California, the southern Sierra Nevada, and southern California desert foothills east to Utah, Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. 'Bruce Dickinson', 'Warriner Lytle', and 'Theodore Payne' are low, widely spreading selections. Sun, good drainage. Adaptable. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Eriogonum giganteum (St. Catherine's lace), evergreen shrub, variable, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with branches sparsely covered in woolly, oval, silvery gray-green leaves and flat-topped clusters of white or pinkish white flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving the plant a multicolored effect in late summer and fall. Native to the Channel Islands off the coast of southern California. Adaptable inland as well as seaside. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 5,7-9,14-24

photos.filename: Eriogonum grande var. rubescens (San Miguel Island buckwheat)
photos.caption: Eriogonum grande var. rubescens (San Miguel Island buckwheat)

photos.filename: Eriogonum grande var. rubescens (San Miguel Island buckwheat)
photos.caption: Eriogonum grande var. rubescens (San Miguel Island buckwheat)

plants.culturalInformation: Eriogonum grande var. rubescens (San Miguel Island buckwheat), evergreen shrub, to 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, spoon-shaped, gray-green leaves, grayish white beneath, and spherical clusters of reddish pink flowers on leafless, 2-foot stems from spring to fall. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Native to dry, rocky cliffs on the northern Channel Islands. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5,14-24

Eriogonum latifolium (coast buckwheat), perennial, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 2 feet wide, with spoon-shaped, silvery white leaves and small, round clusters of pink and white flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving the plant a multicolored effect in late summer and fall. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains from Washington to northern California. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Best along the coast. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Eriogonum spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Eriogonum species, buckwheat, evergreen shrubs and shrubby perennials with green to gray-green or silvery gray leaves and domed or flat-topped clusters of tiny flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to various shades of rusty red or brown, giving plants a multicolored effect in late summer and fall. E. umbellatum, 1-3 feet tall and wide with woolly, gray-green leaves and yellow flowers, is native to mountains from southern British Columbia to southern California and east to Colorado, Arizona, and New Mexico. E. latifolium, 1 foot tall and 2 feet wide with bluish white, felted leaves and creamy white flowers, is native to coastal dunes from Oregon to central California. E. giganteum, 4-6 feet tall and wide with silvery gray-green, woolly leaves and pinkish white flowers, is native to the Channel Islands. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Eriogonum umbellatum and cultivars (sulfur buckwheat), evergreen shrub, from a few inches to 3 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with small, green to gray-green leaves and rounded clusters of bright yellow to creamy white flowers in spring and summer. Flowers age to rusty brown, giving a multi-colored effect in late summer and fall. Native to dry, open, usually rocky mountain slopes from southwestern British Columbia to southern California and east to Colorado and New Mexico. 'Shasta Sulfur', a selection from Mt. Shasta in northern California, is 1 foot tall and 2 feet wide, with sage green leaves edged with pale gray. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, fast drainage. Sunset: 1-24

Eriophyllum confertiflorum (golden yarrow), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, variable, with small, lobed or divided, fine-textured, pale green to gray-green leaves, white-woolly beneath, and tight clusters of golden yellow flowers in early summer. Native to dry sites along the coast from the San Francisco Bay Area to Baja California and in the southern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: N/A

Eriophyllum lanatum and cultivars (woolly sunflower), perennial, variable, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with silvery gray-green, woolly, linear or lobed leaves and golden yellow flowers on tall, upright stems in spring and summer. Native to coastal bluffs and inland forest openings from British Columbia to central California and east to western Wyoming. Self-sows readily. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot locations, good to excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: N/A

Erodium chrysanthum (cranesbill), perennial, 6-8 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with finely divided, silvery gray-green leaves and fragrant, pale yellow to creamy white flowers with silvery veins in late spring or early summer and often again in fall. Native to rocky, open sites in the mountains of Greece and Albania.  Many hybrid cultivars of complicated parentage. Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Best in cool, coastal climates. Sunset: N/A

Erodium reichardii (alpine geranium), perennial, 2-6 inches tall and 1 foot wide, with dark green to silvery green, slightly scalloped leaves and clusters of small, white flowers with purplish pink veins in spring and early summer. Native to the Balearic Islands in the western Mediterranean region. Cultivars with pink flowers are available. Good rock garden plant. Cool sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best in cool, coastal climates. May be offered as E. chamaedryoides. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Eryngium maritimum (sea holly), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with a rosette of stiff, waxy, bluish gray-white, spiny leaves and upright, leafy, branched stems bearing showy, thistlelike clusters of small, purplish blue summer flowers surrounded by sharply spiny bracts. Native to sandy soils and dunes along the coasts of the Atlantic Ocean and the Baltic, Mediterranean, and Black seas. Sun, good to excellent drainage. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Eryngium pandanifolium (giant sea holly), perennial, rosette, 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, of narrowly sword-shaped, arching, bluish gray-green leaves with spiny margins. In mid-summer and early fall 5- to 8-foot, branching stems bear small, rounded to conical clusters of tiny, greenish white flowers that mature to reddish purple or purplish gray and age to dark brown. Offsets to form large clumps. Native to streambanks and seasonally damp grasslands from southern Brazil and Paraguay to Uruguay and Argentina. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Eryngium planum (blue sea holly), perennial, rosette, 1-2 feet tall and wide, of rounded to oval, deeply lobed, spiny, dark green leaves and stiffly upright, branching, 2- to 3-foot stems bearing conical clusters of tiny, blue-violet flowers surrounded by spiny, silvery blue-green bracts in summer. Spreads slowly by seed and by offsets. Native to sandy or gravelly soils from central and southeastern Europe to southwestern Asia. Sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 2-24

Erysimum 'Bowles' Mauve' (Bowles' Mauve wallflower), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped to linear, dark bluish gray-green leaves and tall spikes of small flowers in varying shades of purple from late spring to fall. Cultivar of garden origin, believed to be a hybrid involving E. linifolium, a purple-flowered plant native to northern Portugal and northwestern Spain. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best near the coast. May be short lived. May be offered as Cheiranthus. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Erysimum concinnum (wallflower), perennial, to 1 foot tall and 18 inches wide, with dark green, narrowly lance-shaped leaves and creamy white to pale yellow flowers in spring. Native to coastal bluffs and sand dunes from central California to southwestern Oregon. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best along the coast. May be offered as a subspecies of E. menziesii. Sunset: N/A

Erysimum linifolium (wallflower), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and purple flowers in spring. Native to northwestern Spain and northern Portugal. 'Bowles' Mauve', a hybrid of uncertain parentage, is more upright and taller. 'Variegatum' has gray-green leaves with creamy white margins. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. May be short lived. Sunset: 4-6,14-24

Erysimum menziesii (Menzies wallflower), biennial or short-lived perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 1 foot wide, with gray-green, linear leaves and clusters of small, bright yellow, lightly fragrant flowers in spring. Native to sand dunes along the northern and central California coast. Subspecies concinnum, Pt. Reyes wallflower, has creamy white to pale yellow flowers and is native to coastal bluffs from central California to southwestern Oregon. May be offered as E. concinnum. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Erythrina caffra (Kaffir bloom coral tree), deciduous tree, fast growing to 20-40 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with leaves divided into three light green, broadly oval to triangular leaflets on usually spiny branches. Showy clusters of red-orange or sometimes creamy white flowers appear before the leaves in mid-winter and are followed by beanlike seedpods. Self-sows freely. Native to coastal forests and moist riverbanks in Eastern Cape Province and KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Sun or part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 21-24

Erythrina crista-galli (cockspur coral tree), deciduous or semi-evergreen tree, fast growing to 15-20 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into three, dark green, oval to broadly elliptic leaflets on spiny branches. Loose, showy clusters of large, pink to bright red flowers in spring and summer are followed by long, bean-like seedpods. Native from Bolivia and southern Brazil to northern Argentina and Uruguay. Self-sows and spreads by stem segments; can be weedy or invasive in moist soils. Sun, most soils, including periodically flooded. Sunset: 7-9,12-17,19-24

Erythrina falcata (evergreen coral tree), semi-evergreen tree, 25-40 feet tall and wide, low branching, with mid- to dark green leaves divided into three broadly oval leaflets on spiny branches. Dark red to red-orange, sickle-shaped flowers from early spring into early summer are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native from Bolivia and southern Brazil to northern Argentina and Uruguay. Sun to part shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. Sunset:19-24

Erythrina humeana (Natal coral tree), deciduous shrub or small tree, 12-20 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves divided into three roughly triangular leaflets with prickles on the undersides and small, curved thorns at the base of the leaf stalk. Upright spikes of bright red, elongated pea flowers in late summer and fall are followed by large, dark brown, beanlike pods containing bright orange seeds. Native to grasslands, rocky outcrops, and forest margins in southern Mozambique and eastern South Africa. Sun to part shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 12-13,20-24

Erythrina x bidwillii (Bidwill's coral bean), deciduous or semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 6-15 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into three broadly oval to triangular, mid-green leaflets on spiny branches and upright or arching stems bearing 1- to 2-foot spikes of bright red pea flowers in spring or summer. Seedless hybrid between the South American E. crista-galli and E. herbacea, native to coastal southeastern North America. 'Camdeni' tends to grow as a small tree, while 'Blakei' is a low-growing shrub. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Erythrina x sykesii (Sykes coral tree), semi-deciduous or evergreen tree, 20-30 feet tall and 25-35 feet wide, low branching, with a spiny trunk and branches, dark green leaves divided into three roughly triangular leaflets, and short, tight clusters of bright red pea flowers from fall through spring. Garden hybrid of uncertain parentage believed to involve E. lysistemon, native to eastern South Africa, or E. speciosa, native to Mexico. Sets no viable seed but suckers and spreads vegetatively by rooting stem segments. Considered an environmental weed in parts of coastal eastern and southern Australia. Sun, most soils, including poorly drained. Sunset: 19-24

Eschscholzia californica (California poppy), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with finely dissected, blue-green leaves and golden yellow to orange flowers in late winter to summer. Self-sows freely. Native to grassy, open areas from southern Washington to Baja California and east to New Mexico. Cultivars, available with white, red, or pink flowers, may not persist or reseed. Full sun, most soils. Sunset: 1-24

Eucalyptus 'Moon Lagoon' (fine-leaf mallee), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, olive green adult leaves and rounded, silvery gray-green juvenile leaves. Small clusters of white flowers in spring and summer are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Parentage uncertain, possibly a naturally occurring hybrid. May be offered as E. latens, a species native to southeastern Western Australia. Full sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Eucalyptus camaldulensis (red gum), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 65-90 feet tall and 40-65 feet wide, with creamy white, exfoliating bark, aromatic, lance-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves similar. Clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens from late spring to mid-summer are followed by small, woody, brown seed capsules. Native to both summer- and winter-rainfall climates over much of Australia, usually along streambanks or on sites with seasonal flooding. May spread invasively, especially in riparian habitats. Shedding of bark and dropping of seed capsules can be messy. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.commonName: ash leaved gum, silver dollar tree
plants.culturalInformation: Eucalyptus cinerea (silver dollar gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-50 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with fibrous and furrowed, reddish brown bark and aromatic, broadly lance-shaped, dark gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves oval to nearly round, silvery gray-green, and in pairs on white stems. Small clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens in late winter or early spring are followed by small, brown seed capsules covered in the same white, waxy powder as juvenile leaves and stems. Native to dry, rocky slopes in southeastern Australia. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus cladocalyx (sugar gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 40-90 feet tall and 45-75 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves, paler beneath, juvenile leaves oval to elliptic, and yellowish, shedding bark. Creamy white flowers in summer or fall are followed by barrel-shaped, woody seed capsules. Native to semi-arid, winter-rainfall coastal southeastern South Australia. Self-sows. Considered a high risk for invasiveness in central and southern coastal California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus conferruminata (bushy yate), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk or low branching, fast growing to 15-30 feet tall and wide, with creamy white to pale gray, exfoliating bark and aromatic, oval to elliptic, mid-green leaves. Large, pendulous clusters of flowers with prominent, greenish yellow stamens in spring and summer are followed by tightly clustered, woody seed capsules. Native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as E. lehmannii, which is a similar but different plant. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus erythrocorys (red cap gum), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 10-25 feet tall and wide, with smooth, creamy white to grayish brown bark, aromatic, lance-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves, juvenile leaves oval to broadly lance-shaped. Large, nearly square flowers with prominent, brushlike clusters of bright yellow to yellowish green stamens from late summer to fall are followed by heavy, brown, cup-shaped seed capsules. Native to coastal west-central Western Australia. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus erythronema (red-flowered mallee), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk or low branching, fast growing to 12-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with smooth, powdery, grayish white bark with patches of reddish brown, tan, and green and aromatic, dark green, narrowly lance-shaped leaves, juvenile leaves oval and gray-green. Showy clusters of flowers with prominent, pinkish red, or sometimes pale yellow stamens in summer are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to inland southwestern Western Australia. Best in hot-summer climates. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus globulus (blue gum), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 50-150 feet tall and 30-80 feet wide, with creamy white, gray, greenish, and brown bark, shedding in long strips, and pendulous, aromatic, lance-shaped, dark green leaves, juvenile leaves oval and bluish gray-green. Flowers with prominent, brushlike clusters of white stamens in winter or early spring are followed by rounded, greenish gray seed capsules. Native to southeastern Australia from Tasmania north to New South Wales. Negative impacts on fire regime, groundwater, and native plant communities are widely recognized in California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus gunnii (cider gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 30-60 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with long, narrow, aromatic, dark gray-green adult leaves, rounded, blue-green juvenile leaves, and smooth, peeling, creamy white and pinkish brown bark. Small clusters of white spring or summer flowers are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to Tasmania.  Full sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Eucalyptus kruseana (bookleaf mallee), evergreen shrub or shrubby tree, 8-12 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with rough, gray bark that splits and shreds to reveal coppery brown inner bark. Small, aromatic, rounded to oval, silvery blue-green leaves are closely stacked in pairs on branchlets that seem to head off in all directions. Flowers with brushlike clusters of greenish yellow stamens in winter or early spring are followed by small, bluish green seed capsules. Native to sandy or rocky soils in inland southeastern Western Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus leucoxylon (white ironbark), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 30-75 feet tall and 20-50 feet wide, often multitrunk or low branching, with smooth, bright white bark, grayish brown and shedding on lower trunk, and aromatic, lance-shaped, green to gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves oval and bluish green. Small clusters of flowers with prominent, red, white, or pink stamens in winter to early spring are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to southeastern South Australia and southwestern Victoria, inland or along the coast. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus loxophleba (York gum), evergreen tree or large shrub, fast growing to 15-50 feet tall and wide, often multitrunk or low branching, with smooth, shiny, coppery brown bark, rough gray-brown and shedding on lower trunk, and aromatic, lance-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves, juvenile leaves triangular to oval and bluish gray-green. Small clusters of flowers with prominent, bright white stamens appear sporadically almost year round and are followed by persistent, woody, brown seed capsules. Native to southwestern Western Australia, mostly inland from the coast and often in saline soils. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus macrandra (long-flowered marlock), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with smooth, gray and brown bark, sometimes dark gray and shedding on the lower trunk, and aromatic, lance-shaped, glossy, bright green to olive green leaves, juvenile leaves oval and green. Large clusters of showy flowers with prominent, greenish yellow stamens in summer are followed by woody, greenish brown seed capsules. Native to southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus microtheca (coolibah), evergreen tree or large shrub, variable, fast growing to 15-50 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with rough, fibrous, light to dark gray bark and aromatic, lance-shaped, pendulous, green to gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves narrowly lance-shaped and bluish green. Clusters of small flowers with prominent, creamy white stamens in spring or summer are followed by small, woody, brown seed capsules. Native to streambanks and seasonally flooded places across much of inland northern Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus neglecta (omeo gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 30-50 feet tall and 25-40 feet wide, with aromatic, rounded, blue-green leaves that may lengthen over time but often persist into maturity and peeling, brown bark. Inconspicuous, white, summer flowers are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to mountains of southeastern Australia, sometimes at high elevations. One of the most cold-hardy eucalypts. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Eucalyptus nicholii (willowleaf peppermint), evergreen tree, 35-50 feet tall and 15-35 feet wide, with aromatic,  especially narrow, lance-shaped, light green leaves on pendulous branches and thick, roughly furrowed, reddish brown bark that does not peel. Inconspicuous white summer flowers are followed by woody seed capsules. Native to grasslands and woodlands in the mountains of southeastern Australia. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Eucalyptus parvula (small-leaved gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-30 feet tall and wide, low branching, with smooth, gray bark, peeling in thin strips, and small, narrowly lance-shaped, aromatic, bluish gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves more oval and many persistent into maturity. Small clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens in late summer to fall are followed by cup-shaped, woody seed capsules. Native to mountains of southeastern New South Wales, Australia, usually on poorly drained or seasonally flooded sites. Sun, most soils. May be offered as E. parvifolia. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus polyanthemos (silver dollar gum), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 30-60 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with fibrous, brown bark on lower trunk, smooth, creamy white and gray bark above, and aromatic, pendulous, narrowly oval, gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves broadly oval, bluish gray, and many persistent into maturity. Clusters of flowers with prominent, creamy white stamens in late winter or spring are followed by reddish brown, bowl-shaped seed capsules. Native to inland New South Wales in southeastern Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus preissiana (bell mallee), evergreen shrub or shrubby tree, usually multi-trunk, fast growing to 6-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with smooth, mottled, gray and brown bark and aromatic, broadly oval to rounded, purplish-tinged, gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves similar. Showy flowers with prominent, bright yellow stamens in winter and spring are followed by persistent, reddish, bell-shaped seed capsules. Native to sandy or gravelly soils along the coast of southwestern Western Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus pulverulenta (silver mountain gum), evergreen tree or large shrub, fast growing to 15-30 feet tall and 6-15 feet wide, with smooth, gray bark, often with patches of coppery brown, and aromatic, lance-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves, juvenile leaves oval to round or almost heart-shaped, silvery blue-gray, and stacked in pairs on bluish white, nearly horizontal branchlets. Many juvenile leaves persist into maturity. Small clusters of flowers with prominent, creamy white stamens in winter or spring are followed by cup-shaped, woody seed capsules covered with the same white powder as the juvenile leaves. Native to the mountains of New South Wales in southeastern Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus robusta (swamp mahogany), evergreen tree, fast growing to 60-90 feet tall and wide, with spongy, deeply fissured, reddish gray-brown, persistent bark and aromatic, broadly lance-shaped, leathery, dark green leaves, pale green beneath, juvenile leaves similar but more oval. Clusters of flowers with prominent, creamy white stamens in winter and spring are followed by woody, cup-shaped seed capsules. Native to swampy or seasonally flooded sites along the coast from southeastern Queensland to southern New South Wales, Australia. Sun to part shade, most soils, including both poorly drained and fast-draining. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus rudis (flooded gum), evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-60 feet tall and 25-40 feet wide, with rough, fibrous, gray bark on trunk and larger branches, smooth and pale gray above, and aromatic, lance-shaped, green leaves on somewhat pendulous branches, juvenile leaves oval to rounded and gray-green. Clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens in winter or early spring are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to streambanks and seasonally flooded sites along the coast and in mountains of southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, most soils. Accepts periodic flooding. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus saligna (Sydney blue gum), evergreen tree, 50-150 feet tall and 30-70 feet wide, high-branching, with lance-shaped to sickle-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves, paler beneath, juvenile leaves oval or oblong to lance-shaped.
