Clusters of creamy white flowers in spring are followed by bell-shaped, woody seed capsules. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains of summer-rainfall New South Wales and southeastern Queensland, Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Can be weedy. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus salubris (gimlet), evergreen tree or large shrub, variable, 12-25 feet tall and wide, often multitrunk or low branching, with a grooved and twisted trunk, smooth, shiny, coppery brown and green bark and aromatic, narrowly lance-shaped, glossy, green leaves, juvenile leaves similar. Clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens in summer and fall are followed by woody, reddish brown seed capsules. Native to drier, mostly inland areas of southwestern Western Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus sargentii (Salt River mallee), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 15-35 feet tall and 12-20 feet wide, with rough, fissured, dark gray bark on lower trunk, smooth, coppery brown and green above, and aromatic, narrowly lance-shaped, somewhat glossy, olive green to green leaves, juvenile leaves similar but matte grayish green. Clusters of flowers with prominent, creamy white to pale yellow stamens in spring are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to salt lakes and salt creeks inland in southwestern Western Australia. Sun, most soils. Accepts saline water and soils. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus sideroxylon (red ironbark), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 30-60 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, narrow and sometimes weeping, with rough, deeply furrowed, dark brown, almost black, persistent bark and aromatic, lance-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves on pendulous branches, juvenile leaves variable and more blue. Showy clusters of flowers with prominent, pink or dark red stamens in winter or early spring are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to west-facing slopes in mountains of New South Wales and southeastern Queensland, Australia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 8-24

Eucalyptus spathulata (swamp mallee), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, multitrunk or low branching, with smooth, shiny, reddish brown, persistent bark, aromatic, linear, glossy, olive green leaves, juvenile leaves similar but smaller and sometimes tinged red. Clusters of flowers with prominent, creamy white to pale yellow stamens in spring or summer are followed by small, woody seed capsules. Native to southwestern Western Australia, inland from the coast and usually on saline sites. Sun to part shade, most soils, including poorly drained and saline. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus stellulata (black sallee), evergreen tree or large shrub, 20-40 feet tall and wide, with rough, dark gray bark on lower trunk, smooth, mottled, and multicolored above, and broadly lance-shaped, glossy, green leaves, juvenile leaves broadly oval to heart-shaped and matte blue-green. Star-shaped clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens in winter are followed by small, woody, brown seed capsules. Native to mountain valleys of southeastern Australia, usually along streams or in poorly drained sites. Sun to part shade, most soils, including poorly drained. Accepts periodic flooding. Sunset: N/A

Eucalyptus torquata (coral gum), evergreen tree, 20-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with long, narrow, pale olive green, lance-shaped leaves, juvenile leaves elliptical, and rough, gray-brown bark that does not peel. Showy pink flowers in spring and summer are followed by woody seed capsules. Native to rocky slopes of coastal Western Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-24

Eucalyptus viminalis (manna gum), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 30-90 feet tall and 25-50 feet wide, with rough, fibrous, dark gray or brown bark on lower trunk, shedding in long strips, smooth, creamy white or pale gray above, and aromatic, narrowly lance-shaped to linear, somewhat glossy, green leaves, juvenile leaves similar but smaller and in opposite pairs. Clusters of flowers with prominent, white stamens in summer are followed by woody, brown seed capsules. Native to southeastern Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Euonymus japonicus (evergreen euonymus), evergreen shrub, 8-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with oval, glossy, dark green, leathery leaves with finely serrated margins and small, inconspicuous, greenish white flowers in late spring or early summer followed by small, red, berrylike fruit. Native to China, Japan, and Korea. Many cultivars, some with variegated leaves. Sun or shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, most soils. Adaptable. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 4-20

Euphorbia antisyphilitica (candelilla), succulent, 1-3 feet tall and wide, dense clump of upright, narrowly cylindrical, unbranched, waxy, gray-green stems bearing small, waxy leaves on new growth only. Tiny, inconspicuous flowers surrounded by red nectar glands with white, bractlike appendages resembling petals appear mostly in late winter or spring but may occur almost year round with sufficient moisture. Native to dry, rocky or sandy soils in desert mountains of eastern Mexico and adjacent parts of southern New Mexico and southwesternTexas. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-13,18-21

Euphorbia caput-medusae (Medusa's head), succulent, less than 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with knobby, 2- to 3-foot, cylindrical stems with small, deciduous leaves at the tips and tiny, inconspicuous flowers surrounded by green nectar glands with frilly, white tips that resemble petals in spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky slopes in coastal Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, well-drained soils. Cut back lightly every few years to renew. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia ceratocarpa (horned spurge), perennial or subshrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with upright stems bearing narrow, medium green to bluish green, linear to lance-shaped leaves and tiny, inconspicuous flowers surrounded by showy, chartreuse bracts that resemble petals from spring to fall or almost year round in mild climates. Native to Sicily. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Can be cut back regularly to encourage new flowering stems. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia characias (Mediterranean spurge), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with long, narrow, blue-green leaves on upright stems and tiny, inconspicuous flowers surrounded by showy, chartreuse bracts in spring. Native from Portugal and Spain to Turkey. Subspecies wulfenii has especially large flowerheads and bracts. White sap may be irritating to skin and eyes. Self-sows prolifically and may become invasive. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Euphorbia cyparissias (cypress spurge), perennial, to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with short, linear, bright green leaves on upright stems and tiny, inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers surrounded by showy, chartreuse bracts that resemble petals in spring and early summer. Self-sows, spreads by rhizomes and horizontal, branching roots, and can form large colonies. Native from western, central, and southern Europe to central Asia. Invasive in northeastern North America. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia ferox (pincushion euphorbia), succulent, 6-12 inches tall, upright, columnar, ribbed, green stem bearing thick, sharp, rigid, reddish purple spines and tight clusters of tiny, inconspicuous, yellow flowers surrounded by dark red bracts that resemble petals in spring and summer. Branches at the base to form a small cluster to 2 feet wide. Native to the semi-arid Great Karoo, South Africa. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia ingens (candelabra tree), succulent, 15-25 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, gradually developing a short, thick trunk and multiple upright, ribbed, spiny, green stems. Leaves are small and ephemeral and fall and winter flowers are tiny, inconspicuous, and surrounded by small, greenish yellow bracts that resemble petals. Native to rocky outcrops or deep sand from Angola and Zambia to northeastern South Africa. Prefers a dryish winter. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia lambii (tree euphorbia), evergreen shrub to small tree, 6-10 feet tall and wide, with a thick trunk and upright branches, bare for much of their length and each topped by a rounded cluster of linear, bluish green or yellowish green leaves. Loose clusters of cupped, yellowish green bracts surrounding tiny, inconspicuous, green flowers are held above the leaves in spring. Native to forest edges on the island of La Gomera, Canary Islands. Sun to shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia leucodendron (cat tails euphorbia), succulent, 4-10 feet tall and wide, with narrowly cylindrical, upright, spineless, pale green stems tipped with tiny, ephemeral, green leaves and marked with dark brown dots where old leaves were attached. Tiny, inconspicuous flowers surrounded by greenish yellow bractlike structures that resemble petals in spring and summer. Flowers are followed by showy, purplish red fruit. Native to rocky soils and dry forests in central and southwestern Madagascar. Sun, well-drained soils. Prefers a dry winter dormancy. May be offered as E. alluaudii. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia mauritanica (pencil milk bush), succulent, 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with upright, narrowly cylindrical, smooth, silvery gray-green branches from a short, stocky stem and small, green leaves on young branches only. Tiny, inconspicuous flowers are surrounded by bright yellow nectar glands that resemble petals at stem tips in winter. Native to much of South Africa and adjacent southern Namibia. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Prefers a dry winter. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia milii (crown of thorns), evergreen shrub, 1-4 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with grayish brown, branched, spiny stems and narrow, fleshy, grayish green leaves on new stems only. Tiny, inconspicuous flowers are surrounded by bright red bracts that resemble petals almost year round. Native to Madagascar. Many cultivars, varying mostly in size and color of the bracts, ranging from white, cream, and yellow to many shades of pink and red. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 13,21-24

Euphorbia myrsinites (creeping spurge), perennial, 6 inches to 1 foot tall and 1 foot to 18 inches wide, with oval to triangular, blue-green leaves densely and symmetrically arranged around trailing stems. Showy yellow bracts surrounding small, greenish yellow flowers in late winter or early spring take on red tones in summer. Native from southeastern Europe to central Asia. White sap may be irritating to skin and eyes. Self-sows prolifically. Considered a noxious weed in Washington, Oregon, and Colorado. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia polychroma (cushion spurge), perennial, 12-18 inches tall and 2 feet wide, with upright stems bearing oval to oblong, mid-green leaves that turn red in fall and tiny, inconspicuous, greenish flowers surrounded by showy, sulfur-yellow bracts in mid-spring and early summer. Self-sows freely and can be weedy. Native to central and southeastern Europe and western Asia. Cultivars with purplish and variegated leaves are available. Sun, well-drained soils. Cut back after flowering to control spread. May be offered as a variety of E. epithymoides. Sunset: A2,1-24

Euphorbia resinifera (Moroccan mound), succulent, 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with upright, tightly packed, four-sided columnar, pale blue-green, leafless, spiny stems. Tiny, inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers are surrounded by yellow-orange nectar glands that resemble petals in spring. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco. Sun, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia rigida (gopher spurge), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with bluish gray, lance-shaped leaves symmetrically encircling upright stems and domed clusters of tiny, green flowers with showy, chartreuse bracts in spring. Native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Turkey and the northern coast of the Black Sea. Self-sows readily. Cut stems back to the ground after flowering to control spread. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Euphorbia seguieriana subsp. niciciana (euphorbia), perennial, 12-18 inches tall and wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, grayish blue-green leaves on reddish stems. Tiny, inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers are surrounded by showy, chartreuse bracts that resemble petals from late spring until fall. Native to dry, rocky slopes and grasslands from the Balkan Peninsula to central Asia. Self-sows freely and can be weedy. Sun, most well-drained soils. Cut back after flowering to control spread. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia tirucalli (milk bush), succulent, 15-25 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, single or multitrunk, with thick, woody, primary branches and brushlike clusters of short, thin, cylindrical, green twigs or branchlets at branch ends with green leaves on new branchlets only. Tiny, inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers at branch tips are surrounded by bright yellow nectar glands that resemble petals in spring. Native to various habitats in semiarid and tropical parts of eastern and southern Africa and naturalized from the Arabian Peninsula to India and Indonesia. 'Sticks on Fire' is 4-8 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide with red stems that fade to yellow in summer. Sun, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, fast drainage. Sunset: 13,23-24

Euphorbia x lomi cultivars (euphorbia), evergreen to semi-deciduous shrubs, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with oblong, fleshy to leathery, glossy, dark green leaves on spiny branches. Tiny, inconspicuous flowers are surrounded by cupped bracts that resemble petals in winter and early spring or almost year round in mild climates. Hybrids between E. lophogona and E. milii, both native to coastal rainforests of Madagascar, developed in Thailand and known as Supergrandiflora Hybrids. Many cultivars with bracts in white, yellow, orange, red, pink, or lavender. Sun, afternoon shade in hot climates, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Euphorbia x martinii and cultivars (euphorbia), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 18-30 inches wide, with purple-tinged dark gray-green leaves and burgundy stems, most intense on new growth, and dense clusters of showy chartreuse bracts accented with dark red centers. Natural hybrid between E. characias and E. amygdaloides . Tiny Tim™ ('Waleutiny') is 1 foot tall with light green leaves. 'Red Martin' is 1-2 feet tall with upright leaves exposing reddish leaf undersides and stems. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 3-24

Euphorbia xanti (Baja spurge), succulent, 3-6 feet tall and spreading to form large stands, with a few small, oval to lance-shaped, green leaves on thin, round, gray-green stems. Dense clusters of tiny, inconspicuous flowers are surrounded by reddish purple nectar glands with white, bractlike appendages that resemble petals in mid-winter and spring. Native to coastal bluffs and dunes in central and southern Baja California. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes and by seed. Can be espaliered against a fence or wall. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Euryops pectinatus (euryops), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with deeply lobed, gray-green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers almost year round. Native to rocky slopes near the coast in Western Cape Province, South Africa. 'Viridis' has dark green leaves. Sun to light shade, most soils. Cut back hard every few years or tip prune regularly to renew. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Exochorda x macrantha 'Niagara' (pearl bush), deciduous shrub, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with oval to elliptic, medium green leaves on arching branches and clusters of small, bright white flowers in late spring. Hybrid of garden origin between E. x macrantha 'The Bride', a 3- to 4-foot selection of a much larger hybrid, and E. racemosa, a 15-foot tall species from China. Sun to part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. May be offered under the trade name of Snow Day Surprise. Sunset: N/A

Exochorda x macrantha 'The Bride' (pearl bush), deciduous shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with oval to elliptic, medium green leaves on arching branches and clusters of small, bright white flowers in spring. Hybrid between E. korolkowii, a 12-foot tall species from Turkestan, and E. racemosa, a 15-foot tall species from China. 'The Bride' was selected for its especially prolific bloom. Sun to part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: N/A

Fallopia baldschuanica (fleeceflower), deciduous vine, fast growing to 25-30 feet, with pointed oval to almost triangular, bright green leaves, new growth tinged red, and branched clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in mid-summer to fall. Climbs aggressively by twining and can be invasive, especially in riparian areas. Native to western Asia from China and Tibet to Russia. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. May be offered as Polygonum or as Reynoutria. Sunset: N/A

Fallopia japonica (Japanese knotweed), perennial or subshrub, 4-10 feet tall and spreading to form dense thickets, with large, broadly oval to somewhat triangular, green leaves on hollow stems that resemble bamboo, and sprays of tiny, creamy white flowers in summer. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes and by rooting stems, less often by seed, and can be extremely invasive, especially in riparian areas. Native to eastern Asia from China to Korea and Japan. Sun to part shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. May be offered as Reynoutria or as Polygonum cuspidatum. Sunset: N/A

Fallugia paradoxa (Apache plume), evergreen shrub, upright to 3-6 feet tall and 6 feet wide, with peeling, whitish bark, small, deeply lobed, green leaves, and creamy white spring flowers. Showy clusters of fluffy, pink seedheads with long, feathery plumes remain on the plant as petals fall. Native to desert mountains of southern California east to Texas and south to northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 2-23

Fascicularia pitcairniifolia (fascicularia), succulent, 1-2 feet tall and wide, rosette of narrow, arching, grasslike, spiny-margined, dark grayish green leaves, silvery beneath, and a tight central cluster of tiny, upfacing, cup-shaped, blue flowers in summer. Leaves in the center of the rosette turn bright red as flowers appear. Native to rocky outcrops along the coast in southern Chile and adjacent parts of Argentina. Cool sun to light shade, fast drainage. Plant on an angle to allow water to drain rapidly away. May be offered as F. bicolor. Sunset: N/A

Felicia fruticosa (shrub aster), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with small, narrowly lance-shaped to linear, slightly succulent, mid-green leaves and masses of lavender daisy flowers with yellow centers on tall stems in spring. Subspecies fruticosa is native to winter-rainfall southwestern Western Cape Province and subsp. brevipedunculata is native to summer-rainfall northeastern Limpopo, South Africa. Sun, most soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Aster. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Ferocactus spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Ferocactus species (barrel cactus), succulents, slow growing to 1-8 feet tall, with a cylindrical or barrel-shaped, green to blue-green stem with well-defined ribs bearing clusters of rigid, hooked or straight, sharp, white, pale yellow, or bright red spines. Some species offset to form small or large clumps. Mature plants produce a ring or cluster of small, white, yellow, red, or purple, funnel-shaped flowers at the top of the stem in spring or summer. Flowers are followed by bright yellow or red fruits. Native to deserts of southern California to western Texas and throughout much of Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 8-24

Festuca 'Siskiyou Blue' (Siskiyou Blue fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, 12-18 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, chalky blue leaves and late spring to early summer flowers on 2-foot stems that emerge green and age to tawny gold. Garden origin, believed to be a hybrid between F. idahoensis and the European F. glauca. Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Best in cool-summer climates. Sunset: 1-10,14-24

Festuca californica and cultivars (California fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, 2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, green to bluish green leaves and airy sprays of purple-tinged flowers on 4- to 5-foot stems in summer. Native to open, brushy or wooded slopes in central and northwestern California and southwestern Oregon. 'Serpentine Blue', a selection from northern California, has intensely blue leaves. 'River House Blues' is said to be especially well suited to southern California.  Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Best in cool-summer climates. UC researchers, as part of the UCLPIT program, have demonstrated that F. californica is a low water-use plant in Region 2 when grown in part shade. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Festuca cinerea (fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, 10-12 inches tall and wide, with fine-textured, blue-green to silvery blue-gray leaves and pale yellow flowers on tall stems in summer. Self-sows gently. Native to the western Mediterranean region from southeastern France to western Italy. Usually available as named cultivars with leaves of varying shades of blue. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Rake out old leaves in late winter to renew. May be offered as a subspecies or variety of F. glauca or as F. ovina glauca. Sunset: 1-24

Festuca glauca (blue fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, to 1 foot tall and wide, with fine-textured, narrow, blue-gray leaves and airy sprays of purple-tinged, green flowers on arching stems above the foliage. Native to central and southern Europe. Fairly short lived. 'Elijah Blue' is less than 1 foot tall with silvery blue leaves; tends to turn brown in hot summer sun. May be offered as F. cinerea or F. ovina var. glauca. Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: 1-24

Festuca idahoensis and cultivars (Idaho fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, to 1 foot tall and wide, with narrow, green to bluish green leaves and airy sprays of flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems. Native along the coast and in the mountains from British Columbia to central California and east to Montana, Idaho, and Colorado. 'Tomales Bay', from northern California, is about 6 inches tall with deep blue-green leaves. Cool sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: 1-10,14-24

Festuca mairei (Maire's fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, yellowish gray-green leaves and tall spikes of grayish green flowers in early summer that age to tawny brown. Native to the Atlas Mountains in Morocco and Algeria. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Rake out old leaves in late winter to renew. Sunset: 2-11,14-24

Festuca muelleri (Mueller's fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, 8-10 inches tall and wide, with fine-textured, soft, glossy, dark green leaves and bluish green flowers in summer that age to tan. Native to mountains of central and southern Europe. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Festuca ovina and cultivars (sheep fescue), cool-season bunchgrass, variable, upright to 1 foot tall and wide, with fine-textured, narrow, green to bluish green leaves and greenish yellow, mid- to late-summer flowers on tall stems well above the leaves. Native to many habitats in temperate climates throughout much of Europe, northwestern Africa, and Asia and widely naturalized in North America. Good plant for erosion control. Can be grown as a rough turf. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Festuca rubra (red fescue), cool-season grass, variable, 1-2 feet tall, some forms tufted and hummocky; others, called creeping red fescue, spread by rhizomes and form a rough turf. Leaves are narrow, fine-textured, and green or blue-gray and summer flowers are tawny gold on tall stems. Native to many habitats and climates over much of the northern hemisphere, including much of California. Cultivars vary in size and leaf color. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-10,14-24,A2-3

Foeniculum vulgare 'Purpureum' (bronze fennel), perennial, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, purplish bronze, finely dissected new leaves that age to dark green and large, flat-topped clusters of tiny, yellow flowers in mid- to late summer. Species has yellowish green leaves and is native along the coast in the Mediterranean region. Self-sows freely and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2b-11,14-24

Forestiera pubescens (desert olive), deciduous shrub or small tree, 8-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with smooth, pale gray to almost white bark and lance-shaped to oval, light green leaves that turn yellow in fall. Inconspicuous clusters of tiny, greenish yellow flowers in spring are followed by bluish black fruit. Native to sandy or rocky desert soils, often along streambanks or washes, from southern California east to Colorado, Oklahoma, and Texas and south to northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Needs summer heat. Sunset: N/A

Forsythia x intermedia (forsythia), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 8-10 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with pointed oval, green leaves with serrated margins on both upright and arching stems and bright yellow flowers that appear before the leaves in early to mid-spring. Hybrid of garden origin between F. suspensa, a shrub with a weeping habit, and F. viridissima, with branches stiffly upright. Compact, dwarf, and variegated cultivars are often available. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 2b-11,14-16,18-19,A2-3

Fouquieria columnaris (boojum), succulent, slow growing to 20-50 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide at the base, with a tapering, columnar, succulent stem or trunk. Many short, thin, spiny branches perpendicular to the trunk bear small, oval, dark green leaves after rains. Leaves drop as the soil dries and may reappear several times a year after rainfall. Upright spikes of fragrant, creamy white or pale yellow, bell-shaped flowers are borne near the top of the trunk in late summer and fall. Native to rocky slopes and washes along the west coast of northern and southern Baja California. May be offered as Idria. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Fouquieria diguetii (palo adan), deciduous shrub, slow growing to 8-12 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with small, oval, semi-succulent, mid-green leaves on spiny, upright, branching stems and clusters of bright red, tubular flowers at branch ends in spring and summer. Plants may lose and regrow leaves several times a year in response to drought and rainfall. Native to dry, rocky or sandy soils on slopes and in washes from southern California to southwestern Arizona and northern Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 13,18-20

Fouquieria splendens (ocotillo), deciduous shrub, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with small, oval, semi-succulent, green leaves on thorny, upright, unbranched stems and clusters of bright red, tubular flowers at branch ends in spring and summer. Plants may lose and regrow leaves several times a year in response to drought and rainfall. Native to deserts from southeastern California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 10-13,18-20

plants.botanicalName: Fragaria spp. (CA native and non-natives species)

plants.culturalInformation: Frangula californica and cultivars (coffeeberry), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves, pale green beneath, insignificant, greenish yellow flowers, and showy, red fruits that age to black. Native to dry, sandy or rocky slopes from southwestern Oregon to northern Baja California and east to western New Mexico. 'Eve Case', 'Mound San Bruno', and 'Leatherleaf' are all time-tested selections from coastal northern California. Sun to shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Rhamnus. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Frangula californica subsp. tomentella (chaparral coffeeberry), variable, 6-20 feet tall and wide, with oval to elliptic, dark bluish gray-green leaves, silvery green and velvety beneath, lightly hairy gray stems, and clusters of small, creamy yellow flowers from winter to spring followed by red, berrylike fruits that age to purplish black. Native to coastal mountains and inland foothills from southwestern Oregon to southwestern California and northern Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as F. tomentella or as Rhamnus. Sunset: N/A

Frankenia palmeri (Palmer's frankenia), evergreen shrub, mounding 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with tiny, linear to oval or club-shaped, dark yellowish green, somewhat succulent leaves and small, white, sometimes pink-tinged, widely flared tubular flowers in spring. Native to sand dunes and salt marshes in northwestern Mexico and southwestern San Diego County. Sun, most soils, including saline. Sunset: N/A

Fraxinus dipetala (foothill ash), deciduous tree or large shrub, fast growing to 15-25 feet tall and 12-20 feet wide, with leaves divided into medium green, oval, serrated leaflets that turn bright yellow in fall. Pendant clusters of lightly fragrant, white flowers in spring are followed by winged seedpods. Native to dry slopes and streambanks in coastal mountains and interior foothills from southwestern Oregon south to Baja California and east to western Arizona. Drops leaves early in hot, dry summers. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Freesia species (freesia), perennials from corms, 4 to 18 inches tall, with a fan of narrowly sword-shaped, mid-green leaves and mostly leafless, sometimes branched, horizontal or arching stems bearing one-sided spikes of fragrant, funnel-shaped, white or pale creamy yellow flowers with yellow markings in late winter or early spring. These species, including F. leichtlinii and its subspecies alba, F. caryophyllacea, F. corymbosa, and F. refracta, among others, are native to winter-rainfall Western and Southern Cape provinces of South Africa. Several other species, formerly Anomatheca and still often offered as such, are more widely native from Kenya to northeastern South Africa and some flower in summer. F. laxa and F. grandiflora, with red, star-shaped flowers, and F. verrucosa, with bright pink flowers, are native to summer-rainfall regions of southern or eastern Africa. F. viridis, from winter-rainfall regions of South Africa north of Cape Town, has green flowers. Hundreds of cultivars, mostly hybrids, with single or double flowers and a wide range of flower colors. Sun to light shade, good drainage. All freesias are dormant after flowering. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Fremontodendron (flannel bush), evergreen shrubs with thick, leathery, felted and usually lobed, green to grayish green leaves and large, golden yellow to orange flowers in spring. F. californicum, native to central and southern California, and F. mexicanum, native to southern California and Baja California, are fast growing to 8-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide. F. decumbens, native to the foothills east of Sacramento, is 3-4 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide. 'California Glory' and 'San Gabriel', both hybrids between F. californicum and F. mexicanum, easily reach 18-20 feet tall. 'Ken Taylor' and 'El Dorado Gold', both 4-5 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, are hybrids between 'California Glory' and F. decumbens. 'Dara's Gold', a hybrid of F. decumbens and F. mexicanum, is even smaller. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Furcraea species (furcraea), succulent rosettes of strap-shaped or sword-shaped leaves, with or without spines, and pendant flowers on tall stalks at maturity. Most die after flowering, but tiny plants that form on the flowering stalk fall to the ground and root. F. foetida, native to the Caribbean and northern Brazil, is 4-5 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, stemless or short-stemmed, with long, slightly wavy, strap-shaped, spineless leaves and fragrant, greenish white flowers on a 15- to 20-foot stalk. May be offered as F. gigantea. F. macdougallii, native to the mountains of south-central Mexico, is 6-8-feet tall and wide, with narrow, upright, gray-green leaves, slowly forming an unbranched stem 8-12 feet tall, and greenish white flowers on a stalk rising 15-20 feet. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: 13,16-17,19-24

Gaillardia aristata (great blanket flower), perennial, 1-3 feet tall and 2 feet wide, with lance-shaped, hairy, green, basal leaves and yellow daisy flowers with red centers on hairy, leafless stems in late spring to fall. Native to grasslands, woodlands, and mountain meadows from southern Canada, on both sides of the Rocky Mountains, south to Utah, Colorado, and South Dakota. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

photos.filename: Gaillardia x grandiflora and cultivars (blanket flower)
photos.caption: Gaillardia x grandiflora and cultivars (blanket flower)

photos.filename: Gaillardia x grandiflora and cultivars (blanket flower)
photos.caption: Gaillardia x grandiflora and cultivars (blanket flower)

plants.culturalInformation: Gaillardia x grandiflora and cultivars (blanket flower), perennials, 1-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and large daisy flowers with yellow, orange, or red petals with maroon to orange bases and dark red centers in late spring to fall. Hybrids of garden origin between G. aristata and the annual G. pulchella. Self-sow. Dwarf and double-flowered cultivars are available. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

photos.filename: Gambelia speciosa and cvs. (Island bush snapdragon)
photos.caption: Gambelia speciosa and cvs. (Island bush snapdragon)

plants.culturalInformation: Gambelia speciosa and cultivars (Island bush snapdragon), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with soft, semi-succulent, pale green leaves and bright red, tubular or trumpet-shaped flowers from spring to early fall. Native to the Channel Islands in southern California and Guadalupe Island, off the coast of Baja California. 'Firecracker' is a compact selection. 'Bocarosa' has bright green leaves and masses of red flowers. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as Galvezia. Sunset: 14-24

Garrya elliptica and cultivars (coast silktassel), evergreen shrubs, 6-15 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with leathery, dark green, wavy-edged leaves and pendulous, silvery green catkins in winter or early spring. Native to dry, shaded or open coastal slopes from southern Oregon to southern California. 'James Roof' has foot-long catkins.'Evie' is a denser shrub with closer set leaves and shorter catkins. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Garrya flavescens (ashy silktassel), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and wide, with leathery, yellowish green to gray-green, oval to elliptic leaves, pale gray beneath, and long, pendant catkins of small, greenish flowers in winter and early spring. Native to dry slopes and open woodlands from southern Nevada and Utah south to Baja California and east to western New Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Garrya fremontii (Fremont's silktassel), evergreen shrub, 6-12 feet tall and wide, with leathery, olive green leaves and long, pendant, silvery green catkins in winter or early spring. Native to mountains and foothills, both along the coast and inland, from the Columbia River in southern Washington to parts of southern California. Good choice for hot inland areas. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-10,12,14-17

Garrya veatchii (garrya), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with leathery, oval to elliptical, dark green leaves, grayish white and woolly beneath, and pendulous, silvery green catkins in winter or early spring. Native to dry slopes in the coastal mountains of southern California and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Gaura lindheimeri and cultivars (gaura), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, mid-green leaves on thin, upright and arching stems and loose spikes of white flowers from pink buds in late summer and fall. Self-sows. Native to southeastern Texas, Louisiana, and northern Mexico. Compact and variegated cultivars are available. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Oenothera. Sunset: 2b-24

Gazania species (gazania), annuals and perennials, clumping 6-12 inches tall and wide or 6-12 inches tall and trailing several feet, with linear, lance-shaped, or spoon-shaped, sometimes lobed, dark green or gray-green leaves and large, usually yellow or orange daisy flowers in late winter and spring or summer. Flowers close at night and may open only partially on cloudy days. Many self-sow freely and can be weedy or invasive. Native to rocky cliffs and sunny slopes in southern Africa, especially South Africa. G. rigens is a clumping species with yellow or orange flowers and narrow, almost linear, green leaves; the variety leucolaena is similar but trailing. G. krebsiana, a clumper, has deeply lobed, dark green leaves, silvery beneath, and dark red-orange or yellow flowers with dark brown markings at the base of the petals; G. rigida is similar. Hundreds of cultivars, mostly hybrids, with yellow, orange, red, pink, or purple flowers, often with centers or stripes in contrasting colors. Cool sun to light shade or afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Geijera parviflora (Australian willow), evergreen tree, 25-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with aromatic, pendulous, long, narrowly lance-shaped to linear, glossy dark green leaves on upright or slightly weeping branches and inconspicuous clusters of small, creamy white flowers in fall. Native to dry woodlands away from the coast in eastern Australia. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Gelsemium sempervirens (Carolina jessamine), evergreen vine, fast growing to 12-20 feet, with glossy, dark green, lance-shaped leaves and fragrant, yellow, funnel-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring. Climbs by twining. Native to open woodlands from Virginia and Florida west to Arkansas and east Texas and south to Guatemala. Sun, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Genista lydia (Lydia woadwaxen), evergreen or deciduous shrub, mounding 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with widely spaced clusters of small, linear to elliptic, bluish green leaves on stiff, arching, green branches and masses of bright yellow pea flowers in late spring or early summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils in the Balkans, Greece, and Turkey. Sun, well-drained soils. Prune only lightly; does not respond well to hard cutting back. Sunset: 2b-6,14-17

Geranium incanum (carpet geranium), perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with finely dissected, aromatic, silvery green leaves and lavender flowers with dark purple veins from late spring into fall or almost year round in mild coastal climates. Drapes over walls. Self-sows freely. Native to rocky slopes in coastal, winter-rainfall, western and southern South Africa. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Can be cut back hard to renew. Sunset: 14-24

Gladiolus watsonius (gladiolus), perennial from corm, 12-18 inches tall, with one to several basal, upright, strap- or sword-shaped, green leaves and a one-sided spike of pendulous, red-orange, funnel-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring. Summer dormant. Forms offsets. Native to sandy or clay soils on steep slopes in southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Glandularia aristigera and cultivars (South American rock vervain), perennial, variable, upright to 2 feet tall or almost mat-forming and 3-6 feet wide, with green leaves finely dissected into linear segments  and round-top clusters of lavender, purple, or sometimes white or pink flowers in spring to mid-summer. Native to wetlands, open areas, and rocky outcrops from southern Brazil and southwestern Bolivia to central Argentina. Sun, most soils. Adaptable. Can be weedy or invasive. May be offered as G. tenuisecta or as Verbena. Sunset: N/A

Glandularia lilacina and cultivars (lilac verbena), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with finely dissected, bright green leaves and small clusters of tiny, lightly fragrant, star-shaped, lavender flowers in spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils on mountain slopes in Baja California and on adjacent Cedros Island. 'De la Mina', Cedros Island verbena, has darker lavender flowers. Cool sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as Verbena. Sunset: 12-24

Glaucium flavum (yellow horned poppy), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, low rosette of deeply incised, wavy-edged, silvery gray-green leaves and silky, golden yellow, cup-shaped flowers on tall, branched stems in spring and summer, followed by long, curved seedpods. Self-sows freely and can be weedy. Native to coastal regions of southern Europe, northern Africa, and western Asia. Full sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Glechoma hederacea (ground ivy), perennial, a few inches tall and spreading widely by rooting stems, with aromatic, heart-shaped, finely hairy, dark green leaves with scalloped margins and small, tubular, blue-violet flowers on 8- to 10-inch stems in mid-spring to early summer. Forms dense mats and can be weedy or invasive. Native to grasslands and woodlands in Europe and Asia and naturalized in much of North America north of Mexico. 'Variegata' has green leaves edged in white. Sun or shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-10,14-24,A2-3

Gleditsia triacanthos (honey locust), deciduous tree, fast growing to 50-70 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with large, feathery or fernlike leaves divided into small, yellowish green, oval leaflets that turn bright yellow in fall. Clusters of inconspicuous, fragrant, greenish white flowers in late spring or early summer are followed by 12- to 18-inch long, twisted, beanlike, green seedpods that age to reddish brown. Trunk and lower branches have long, stiff, sharp, sometimes branched thorns. Forms thickets and can spread aggressively. Dropping of seedpods can be messy. Species is native to open woodlands, river floodplains, and rocky hillsides in central and eastern North America.The variety inermis is thornleess, and thornless and fruitless cultivars are available. Sun, most soils, including periodically flooded. Adaptable. Sunset: 1-16,18-20

Graptopetalum species (graptopetalum), succulent rosettes 2-6 inches tall and wide, with thick, chalky gray-green or blue-gray, triangular leaves, often tinged with gold or pink. Clusters of tiny, star-shaped, white or yellow summer flowers arise on stems from the center of the rosette. Rosettes grow at the tips of lengthening stems that drape over rocks, pile up in foot-tall groups, or break off and root. Usually said to be native to Mexico, but native origins of some are uncertain and may include parts of South America. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, excellent drainage. Plants of Echeveria and Sempervivum are sometimes offered as Graptopetalum. Sunset: 17,19-24

Graptoveria hybrids (graptoveria), succulents, rosettes 6-8 inches tall and 6-12 inches wide, spreading by offsets to form a tight colony, with smooth, thick, succulent leaves in shades of green, gray-green, blue-green, pink, or red, often tinged with a contrasting color. Loose clusters of tiny, star-shaped flowers, usually yellow, orange, or pink, arise on tall or short stems in spring or summer. Hybrids between species or varieties of Echeveria, native from Mexico to northwestern South America, and Graptopetalum, native from Mexico to southwestern North America. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 17-24

Grevillea robusta (silk oak), evergreen tree, fast growing to 50-75 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with fernlike leaves divided into deeply lobed or divided, dark green leaflets, silvery gray beneath, and yellow-orange flowers in one-sided, sometimes branched, brushlike clusters in spring. Native to both wet and dry rainforests along the coast and in coastal mountains of eastern Australia. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Can be weedy or invasive in moist climates. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Grevillea species and cultivars (grevillea), evergreen shrubs with a wide range of shapes, sizes, and colors of leaves and flowers. Most are native to Australia, where they grow in many different habitats and climates, from desert to rainforest and from seaside to high mountains. Most flower in winter and spring. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Greyia sutherlandii (Natal bottlebrush), deciduous shrub, 6-10 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with large, leathery, heart-shaped to almost circular leaves with scalloped margins that turn red in fall and cylindrical clusters of bright red, funnel-shaped flowers with protruding stamens at branch ends in late winter to early spring or almost year round. Native to rocky outcrops in eastern and northern South Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Flowers best away from the coast. Sunset: N/A

Grindelia hirsutula (hairy gum plant), perennial or subshrub, highly variable, prostrate or upright, 1-5 feet tall and wide, sometimes larger, with oblong, oval, or lance-shaped, sometimes lobed or serrated, sometimes hairy, bright green leaves and clusters of large, yellow daisy flowers from spring to fall or almost year round. Native to many habitats from streambanks to forest openings, tidal marshes, dry prairies, and seaside bluffs throughout much of Canada, Oregon, and California. Variety maritima is 12-18 inches tall and native to sandy soils along the coast in the San Francisco Bay Area. Sun, drainage requirements vary. Sunset: N/A

Grindelia stricta (Oregon gumweed), perennial or subshrub, variable, prostrate to upright, from less than 1 foot to 4 feet tall and 1-6 feet wide, with fleshy, bright green, lance-shaped to oblong, sometimes hairy leaves and yellow flowers in spring and summer. Native to coastal bluffs, dunes, and marshes along the west coast of North America from California to Alaska. Several recognized varieties and some natural hybrids are offered under various names. Plants offered as var. platyphylla generally are low groundcovers. Sun, drainage requirements vary. Sunset: N/A

Grindelia stricta var. platyphylla (gum plant), perennial, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and spreading by rooting stems to 6 feet wide or more, with lobed, mid-green leaves and yellow daisy flowers from spring to fall. Native to sand dunes, tidal marshes, and coastal bluffs from northern to central California and the northern Channel Islands. Sun to part shade, sandy or other fast-draining soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Gutierrezia sarothrae (matchweed), perennial or subshrub, less than 1 foot to 3 feet tall and  wide, with narrowly linear to threadlike, yellowish green leaves and loose clusters of small, yellow daisy flowers at stem tips in late summer and fall. Native to dry, rocky slopes and grasslands from western and central Canada to northern Mexico. Can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Gymnocladus dioicus (Kentucky coffee tree), deciduous tree, slow growing to 60-80 feet tall and 40-50 feet wide, with 2- to 3-foot long leaves twice divided into paired, blue-green leaflets and clusters of fragrant, greenish white flowers in spring. On female trees flowers are followed by flattened, bean-like, reddish brown seedpods that persist into winter. Trees leaf out late in spring and drop leaves early in fall. Native from southern Ontario south through Wisconsin and Michigan to Arkansas and Oklahoma, often in floodplains or other seasonally moist locations. Sun, most soils, including occasionally flooded. May be offered as G. dioica. Sunset:1-3,7-10,12-16,18-21

Gypsophila paniculata (baby's breath), perennial, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with linear to narrowly lance-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves and masses of tiny, white flowers on thin, branching stems from early summer to fall. Native to dry, sandy or rocky soils in central and eastern Europe east to western China. Self-sows freely and can be weedy; naturalized and considered invasive in much of North America. Cultivars with double flowers are available. Sun, well-drained, alkaline to neutral soils. Sunset: 1-10,14-16,18-21,A2-3

Hakea laurina (sea urchin tree), evergreen shrub, 12-20 feet tall and wide, with lance-shaped, sharply pointed, bluish green leaves resembling eucalyptus and pink flowers in spherical heads in late fall to mid-winter. Native to sandy soils along the south coast of Western Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. Good coastal plant. Sunset: 9,12-17,19-24

Hakea suaveolens (sweet hakea), evergreen shrub, 12-20 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with stiff, pale green leaves divided into sharply pointed, needlelike leaflets and clusters of small, fragrant, white flowers in winter. Native along the south coast of Western Australia. Can be weedy. Potentially invasive in coastal areas. May be offered as H. drupacea. Sunset: 9, 12-17, 19-24

Halimium atriplicifolium (yellow rock rose), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with broadly oval, silvery gray-white leaves and clusters of bright yellow flowers in spring or summer. Flowers drop petals in late afternoon, replaced by new flowers the next morning. Drops some leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to central and southern Spain and northern Morocco. Sun, fast-draining soils. Sunset: N/A

Halimium lasianthum (yellow rock rose), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with felted, silvery gray-green leaves and yellow spring or summer flowers with a maroon or dark brown blotch at the base of each petal. Flowers drop petals in late afternoon, replaced by new flowers the next morning. Native to gritty soils in southern Portugal and southern Spain. Sun, fast-draining soils. Sunset: N/A

Halimium ocymoides (yellow rock rose), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with woolly, oval, silvery gray-green leaves with reddish stems bearing bright yellow flowers with a dark purplish brown spot at the base of each petal in late spring and early summer. Flowers last less than a day, but new flowers quickly replace them. Native to southern Portugal and southern Spain. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Hardenbergia comptoniana (western Australia coral pea), evergreen vine, fast growing to 10-15 feet, with dark green leaves divided into 3-5 lance-shaped leaflets and pendant clusters of lavender-purple flowers in mid-winter to spring, followed by gray-brown seedpods. Native to sandy soils in southern Western Australia. Climbs by twining stems. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 15-24

Hardenbergia violacea (lilac vine), evergreen vine, fast growing to 10-15 feet, with dark green, leathery, lance-shaped leaves, pendulous clusters of lavender-purple or white flowers in mid-winter to spring, and gray-brown seedpods. Climbs by twining stems. Native to eastern and southern Australia from the coast into the mountains. 'Happy Wanderer’ has larger leaves and flowers than the species. 'Alba' has white flowers. 'Mini-Ha-Ha' is a 3-foot shrub. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Haworthia species (haworthia), succulents, variable, small rosettes, 2-6 inches tall and wide, with tightly packed, stiff or soft, fleshy, dark green or pale green and translucent, usually triangular leaves, often marked with lines or spots or raised bumps, and small, white flowers in spring to fall. Most offset readily to form small colonies; others rarely offset or remain solitary. Species are native to winter-rainfall or summer-rainfall southern Africa. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, fast drainage. Sunset: 15-17,20-24

Hedera helix (English ivy), evergreen vine, fast growing to 20-80 feet, with dark green leaves, lobed in the lengthy juvenile stage, unlobed at maturity. At maturity also, plants become more shrublike and bear clusters of greenish yellow, late-summer flowers followed by purplish black berrylike fruit. In the vining stage, ivy climbs by fibrous aerial roots, attaching itself to almost any surface. Can be highly invasive. Native to much of Europe and western Asia. Hundreds of cultivars, some dwarf or variegated. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most soils. Sunset: 3-24

plants.botanicalName: Hedychium coccinium (partial shade in South Inland)

plants.culturalInformation: Helianthemum nummularium and cultivars (sun rose), evergreen shrub or subshrub, 8-12 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaves and pink or yellow flowers in spring and early summer. Each flower lasts only a day but new flowers continue to open for weeks. Spreads by rooting stems. Cascades over walls. Native to central, southern, and eastern Europe, the Caucasus, and the Atlas Mountains. Most cultivars are hybrids with H. apenninum, a species native to western Europe and the Mediterranean region. Cool sun or part shade, well-drained, alkaline soils. Cut back after flowering to renew. Sunset: 2b-9,14-24

Helianthus maximiliani (Maximilian sunflower), perennial, 5-8 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with long, tapered, hairy, rough-textured, grayish green leaves and stiffly upright stems bearing large, bright yellow sunflowers with darker yellow centers in late summer and fall. Spreads by rhizomes and by seed and can be weedy or invasive. Native to the Great Plains region of central North America. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Helichrysum amorginum ‘Blorub’ (Ruby Clusters strawflower), small mounding perennial with wooly, whitish-gray leaves, 6- 8 inches tall and 10-16 inches wide. Small, rounded deep rose flower buds appear in early spring before opening into small whitish flowers with bright yellow centers that fade to white and beige. Best appearance if deadheaded in July. Full sun. Most soils except very waterlogged, good container plant. Sunset zones: unknown.

Helichrysum bracteatum (strawflower), perennial, mat-forming or upright to 2-3 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with long, lance-shaped, green to gray-green leaves and tiny, bright yellow flowers clustered in a central disk and surrounded by a ring of yellow or sometimes white, papery bracts that resemble the petals of a daisy. Native to a wide variety of soils and moisture regimes throughout much of Australia. Many cultivars, with bracts in shades of orange, red, pink, and purple as well as yellow and white. Sun to light shade, most soils. May be offered as Xerochrysum or as Bracteantha. Sunset: N/A

Helichrysum italicum (chamomile sunray), perennial or subshrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with linear, aromatic, silvery gray-white leaves and round-topped clusters of tiny, yellow flowers in summer. Native to dry, rocky or sandy slopes in the Mediterranean region from Morocco through eastern Spain and southern France to the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey. Sun, well-drained soils. Cut back hard in fall to renew. May be offered as a variety of H. angustifolium or as Gnaphalium. Sunset: 13-24

Helichrysum petiolare (licorice plant), evergreen shrub, variable, 1-6 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, densely felted, oval to rounded, silvery gray-green leaves and tiny, inconspicuous flowers with creamy white bracts in summer. Drapes over walls and climbs other plants. Native to southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Cultivars with chartreuse or variegated leaves are available. Spreads by seeds and by stem fragments and can be weedy or invasive. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 16-17,22-24

Helictotrichon sempervirens (blue oat grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with blue-gray leaves and light tan, mid-summer flowers on tall spikes a foot or more above the foliage. Native to southwestern Europe, from France to Italy. Cool sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best near the coast and in cooler summer climates. May be short lived. Sunset: 1-12,14-24

Helleborus argutifolius (Corsican hellebore), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, dark bluish green leaves divided into three lance-shaped leaflets with toothed margins and showy clusters of pale greenish white sepals surrounding small, inconspicuous flowers in late winter and early spring. Native to varied habitats on the Mediterranean islands of Corsica and Sardinia. Cool sun or light shade along the coast, light shade to full shade inland, well-drained soils. May be offered as H. lividus subsp. corsicus or as H. corsicus. Sunset: 3b-9,14-24

Helleborus foetidus (stinking hellebore), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, dark bluish green, leathery leaves divided into lance-shaped leaflets with serrated margins. Clusters of tiny, inconspicuous flowers with prominent stamens are surrounded by bell-shaped, yellowish green, red-tipped sepals that resemble petals and wavy-edged, pale green bracts in late winter to early spring. Self-sows. Native to forests and woodlands in the mountains of central and southern Europe. Many cultivars. Cool sun to shade or part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Good for dryish shade. Sunset: 2b-9,14-24

Helleborus lividus (Majorcan hellebore), perennial, less than 1 foot to 18 inches tall and 18 inches to 3 feet wide, with pink-tinted stems bearing leaves divided into oval to elliptic, glossy, dark grayish green leaflets, pinkish beneath and with prominent silvery veins. Clusters of tiny, inconspicuous flowers are surrounded by bell-shaped, pink-tinted, pale green sepals that resemble petals in mid-winter and early spring. Native to the mountains along the northeast coast of Mallorca, often on streambanks or in seasonally wet places. Part shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Hermannia verticillata (honeybells), perennial or subshrub, 12-18 inches tall and 3-5 feet wide, with small, deeply divided, bright green leaves on trailing stems and small, fragrant, nodding, bell-shaped, yellow or pale orange flowers in late winter and spring or much of the year in mild-winter climates. Native to sandy soils along the southwestern coast of Western Cape Province, South Africa. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: N/A

Hesperaloe parviflora (red yucca), succulent, 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with a rosette of stiff, narrow, grasslike leaves with no spines or teeth and with white, fraying fibers on leaf margins. Rose-pink, tubular flowers on 5- to 6-foot, arching stems in summer. Native to deserts of western Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2b,3,7-16,18-24

Hesperocyparis arizonica (Arizona cypress), evergreen coniferous tree, upright to 40-50 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green to silvery blue-green, scalelike leaves and small, rounded, reddish brown cones. Native to dry, rocky mountain slopes from southern California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Full sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Cupressus. Sunset: 7-24

Hesperocyparis bakeri (Modoc cypress), evergreen coniferous tree, slow growing to 30-60 feet tall and 15-35 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green to blue-green, scalelike leaves in pendulous sprays and small, brown, rounded cones. Native to mixed evergreen forests in the mountains of northern California and southwestern Oregon. Sun, coarse, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Hesperocyparis forbesii (Tecate cypress), evergreen coniferous tree, upright and symmetrical, 20-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with aromatic, light green, scalelike leaves, colorful peeling bark, and small, round cones. Native to dry slopes in coastal mountains of southern California and Baja California. Thrives inland as well as near the coast. May be offered as Cupressus or as a variety of C. guadalupensis. Sunset: 8-14,18-20

Hesperocyparis goveniana (Gowen cypress), evergreen tree or shrub, slow growing and highly variable, from 3- to 6- foot shrubs to 20- to 40-foot trees and sometimes trees to 150 feet tall, with fibrous, brown or gray bark, dense sprays of bright yellowish green, aromatic, scale-like leaves, and small, round or oval cones. Native to a few scattered locations in coastal Monterey, Sonoma, and Mendocino counties. Sun or light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cupressus or as Callitropsis. Sunset: N/A

Hesperocyparis guadalupensis (Guadalupe Island cypress), evergreen tree, fast growing to 35-65 feet tall and 20-35 feet wide, with dense sprays of aromatic, bluish gray-green to dark green, scalelike leaves, and small, round, gray or brown cones. Native to the fog-drenched, mountainous northern end of Guadalupe Island in Baja California. The former variety forbesii, a shrubby tree to 30 feet tall now classified as a separate species, is native to a few locations in southern California and mainland Baja California, often along seasonal streams. Both may be offered as Cupressus. Sun or light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Hesperocyparis macnabiana (MacNab cypress), evergreen shrub or small tree, 10-40 feet tall and often wider than tall, with short, flat sprays of gray-green, aromatic, scalelike leaves and small, oval cones. Native to the inner northern California Coast Ranges and the northern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun or light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cupressus or as Callitropsis. Sunset: N/A

Hesperocyparis macrocarpa (Monterey cypress), evergreen tree, variable, fast growing to 25-75 feet tall and wide, with fibrous, reddish brown bark that ages to furrowed and gray, aromatic, bright green to dark green, scalelike leaves, and small, round, greenish brown cones. Native to sandy soils in coastal Monterey County. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best along the coast. May be offered as Cupressus or as Callitropsis. Sunset: 17

Hesperocyparis sargentii (Sargent cypress), evergreen tree, 30-60 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with dark gray-green, aromatic, scale-like leaves, furrowed, gray-brown bark, and small, usually round cones. Native to the Coast Ranges from Mendocino County to Santa Barbara County. Full sun, most well-drained soils. Good coastal or inland. May be offered as Callitropsis or as Cupressus. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Hesperocyparis stephensonii (Cupressus arizonica ssp. arizonica, C. arizonica var. glabra))

plants.culturalInformation: Hesperoyucca whipplei (yucca), succulent, stemless rosette, 3-4 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with narrow, rigid, gray-green leaves with sharp marginal and terminal spines. Creamy white to purplish, bell-shaped flowers on a 10- to 15-foot stalk after about 10 years. Rosette dies after flowering but may be replaced by offsets. Native to dry, rocky soils from coastal southern California to northwestern Baja California and east to the western slopes of the southern Sierra Nevada. Not easy outside its native range. Full sun, excellent drainage. May be offered as Yucca. Sunset: 2-24

Heteromeles arbutifolia (toyon), evergreen shrub, 8-12 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, clusters of creamy white flowers at branch ends in summer, and red, berrylike fruit  in winter. Native to mountains of coastal California and Sierra Nevada foothills north to southern Oregon and south to Baja California. ‘Davis Gold’ has bright yellow fruit. Sun along the coast, part shade inland, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Heterotheca sessiliflora (sessile flower false golden aster), perennial, variable, mat forming to 2-4 feet tall and wide, with hairy or bristly, oblong, green leaves, often folded along the midrib, and yellow daisy flowers in spring and summer or almost year-round. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains of central to southern California and northern Baja California. 'San Bruno Mountain', a selection of subspecies bolanderi, is 8-10 inches tall and 18 inches wide. Cool sun to light shade, afternoon shade inland, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Heterotheca villosa (hairy golden aster), perennial or subshrub, variable, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with green to gray-green, often aromatic, usually hairy, and sometimes wavy-edged, lance-shaped leaves and branched clusters of bright yellow daisy flowers in summer. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in much of western and midwestern North America. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Chrysopsis. Sunset: N/A

Heuchera elegans (urn-flowered alumroot), perennial from rhizomes, 2-3 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, dense mat of bright green, lobed and rounded leaves and drooping clusters of bell-shaped, white, spring and summer flowers with pink bracts on 8- to 10-inch stems. Native to partly shaded, rocky slopes in the San Gabriel Mountains northeast of Los Angeles. Cool sun to shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as H. caespitosa. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Heuchera hybrids and cvs. ( CA natives and non-natives)

photos.caption: Heuchera hybrids and cvs. ( CA natives and non-natives)

plants.culturalInformation: Heuchera maxima (island alumroot), perennial, 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with large, bright green, heart-shaped leaves, often mottled with gray or light green, and airy clusters of tiny, bell-shaped, pinkish white, early spring flowers on 2- to 3-foot, maroon stems. Native to rocky or sandy soils on the northern Channel Islands. Many hybrids. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Plants occasionally may need lifting and resettling as they tend to push themselves up and out of the soil. Sunset: 15-24

Hibiscus syriacus (rose of Sharon), deciduous shrub, upright to 8-12 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with broadly oval, lobed and toothed, medium green leaves, pale yellowish green when new, and large, pink, purple, or white, single or double, trumpet-shaped flowers with a prominent column of stamens from midsummer to fall. Each flower lasts only a day but flowering can be prolific. Self-sows freely and can be invasive. Can be trained as a small tree. Native to south-central and southeastern China. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Holodiscus discolor (oceanspray), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 3-10 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves, white hairy beneath, and long sprays of tiny, fragrant, creamy white flowers from pink-tinged buds in late summer. Native to coastal and inland mountains from southern British Columbia to southern California and east to the northern Rocky Mountains. Light shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-9,14-19

Homeria species (Cape tulip), perennials from corms, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and less than 1 foot wide, with one to a few narrowly sword-shaped, basal leaves and a single upright, leafy stem bearing yellow, orange, pink, lilac, or bicolor flowers enclosed in a pair of sheathing bracts (spathes). Flowers are followed by leathery seed capsules. Some species spread aggressively by seed and by offsets and can be weedy or invasive. Most are native to a variety of habitats in winter-rainfall, southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa, from deserts to woodlands, shrublands, and grasslands. Some may be offered as Moraea. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Homoglad hybrids (homoglad), perennials from bulbs, 2-3 feet tall and 6 inches wide, with narrow, rushlike, dark green leaves and tall, thin stems bearing multicolored, funnel-shaped flowers, fragrant in the evening, in various combinations of orange, yellow, white, pink, purple, or cream. Leaves appear in late fall and flowers in spring. Summer dormant. Hybrids between Gladiolus tristis and Homoglossum watsonium (now Gladiolus watsonius), both native to southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Spread slowly by offsets. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Hordeum brachyantherum (meadow barley), cool-season bunchgrass, upright to 2-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, green to bluish green leaves and purplish flowers in summer. Native to seasonally moist meadows, streambanks, salt marsh edges, and forest openings from Alaska to northern Mexico and east to the Rocky Mountains. Self-sows. Sun, most soils, including periodically flooded. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Hosackia crassifolia  var. otayensis (Lotus crassifolius var. otayensis)

plants.culturalInformation: Humulus lupulus (hops), deciduous vine, fast growing to 15-30 feet, with deeply lobed and serrated, dark green leaves and male or female flowers in summer. Male plants produce greenish yellow flowers in catkins; female plants bear fragrant, greenish flowers in conelike arrangements of papery bracts. Female flowers are followed by cone-shaped fruits. Climbs by twining stems. Native to Europe, western Asia, and North America. Sun to part shade. Sunset: 1-10,14-21,A2-3

Hunnemannia fumariifolia (Mexican tulip poppy), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with finely divided, blue-green leaves and bright yellow, cup-shaped flowers with crinkled petals from mid-summer through fall. Self-sows lightly. Native to high deserts of northern Mexico, southwestern Texas, and Arizona. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

plants.botanicalName: Hylotelephium spp. and cvs. (Some are Sedum)
plants.culturalInformation: Hylotelephium species and cultivars (stonecrop), succulents, mat-forming to upright and 1-2 feet tall, with fleshy stems and green, bluish green, or red-tinged leaves. Showy clusters of tiny, white, pink, or red, star-shaped flowers appear in late summer or fall. Many species and dozens of cultivars. Species are native to Europe, Asia, and North America. H. cauticola, native to Japan, is 3-6 inches tall and 12-18 inches wide, with rounded, purple-edged, blue-gray leaves on pink stems and rose-pink flowers from purplish gray buds. H. spectabile, native to China and Korea, is 18 inches tall and wide, with finely toothed, bluish green leaves and flat-topped clusters of pink flowers. H. 'Herbstfreude', a hybrid involving H. spectabile formerly known as Sedum 'Autumn Joy,' has grayish green, serrated, oval leaves and rose pink flowers that mature to deep red. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Afternoon shade in hot-summer climates. May be offered as Sedum. Sunset: zones vary

Hymenolepis parviflora (golden coulter bush), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with green to gray-green leaves deeply divided into needlelike, linear lobes and dense clusters of fragrant, sulfur yellow flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky slopes in western and southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun, excellent drainage. Cut back gently after flowering to renew. May be offered as H. crithmifolia or as Athanasia. Sunset: N/A

Hypericum aegypticum (dwarf St. John's wort), evergreen shrub or subshrub, less than 1 foot to 3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, elliptical to narrowly oblong, bluish gray-green leaves and yellow, shallowly cup-shaped flowers in summer. Native to rocky, sea-facing slopes along the coast from Morocco to Libya and on several islands in the Mediterranean Sea, including Crete, Sardinia, and Malta. Sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Hypericum androsaemum (sweet amber), evergreen shrub, upright to 2-4 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, oval to oblong, dark green leaves that take on reddish tints in fall. Clusters of cup-shaped, yellow flowers with prominent yellow stamens in spring and summer are followed by small, red, berrylike fruit that matures to black. Self-sows freely and may form dense stands; can be weedy or invasive. ‘Red Ignite’ is rust-resistant cultivar reaching 3-5 feet high and 5-7 feet wide; blooms from May through late fall with sporadic winter bloom. Best appearance maintained by cutting back in early spring.  Native to shady woodlands in the Mediterranean region. Sun to part shade, part shade or afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b-24

Ilex aquifolium (English holly), evergreen tree or large shrub, slow growing to 20-50 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, single- or multitrunk, with glossy, leathery, dark green, oval to elliptic, wavy-edged, usually spiny leaves. Clusters of inconspicuous, fragrant, greenish white flowers in spring are followed by red or orange, berrylike fruit on female plants. Native from the Atlas Mountains and northern Spain north to western Norway and east through France, Italy, the Balkan Peninsula, and coastal northern Turkey to the Caucasus. Suckers to form dense thickets and seeds are spread widely by birds. Considered invasive in much of coastal western North America. Variegated and seedless cultivars are available. Sun to part shade, shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Best in neutral to acidic soils but adaptable. Sunset: 4-9,14-17

Ilex cornuta 'Burfordii' (Burford holly), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 15-18 feet tall and 12-15 feet wide, with glossy, leathery, oval to elliptic, dark green leaves, usually with a single sharp spine at the tip, and clusters of inconspicuous, fragrant, greenish white flowers in spring. Flowers are followed by red, berrylike fruit without pollination. Species is native to eastern China and Korea. Compact and dwarf forms are available. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-24

Ilex vomitoria (yaupon), evergreen shrub, 15-25 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with small, glossy, dark green, oval to rounded leaves with scalloped or serrated margins and inconspicuous, greenish white, fragrant flowers in spring. Flowers are followed by red, berrylike fruit on female plants. Suckers and may form dense thickets. Native to sandy soils near the coast from southern Virginia to northern Florida and west to southeastern Oklahoma and Texas. Dwarf and weeping cultivars are available. Sun or shade, most well-drained soils, including alkaline. Sunset: 3-9,11-24

Ipheion uniflorum (spring star flower), perennial from bulb, 4-6 inches tall and wide, with aromatic, grasslike, green leaves and multiple stems with fragrant, star-shaped, pale blue or almost white flowers in early spring. Summer dormant. Native to Argentina and Uruguay. Spreads rapidly by offsets and by seed. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. May be offered as Triteleia or as Brodiaea. Sunset: 2b-24

Iris douglasiana (Douglas iris), perennial from rhizomes, with strap-shaped, glossy green leaves and light blue-violet to dark purple or sometimes white flowers with purple, blue, or gold veining in late winter or early spring. Native to coastal bluffs and grasslands from central western Oregon to southern California. Hybridizes readily in the wild. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Iris germanica (German iris), perennial, 12-18 inches tall, bearded iris with fans of gray-green, broadly strap-shaped leaves and flowers with ruffled, blue, violet, or white petals and yellow beards on 2- to 4-foot stems in spring, sometimes reblooming several times in mild-winter coastal gardens. Likely a natural hybrid between I. pallida and I. variegata. One parent of most modern hybrid tall bearded irises, which are often offered as selections of I. germanica. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Lift and divide in summer every three to five years or as needed to renew. Sunset: 1-24

Iris (Pacific Coast hybrids), perennials from rhizomes, 8-24 inches tall and slowly spreading, with sword-shaped to narrow, grasslike, green leaves and colorful, intricately patterned, sometimes lightly fragrant flowers in late winter or early spring. Dormant but only partially deciduous in summer. May form small or large colonies. Species are native to the Pacific Coast of North America, from southern California to southwestern Washington, west of the Cascades. Hundreds of cultivars, mostly hybrids, offer a vast selection of flower shapes and colors. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Iris x hollandica (Dutch iris), perennials from bulbs, 18 inches to 2 feet tall and 4-6 inches wide, with upright, narrowly linear, green leaves and large, blue, yellow, white, or multicolored flowers on 2-foot stems in late spring or early summer. Hybrids involving I. tingitana from North Africa, I. xiphium var. praecox from Spain, and I. xiphium var. lusitanica from Portugal. Sun, excellent drainage. Need moisture in spring to bloom well. Prefer a dry summer dormancy. Sunset: 2b-24

Isoplexis canariensis (Canary Island foxglove), evergreen shrub, 4-5 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with long, lance-shaped to pointed oval, dark green leaves with finely serrated margins and tall spikes of yellow-orange, trumpet-shaped flowers in late spring and summer. Native to humid subtropical forests on several of the Canary Islands. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best in mild coastal climates with cool nights. Short lived and not always easy in cultivation. May be offered as Digitalis. Sunset: N/A

Isopogon formosus (rose coneflower), evergreen shrub, upright to 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with dark green leaves divided into narrow, cylindrical leaflets, new growth tinted red, and rounded clusters of tiny, purplish pink flowers with protruding, yellow tipped styles in late winter and spring. Flowers are followed by persistent, oval, conelike seedpods. Native to coastal dry woodlands and shrublands in southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, well-drained, sandy or gravelly soils. Prune only lightly to shape. Not always easy in cultivation. Sunset: N/A

Iva hayesiana (poverty weed), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 5-8 feet wide, with fleshy, aromatic, lance-shaped to elliptic, pale green leaves and tight clusters of tiny, inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in spring and summer. Spreads by rooting stems. Native to seasonal streams, salt marsh edges, and alkaline flats in northern Baja California and adjacent parts of San Diego County. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Ixia species (African corn lily), perennials from corms, 1-2 feet tall and 8-12 inches wide, with upright, grasslike, green leaves and tall spikes of star-shaped or cup-shaped flowers on long, thin stems in late spring. Flowers open flat in bright sun and are partially closed on cloudy days. Summer dormant. Native to winter-rainfall parts of western and southern South Africa. Most plants offered are hybrids involving the yellow-flowered I. maculata and bear flowers in shades of yellow, orange, red, pink, or creamy white, usually with dark centers. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage, neutral to alkaline soils. Spread by seed and by offsets and can be weedy or invasive. Need a dry summer dormancy. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Jasminum mesnyi (primrose jasmine), evergreen or semi-evergreen vining shrub, mounding 6-10 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves divided into glossy, oblong to lance-shaped leaflets on arching branches and sometimes fragrant, yellow flowers in winter or spring. Native to southwestern China. Can be cut back hard to renew. May be offered as J. primulinum. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24
