Jasminum nitidum (angel wing jasmine), evergreen shrubby vine, to 10-15 feet, with glossy, lance-shaped, dark green leaves and fragrant, spidery, bright white flowers with purple undersides in spring and summer. Native to India and Bangladesh and naturalized in parts of tropical southeastern Asia. Can be invasive in mild-winter climates. Sun or part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as J. laurifolium var. laurifolium. Sunset: N/A

Jasminum nudiflorum (winter jasmine), deciduous vining shrub, mounding 4-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with arching branches, leaves divided into glossy, dark green, oval leaflets, and unscented, bright yellow flowers in winter or early spring. Spreads by rooting stems and can form colonies. Needs support to climb. Cascades over walls. Native to northern China. Sun to part shade, most soils. Best in cooler, coastal climates. Can be cut back hard after flowering to renew. Sunset: 2-21.

Jasminum officinale f. grandiflorum (common jasmine), deciduous or semi-evergreen vine, to 15-20 feet, with leaves divided into medium green, pointed oval leaflets and clusters of fragrant, star-shaped, white flowers from mid-spring into fall. Climbs by twining stems. Species is native from the Caucasus through parts of western Asia to the Himalayas. May be offered as J. grandiflorum, which is a more tender, shrubby plant. Plants offered as J. officinale f. affine or J.officinale 'Affine' generally have flowers with broader petals from pink-tinged buds. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

Jubaea chilensis (Chilean wine palm), palm, slow growing to 50-80 feet tall and 20-25 feet wide, with a broad trunk, featherlike, gray-green leaves, and small purple flowers, followed by round fruit, green when new and ripening to bright yellow. Native to dry woodlands in the mountains of central Chile. One of the hardiest palms. Old leaves drop cleanly on mature trees, leaving a smooth, gray trunk. Sun to part shade, well-drained soil. Sunset: 12-24

Juglans hindsii (California black walnut), deciduous tree, 30-60 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into many lance-shaped, mid-green leaflets with serrated margins. Inconspicuous, greenish white flowers in spring are followed by smooth, hard-shelled nuts encased in thick, green husks. Provenance uncertain but believed to be native to a few locations in northern California and southwestern Oregon, often near streams. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as a subspecies of J. californica, which is native to southern California. Sunset: 5-9,14-20

plants.botanicalName: Juncus aquatic spp. (native and non-native spp.)

photos.filename: Juncus patens and cvs. (California gray rush)
photos.caption: Juncus patens and cvs. (California gray rush)

plants.culturalInformation: Juncus patens and cultivars (California gray rush), grasslike plant, to 2 feet tall and wide, with stiffly upright, gray-green to bluish green, leafless stems and tiny, rusty brown flowers partially hidden among the stems in spring and summer. Native to moist or seasonally moist coastal locations from southern Washington to northern Baja California. 'Elk Blue', from coastal northern California, has especially narrow and especially blue stems. Can grow in shallow water. Spreads by rhizomes in moist or wet locations. Sun to shade, most soils. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Juniperus californica (California juniper), evergreen shrub, 10-20 feet tall and wider than tall, with aromatic, light green, scalelike leaves, needlelike when new, peeling, gray bark, and small, round, blue-brown cones. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the mountains of California, Baja California, southern Nevada, and western Arizona. Sun, good drainage. Sunset: 3,6-12,14-24

Juniperus scopulorum and cultivars (Rocky Mountain juniper), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-40 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with aromatic, light to dark green or bluish gray, scalelike leaves, needlelike when new, peeling, reddish brown bark, and small, berrylike cones. Native to dry, rocky ridges from British Columbia south through the Rocky Mountains to Arizona and New Mexico. 'Wichita Blue' is 15-20 feet tall with blue-gray leaves. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 1-24

Juniperus species (juniper), coniferous trees and shrubs, variable, from tall trees to upright, low-spreading, or mat-forming shrubs, with resinous, aromatic leaves, fibrous and often peeling bark, and fleshy, berry-like blue or sometimes reddish brown female seed cones. Many species have stiff and sharply pointed, needle-like juvenile leaves and scalelike mature leaves, while others, such as the widely distributed J. communis, retain the needle-like leaves in maturity. Native to many habitats throughout much of the northern hemisphere and especially common in semi-arid regions and at mid- to high elevations. Many cultivars. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Justicia californica (chuparosa), semi-evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, green to gray-green, oval to triangular leaves and bright red or sometimes yellow, narrowly tubular flowers in spring. Native to sandy or rocky soils, often in washes, in deserts of southeastern California, southern Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. May be offered as Beloperone. Sunset: 10-14,18-24

Justicia spicigera (Mexican honeysuckle), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with large, oval to broadly lance-shaped, light green leaves and narrowly tubular, orange flowers intermittently from early spring through late fall. Native to dry and moist forests and woodlands from Mexico south to Colombia. Cool sun or part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-24

Kalanchoe species (kalanchoe), succulents, 6 inches to 6 feet tall and wide, some stemless rosettes, a few almost vinelike or trailing, others shrubby on upright, branched or unbranched stems. Leaf shapes and colors range from smooth and glossy green to softly felted and gray and from rounded to triangular to lance-shaped or cylindrical. Leaves may have toothed or serrated margins and many are edged, flushed, or otherwise marked with contrasting colors. Flowers of most species have small, pendulous, tubular or bell-shaped flowers in winter or early spring. Offsets may appear on leafless stems, in leaf axils, or along leaf margins. Most species are native to southern and eastern Africa, especially Madagascar. Hundreds of cultivars. Cool sun to light shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Best in mild, coastal climates. Sunset: zones vary

Keckiella antirrhinoides (yellow penstemon), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with small, narrowly oval to lance-shaped, glossy, green leaves and showy, fragrant, tubular or trumpet-shaped, yellow flowers in late winter or early spring. Native to dry, rocky slopes in deserts of southern California, western Arizona, and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade or full shade inland, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Deciduous and dormant in late summer if grown dry. Cut back in late summer or fall to renew. May be offered as Penstemon. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Keckiella cordifolia (climbing penstemon), evergreen or semi-evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with small, oval to heart-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves and showy, red-orange, tubular or trumpet-shaped flowers in spring and early summer. Native to sandy or rocky slopes in coastal mountains of southern California and northern Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Deciduous and dormant in late summer if grown dry. Cut back in late summer or fall to renew. May be offered as Penstemon. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Kleinia repens (blue chalksticks), succulent, 6-10 inches tall and 2-4 feet wide, spreading by rooting stems, with short, cylindrical, waxy, blue-gray leaves and short stems bearing loose, open clusters of tiny white flowers in late summer. Native to coastal Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. May be offered as Senecio serpens or as Curio repens. Sunset:16-17,21-24

Kniphofia galpinii (coral poker), 1-2 feet tall and wide, with bright green, grasslike leaves and upright spikes of pendant, tubular, red to orange flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems from mid-summer to fall. Native from northern central KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, south to northern Eswatini. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-9,14-24

Kniphofia species and cultivars (red-hot poker), perennials from rhizomes, rosette of arching, grasslike to strap-shaped, finely toothed leaves and cylindrical spikes of small, brightly colored, usually closely spaced, tubular flowers on upright stems. Flowers are held well above the leaves and buds open from the bottom of the spike to the top, changing color as they mature. Most spread by rhizomes, some quite widely. Most are native to various habitats in South Africa or eastern Africa. K. galpinii has bright green leaves 1-2 feet tall and coral red buds that mature to yellow on 3-foot stems in summer. K. northiae has gray-green leaves 2-4 feet tall and red buds that mature to yellow on 5- to 6-foot stems in summer. K. rooperi has dark green leaves 2 feet tall and short spikes of bright orange buds that mature to yellow on 4-foot stems in fall and winter. K. thomsonii, the only alpine Kniphofia, has blue-green leaves 2-3 feet tall and unusually tall spikes of widely spaced orange flowers on 4- to 5-foot stems in summer. Hundreds of hybrids in a range of sizes and flower colors as well as flowering times. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

photos.filename: Kniphofia uvaria hybrids and cultivars (red hot poker)
photos.caption: Kniphofia uvaria hybrids and cultivars (red hot poker)

plants.culturalInformation: Kniphofia uvaria hybrids and cultivars (red hot poker), perennials from rhizomes, clump forming, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with sword-shaped to grasslike, finely toothed, green to gray-green or bluish green basal leaves and upright, cylindrical spikes of densely clustered, pendant, tubular flowers on sturdy, 2- to 6-foot, leafless stems in late spring and summer. Flowers open from the bottom of the spike to the top and change color as they mature. Species are native to southern and eastern Africa. Many hybrids, with flower colors ranging from red to orange, yellow, lime green, or nearly white. Sun, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Koeleria macrantha (June grass), cool-season bunchgrass, variable, from less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, light green to bluish green leaves and silvery green flowers that age to tan. Self-sows freely. Native to semi-arid, mid- to high elevation grasslands and forest openings of Europe, Asia, and North America. In North America it is found from southeastern Alaska to northern Mexico and east to the central East Coast. 'Barkoel' and 'Barleria' are slow-growing selections of European plants offered as rough, low-maintenance turf grasses. Best near the coast or at higher elevations. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. May be offered as K. cristata. Sunset: N/A

Koelreuteria paniculata (golden-rain tree), deciduous tree, 25-40 feet tall and wide, with long, feathery leaves divided into bright green, deeply serrated leaflets, new growth reddish. Showy clusters of yellow flowers in summer are followed by yellow fruits that age to papery, brown seed capsules. Dropping of fruit can be messy. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. Native to China, Korea, and Japan. Sun, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 2-24,A2

Kolkwitzia amabilis (beauty bush), deciduous shrub, upright and fast growing to 8-12 feet tall and wide, with dark green, oval leaves on arching, almost weeping branches and clusters of ruffled, bell-shaped, pale pink flowers with yellow centers in late spring or early summer. Spreads by suckering roots, but not aggressively. Native to central China. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Can be cut back hard to renew. May be offered as Linnea. Sunset: 2-11,14-20

Krascheninnikovia lanata (winterfat), semi-deciduous subshrub, upright to spreading, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with linear to lance-shaped, grayish white leaves and spikes of silvery white flowers following spring or summer rains. Leaves remain on the plant in winter and are shed in spring as new leaves appear or when the plant is stressed by lack of water. Native to arid regions of western North America from southern Alberta and Saskatchewan south through eastern Washington to Baja California and east to western Nebraska and Texas. Sun, neutral to alkaline soils. Sunset: N/A

Kunzea species (kunzea), evergreen shrubs to small trees, 1-15 feet tall and 2-12 feet wide, with aromatic, green or gray-green leaves and showy clusters of small, fragrant flowers with tiny petals and prominent stamens. Most species are native to southwestern Australia, with a few from southeastern Australia and New Zealand. K. pomifera, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, has small, oval, green leaves and white flowers in spring. K. affinis, 4-6 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, has dark green, needlelike leaves and pink flowers in mid-winter to spring. K. ambigua, 5-15 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, has narrowly linear, green leaves and bright white flowers in spring and summer. Sun to part shade, good to excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Lachenalia species (Cape cowslip), perennials from bulbs, 8-12 inches tall and wide, with one to several sword-shaped, lance-shaped, or grasslike, green leaves and upright spikes of tubular or bell-shaped, sometimes fragrant flowers in winter or early spring. Flowers are pendulous, upright, or held horizontally on stems and may be white, yellow, orange, red, blue, or purple, often multicolored. Native to varied habitats in Western Cape Province, South Africa, and Namibia. Many cultivars. Deciduous and dormant in summer, when they should be kept dry. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-17,23-24

Lagerstroemia species and cultivars (crape myrtle), deciduous trees and shrubs, variable, 6-30 feet tall and 6-15 feet wide, with mottled, multicolored, peeling bark and oval to elliptic, green leaves that turn bright yellow, orange, or red in fall. Showy clusters of crinkled flowers in summer and fall are followed by small, round seed capsules. Most plants offered are selections of L. indica, a red-flowered species native to southeastern China, or hybrids of L. indica and L. fauriei, a white-flowered species from Japan. Dozens of cultivars with flowers in many shades of red, pink, purple, and white and some with purple leaves. Best where summers are long and hot, but some cultivars perform acceptably in cooler climates. Sun, good drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 7-10,12-14,18-21

L. indica 'Deleb' (Delta Eclipse™ crape myrtle), deciduous perennial shrub with burgundy purple foliage and lavender flowers, to 8-12 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide. L. 'Purple Magic' (Purple Magic crape myrtle) is a shrub 7-8 feet tall and wide with green leaves and deep purple flowers. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 7-10, 12-15, 18-21.

Lagunaria patersonii (primrose tree), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with leathery, olive green leaves, gray-green beneath, and large, pink flowers that fade to white in summer, followed by persistent brown seed capsules. Native to islands off the coast of eastern Australia and to coastal Queensland. 'Royal Purple' has purple flowers. Full sun, good drainage. May be offered as L. patersonia. Sunset: 13,15-24

Lampranthus species (ice plant), succulents, shrubby or trailing, with long and cylindrical or short and triangular, fleshy, green to gray-green leaves and large, brightly colored daisy flowers in summer. Most are native to coastal western, southern, and northern South Africa and southern Namibia. Many cultivars and hybrids. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plants. Drape over rocks and walls. Plants may need replacing or filling in after several years. Sunset: 14-24

Lantana 'New Gold' (lantana), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and trailing 4-6 feet wide, with dark green, rough-textured leaves and rounded clusters of tiny, golden yellow flowers in summer through fall. Similar to L. camara but possibly a hybrid. Nearly sterile, produces little or no seed. Drapes over walls and containers. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as a selection of L. montevidensis or of L. camara. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Lantana camara and cultivars (lantana), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with broadly oval, aromatic, rough-textured, dark green leaves with serrated margins. Rounded clusters of tiny, fragrant, tubular, yellow, orange, red, purple, white, or multicolored flowers are followed by berrylike fruit. Flowers change color after pollination. Species spreads aggressively by seed and can be weedy or invasive. Native to Central and South America. Hundreds of cultivars. Sun, most soils. Adaptable. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Lantana hybrids (lantana), evergreen shrubs, 1-6 feet tall and 2-8 feet wide, shrubby, mounding, or trailing, with aromatic, oval, green or gray-green, coarse-textured leaves and tight clusters of brightly colored flowers in spring and summer or intermittently year round in mild climates. Most are hybrids of L. camara and L. montevidensis. Some are low seed producers and may be less invasive than the species. May be offered as Lantana x hybrida. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Lantana montevidensis (trailing lantana), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with aromatic, oval, coarsely toothed, lightly hairy, green leaves tinged purplish in cold weather. Circular clusters of tiny, lavender or sometimes white, funnel-shaped flowers almost year round in mild-winter climates are followed by berrylike fruit. Spreads aggressively by seed and can be weedy or invasive. Native to South America from Bolivia, Paraguay, and southern Brazil to Argentina and Uruguay. Sun to light shade, sandy soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as L. sellowiana. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Larrea tridentata (creosote), evergreen shrub, 3-8 feet tall and wide, with tiny, resinous, aromatic, dark green leaves divided into two linear leaflets and small, yellow flowers in spring or intermittently after rains. Flowers are followed by small, hairy, rusty brown or white fruit. Spreads slowly by seed and by suckering roots. Native to the Mojave, Sonoran, and Chihuahuan deserts of North America from southeastern California to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 7-14,18-21

Laurus 'Saratoga' (Saratoga bay), evergreen tree or large shrub, slow growing to 12-30 feet tall and wide, with leathery, aromatic, dark green leaves and inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in spring. Species is native to low-elevation and coastal habitats in the Mediterranean region. This cultivar is smaller, has larger leaves, and is said to be more disease resistant than the species. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Good formal or informal screen. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

Laurus nobilis (sweet bay), evergreen tree or large shrub, variable, usually multitrunk, slow growing to 15-40 feet tall and wide, with leathery, aromatic, dark green leaves and inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in spring. Native to low-elevation and coastal habitats in the Mediterranean region. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Good formal or informal screen. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

Lavandula species and cultivars (lavender), evergreen shrubs and shrubby perennials, mounding or upright to 1-4 feet tall and 2-5 feet wide, with aromatic, green to gray-green or silvery gray, needlelike, linear, lobed, or deeply dissected leaves and spikes of small, lavender, purple, or sometimes white flowers, some with showy bracts. Almost four dozen species are native to western Europe, the Mediterranean, northern and eastern Africa, or parts of Asia. Hundreds of cultivars. Flowering times and cold tolerances vary. Sun to light shade, good to excellent drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: zones vary

Lavatera maritima (bush mallow), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-8 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with lobed and serrated, gray-green leaves and pale pinkish white flowers with purple centers and veins from early spring to late fall and intermittently year round. Native near the coast in southern France. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Short lived. May be offered as L. bicolor. Sunset: 6-9,12-24

Leonotis leonurus (lion's tail), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with lance-shaped, dark green leaves and whorled clusters of velvety, bright orange, tubular summer flowers encircling the stems at intervals. Native to rocky soils in southeastern Africa. Cool sun, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. May not survive wet winters in heavy soils. Sunset: 8-24

Leonotis menthifolia (mint-leaf lion's tail), shrubby perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with small, rounded to oval, dark green leaves with scalloped margins and whorled clusters of velvety, tawny or bright orange, tubular summer flowers encircling the stems at intervals. May self-sow. Native to rocky outcrops in eastern Africa from Sudan to northern South Africa. Cool sun, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. May be offered as L. ocymifolia. Sunset: N/A

Lepechinia calycina (pitcher sage), evergreen shrub, 3-8 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, softly hairy, lance-shaped to oval, gray-green to yellowish green leaves and tubular, lavender-tinted, white flowers in spring. Native to rocky slopes along the coast and in coastal mountains of central to southern California and the northern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Lepechinia fragrans (fragrant pitcher sage), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, oval to almost triangular, softly hairy, gray-green leaves and pinkish lavender to magenta, tubular flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky, often north-facing slopes in the mountains of central and southern California, the Channel Islands, and Baja California. Full sun along the coast, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Lepechinia hastata (Mexican pitcher sage), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, softly felted, almost triangular, silvery green leaves and tubular, magenta flowers in summer and early fall. Native to Baja California, including Baja California Sur. Sun along the coast, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Leptospermum 'Dark Shadows' (Dark Shadows tea tree), evergreen shrub to small tree, 12-15 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with burgundy-tinted, dark olive green, narrowly lance-shaped leaves and masses of small, white flowers in spring or early summer followed by woody seed capsules. Garden origin, believed to be a seedling of a plant with dark coppery or bronzy green leaves, possibly a cultivar of L. macrocarpum or L. nitidum. Sunset: 14-24

Leptospermum laevigatum (Australia tea tree), evergreen shrub to small tree, fast growing to 15-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with small, narrowly oblong, aromatic, grayish green leaves and masses of small, white flowers in spring or early summer followed by persistent, woody seed capsules. Native to sand dunes and bluffs in coastal southeastern Australia from New South Wales to Tasmania. Considered a high risk for invasiveness in parts of coastal California. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 14-24

Leptospermum laevigatum 'Reevesii' (dwarf tea tree), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, narrowly oblong, aromatic, gray-green leaves and masses of small, white flowers in spring or early summer followed by persistent, woody seed capsules. Species is native to sand dunes and bluffs in coastal southeastern Australia from New South Wales to Tasmania. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as L. laevigatum 'Compacta'. Sunset: 14-24

Leptospermum petersonii (lemon-scented tea tree), evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 8-20 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide, with small, linear, pale green, aromatic leaves on arching branches and small, white flowers with green centers in spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils in southeastern Australia and on North Island, New Zealand. Sun to light shade, well-drained, neutral to slightly acidic soils. Good seaside plant. Prune only lightly as needed. Sunset: 14-24

Leptospermum rotundifolium (tea tree), evergreen shrub, 8-10 feet tall and wide, with small, oval, glossy green, aromatic leaves with pointed tips on branches that arch to the ground and small, white, pink, or lavender flowers with green centers in spring. Native to parts of southeastern Australia. Many cultivars, including dwarf and prostrate forms. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 14-24

Leptospermum rupestre (tea tree), evergreen shrub, variable, 1 foot tall and 3 feet wide or 3-5 feet tall and 8 feet wide, with small, aromatic, oval to elliptic, glossy green leaves on arching, reddish branches and small, fragrant, white flowers in summer to fall. Leaves take on red or bronze tones in fall. Low forms follow contours, spilling over rocks and walls. Native to Tasmania. Sun to part shade, most soils, including poorly drained. Good seaside plant. May be offered as a prostrate variety of L. scoparium. Sunset: N/A

Leptosyne gigantea (giant coreopsis), perennial, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with finely dissected, bright green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers from late winter to late spring. Deciduous in summer if grown dry. Native to sand dunes and coastal bluffs in southern California, including the Channel Islands. Sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Coreopsis. Sunset: N/A

Leptosyne maritima (sea dahlia), perennial, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with deeply divided, semi-succulent, bright green leaves with narrowly linear lobes and yellow daisy flowers from late winter through spring. Deciduous and dormant in summer. Native to seaside bluffs and dunes in coastal San Diego County and northern Baja California. Sun, fast-draining, sandy soils. May be offered as Coreopsis. Sunset: N/A

Lessingia filaginifolia 'Silver Carpet' (California beach aster), perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 3-6 feet wide, with small, silvery gray-white leaves and pinkish lavender flowers with yellow centers in late spring and summer. Species is native to sandy or rocky soils on coastal bluffs and mountain slopes from southwestern Oregon to Baja California. This selection is from Monterey County. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good along the coast or inland. May be offered as Corethrogyne. Sunset: N/A

Lessingia filaginifolia (sand aster), perennial, a few inches tall and 3-6 feet wide, with small, silvery gray-white leaves and lavender, pink, or white flowers with yellow centers in late spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils on coastal bluffs and mountain slopes from southwestern Oregon to Baja California. Usually available as 'Silver Carpet'. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good along the coast or inland. May be offered as Corethrogyne. Sunset: N/A

Leucadendron argenteum (silver tree), evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with large, silvery gray-green, softly hairy, lance-shaped leaves held upright and densely covering upright branches. Conelike flowerheads at tips of branches are surrounded by silvery gray, leaflike bracts and are mostly concealed from below. Native to clay soils on cool slopes of the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. Short-lived. Cool sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-17,20-24

Leucadendron species, hybrids, and cultivars (conebush), evergreen shrubs and small trees, most 3-10 feet tall and wide, a few much larger, with lance-shaped, elliptical, or sometimes needlelike leaves and colorful bracts surrounding conical flowerheads that form woody, cone-like seedheads after flowering. Most bloom in winter or spring. Native to South Africa. Sun to part shade, good air circulation, excellent drainage. Sunset: 16-17,20-24

Leucojum aestivum (summer snowflake), perennial from bulb, 12-18 inches tall and 8-12 inches wide, with grasslike, dark green leaves and small clusters of fragrant, white, nodding, bell-shaped flowers on leafless stems in spring. Spreads by offsets. Native to seasonally damp places in much of Europe. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Summer dormant. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: 1-10,14-24

photos.filename: Leucophyllum langmaniae 'Lynn's Legacy' (Lynn's everblooming Texas sage)
photos.caption: Leucophyllum langmaniae 'Lynn's Legacy' (Lynn's everblooming Texas sage)

photos.filename: Leucophyllum langmaniae 'Lynn's Legacy' (Lynn's everblooming Texas sage)
photos.caption: Leucophyllum langmaniae 'Lynn's Legacy' (Lynn's everblooming Texas sage)

plants.culturalInformation: Leucophyllum langmaniae 'Lynn's Legacy' (Lynn's everblooming Texas sage), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with felted, sage green leaves and lightly fragrant, funnel-shaped, lavender flowers in late summer and early fall. Long-flowering selection of a species native to the Chihuahuan Desert in northern Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Best in hot-summer, mild-winter climates and alkaline soils. Sunset: 7-24

Leucophyllum species and cultivars (Texas ranger), evergreen shrubs, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with felted, silvery gray, gray-green, or green leaves and lightly fragrant, pink or purple, funnel-shaped flowers in late summer and early fall. Native to rocky soils in the Chihuahuan Desert from northeastern Mexico to southern Texas and New Mexico. Full sun, excellent drainage. Best in hot-summer, mild-winter climates and in alkaline soils. Sunset: 7-24

Leucophyta brownii (cushion bush), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with tiny, silvery white, scale-like leaves and small, button-shaped clusters of tiny, pale yellow to creamy white flowers in spring and summer. Native along the south coast of Australia from southwestern Western Australia to the north coast of Tasmania. Sun, fast drainage. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Calocephalus. Sunset: N/A

Leucospermum species and cultivars (pincushion bush), evergreen shrubs and small trees, variable, from mat-forming to upright and 3-15 feet tall and wide, with leathery, green to gray-green, narrowly oval leaves and large, round or cone-shaped heads of tiny, tightly clustered, narrowly tubular flowers whose protruding, brightly colored styles are the most prominent feature. Flowers are orange, red, pink, or creamy white and appear mostly in winter and early spring or almost year round in mild-winter climates. Native to highly specialized habitats and soils from South Africa to Botswana and Zimbabwe. Dozens of species and cultivars. Sun, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Not easy in cultivation. Sunset: 15-17,21-24

Lewisia columbiana var. rupicola (Columbia lewisia), succulent, 6 inches tall and 8-10 inches wide, upright rosette of fleshy, narrowly spoon-shaped, gray-green leaves and foot-tall leafless stems bearing airy sprays of small, white to pale pink or magenta flowers, often with purple veins, in spring and early summer. Forms offsets. Native to rocky cliffs and slopes west of the Cascades from southwestern British Columbia to northwestern Oregon. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Best along the coast. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: 1-7,14-17

Lewisia cotyledon (bitter root), succulent, 4-6 inches tall and 8-12 inches wide, flat rosette of oval to spoon-shaped, fleshy, dark green leaves and tall stems bearing sprays of pink, white, or yellow-orange flowers in spring. Forms offsets. Native to rocky soils in coastal mountains of southwestern Oregon and northern California. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage, neutral to acidic soils. Best along the coast. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: 1-7,14-17

Libertia species (libertia), perennials from rhizomes, 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, clump forming, with fans of upright or arching, grasslike to narrowly sword-shaped, green to bluish green or sometimes coppery orange leaves. Clusters of late spring to mid-summer, white flowers resembling orchids are held on stiff, branched stems usually well above the leaves. Some spread by rhizomes or stolons to form dense colonies. Species are native along the coast and in the mountains on both North and South islands, New Zealand, and in western South America from Colombia to Chile and Argentina. Cool sun to light shade, part shade or shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Ligustrum japonicum (Japanese privet), evergreen shrub or small, multitrunk tree, upright and fast growing to 8-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with leathery, oval to oblong, glossy, dark green leaves. Clusters of fragrant, creamy white flowers in late spring or early summer are followed by oval, dark purple, berrylike fruit. Spreads freely by seed and by suckering roots and can be weedy or invasive, especially in moist locations. Native to central and southern Japan and Korea. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-24

Ligustrum lucidum (glossy privet), evergreen shrub or small tree, 20-35 feet tall and wide, with leathery, dark green, oval to broadly lance-shaped leaves. Showy clusters of creamy white flowers in late spring or summer are followed by persistent, oval, blue-black berrylike fruit. Spreads by seed and can be highly invasive, especially in moist soils. Native to southern China and Korea. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 5-24

Ligustrum ovalifolium (California privet), semi-evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-15 feet tall and wide, with oval to elliptic, glossy, green leaves and showy, upright clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in summer. Flowers are followed by round, berrylike fruit that matures to black. May form dense thickets and can be weedy or invasive. Drops some leaves in winter and in summer if grown dry. Native to Japan and Korea. Variegated cultivars are available. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3b-24

Ligustrum sinense 'Sunshine' (Sunshine Chinese privet), evergreen shrub to 6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide with bright chartreuse to golden foliage gracefully arranged in attractive layers around the central stem. May be left natural or sheared for a more formal look. No flowers, non-invasive. Foliage turns more gold in sun or brighter shade. Cool coastal sun or part shade inland; may need to increase water to moderate in full sun inland locations. Most soils. Sunset zones: 4-24.

Lilium humboldtii (Humboldt lily), perennial from bulb, 5-8 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with whorls of bright green, wavy-edged, lance-shaped leaves on tall, upright stems topped by large, orange or yellow, pendant flowers with maroon-spotted, strongly reflexed petals and prominent stamens in summer. Dormant after flowering. Native to forest edges and open woodlands in foothills of the Sierra Nevada and coastal mountains of northern, central, and southern California. Part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 3,7,14-24

Lilium pardalinum (leopard lily), perennial from bulb, variable, 4-7 feet tall and less than 1 foot wide, with whorls of green, lance-shaped leaves on tall, upright, unbranched stems and large, pendant, red-orange flowers with maroon-spotted, strongly reflexed petals and prominent stamens in summer. Dormant after flowering. May spread to form large colonies. Native to streambanks, moist meadows, and other damp areas in coastal mountains and inland foothills from southern Oregon to northern Baja California. Cool sun to part shade or shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-7,14-17

Limonium perezii (statice), perennial from rhizome, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, basal rosette of large, wavy-edged, broadly oval or rounded triangular, dark green leaves and showy clusters of tiny, bicolored flowers with white petals and papery, purple sepals. Flowers are borne on branched, red stems well above the leaves nearly year round in mild climates. Native to the island of Tenerife in the Canary Islands. Sun, well-drained soils. Can be weedy or invasive in coastal riparian habitats. Sunset: 13,15-17,20-24

Linaria purpurea (toadflax), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with small, narrowly lance-shaped to linear, blue-gray leaves in whorls around stiffly upright stems topped with tall, narrow spikes of tubular, lavender-blue flowers in late spring and summer. Self-sows freely and can be weedy. Native to the Mediterranean region of southeastern Europe. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Linum species (flax), annuals, biennials, and short-lived perennials, 6 inches to 2 feet tall and wide, with small, linear to narrowly lance-shaped leaves and cup-shaped flowers with widely flared petals from spring to mid-summer. Most self-sow freely and some can be weedy or invasive. L. lewisii, a perennial native to dry slopes and ridges from Alaska to Baja California and east to the Mississippi River, is 1-2 feet tall and wide with pale to dark blue, lavender, or sometimes white flowers well above the leaves; may be offered as a variety of L. perenne, a similar plant native to Europe and Asia. L. grandiflorum, an annual native to the Mediterranean region, is 1-2 feet tall and 6-12 inches wide with gray-green leaves and pink or bright red flowers. L. flavum 'Compactum', 6 inches tall and wide, is a dwarf selection of a yellow-flowered perennial from the mountains of central and southern Europe. Several other species and cultivars are commonly available, usually as seed. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Lobelia cardinalis hybrids and cvs. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Lobelia laxiflora (Mexican lobelia), perennial or subshrub, mounding 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with long, narrow, mid-green leaves and red and yellow, tubular flowers from late spring to fall. Native to partially shaded slopes or seasonally damp washes from southern Arizona and northern Mexico intermittently to Colombia. Spreads by rhizomes and can be weedy or invasive, especially in moist soil. Cut back hard after flowering to renew. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Lobelia tupa (giant red lobelia), perennial or subshrub, 4-8 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with large, lance-shaped, felted, grayish green leaves on upright, purplish red stems topped by spikes of tubular, bright red flowers in mid- to late summer or fall. Self-sows and may spread by rooting stems to form small colonies. Native to sandy or gravelly soils along the coast and in coastal mountains of central Chile. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Lobostemon fruticosus (pajama bush), evergreen shrub or subshrub, fast growing to 3-4 feet tall and wide, with oval to elliptical, softly hairy, gray-green leaves on hairy stems and clusters of funnel-shaped flowers in subtle shades of pale blue and pink from early spring to mid-summer. Native to sandy or rocky slopes along the west coast of Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Lomandra longifolia (spiny headed mat rush), perennial, clump forming, 2-5 feet tall and wide, with grasslike or narrowly straplike, green leaves and flowering stems, usually shorter than the leaves, bearing clusters of tiny, whitish yellow, spring or summer flowers with noticeably bristly bracts. Native to varied habitats in eastern Australia. Breeze™ is 2-3 feet tall and wide with narrower, dark green leaves. Evergreen Baby™ is 18 inches tall and wide with even narrower, dark green leaves. Platinum Beauty™, 2-3 feet tall and wide, has green leaves with a white center stripe and white edges. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Lomatium californicum (California celery), perennial, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, basal clump of blue-green, triangular, deeply lobed leaves divided into lobed or serrated leaflets and 2- to 3-foot stems bearing broad, flat-topped umbels of clustered, tiny, yellow flowers in spring. Native to dry, rocky, usually shaded slopes in coastal mountains from southern Oregon to the western Transverse Ranges in southern California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Lonicera hispidula (California honeysuckle), deciduous to semi-evergreen shrubby vine, to 6-10 feet, with green to bluish green, oval leaves and clusters of fragrant, trumpet-shaped, lavender to bright pink flowers in spring and summer followed by red berries. Native to south- or west-facing slopes and forest openings, often along streambanks, from southwestern British Columbia to southern California. Best along the coast with leaves in sun and roots in shade. Sunset: N/A

Lonicera interrupta (chaparral honeysuckle), deciduous vining shrub, 5-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with oval to elliptical, green to bluish green leaves on wiry stems. Upright clusters of small, fragrant, trumpet-shaped, creamy white or pale yellow flowers in spring or early summer are followed by red berries. Native to rocky slopes and washes in mountains and foothills of southern Oregon, California, and Arizona. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good for dry shade. Sunset: N/A

Lonicera involucrata (twinberry), deciduous shrub, 4-12 feet tall and wide, with pointed oval to broadly lance-shaped, bright green leaves and tubular, yellow, sometimes red-tinted flowers in summer. Flowers are cupped by two green, leaflike bracts that turn dark red as paired, shiny, purplish black berries mature. Native to usually shaded, seasonally wet and riparian sites from southern Alaska east to Quebec and south through the western United States to northern Mexico. Cool sun to part shade, most soils, including boggy or periodically flooded. Sunset: N/A

Lonicera japonica (Japanese honeysuckle), semi-evergreen vine, fast growing to 15-30 feet tall, with oval, dark green leaves and fragrant, tubular, white flowers in summer followed by glossy, purplish black berries. Climbs by twining. Self-sows and spreads by rooting stems to form thickets; can be weedy. Highly invasive in the eastern and southern United States and in many other temperate regions of the world. Native to eastern China, Japan, and Korea. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Lonicera nitida (box honeysuckle), evergreen shrub, mounding to 6-8 feet tall and wide, with glossy, dark green, oval leaves on arching branches. Clusters of tubular, creamy white, sometimes fragrant flowers in late spring are followed by blue-purple berries. Native to sunny or partly shaded streamsides in the mountains of southwestern China. 'Baggesen's Gold' is 4-6 feet tall and wide and has bright yellow-green new leaves. 'Twiggy', a sport of 'Baggesen's Gold', is 2-3 feet tall and wide. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Lonicera subspicata, chaparral honeysuckle, evergreen vining shrub, 3-8 feet tall and wide, with oval, green to bluish green leaves and clusters of fragrant, trumpet-shaped, creamy white to pale yellow flowers in summer followed by red or yellow berries. Native to dry, west-facing slopes, usually partly shaded by other vegetation, in coastal mountains of central and southern California. Cool sun or part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Loropetalum chinense and cultivars (fringe flower), evergreen shrub, 8-12 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with small, oval to elliptical, olive green or reddish purple leaves on arching or horizontal branches and clusters of white to creamy white or pink flowers with frilly, narrow petals in spring. Native to forested slopes and open spaces from the mountains of northeastern India to China and Japan. Many cultivars, including compact plants 4-6 feet tall and 1- to 3-foot, mounding groundcovers. Sun to part shade, neutral to acidic, well-drained soils. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Lotus berthelotii (parrot's beak), perennial, 8-12 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with trailing stems bearing whorls of soft, silvery gray-green leaves divided into needlelike leaflets and bright red to red-orange, beaklike or clawlike flowers in spring and early summer. Drapes over rocks and walls. Native to the Canary Islands. Cool sun or light shade, excellent drainage. Best where summer nights are cool. Sunset: 9,15-24

Lotus corniculatus (birdsfoot trefoil), perennial, upright or sprawling, dense mat to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with green leaves divided into oval to elliptical leaflets resembling a three-leaf clover and tightly packed, flat-topped clusters of yellow pea flowers in summer. Native to grasslands and streambanks throughout much of Europe and western Asia and parts of northern Africa. Self-sows and spreads by rooting stems; can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most soils, including poorly drained and heavy clay. Sunset: N/A

Lupinus albifrons (silver lupine), evergreen shrub or sub-shrub, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with silvery gray-green leaves divided into lance-shaped leaflets and tall spikes of fragrant, blue-violet or purple pea flowers well above the leaves in spring and summer. Native to sandy or rocky soils in coastal mountains and inland foothills from southern Oregon to northern Baja California. Compact, low-growing forms are sometimes available. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Lupinus arboreus (coastal bush lupine), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-6 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into lightly hairy, green to gray-green, narrowly lance-shaped to linear leaflets and fragrant, usually yellow pea flowers from spring to mid-summer. Native to dunes and coastal bluffs from southern to central California and naturalized along the coast as far north as Vancouver Island. Self-sows freely and can be weedy or invasive. Blue-flowered forms may be hybrids. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 4-5,14-17,22-24

Lupinus excubitus (grape soda lupine), evergreen shrub or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with leaves divided into narrowly lance-shaped to linear, hairy, silvery gray-green leaflets and tall spikes of fragrant, purple pea flowers in spring or summer. Self-sows. Native to rocky or gravelly soils in mountains and deserts of southern and southeastern California, southern Nevada, and northwestern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Lupinus latifolius (broadleaf lupine), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and  wide, with green leaves divided into elliptic to lance-shaped leaflets and whorls of lavender-blue, sometimes white, pea flowers in early to late summer. Native to wooded slopes and moist mountain meadows from British Columbia to northern Baja California and east to Utah and New Mexico. Cool sun to part shade or shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Lychnis coronaria (rose campion), perennial, mounding 1-2 feet tall and wide, with soft, silvery gray, densely felted, lance-shaped leaves and 2- to 3-foot, gray-white stems bearing small, pink, magenta, or sometimes white, trumpet-shaped flowers with widely flared petals in summer. Native to southeastern Europe. Short-lived but self-sows freely. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Silene. Sunset: 1-9,14-24

Lygeum spartum (false Esparto grass), evergreen grass with stiff, narrow, bluish-grey-green leaves growing to 3 feet tall and forming a clump up to 4-5 feet wide. In spring curious straw-colored flowers appear, shaped like a small cranes head, they persist on the plant throughout the season. Native to the Mediterranean region of North Africa. Self-cleaning, it does not require spring pruning. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 7-9, 12-24

Lyonothamnus species (ironwood), evergreen tree, 25-50 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with dark green leaves, paler beneath, and clusters of creamy white flowers in late spring to early summer followed by persistent brown seedpods. Fibrous, reddish gray bark peels to reveal shiny, red underbark. Native to rocky soils on north-facing slopes on the Channel Islands. Usually available as subspecies aspleniifolius, with leaves divided into narrow, notched leaflets. Subspecies floribundus has smooth-edged, undivided leaves. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade inland, excellent drainage. Best near the coast. Sunset: 14-17,19-24

Macfadyena unguis-cati (cat's claw), evergreen vine, to 30-50 feet, with large, glossy, dark green leaves divided into two, oval to lance-shaped leaflets. Bright yellow, trumpet-shaped flowers in spring are followed by long, linear seed capsules. Native to forests from Mexico to Argentina. Climbs by clawlike tendrils and aerial roots. Self-sows and spreads by tubers; can be highly invasive in riparian zones. Sun to part shade, most soils. Cut back hard after flowering to control size. May be offered as Dolichandra. Sunset: 8-24

Macropidia fuliginosa (black kangaroo paw), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fans of sword-shaped, bluish gray-green leaves. Branched, 3- to 4-foot stems bear chartreuse flowers with dense, black hairs and pendulous stamens from mid-spring to mid-summer. Native to sandy or gravelly soils a few miles inland from the coast of southwestern Western Australia. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Not easy in cultivation. Sunset: N/A

Mahonia oiwakensis (Chinese holly grape), evergreen shrub, stiffly upright to 6-12 feet tall and 6 feet wide, with 2-foot long, horizontal to arching leaves divided into many dark bluish green leaflets with spiny margins. Densely clustered upright spikes of small, lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in winter or early spring are followed by blue-black, berrylike fruit. Native to forest edges and openings in central and southwestern China. Part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as M. lomariifolia. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Maireana sedifolia (pearl bluebush), evergreen shrub, upright to 3-4 feet tall and wide, with grayish, nearly white, semi-succulent leaves and inconspicuous pinkish white flowers in spring. Native to inland, arid and semi-arid parts of South Australia. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Malacothamnus fasciculatus (bush mallow), evergreen shrub, variable, fast growing to 4-12 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with oval to rounded, sometimes lobed, softly hairy, gray-green leaves and long clusters of upfacing, cup-shaped, pale pink flowers in late spring and summer. Spreads by rooting stems to form thickets. Native to dry slopes and canyons in mountains of central and southern California and northern Baja California. Sun, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Malacothamnus fremontii (Fremont's bush mallow), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-6 feet tall and wide, spreading to form thickets, with oval to rounded, lobed, hairy, silvery gray-green leaves on stiffly upright, branching stems and elongated clusters of pale purplish pink, cup-shaped flowers in spring and summer. Native to woodlands and shrub-lands in mountains and foothills of California and Baja California. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Cut back in fall to renew. Sunset: N/A

Malacothamnus jonesii (Jones's bush mallow), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 4-8 feet tall and wide, with oval to rounded or almost triangular, densely hairy, lobed, gray-green leaves on upright, branching stems and loose clusters of pale pinkish purple, cup-shaped flowers in late spring and summer. Native to woodlands and shrublands in coastal mountains of central California. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Malacothamnus palmeri (Palmer's mallow), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-8 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with oval, lobed, hairy, gray-green leaves on upright, branching stems and elongated clusters of pale pink or white, cup-shaped flowers in summer. Native to mixed evergreen forest and shrublands in coastal mountains and foothills of central California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Malephora species (iceplant), mat-forming succulents with soft and somewhat waxy, cylindrical to triangular, bright green to bluish gray-green, sometimes red-tinged leaves and yellow, orange, or coppery red daisy flowers in spring and intermittently year round. Flowers close in the evening and open mid-day. Native to sandy soils in southern Africa from southern Namibia south to the Western Cape and east to the Eastern Cape and Free State. M. crocea, less than 1 foot tall and spreading 4-6 feet wide, has cylindrical, fingerlike, gray-green leaves and coppery orange flowers. M. lutea is similar but with triangular, green leaves and yellow flowers. Drape over rocks and walls. Self-sow and spread by rooting stems; can be weedy or invasive, especially in mild coastal areas. Sun, most well-drained soils, including saline. May be offered as Mesembryanthemum. Sunset: zones vary

Malosma laurina (laurel sumac), evergreen shrub to small tree, fast growing to 8-20 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with large, lance-shaped, aromatic, green leaves with red margins and large clusters of tiny, fragrant, white flowers in late spring and early summer. Native to sandy or rocky slopes in coastal mountains and valleys from Point Conception and the Channel Islands to Baja California. Sun to part shade, good drainage. May be offered as Rhus. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Malus spp.(edible) e.g''Anna'' (low chill variety for low desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Malva assurgentiflora (tree mallow) evergreen shrub, fast growing to 8-12 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, with large, dark green, maplelike leaves and showy pinkish lavender flowers with white stripes from mid-spring to late summer. Native to coastal bluffs on the Channel Islands in coastal southern California and naturalized on the coastal mainland. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Lavatera. Sunset: 14-24

Mammilaria geminispina (cactus), succulent, variable, slow growing, spherical to short columnar, green stem covered with silvery white spines and woolly white hairs that give the plant a gray-white appearance. At maturity a ring of small, pink to magenta, funnel-shaped flowers near the top of the stem open a few at a time in late summer or fall. Offsets to form a tight, mounding cluster of spiny stems to 1 foot tall and 1-3 feet wide. Native to rocky soils in mountains of east-central Mexico. Prefers a dryish winter. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Marrubium bourgaei 'All Hallows Green' (horehound), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with rough-textured, lime green leaves and small, greenish to creamy white flowers in spring. Species is native to rocky soils in mountains of Turkey and parts of western Asia. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Ballota. Sunset: N/A

Mathiasella bupleuroides (green dream), perennial, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with bluish gray-green, lobed, finely serrated leaves and clusters of tiny, green flowers surrounded by a cup of lime green bracts in spring and early summer. Bracts take on pink tones in late summer and fall. Native to northeastern Mexico. Cool sun to light shade or shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as the cultivar 'Green Dream'. Sunset: N/A

Melaleuca armillaris (bracelet honey myrtle), evergreen tree or large shrub, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, multi-trunk or low branching, with mid-green, sharply pointed, needle-like leaves and peeling, gray bark. Brush-like spikes of creamy white flowers in late spring and summer are followed by woody seed capsules. Native to coastal southeastern Australia. Good seaside plant. Can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most soils, including saline. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Melaleuca elliptica (granite honey-myrtle), evergreen shrub, upright and arching, fast growing to 8-12 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, leathery, narrowly oval to elliptical, bluish gray-green leaves, new growth bronzy, and papery, peeling bark. Brushlike spikes of red flowers in late spring and summer are followed by woody seed capsules. Native to rocky outcrops in coastal southern Western Australia. Sun, most soils, including poorly drained but not flooded. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Melaleuca incana (gray honey-myrtle), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-10 feet tall and wide, with thin, weeping branches bearing soft, fine-textured, linear to elliptical, bluish gray-green leaves, new growth pale green and winter color sometimes purplish. Brushlike spikes of pale creamy yellow flowers in late spring and early summer are followed by small, woody seed capsules. Native to sandy soils in southwestern Western Australia, often in seasonally wet locations. Low-growing, trailing forms are available. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Melaleuca lanceolata (black tea), evergreen shrub or small tree, slow growing to 15-25 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, densely covered with small, flattened, linear to almost needlelike, aromatic, dark green leaves. Brushlike spikes of creamy white flowers in spring are followed by tight clusters of small, round, woody seed capsules. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. Native to coastal cliffs and dunes in southeastern Australia. Sun, most soils, including periodically flooded. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Melaleuca linariifolia (flaxleaf paperbark), evergreen shrub or small tree, often multitrunk, 20-30 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with stiff, gray-green or bluish green, narrowly linear leaves, papery, white, peeling bark, and clusters of white, brushlike flowers in summer followed by persistent, woody seed capsules. Native to coastal southeastern Australia, usually near streams or in areas with periodic flooding. Sun, most soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 9,13-24

Melaleuca nesophila (pink melaleuca), evergreen shrub or small tree, 15-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with small, linear to oval, bright green leaves, spongy, peeling, grayish white bark, and clusters of brushlike, lavender flowers for much of the year. Fruit is a woody seed capsule. Native to the southwestern coast of Western Australia. Sun, most soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 13,16-24

Melaleuca styphelioides (prickly leaved paperbark), evergreen tree, 25-40 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with small, light green leaves with sharply pointed tips, papery white or gray-brown, peeling bark, and clusters of brushlike, creamy white flowers in summer followed by grayish brown, woody seed capsules. Native to southeastern Australia, often along creeks. Sun, most soils. Accepts heavy soils. Sunset: 9,13-24

Melaleuca viridiflora var. rubriflora (cajeput tree), evergreen shrub or tree, fast growing to 20-40 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with papery, peeling, brownish white bark and long, narrowly oval to lance-shaped, glossy, mid-green leaves. Brushlike spikes of pink to red flowers in late spring and summer are followed by woody seed capsules. Native to summer-rainfall eastern and northern Australia and New Guinea. Invasive in wet locations and listed in the United States as a federal noxious weed. Sun, most soils, including periodically flooded and saline. May be offered as M. quinquenervia. Sunset: 13,19-24

Melampodium leucanthum (blackfoot daisy), perennial, 6-12 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, dark gray-green, hairy leaves and fragrant, bright white daisy flowers with yellow centers from spring to fall. Self-sows freely. Native to dry, rocky soils from southern Colorado to central Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Needs summer heat. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 2-3,10-13

Melia azedarach (chinaberry), deciduous tree, variable, fast growing to 30-50 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with leaves divided into oval to elliptical, dark green leaflets and loose spikes of fragrant, star-shaped, white, pale pink, or lilac flowers in spring. Flowers are followed by yellow, berrylike fruits. Native to both wet and dry habitats and well-drained to poorly drained soils from northern India to central China and southeastern Asia. Self-sows freely and spreads by root sprouts to form dense stands. Variegated and multitrunk cultivars are available. Sun to light shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. Adaptable. Can be weedy or invasive in warm climates, especially in wet locations. Sunset: N/A

Melianthus major (honey bush), evergreen shrub or subshrub, fast growing and upright or sprawling to 8-12 feet tall and wide, with large, coarse-textured, aromatic leaves divided into many sharply serrated, bluish to silvery green leaflets. Upright, narrow spikes of tubular, reddish brown to maroon flowers with green stamens in late winter and early spring are followed by pale green, papery, beanlike seedpods. Native to southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Summer dormant. Self-sows and spreads rapidly by suckering roots; can be weedy or invasive. Sun to part shade, most soils. Cut back hard to renew. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Melianthus minor (honey bush), evergreen shrub, 5-6 feet tall and wide, with aromatic leaves divided into mid-green, lightly hairy leaflets with deeply toothed or serrated margins. Loose clusters of reddish orange, tubular flowers in late spring to mid-summer are followed by inflated seedpods. Similar to M. major but smaller, with smaller, greener leaves and flowers held within instead of above the foliage. Native to the Cape provinces, South Africa, and southern Namibia. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Self-sows and can be weedy, especially in coastal areas. Sunset: N/A

Melianthus villosus (honey bush), perennial, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, bluish green leaves divided into many lance-shaped leaflets with serrated margins. Upright spikes of maroon summer flowers with dark brown bracts are followed by bright green, inflated seedpods. Native to moist forest edges in the Drakensberg Mountains of southern Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Cut back in spring before new growth appears. Sunset: N/A

Melica californica (onion grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1 foot tall and wide, with narrow, bright green leaves and small, airy spring flowers with translucent, papery bracts on 2- to 3-foot stems. Native to the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills of central to northern California and southwestern Oregon. Self-sows. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Dormant by mid-summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Melica imperfecta, Coast Range onion grass, cool-season bunchgrass, 1 foot tall and wide, with narrow, green to yellowish green leaves and small, airy flowers with translucent, papery bracts on 2- to 3-foot stems in spring. Native to dry, rocky hillsides in coastal mountains of central to southern California, foothills of the southern Sierra Nevada, the western Mojave desert, and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Dormant by mid-summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Melica torreyana, Torrey's melic, cool-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, grayish green leaves and small, airy spring flowers that age to purplish white. Native to chaparral and forests in central California coastal mountains and Sierra Nevada foothills. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Dormant by mid-summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Mentha spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Mentha species (mint), perennials with aromatic leaves with serrated margins and small, usually purplish to white flowers in spring or summer. Native to many habitats, most often moist and at least part shady, across North America, Europe, Africa, Asia, and Australia. Many species and cultivars. Two species are native to North America, including California. M. arvensis, native to much of North America, is 6-18 inches tall with clusters of tiny, white, pink, or lavender flowers. M. canadensis, native to damp areas from the Northwest Territories to central Mexico, is less than a foot to 18 inches tall with clusters of tiny, blue-violet flowers. M. canadensis may be offered as a variety of M. arvensis. Most mints spread rapidly by stolons or rhizomes and some can be weedy or invasive. Sun to part shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: zones vary

Metrosideros excelsa (New Zealand Christmas tree), evergreen tree, usually multitrunk, 20-35 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with leathery, oval to oblong, dark olive green leaves, white hairy beneath, and brushlike clusters of bright red, pink, or sometimes yellow or white flowers with prominent stamens in late spring or summer. Native to coastal northern North Island, New Zealand. Compact cultivars are sometimes available. Sun to part shade, well-drained, neutral to alkaline soils. May be offered as M. tomentosa. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 16-17,23-24

Mimulus aurantiacus (sticky monkeyflower), perennial or subshrub, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with linear to lance-shaped, glossy, dark green, resinous leaves and orange or yellow, sometimes red or creamy white, trumpet-shaped flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky or sandy soils in many habitats from southwestern Oregon to Baja California. Dormant and semi-deciduous in mid-summer where summers are hot, perking up again with fall rains. Most plants offered are selections or hybrids of six naturally occurring varieties that differ in several flower and leaf characteristics. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be short-lived in heavy soils. May be offered as Diplacus. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

photos.filename: Mimulus aurantiacus var. puniceus (red bush monkeyflower)
photos.caption: Mimulus aurantiacus var. puniceus (red bush monkeyflower)

plants.culturalInformation: Mimulus aurantiacus var. puniceus (red bush monkeyflower), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with dark green, resinous, linear to lance-shaped leaves and bright red or red-orange, trumpet-shaped flowers in winter to spring. Native to dry, rocky slopes and woodland openings in coastal southern California and northern Baja California. Semi-deciduous in summer. Cool sun to part shade, part shade inland, well-drained soils. Prefers a dry summer dormancy. May be offered as Diplacus puniceus. Sunset: N/A

Mirabilis laevis var. crassifolia (wishbone bush), perennial or subshrub, 1-3 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, with small, oval to rounded, lightly hairy, gray green leaves and small clusters of broadly funnel-shaped, lavender, pink, purple, or sometimes white flowers in winter and spring. Native to meadows, washes, and dry, rocky places in coastal central and southern California and northern Baja California. Self-sows and spreads by rooting stems. Drops some leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as M. californica. Sunset: N/A

Monardella macrantha (scarlet mondardella), perennial, 6 inches to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, aromatic leaves and clusters of showy, bright red to red-orange, tubular flowers in late spring to early summer. Native to coastal mountains of central and southern California to Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Not easy in cultivation. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Monardella odoratissima (mountain pennyroyal), perennial, variable, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 2 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped to narrowly elliptic, green or gray-green, sometimes hairy leaves on stiffly upright, branched stems. Small, dense, rounded or flat-topped clusters of tiny, fragrant, pinkish purple to white flowers are held in a cup of purplish green bracts in summer. Native to dry, rocky places in foothills and mountains, mostly east of the Cascades, from British Columbia to Baja California and east to Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico. Cool sun to part shade or shade, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 1-3,7-10,14-24

Monardella villosa (coyote mint), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-green to blue-green leaves and spherical clusters of bright lavender or pinkish purple, tubular flowers in late spring to early summer. Native to the Sierra Nevada foothills and Coast Ranges from central California to southern Oregon. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Moraea species (moraea), perennials from corms with one to a few or many strap-shaped, green to bluish green leaves and blue, white, purple, pink, yellow, or orange, sometimes fragrant, irislike flowers with decorative markings in contrasting colors. Some flower in spring while others flower in fall or winter. Some spread by offsets, others by seed or by stolons. Most are native to the grasslands of winter-rainfall southern Africa, especially South Africa's Northern and Western Cape provinces, the arid or semi-arid Karoo, and summer-rainfall Eastern Cape. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Morella californica (Pacific wax myrtle), evergreen shrub, usually multitrunked, upright to 10-20 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, glossy, green leaves and inconspicuous flowers and fruits. Native to coastal and inland foothills and valleys from southwestern British Columbia to southern California. Sun along the coast, afternoon shade inland, most soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Myrica. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Muehlenbeckia complexa (maidenhair vine), semi-evergreen vine, fast growing, climbing by twining to 20-30 feet tall or a dense mat sprawling along the ground, with small, almost round, glossy green leaves on wiry, dark stems and tiny, fragrant, greenish white flowers in spring. Native to coastal and inland mountains of North and South islands, New Zealand. Drapes over rocks and walls. Can be weedy or invasive. Can be cut back hard to shape or control spread. Sun or shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as M. axillaris, which is a much smaller plant. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

photos.filename: Muhlenbergia capillaris and cultivars (hairy awn muhly)
photos.caption: Muhlenbergia capillaris and cultivars (hairy awn muhly)

plants.culturalInformation: Muhlenbergia capillaris and cultivars (hairy awn muhly), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with fine-textured, wiry, dark green leaves and tall plumes of purplish pink flowers in late summer or fall followed by a haze of airy seedheads. Native to grasslands and open woodlands from Massachusetts to Kansas south to Florida and west to Texas. 'White Cloud' is taller and more erect with white flowers. Self-sows. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 4-24

Muhlenbergia dubia (pine muhly), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and 2 feet wide, with fine-textured, bright green leaves and tall plumes of purple-tinged, creamy white flowers in late summer and fall. Self-sows but not aggressively. Native to desert mountains from Arizona to southwestern Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 3b,7-24

Muhlenbergia dumosa (bamboo muhly), warm-season grass, 4-6 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes to 3-6 feet wide, with bright green, linear leaves 3-4 inches long arrayed along narrow, semi-woody, branched stems. Resembles an extremely fine-textured bamboo. Small flowers mostly hidden among the leaves cover the plant with a pinkish green haze in late fall. Native to southern Arizona and northern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Cut back in winter to renew. Sunset: 8-24

Muhlenbergia emersleyi (bull grass), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fine-textured, bluish gray-green leaves and tall plumes of early-summer purplish pink flowers that age to tan. Native to rocky slopes in open woodlands from Arizona to western Texas and south through the mountains to southern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 2-24

Muhlenbergia lindheimeri (Lindheimer muhly), warm-season bunchgrass, upright to 3-5 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with fine-textured, medium green to bluish gray leaves and 5- to 6-foot stems with showy, purple-tinged, late-summer flowers that age to silvery gray. Self-sows but not aggressively. Native to central Texas and northern Mexico. Autumn Glow™ has creamy white flowers. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 6-24

Muhlenbergia pubescens (soft muhly), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with finely hairy, bluish gray-green, arching leaves that turn reddish purple in fall and airy spikes of purplish gray-green flowers on stems 2-3 feet above the leaves in summer and fall that mature to tan. Native to rocky slopes in central, northeastern, and southwestern Mexico. Sun or light shade, well-drained soils. Does not need cutting back. Sunset: 8-24

Muhlenbergia rigens (deer grass), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with narrow, arching, bright green to gray-green leaves and tall plumes of yellow to purplish flowers followed by airy seedheads in late summer and fall. Native to many habitats from northern California south to Mexico and east to Texas. Self-sows. Sun or light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Good seaside grass. Sunset: 4-24

Myoporum parvifolium (myoporum), evergreen shrub, fast growing, dense mat 6-8 inches tall and 6-10 feet wide, with small, finely toothed, linear to narrowly oblong, mid-green leaves, new growth sometimes purplish, and bell-shaped, white or pale pink flowers in spring and summer. Native to coastal eastern South Australia. Spreads by rooting stems. Sun or light shade, most well-drained soils, including saline. Short lived. Drapes over walls. Good seaside plant. Adaptable. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Myrsine africana (African boxwood), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with small, aromatic, leathery, dark green leaves, new growth reddish, and inconspicuous yellow flowers in spring. Native to both summer- and winter-rainfall regions of eastern and southern Africa and parts of Asia. Sun to light shade, most soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Myrtus communis (myrtle), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 6-10 feet tall and wide, with small, aromatic, glossy, dark green leaves, new growth reddish, and small, fragrant, white flowers with long, yellow stamens in summer. Native to Mediterranean regions of southern Europe, northern Africa, and western Asia. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-24

Nandina domestica and cultivars (heavenly bamboo), evergreen shrub, 1-8 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with large, green, feathery leaves divided into oval to lance-shaped leaflets, new growth reddish, and long, arching sprays of tiny, white flowers in spring. Flowers are followed by small, green berries that mature to bright red and persist into fall and winter. Leaves turn red in fall. Self-sows and spreads by rhizomes; can be weedy or invasive. Native to northern India, China, and Japan. Many cultivars, including compact plants, plants with especially fine-textured leaves, and plants with dark purple leaves. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 4-24

Narcissus species (daffodil), perennials from bulbs with strap-shaped to narrow, almost rush-like leaves and late winter or early spring flowers, singly or in small clusters. Flowers are yellow, white, or some combination of the two with petals surrounding a central trumpet-shaped structure. Native to the western Mediterranean region, especially southwestern Spain and Portugal. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Summer dormant. Need moisture in late winter to bloom well. Sunset: 1-24,A2-A3

Nauplius sericeus (Canary Island daisy), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with rosettes of thick, silvery green, silky haired, broadly lance-shaped to oblong leaves at the tips of upright, dark gray stems. Large, bright yellow daisy flowers arise from the centers of the rosettes from late winter to early summer. Native to rocky slopes along the coast and in the mountains on the island of Fuerteventura, Canary Islands. Short lived, but may self-sow. Sun, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. May be offered as Asteriscus or as Odontospermum. Sunset: 16-17,19-24

Neomarica caerulea (walking iris), perennial from rhizomes, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with dark green, stiffly upright, sword-shaped leaves. Large, violet-blue, irislike flowers with darker blue, white, and reddish brown markings are borne on sturdy, upright, 4- to 5-foot stems in late spring and summer. Flowers last only a day but new flowers continue to open for weeks. Offsets form at the ends of the flowering stems, bending stems to the ground where they root. Native to partly shaded forests and woodlands in subtropical southern Brazil. Self-sows and spreads by rhizomes and offsets; can be invasive in warm, humid climates. Sun to part shade or shade, fast drainage. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: 16-17,21-24

Nepeta species (catmint), perennials, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, silvery gray-green leaves and upright spikes of lavender-blue flowers in summer. Most are native to the Mediterranean region, from southern Europe and northern Africa to southwestern Asia. N. x faassenii 'Select Blue', 18 inches tall and wide, has darker blue-violet flowers. N. x faassenii 'Six Hills Giant' and N.  x faassenii 'Walker's Low', both 2-3 feet tall and 4 feet wide, are especially vigorous and long blooming. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 1-24

Nerine species (nerine), perennials from bulbs, with narrowly strap-shaped, green leaves and round-topped to spherical clusters of pink, sometimes red or white, funnel-shaped flowers with prominent stamens and narrow, often wavy-edged petals curled back at the tips. Flowers are borne on leafless stems before, after, or along with the leaves. Most species are native to rocky soils in arid or semi-arid parts of summer-rainfall southern Africa, especially South Africa. Most plants offered are selections or hybrids of N. sarniensis, a winter-growing species from winter-rainfall Western Cape Province, N. undulata, a summer-growing species from summer-rainfall Eastern Cape Province, and N. bowdenii, a summer-growing species from the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal. Summer-growing species tend to prefer a dry winter rest. All need moisture during the growing season to bloom well. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-6,8-9,13-24

Nerium oleander and cultivars (oleander), evergreen shrub to small tree, 6-18 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with leathery, lance-shaped, mid-green leaves and clusters of showy white, pink, or red flowers from spring to fall followed by long, narrow seed capsules. Native to or naturalized throughout the Mediterranean region east to parts of Asia, usually along intermittent streams. Many cultivars add yellow, pale orange, purplish pink, multicolored, and double flowers as well as compact plants 2-5 feet tall and wide. Best in hot-summer, mild-winter climates. Good coastal plant. Sun, most soils. Sunset: 8-16,18-24
