Nolina species (CA native and non-native), bear grass, 3-4 feet tall and wide, succulent rosettes of grasslike, strap-shaped, or narrowly sword-shaped, green leaves with finely serrated margins but no spines and dense clusters of tiny, fragrant, white or greenish white flowers on tall, branched stalks in spring. Some slowly form short or tall, sometimes partially underground stems or trunks. Native to rocky slopes in high-desert grasslands and woodlands of western North America. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Need summer heat. Sunset: zones vary

Notholithocarpus densiflorus (tanbark oak) evergreen tree or large shrub, variable, slow growing to 65-80 feet tall and 20 to 50 feet wide, sometimes shrubby to 10 feet tall, with leathery, oblong, toothed, dark olive green leaves, pale tan and felted beneath. Small, white flowers are borne in upright catkins and followed by oaklike acorns. Native to forests in coastal mountains from southwestern Oregon south to the Transverse Ranges above Santa Barbara and intermittently in the northern Sierra Nevada. Cool sun to part shade or shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Lithocarpus. Sunset: 4-7,14-24

Oemleria cerasiformis, osoberry, deciduous shrub, 8-15 feet tall and suckering to form thickets 10-15 feet wide, with medium green, oblong to lance-shaped leaves, pale gray-green beneath, and pendant clusters of small, fragrant, greenish white, bell-shaped flowers in late winter or early spring. Native to forest edges and openings west of the Cascades and Sierra Nevada from southern British Columbia to central California. Cool sun to part shade or shade, humusy, acidic soils. Can be cut back hard to renew. May be offered as Osmaronia. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Oenothera californica (California evening primrose), perennial, variable, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and spreading 8-10 feet wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaves, often wavy-edged, toothed, or lobed, and large, fragrant, bowl-shaped, white flowers with bright yellow centers in late winter or early spring. Flowers open in the evening. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in open woodlands, shrublands, and high-desert dunes from California and southern Nevada to northern Baja California, Arizona, and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Oenothera macrocarpa (Missouri evening primrose), perennial, 6 inches to 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped, green leaves and large, cup-shaped, lightly fragrant, bright yellow flowers in summer followed by papery, winged seedpods. Native to the southern and central United States and northern Mexico, usually in full sun and rocky or sandy soils. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as M. missouriensis. Sunset: 1-24

Oenothera speciosa (Mexican evening primrose), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes, with linear or lance-shaped, mid-green leaves and large, pink or white, bowl-shaped flowers with white centers and pink or red veins in spring. Each flower lasts only a day. Native to rocky soils in grasslands from Missouri and Kansas to Texas and northeastern Mexico. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as O. berlandieri. Sunset: 2b-24

Olea europaea (olive), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-35 feet tall and wide, with gray-green, lance-shaped leaves, silvery beneath, small, white flowers, and oval, green fruits. Native to the Mediterranean region, from southern Europe and northern Africa to southwestern Asia. Fruit drop can be messy and trees can spread invasively. Fruitless cultivars have been developed, but all may produce a few fruits occasionally. 'Majestic Beauty' is said to fruit the least. Full sun, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,11-24

plants.botanicalName: Ophiopogon planiscapus var. nigrescens SHADE in desert
Opuntia spp. & cvs. (CA natives and non-natives)

plants.culturalInformation: Origanum species and cultivars (oregano), perennials from rhizomes, a few inches to 2 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with small, green to gray-green, often aromatic leaves and late-summer clusters of tiny flowers with small bracts or inconspicuous flowers within elongating spikes of large, overlapping bracts. Most are native to mountains of southern Europe, North Africa, and western Asia. May spread by rhizomes or by rooting stems. Sun to part shade, fast-draining soils. Sunset: zones vary

Ornithogalum thyrsoides (chincherinchee), perennial from bulb, 12-18 inches tall and 6 inches wide, with a few strap-shaped, bright green leaves and conical spikes of cup-shaped, white flowers on leafless stems in late spring to mid-summer. Dormant after flowering. Native to winter-rainfall Western and Northern Cape provinces, South Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: 4-24

photos.filename: Ornithostaphylos oppositifolia (palo blanco or Baja birdbush)
photos.caption: Ornithostaphylos oppositifolia (palo blanco or Baja birdbush)

plants.culturalInformation: Ornithostaphylos oppositifolia (palo blanco or Baja birdbush), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 15 feet tall and 10 feet wide, with leathery, linear, dark green leaves and, smooth, reddish brown bark. Clusters of small, urn-shaped, white flowers in winter or spring are followed by small, berrylike fruit. Native to northern Baja California and adjacent slopes just north of the border in San Diego County. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Orthrosanthus var. chimboracensis centroamericanus  now O. monadelphus

plants.culturalInformation: Orthrosanthus multiflorus (blue flag), perennial from rhizomes, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with fans of narrowly strap-shaped or grasslike, dark green leaves and loose spikes of star-shaped, blue flowers on upright stems in late spring and summer. Each flower lasts only a day. Native to coastal southern Australia. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Light shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 14-17,19-24

Oscularia deltoides (pink iceplant), succulent, 3-6 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, blue-gray leaves with softly toothed margins on red stems and masses of magenta daisy flowers with yellow centers in spring and summer. Native to rocky soils in low mountains of southwestern Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Lampranthus. Sunset: 14-24

Osteospermum species (African daisy), perennials and subshrubs, 1-3 feet tall and wide, upright, mounding, or trailing, with lance-shaped to oblong, sometimes lobed or toothed, green to gray-green leaves and showy, white, pink, yellow, purple, or bicolored daisy flowers from spring to fall in cooler climates and in spring in hot climates. Flowers close at night or on overcast days. Native to sandy or rocky soils in southern Africa and parts of the Arabian peninsula, often along the coast or at higher elevations. Most plants offered are hybrids of several species. Cool sun to light shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Dimorphotheca. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pachycereus marginatus (Mexican fence post cactus), cactus, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall or more, with a stiffly upright, green, cylindrical stem with five to seven ribs, each accented with a prominent white, longitudinal stripe of areoles or buds bearing short, sharp spines. Showy, tubular, pinkish red flowers among the spines in spring are followed by spiny, yellowish to red fruit. New stems or branches develop at the base, gradually forming a clump 6-10 feet wide. Native to central Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. May be offered as Stenocereus. Sunset: N/A

Pachypodium lamerei (pachypodium), Madagascar palm, succulent shrub, slow growing to 4-8 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with a thick, gray, water storing stem covered with long, stout, hooked spines and topped by a spiral arrangement of long, linear to lance-shaped, dark green leaves that are deciduous in winter when the plant is dormant. At maturity large, fragrant, white, summer flowers with twisted petals are followed by long, curved fruit. Native to dry forests in the fog belt of southern and southwestern Madagascar. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Prefers a dry winter dormancy. Sunset: N/A

Pallenis maritima (gold coin), perennial, 1 foot tall and 3-4 feet wide, with small, spoon-shaped, green leaves and small, bright yellow daisy flowers in spring and summer. Native to the Mediterranean region along the coast from the Canary Islands to Greece. Sun, good drainage. Best near the coast and in sandy soils. May be offered as Asteriscus 'Gold Coin' or as Odontospermum. Sunset: N/A

Panicum species (panic grass), several hundred species of annual or perennial, warm-season grasses native to tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate regions of the world, including warmer parts of Europe and North America. A diverse collection of species, most with flowers in loose, branching clusters but ranging from sod-forming to clumping, from leaves mostly basal to leafy stemmed, from barely 1 foot to 10 feet tall, and from open and sunny to shaded natural habitats. Some can be invasive outside their native range. Cultural requirements vary. Sunset: N/A

Panicum virgatum and cultivars (switch grass), warm-season grass, clumping or sod-forming, usually stiffly upright to 3-5 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrow, mid-green to blue-green leaves that age to various shades of yellow in fall. Airy spikes of red- or pink-tinged summer flowers rise a foot or more above the leaves. Spreads slowly by short rhizomes and may self-sow. Native to grasslands and open woodlands throughout much of North America, mostly east of the Rocky Mountains. Many cultivars, some of which are especially colorful or especially tall in bloom. 'Blue Tower' and 'Cloud Nine' are up to 8 feet tall in flower. Blue-green leaves of 'Shenandoah' and 'Prairie Fire' turn dark reddish purple in summer. Sun to part shade, most soils, including periodically flooded. Sunset: 1-11,14-23

Parkinsonia 'Desert Museum' (palo verde) deciduous tree or large shrub, fast growing to 20-35 feet tall and wide, with bright green leaves, lime-green bark, and fragrant, funnel-shaped, bright yellow flowers in spring. Seedless, thornless hybrid involving three potentially invasive and thorny species from the southwestern United States and Mexico: P. aculeata, P. florida, and P. microphylla. Full sun, fast drainage. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Best inland; prone to powdery mildew along the coast. May be offered as Cercidium. Sunset: 8-14,18-20

Parkinsonia aculeata (Mexican palo verde), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 12-25 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk or low-branching, with mid-green leaves divided into many tiny, oval leaflets on spiny, bright green to yellowish green branches. Fragrant, bright yellow pea flowers with one red-orange petal in mid-spring and early summer are followed by brown, beanlike seedpods. Native to arid regions from southern Arizona to western Texas and south through Mexico and Central America. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. May form dense thickets. Self-sows freely and can be weedy or invasive. Fruit drop can be messy. Sun, most soils, including saline. Best inland. May be offered as Cercidium. Sunset: 8-24

Parkinsonia florida (blue palo verde), semi-deciduous tree or large shrub, 20-30 feet tall and wide, multitrunk or low branching, with leaves divided into small, oval, bluish green leaflets on spiny, green branches. Showy clusters of bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. May bloom again in summer following rains. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in desert washes of central and southwestern Arizona, southeastern California, northern Baja California, and northwestern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cercidium. Sunset: 8-14,18-20

Parkinsonia praecox (palo brea), semi-evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-30 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk or low branching, with gray-green leaves divided into many small, oval leaflets on spiny, smooth, lime green branches. Showy, yellow pea flowers in late spring are followed by beanlike seedpods. Native to arid climates from Baja California south into arid parts of northern South America. Fruit drop can be messy. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cercidium. Sunset: 10-14,18-20

Parrotia persica (Persian witch hazel) deciduous tree or large shrub, usually multitrunk, slow growing to 20-35 feet tall and wide, with peeling bark and broad, deeply veined, oval leaves that emerge reddish purple in spring, mature to dark green, and turn yellow, orange, and bright red in fall. Early spring flowers lack petals, but red stamens are showy on bare branches. Native to the mountains of Azerbaijan and northern Iran. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Best in cool-summer climates. Sunset: 2b-7,14-17

Parthenocissus tricuspidata (Boston ivy), deciduous or semi-evergreen vine, fast growing to 30-50 feet, with large, glossy, dark green, usually three-lobed leaves that turn bright red in fall. Inconspicuous, greenish white flowers in late spring are followed by purplish black, berrylike fruits mostly hidden among the leaves. Climbs by branching tendrils with adhesive pads. Native to Japan and eastern China. Sun to part shade or shade, most soils. Adaptable. Several cultivars, varying mostly in leaf size and color. Sunset: 1-24

Pelargonium peltatum (ivy geranium), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with glossy, bright green, somewhat fleshy, lobed leaves on trailing branches and rounded clusters of small. red, pink, lavender, or white flowers from spring through fall. Cascades over walls. Native to coastal southern South Africa. Many plants offered are hybrids. Cool sun to light shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Best where summer nights are cool. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pelargonium sidoides (South African geranium) 12-18 inches tall and wide, with small, heart-shaped, gray-green leaves and small, dark burgundy, almost black flowers on long, narrow, branching stems in spring and summer. Native to rocky soils in summer-rainfall grasslands of Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pelargonium tomentosum (peppermint-scented geranium), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with soft, finely hairy, aromatic, green leaves and clusters of small, white flowers on tall stems in spring and summer. Native to sandy soils in light shade on streambanks and in forest edges in mountains of southern South Africa. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soil. Sunset: N/A

Pelargonium x hortorum, garden geranium, perennial, mounding 1-3 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, medium green, rounded and slightly lobed or scalloped leaves on semi-succulent stems and dense clusters of showy summer flowers in shades of red, orange, purple, or white. Hybrids of complicated parentage involving P. zonale and P. inquinans, both native to coastal South Africa. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pellaea andromedifolia (coffee fern), fern, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and wide, slowly spreading clump of leaves divided into widely spaced, roundly oval segments with edges rolled under, green when new and aging to reddish, purplish, or brown. Appears with first rains, dormant in summer. Native to partly shaded, rocky slopes in coastal mountains and inland foothills from southern Oregon through California and northern Baja California. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Pellaea mucronata (bird's foot cliffbrake), fern, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with pale green to bluish green leaves aging to purplish or brown and divided into widely spaced, oval leaflets often with edges rolled under. Native to rocky or dry places in mountains and valleys of California and parts of Oregon, Nevada, and Baja California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Summer dormant and deciduous if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Pennisetum alopecuroides (black pennisetum), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with arching, narrow, bright green leaves that age to bronzy gold and fade to tan. Silvery to pinkish white, bristly, brushlike flowers on arching stems rise well above the leaves in late summer. Self-sows freely and can be weedy or invasive in warm-winter climates. Native to eastern China and Japan. Many cultivars differing mostly in size, flower color, and cold hardiness. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as Cenchrus. Sunset: 2b-24

Pennisetum massaicum (bunny tails), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, arching, mid-green leaves and bristly, almost brush-like, dark reddish brown flowers in late spring and summer that age to tan. Native to grasslands from eastern South Africa north to Kenya and southern Somalia. Sun or light shade, most soils. May be offered as P. massiacus or as Cenchrus massaicus. Sunset: 4-12,14-24

Pennisetum orientale (Chinese fountain grass), warm-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, arching, green to gray-green leaves that age to yellowish tan. Pale pink or purplish, brushlike flowers on arching stems rise well above the leaves in summer. Native to central and southwestern Asia and northwestern India. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Spreads slowly by rhizomes. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as Cenchrus. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Pennisetum setaceum (fountain grass), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with arching, narrow, green leaves and brushlike flowers, often but not always pink to pale purplish, well above the leaves in late summer. Self-sows readily and is considered highly invasive in mild-winter parts of western and southern North America, Australia, South Africa, and southern Europe. Native to sunny grasslands in northern Africa, southwestern Asia, and the Arabian peninsula. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cenchrus. Sunset: 8-24

Pennisetum x advena (purple fountain grass), 3-4 feet tall and wide, with arching, narrow, burgundy leaves and purplish red, brushlike flowers in summer. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between P. setaceum and P. macrostachys, a species native to Indonesia. Unlike the invasive P. setaceum, it seldom self-sows. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as P. setaceum 'Rubrum' or as Cenchrus x cupreus. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Penstemon SW native spp. and cvs.
plants.culturalInformation: Penstemon (Southwest natives), perennials or subshrubs, basal rosettes or low-growing mats with flowers on tall, sparsely leafy stems or flowers a few inches above the leaves. Leaves are green to blue-green or gray-green, sometimes leathery. Showy, early to late spring or summer flowers are tubular to funnel-shaped, usually pendulous. Native to dry, rocky or sandy soils in mountains, deserts, and semi-deserts of the southwestern United States. Many species and cultivars. May self-sow. Loved by hummingbirds. P. eatonii has dark green, leathery, lance-shaped leaves with wavy margins and bright red flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems. P. palmeri has thick, powdery gray, triangular leaves and fragrant, lavender-pink or white flowers on 3- to 5-foot stems. P. pseudospectabilis has blue-green, oval leaves with serrated margins and purplish pink flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems. P. pinifolius has needlelike, green leaves and red-orange flowers on 12- to 18-inch stems. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: zones vary

Perideridia kelloggii (yampah), perennial, basal rosette of green leaves divided into narrowly lance-shaped to linear leaflets and flat-topped to domed clusters of tiny white flowers on upright, 3- to 5-foot, sparsely branched stems in summer. Flowers are followed by oblong, ribbed fruit. Self-sows. Native to coastal and mountain habitats of northern and central California and the northern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun to light shade, most soils, including slow draining. Sunset: N/A

Peritoma arborea (bladderpod), evergreen shrub, mounding 3-6 feet tall and wide, with bluish green leaves divided into three pointed-oval leaflets and bright yellow, funnel-shaped flowers with protruding stamens in spring and intermittently year round. Flowers are followed by inflated green seed capsules that age to light brown. Self-sows readily. Native to coastal bluffs and desert washes in southern California and Baja California. Sun, most well-drained soils, including saline. May be offered as Isomeris. Sunset: N/A

Perityle incana (Guadalupe Island rock daisy), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with fine-textured, deeply divided, silvery gray-green leaves and clusters of yellow flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky coastal cliffs on Guadalupe Island off the coast of northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: N/A

Perovskia species and cultivars (Russian sage), perennials, upright to 2-3 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with oval to oblong, toothed or lobed, sometimes finely dissected, grayish green leaves and lavender to purplish blue, tubular flowers on upright, branched stems in mid- to late summer. Species are native to arid regions of central and southern Asia, from Kazakhstan to northern India and eastern China. Usually available as P. atriplicifolia. Cultivars are either selections of P. atriplicifolia or hybrids with P. abrotanoides and differ mostly in the leaves. Full sun, most well-drained soils. May spread by rooting stems. Sunset: 2-24

Phacelia californica (scorpion flower), perennial, 1 foot tall and wide, with velvety, silvery gray-green leaves and purplish pink, funnel-shaped flowers in one-sided, coiled clusters that uncurl as the flowers open in sequence. Self-sows. Important source of nectar for pollinators, especially bees. Native to coastal bluffs and woodland openings in northern California and western Oregon. Sun or part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Philadelphus mexicanus  (evergreen mock orange), evergreen vining shrub, fast growing to 8-10 feet tall and wide, or 12-15 feet tall if its arching branches are supported, with pointed-oval, dark green leaves and fragrant, bowl-shaped, creamy white flowers with yellow stamens in late spring and summer. Can be grown as a shrub, vine, bank cover, or espalier. Native to central and southern Mexico and Guatemala. 'Flore Plena' has double flowers. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Philadelphus microphyllus (littleleaf mock orange), deciduous shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with pointed oval, mid-green leaves on arching branches and small, fragrant, bell-shaped, white flowers in late spring or early summer. Native to rocky soils in foothills and mountains from Wyoming south to California and east to Texas and northern Mexico. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-3,7,10,14-16,18

Phlomis fruticosa (Jerusalem sage), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with felted green to gray-green leaves and whorled clusters of light yellow, tubular, spring and summer flowers at intervals on upright stems. Native to dry, rocky slopes from Crete and Sardinia to western Turkey and Cyprus. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 3b-24

Phlomis italica (Italian Jerusalem sage), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with felted, woolly, gray-green leaves and whorled clusters of tubular, pinkish lavender flowers at intervals on upright stems in summer. Native to the Balearic Islands off the eastern coast of Spain. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 5-24

Phlomis lanata (Crete Jerusalem sage), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with felted, gray-green leaves and whorled clusters of lemon yellow or yellow-orange, tubular flowers at intervals on upright stems from spring to fall. Native to rocky slopes in shrublands and woodland openings on the island of Crete. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 7-24

Phlomis purpurea (purple Jerusalem sage) evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with felted, gray-green leaves and whorled clusters of purplish pink to lavender, tubular flowers at intervals on upright stems in spring and summer. Native to rocky slopes from Portugal and Spain to Morocco. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Subspecies caballeroi has yellow-green leaves. May be offered as P. caballeroi. Sunset: 7-24

Phlomis russeliana (phlomis) perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with felted, olive green leaves and whorled clusters of soft yellow, tubular flowers at intervals on upright stems in summer. Spreads by rhizomes. Native to forest and woodland openings in the mountains of Turkey. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 2-24

Phlomis spectabilis (Kashmir sage), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, spreading to form a large clump, with soft, broadly oval to heart-shaped, mostly basal, mid-green leaves and whorls of tubular, pale purplish pink flowers at intervals on tall stems in spring and summer. Native to dry, rocky soils from the mountains of eastern Afghanistan to the Himalayas. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as P. cashmeriana. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Phlox spp. and cvs. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Phoenix canariensis (Canary Island date palm), palm, 40-60 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with a thick, columnar trunk topped with arching, featherlike, dark green leaves divided into many linear leaflets. Leaves have long, sharp spines at the base. Drooping clusters of creamy yellow flowers in spring are followed by orange fruits on female trees. Native to the Canary Islands. Sun to light shade, most soils. Adaptable. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Phoenix dactylifera (date palm), palm, 50-80 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with a columnar trunk, sometimes suckering to produce several trunks, topped with arching, featherlike, dark gray-green leaves with long, sharp spines at the base. Leaves are divided into many stiff, linear, sharply pointed leaflets. Drooping clusters of creamy yellow flowers in spring are followed by large, yellow or orange fruits on female trees. Origin uncertain but believed to be native to desert oases in northern Africa and southwestern Asia. Sun, well-drained soils. Needs summer heat to bear fruit. Sunset: 8-9,11-24

Phoenix roebelenii (pygmy date palm), palm, slow growing to 6-10 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, usually single trunk, with arching, glossy green, featherlike leaves with long, sharp spines at the base. Leaves are divided into many linear leaflets. Drooping clusters of small, creamy yellow flowers in spring are followed by small, purplish black fruits on female trees. Native to southern China, Laos, and northern Vietnam. Cool sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Sunset: 13,16-17,22-24

Phormium hybrids, flax, perennials, variable, 2-10 feet tall and 2-8 feet wide, with upright or arching, strap-shaped leaves and tubular flowers on branched stalks in late spring or early summer. Most plants available are cultivars of or hybrids between P. tenax and P. cookianum (P. colensoi), both native to seasonally moist or exposed coastal habitats in New Zealand. Many may grow larger than expected and those with variegated or unusually colored leaves may revert to solid bronze or green. 'Dark Delight' is 4-5 feet tall with dark purple leaves. 'Duet' is 2 feet tall with green leaves with creamy white edges. 'Jester' is 18 inches tall with pink and lime green leaves. Cool sun to part shade, good drainage. Good coastal plants. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Phormium tenax (New Zealand flax), perennial, upright to 8-10 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with bronzy green, strap-shaped leaves and red-orange, tubular flowers on tall stalks in late spring or early summer. Native to various habitats in New Zealand, from seasonally wet places to exposed coastal cliffs. Most plants available are cultivars. 'Tom Thumb', 2-3 feet tall and wide, has wavy-edged, olive green leaves with dark bronzy red margins. 'Dusky Chief', 6-8 feet tall and 6 feet wide, has variable leaves, pale to dark maroon when new, silvery gray beneath, and aging to purplish gray. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Good coastal plants. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Phyla nodiflora hybrids and cvs., dense groundcover forms a mat 1-2 inches high and reaching 5-10 feet wide in a year, widely spreading stems covered with small oval leaves. Tiny verbena flowers in shades of white to pink cover the mats beginning April and continuing through the summer and on the outer edges in fall. Bees and butterflies are highly attracted to these flowers. May be mowed to remove flowers if undesirable. Good on slopes. May die back some in winter in colder locations but recovers the following spring. Low in all regions except not applicable to Regions 5 and 6. Sun to light shade. Most soils. Sunset zones:8-24; H1, H2.

Phylica plumosa (Cape myrtle), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with small, needlelike, hairy, grayish green leaves densely covering stiffly upright stems and tiny, yellow, late spring flowers surrounded by feathery, creamy white bracts longer than the leaves. Native to the southwestern coast of Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Phylica pubescens (featherhead) evergreen shrub, upright to 4-6 feet tall and wide, with narrow, needlelike, silvery gray-green leaves covered in white or yellowish hairs and small, creamy white fall to late-winter flowers hidden among feathery, creamy white bracts. Native to dry sandstone cliffs east of Cape Town, South Africa. Sun, excellent drainage, good air circulation. May be offered as P. plumosa. Sunset: N/A

Phyllostachys species (bamboo), grass, 15-40 feet, sometimes 70 feet tall, shrubby to treelike, fast growing and spreading widely by aggressively running rhizomes and forming dense colonies over time. Stems usually are stiffly upright, woody, and hollow except at nodes where narrow, leaf-bearing branches develop. Evergreen leaves are green, strap-shaped, and tapering with pointed tips. Stems are usually green but in some species are yellow or nearly black, often with stripes or markings in contrasting colors. Flowering is infrequent and unpredictable, occurring about once every 8-10 years. Most species are native to central and southeastern China. Many cultivars. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Physocarpus capitatus (ninebark) deciduous shrub, 5-10 feet tall and wide, with lobed, maplelike, green leaves on arching stems and colorful, multi-layered, peeling bark. Rounded clusters of tiny, white flowers with red-tipped stamens in spring are followed by glossy, red fruit that ages to brown. Native to the mountains of western North America from southeastern Alaska to central California and east to Montana and Utah. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained, acidic soils. Accepts seasonal flooding. Sunset: 2b-9,14-19

Physocarpus opulifolius (common ninebark), deciduous shrub, 5-8 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with lobed, maple-like, green leaves on arching stems and colorful, multi-layered, peeling bark. Rounded clusters of tiny, pink or white flowers in late spring are followed by glossy, red fruit that ages to brown. Native to rocky hillsides and along streams in central and eastern North America. Diabolo™ has purple leaves. Sun to part shade, most soils. Cut back in winter to renew. Sunset: 1-10,14-17,A1-3

Pinus attenuata (knobcone pine), evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 20-60 feet tall and  20-25 feet wide, often multitrunk, with long, flexible, green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves on horizontal branches that turn up at the ends and cones held closely to trunk and branches. Native to dry, rocky slopes in coastal mountains from southwestern Oregon to central California, on western slopes of the northern Sierra Nevada foothills, and intermittently in coastal mountains of southern California and Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-10,14-21

Pinus brutia, Calabrian pine, evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with long, dark green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves and an upright, rounded, open habit. Native to the northeastern Mediterranean region, mostly near the coast, from southeastern Bulgaria and northwestern Turkey to Syria and Lebanon. May be offered as a variety of P. halepensis, a similar tree native to the northwestern Mediterranean. Sun, good drainage. Best near the coast. Sunset: 6-9,12-24

Pinus brutia subspecies eldarica, eldarica pine, evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with long, dark green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves and an upright, rounded, open habit. Native to dry, rocky soils on north-facing slopes of the Caucasus Mountains of northern Azerbaijan. Sun, good drainage. Similar to P. brutia but adapted to hot-summer climates with occasional summer rain. May be offered as P. eldarica or as a variety of P. halepensis. Sunset: 6-9,11-24

Pinus bungeana, lacebark pine, evergreen coniferous tree , slow growing to 50-75 feet tall and 20-35 feet wide, usually multitrunk or low branching and sometimes shrubby, with dark to bright green, sharply pointed, needlelike leaves, multicolored, peeling bark, and small, yellowish brown cones. Native to the mountains of central and northeastern China. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-10,14-21

Pinus canariensis (Canary Island pine), evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with long, drooping, dark green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves on upswept branches, reddish brown and tan, fissured bark, and large brown cones. Native to the fog belt of the western Canary Islands off the coast of Morocco. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pinus cembra, Swiss stone pine, evergreen coniferous tree, exceptionally slow growing to 50-80 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, narrowly upright when young, open and rounded at maturity, with stiff, dark green to bluish green, needlelike leaves, gray-brown, fissured bark, and small, purplish brown cones. Native to subalpine forests in the Alps and Carpathian Mountains of south-central Europe. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-7,10,A1-3

Pinus coulteri (Coulter pine), evergreen coniferous tree, 50-80 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with an upright and open habit, long, gray-green, mostly upright, needlelike leaves on horizontal to upswept branches, dark gray-brown, deeply furrowed bark, and large, heavy, spiny cones. Native to dry, rocky slopes and ridges in the coastal mountains of southern California and Baja California and intermittently in the San Francisco Bay Area. Sun, well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 3-10,14-23

Pinus edulis (pinyon pine), evergreen coniferous tree or large shrub, slow growing to 15-40 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, often multitrunk and low branching, with short, upcurved, dark green to bluish green, needlelike leaves and an irregular, spreading habit. Native to dry, rocky slopes and mesas from Utah, Colorado, and southeastern California to Arizona, New Mexico, and northern Mexico. May be offered as a variety of P. cembroides or P. monophylla. Sunset: 1-11,14-21

Pinus halepensis, Aleppo pine, evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 50-80 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, with long, dark green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves and an upright, rounded, open habit. Similar to P. brutia but more widely native to much of the Mediterranean region from Morocco to Tunisia and from Spain to Israel. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Pinus heldreichii, Bosnian pine, evergreen coniferous tree, slow growing to 60-80 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with stiff, sharply pointed, dark green, needlelike leaves and purple cones on upturned branches. Native to rocky soils in subalpine forests from Bosnia and Bulgaria to Albania and northern Greece. Compact and dwarf cultivars are often available. Sun, well-drained soils. Best in cool-summer climates. May be offered as P. leucodermis. Sunset: 2-11,14-24

Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey pine), evergreen coniferous tree, slow growing to 80-120 feet tall and 25-40 feet wide, with long, bluish gray-green, needlelike leaves on pendulous branches, thick, deeply furrowed, reddish brown bark, and large, spiny, dark purple cones that age to brown. Native to mid- to high elevations in mountains of southwestern Oregon and western Nevada south through the Sierra Nevada to northern Baja California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Best in cool-summer climates. Sunset: 2-9,14-19

Pinus lambertiana, sugar pine, evergreen coniferous tree, narrowly upright to 80-200 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with long, bluish green, needlelike leaves, deeply furrowed, dark reddish brown bark, and exceptionally long, narrow cones that hang down near the ends of horizontal to upswept branches. Native to rocky soils in mixed evergreen forests from the western slopes of the Cascade Mountains in central Oregon through the northern California Coast Ranges and the Sierra Nevada into northern Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-9,15-17

Pinus longaeva, bristlecone pine, evergreen coniferous tree, variable and slow growing to 15-30 feet tall and wide, irregular in habit, with short, dark green to bluish green, needlelike leaves tightly clustered on upright branches. Reddish brown, deeply fissured bark aging to gray and small, bristly, dark purple cones. Native to higher elevations in mountains of eastern California, Nevada, and Utah. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. May be offered as a variety of P. aristata. Sunset: 1-11,14-19,A2-3

Pinus monophylla (single-leaf pinyon pine), exceptionally slow growing to 15-30 feet tall and wide, low branching, with stiff, gray-green or blue-gray, needlelike leaves on upswept branches, rough, gray, furrowed bark, and small, round cones. Native to dry, rocky slopes and ridges at mid- to high elevations in the mountains of southeastern California to Arizona, New Mexico, and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best in semi-arid climates. Sunset: 2-12,14-21

Pinus montezumae, Montezuma pine, evergreen coniferous tree, 70-90 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with long, dark green, needlelike leaves at tips of nearly horizontal branches, rough, dark reddish to gray-brown bark, and large, spiny, brown cones. Native to mid- to high elevations in mountains of mostly summer-rainfall eastern and central Mexico south into Guatemala. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Pinus mugo (mugo pine), evergreen tree or shrub, variable, usually multi-trunked, dense and low branching, 15-20 feet tall and 20-25 feet wide, with dark green to dark grayish green needle-like leaves. Native to the mountains of central and southern Europe from Spain to the Balkan Peninsula. Usually available as dwarf cultivars, 1-2 feet tall, and mid-sized cultivars, 6-10 feet tall. Sun to light shade, well-drained soil. Best in cool-summer climates. Sunset: 1-11,14-24

Pinus muricata, bishop pine, evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 45-80 feet tall and 20-40 feet wide, with long, dark green, needlelike leaves on spreading or ascending branches, dark gray, deeply furrowed bark, and asymmetric, spiny cones. Native to dry, rocky soils intermittently from coastal northern California and the Channel Islands south to northwestern Baja California. Sun, most soils. Best along the coast. Good seaside tree. Sunset: 5,14-17,22-24

Pinus pinaster (cluster pine), evergreen coniferous tree, fast growing to 65-100 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with an irregular, rounded habit, deeply fissured, reddish brown bark, and long, stiff, bright green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves clustered at the ends of upswept branches. Native to dry, sandy soils along the coast or in coastal mountains of the western Mediterranean region. Sun, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: N/A

Pinus pinea (Italian stone pine), evergreen coniferous tree, 40-80 feet tall and 40-60 feet wide, high branching and broadly flat-topped, with reddish brown bark and long, bright green to bluish gray-green, needlelike leaves on upswept branches. Origins uncertain; long in cultivation and naturalized throughout the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Syria and Morocco to Libya. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,11-24

Pinus ponderosa (ponderosa pine), evergreen coniferous tree, 60-125 feet tall and 25-30 feet wide, upright and columnar, with reddish orange, furrowed bark, almost black on young trees, and dark yellowish green, needlelike leaves on pendulous branches that turn up at the ends. Native to the mountains of western and midwestern North America from British Columbia south to Baja California and east to North Dakota, Nebraska, Texas, and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-10,14-21

Pinus sabiniana (foothill pine), evergreen tree, 40-75 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with long, drooping, pale gray-green needles on upturned branches, dark brown, furrowed bark, and large, heavy, brown cones. Native to southwestern Oregon and coastal mountains and Sierra Nevada foothills around the Central Valley in California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Pinus torreyana (Torrey pine), evergreen coniferous tree, slow growing to 25-40 feet tall and wide, with an irregular, open habit, deeply furrowed, reddish brown bark, and long, dark green, needlelike leaves clustered near the upturned ends of spreading or ascending branches. Native to dry, sandy soils in the fog belt of coastal San Diego County and Santa Rosa Island off the coast of southern California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Best along the coast. Sunset: N/A

Pinus wallichiana (Himalayan pine), evergreen coniferous tree, slow growing to 30-80 feet tall and 20-35 feet wide, low branching, with fissured, dark gray bark, long, pendulous cones, and long, drooping, bluish gray-green, needlelike leaves on widespreading, almost horizontal branches. Native to valleys and foothills of the Himalayas from eastern Afghanistan to southwestern China. Cool sun to part shade, acidic, well-drained soils. May be offered as P. griffithii. Sunset: 4-6,15-17,A2-3

Pistacia chinensis (Chinese pistache), deciduous tree, 30-40 feet tall and wide, with compound leaves divided into narrow leaflets and clusters of inconspicuous greenish flowers. Leaves turn brilliant red, orange, or yellow in fall. Native to cool, moist climates of central and western China, Taiwan, and the Philippines. Fruit of female plants can be messy and plants may spread by seed. 'Keith Davey' is a fruitless male selection. Sun, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast or in cool-summer climates. Considered invasive in some parts of California. Sunset: 4-23

Pistacia lentiscus (mastic), evergreen shrub or small tree, multitrunk, 8-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with aromatic, leathery leaves divided into narrowly oval, dark green leaflets and clusters of small, greenish flowers in spring followed by small, berrylike, red fruit that ages to black. Native to dry, open woodlands and shrublands in the Mediterranean region, mostly near the coast, from Spain and Morocco to Turkey and Israel. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pistacia vera (pistachio), deciduous tree, 25-30 feet tall and wide, single or multitrunk, with gray-green leaves divided into oval leaflets. Brownish green flowers that lack petals are followed in female trees by hard, cream-colored, berrylike fruits that split when ripe to partially expose the single seed. Native to deserts of southwestern and central Asia. Both male and female trees are needed for pollination and fruit production. Need both summer heat and winter chill to fruit well. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 7-12,14-15,18-21

Pittosporum angustifolium (willow pittosporum), evergreen tree, slow growing to 20-30 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, narrowly upright, with long, narrowly linear, dark gray-green leaves that hang down from pendulous branches. Fragrant, bell-shaped, creamy yellow flowers in late winter or spring are followed by orange fruit that splits to reveal dark red seeds. Native to arid and semi-arid regions away from the coast in much of Australia. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Adaptable. May be offered as P. phillyraeoides or P. phyllireoides. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Pittosporum tobira and cultivars (tobira), evergreen shrub or small tree, 10-15 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, dark green, oval to spoon-shaped leaves and clusters of small, fragrant, white flowers in spring that age to creamy yellow. Flowers are followed by green seed capsules that age to dark brown and split to release sticky, bright orange seeds. Dropping of leaves, flowers, and fruit can be messy. Native to China, Japan, and Korea. 'Variegata', 5-12 feet tall, has gray-green leaves with creamy white margins. 'Oakleaf', possibly a hybrid, is 6-8 feet tall with wavy-edged leaves with pointed tips. 'Wheeler's Dwarf' and 'Nanum' are 2-3 feet tall. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plant.  Sunset: 8-24

Pittosporum undulatum (Victorian box), evergreen tree or large shrub, 25-35 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, single or multitrunk, with glossy green, lance-shaped to elliptical leaves with wavy margins and clusters of small, fragrant, creamy white flowers in early spring. Flowers are followed by yellowish orange, berrylike fruit that splits to release sticky, red-orange seeds. Native to both wet and dry forests in southeastern Australia. Self-sows and can be invasive, especially in moist soils, even within its native range. Fruit drop can be messy. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-17,21-24

plants.botanicalName: Platanus x hispanica and cvs. (Platanus x acerfolia)

plants.culturalInformation: Plecostachys serpyllifolia (straw flower), perennial or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with tiny, oval, pale green leaves, woolly and white beneath, on a tangle of thin, woolly, white stems and clusters of tiny, white flowers with pinkish centers in summer to fall. Native to sandy soils along the coast and in coastal foothills from winter-rainfall Western Cape Province to summer-rainfall Eastern Cape Province and KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Can be invasive in coastal wetlands. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Helichrysum. Sunset: N/A

Plectranthus neochilus (lobster flower), perennial, mounding 1 foot tall and 2-3 feet wide, with oval to rounded, aromatic, slightly succulent, gray-green leaves with scalloped margins and short, upright spikes of fragrant, blue and purple flowers from spring to late fall. Native from South Africa's Eastern Cape Province north through Zimbabwe to Zambia. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Coleus. Sunset: N/A

Plumbago auriculata (Cape plumbago), evergreen shrub, 5-8 feet tall and wide, with small, oval to oblong, mid-green leaves on lax, arching or sprawling stems and clusters of blue or sometimes white, trumpet-shaped flowers in spring and summer or intermittently year round. May spread by rooting stems. Native from Eastern Cape Province to KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Cut back in winter to renew. May be offered as P. capensis. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Poa secunda (pine bluegrass), cool-season bunchgrass, variable, less than 1 foot to 3 feet tall and wide, with narrow, mid-green leaves that may take on purplish red tones as they age and tall, narrow flower spikes on mostly leafless stalks in early spring. Dormant in summer, reviving with fall rains. Native to widely varied habitats from southeastern Alaska east across southern Canada and south through the Great Plains and western states to northwestern Mexico. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Polygala x dalmaisiana (sweet pea shrub), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with grayish green, rounded oval leaves and pinkish purple flowers resembling sweet pea from mid-spring through summer or almost year round in mild-winter climates. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between P. myrtifolia and P. oppositifolia, both from along the coast and in the mountains of southern and southeastern South Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as a variety of P. myrtifolia. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Polypodium californicum (California polypody), fern, 12-18 inches tall and slowly spreading by rhizomes, with bright green fronds arising at intervals. Native to shaded slopes and canyons along the coast and in coastal mountains in northern and central California and in moist locations in southern California and Baja California. Full to part shade, most soils. Deciduous and dormant in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 4-9,14-17,22-24

Portulacaria afra and cultivars (elephant's food), succulent, 6-10 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, bright green, fleshy, oval to rounded leaves. Clusters of tiny, pale lavender, spring flowers appear only when winters have been exceptionally dry. Native to rocky slopes in Eastern Cape Province, South Africa, north into Mozambique. Mat-forming or trailing and variegated cultivars are available. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Primula species (California natives (shooting stars)), perennials, variable, with a basal rosette or low clump of lance-shaped to oval, mid-green leaves that appear in spring and die back in summer and clusters of white, pale or dark pink, or purple flowers on short or tall, leafless stems in spring. Flowers are pendulous with distinctively reflexed sepals and prominent stamens. California natives are found from northern to southern parts of the state and from valley grasslands to foothill woodlands, often in seasonally wet areas. All need a dry summer dormancy and moisture in spring. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Dodecatheon. Sunset: zones vary

Prosopis alba (Argentine mesquite), semi-evergreen tree, fast growing to 20-40 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, usually low branching, with bluish green leaves divided into many short, linear leaflets on spiny branches. Pendulous catkinlike spikes of tiny, greenish white to yellowish flowers in spring are followed by large, brownish white, beanlike seedpods. May spread by root sprouts to form dense thickets. Native to seasonal watercourses and groundwater sinks from Peru to Uruguay and Argentina. Thornless cultivars are available. Sun, most well-drained soils, including alkaline and saline. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

Prosopis glandulosa (honey mesquite), deciduous tree or large shrub, variable, 10- to 15-foot shrub or 20- to 40-foot tree, with spiny twigs and mid-green leaves divided into many feathery leaflets on drooping branches. Pendulous catkinlike spikes of tiny, yellowish green flowers in spring to late summer are followed by long, narrow, yellowish brown, beanlike seedpods. Native from Kansas to Texas and northern Mexico. The variety torreyana is native from western Texas to southeastern California. P. glandulosa can be highly invasive, especially outside its natural range. Sun, most well-drained soils, including alkaline and saline. May be offered as a variety of P. chilensis. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

photos.filename: Prosopis glandulosa var. torreyana (western honey mesquite)
photos.caption: Prosopis glandulosa var. torreyana (western honey mesquite)

plants.culturalInformation: Prosopis glandulosa var. torreyana (western honey mesquite), deciduous tree or large shrub, 15-20 feet tall and wide, with spiny twigs and mid-green leaves divided into many widely spaced, feathery, linear leaflets on drooping branches. Pendulous catkinlike spikes of creamy yellow flowers in spring are followed by long, narrow, beanlike seedpods. Similar to P. glandulosa except smaller leaflets. Native to dry grasslands and desert washes from southeastern California and northern Mexico to western Texas. Sun, most well-drained soils, including alkaline and saline. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

Prosopis hybrids and cultivars deciduous to semi-evergreen trees, fast growing to 30-40 feet tall and 30 feet wide, with green to bluish green, feathery leaves divided into many small, linear leaflets and catkinlike spikes of yellow flowers in spring followed by long, narrow, beanlike seedpods. Hybrids offered in the nursery trade are often the result of natural hybridization between or among P. alba, P. glandulosa, P. chilensis, and P. velutina. Hybrids and cultivars are selected for such characteristics as lack of spines or seeds, cold hardiness, stronger branching structure, denser foliage, or more upright form. Because hybrids are so common in nature, some plants offered as one species or another may actually be hybrids. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils, including alkaline and saline. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

Prosopis velutina (velvet mesquite), deciduous tree, 20-30 feet tall and wide, often multitrunk or low-branching, with spiny branches bearing bluish green leaves divided into many small, feathery, linear leaflets. Clusters of greenish yellow flowers in summer are followed by long, narrow, beanlike seedpods. Native to deserts from southeastern Arizona to southern New Mexico and northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 10-13,18-24

Prostanthera ovalifolia (mint bush), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 6-8 feet tall and wide, densely covered with small, oval to rounded or sometimes lance-shaped, aromatic, dark green leaves, grayish beneath, and masses of small, tubular, purple, sometimes pink or white flowers in spring. Native to inland areas of southeastern Australia. Variegated cultivars are available. Cut back lightly after flowering to promote next year's bloom. Cool sun to part shade, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 14-17,19-24

Prostanthera rotundifolia (round leaf mint bush), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with small, rounded, aromatic, dark gray-green leaves and pinkish purple, tubular flowers in spring and early summer. Native to southeastern Australia, including Tasmania and South Australia. Cut back after flowering to maintain form and promote next year's bloom. Cool sun to part shade, light shade inland, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 14-17,19-24

Protea species and cultivars (protea), evergreen shrubs, 3-16 feet tall and 4-10 feet wide, with leathery, oval to oblong, glossy, dark green leaves and dome-shaped to conical clusters of tiny flowers surrounded by large, colorful bracts that resemble petals. Flowering is usually heaviest in fall, winter, or spring. Native to South Africa, especially the southern and southwestern coastal mountains. Many species and cultivars. The most commonly grown species, P. cynaroides and its cultivars, bear flower heads from 5-12 inches wide with pale silvery pink, creamy white, or dark red bracts. 'Arctic Ice' has pure white flowers and bracts. Sun, slightly acidic, low-nutrient soils, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Not always easy in cultivation. Short lived. Best along the coast. Sunset: 16-17,21-24

plants.botanicalName: Prunella spp. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Prunus andersonii (desert peach), deciduous shrub, 3-8 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes, with small, oval to lance-shaped, finely serrated, green leaves on thorny branches and masses of small, dark to pale pink or nearly white flowers in spring followed by reddish orange fruits. Native to dry, rocky or sandy soils in deserts and mountains of eastern California and western Nevada. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Prunus caroliniana (Carolina laurel), evergreen shrub or small tree, 20-30 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, low branching, with clusters of narrowly oval, leathery, dark green leaves and showy clusters of small, creamy white flowers in late winter or early spring followed by small, round, blue-black fruit. Native to southeastern North America from North Carolina to Florida and west to eastern Texas. Compact cultivars are often available. Fruit drop can be messy. Self-sows and can be invasive. Sun to part shade, well-drained acidic soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: 5-24

Prunus fasciculata (desert almond), deciduous shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with small, linear, bright green leaves arranged in small clusters along thorny branches and small, white flowers in spring followed by small, yellowish fruit that ages to reddish brown. Suckers and can form thickets. Native to dry, rocky, high-desert slopes and washes from Nevada and Utah to California, Arizona, and Baja California. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Prunus ilicifolia (holly leaf cherry), evergreen shrub or small tree, 15-25 feet tall and wide, with leathery, glossy, dark green leaves with spiny margins, narrow spikes of fragrant, creamy white flowers in spring, and reddish to dark purple fruits in fall. Native to coastal mountains and foothills in central and southern California, the Channel Islands, and Baja California. Subspecies lyonii is similar but leaves are not spiny. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Fruit drop can be messy. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

Prunus ilicifolia lyonii (Catalina cherry), evergreen shrub, 15-30 feet tall and wide, with glossy, dark green leaves, clusters of small, creamy white flowers in spring, and red to dark purple fruits in fall. Native to the Channel Islands in southern California and the Baja California mainland. Fruit drop can be messy. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as P. lyonii. Sunset: 5-9,12-24

Prunus mume (Japanese apricot), deciduous tree, 12-20 feet tall and 15-20 feet wide, with oval, mid-green leaves with finely serrated margins and fragrant, white, pink, or red flowers in mid- to late winter or early spring followed by oval, greenish yellow fruit. Native to the mountains of southern China, sometimes at high elevations, and long grown in Korea and Japan. Compact, weeping, and double-flowered cultivars are available. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3,7-9,12-22

Prunus varieties (edible apricot), deciduous trees, 15-20 feet tall and wide, with thin, rounded, bright green leaves and showy clusters of cup-shaped, pink-tinged white flowers in late winter or early spring. The species, P. armeniaca, is native to central Asia and has been widely cultivated for hundreds of years. Many cultivars, which vary in timing of bloom and fruit ripening, winter chill and summer heat requirements, frost tolerance, and fruit quality. 'Royal' requires less winter chill than most and is a good choice for mild-winter gardens. 'Pixie Cot' is a dwarf tree, only 6-8 feet tall. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Pseudopanax ferox (fierce lancewood), evergreen shrub to small tree, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with a central, grayish white trunk, deeply grooved when mature. Juvenile leaves are downward growing, long, narrow, stiff, dark or light greenish gray-brown with a prominent midrib and irregular, blunt lobes or teeth along the margins. After 10-15 years the stem branches to form a rounded, compact, treelike crown with shorter, leathery, linear, dark green mature leaves, sometimes with a few marginal teeth toward the tips. Inconspicuous greenish flowers are followed by small, oval, dark purplish brown fruit on female trees. Native to varied habitats on sandy or gravelly soils along the coast and in the mountains of New Zealand. Cool sun, well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 16-17,21-24

Pseudotsuga macrocarpa (big cone spruce), evergreen coniferous tree, 50-90 feet tall and 30-40 feet wide, with short, stiff, dark bluish green, needlelike leaves encircling twigs on long, pendulous to widely spreading branches and large cones hanging down from branch ends. Similar to the interior variety of Douglas fir, P. menziesii subsp. glauca, but with larger cones. Native to dry slopes and canyons in mountains of southern California. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 3-11,14-23

Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas fir), evergreen coniferous tree, 60-200 feet tall and narrowly upright to conical, with short, dark green to yellowish green, needlelike leaves encircling twigs on pendulous lower and ascending upper branches. Pendulous cones have conspicuous, papery bracts. Coastal variety menziesii is native along the coast from southwestern British Columbia to central California; interior variety glauca is native from Alberta south through the Rocky Mountains to western Texas and central Mexico; both varieties grow at progressively higher elevations north to south. Compact, dwarf, weeping, and blue-leaved cultivars are available. Part sun to shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 1-10,14-17,A2-3

Psilostrophe cooperi (paper flower), perennial or subshrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with pale green to gray-green, lightly hairy, narrowly linear to needlelike leaves and pale or bright yellow daisy flowers in spring and fall that become papery as they age. Native to rocky slopes and sandy washes in deserts of eastern California and southern Nevada to Arizona and northwestern Mexico. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 7-12,18-21

Psoralea pinnata (scurfy pea shrub), evergreen shrub, 8-10 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with dark green leaves divided into soft, needlelike leaflets and fragrant, bicolored, lavender and white flowers resembling sweet pea in spring and summer. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains from southwestern Western Cape Province to northeastern South Africa. Short lived. May self-sow. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Needs moisture in winter to bloom well. Sunset: N/A

Ptelea crenulata (western hop tree), deciduous shrub or small tree, 10-15 feet tall and wide, with glossy, bright green, aromatic leaves divided into three oval to broadly lance-shaped leaflets. Clusters of fragrant, creamy white flowers in spring are followed by papery, winged fruit. Native to northern California, from the foothills of the southern Cascades and western Sierra Nevada through the Coast Ranges to the San Francisco Bay Area. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Pteris spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Punica granatum (pomegranate), evergreen to semi-evergreen shrub, usually multitrunk or low-branching, 6-20 feet tall and 4-15 feet wide, with thorny branches and lance-shaped to narrowly oblong, glossy green leaves, bronzy when new and turning yellow in fall. Showy, trumpet-shaped, red-orange flowers in mid- to late summer are followed by spherical, bright red, leathery fruits. Native from Iran to the Himalayas. 'Nana' is 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide with smaller fruit. Needs summer heat to flower and fruit well. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-24

Punica granatum and cultivars (pomegranate), evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees, 6-20 feet tall and 4-15 feet wide, with narrowly lance-shaped to oblong, glossy, green leaves and trumpet-shaped, red-orange or sometimes white flowers in summer. Where summer heat is sufficient, flowers are followed by large, round, leathery, usually red fruit. Species is native from Iran to the Himalayas and parts of southern Europe. Many cultivars. 'Nana' is 3 feet tall with red flowers. 'Haku Botan' has frilly, double, white flowers and greenish yellow fruit. 'Ambrosia' has especially large fruit and is said to be adaptable to cool- as well as hot-summer climates. Fruit drop can be messy. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-24

Puya species (puya), perennials, 2-4 feet tall and wide, rosettes of green or bluish green, narrowly strap-shaped, succulent or semi-succulent leaves with spiny margins and waxy, bell-shaped, bright blue-green flowers on 3- to 8-foot stalks in spring but not every year. Spread slowly by offsets to form large colonies. Native to dry, rocky slopes in the Andes of Chile and Argentina. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 9,13-17,19-24

Pyracantha species and cultivars (firethorn), evergreen to semi-evergreen shrubs, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with dark green, oval to elliptic or lance-shaped leaves on spiny branches. Showy clusters of small, white flowers in spring are followed by bright red, yellow, or reddish orange berrylike fruits. Self-sow and seeds are spread by birds; considered invasive. Most plants offered in the trade are cultivars of P. angustifolia, P. coccinea, P. koidzumii, or P. rogersiana, all native to southeastern Europe or Asia and varying primarily in cold hardiness and fruit color. Many cultivars. P. coccinea 'Teton' is cold hardy, 10-12 feet tall and 4 feet wide, with yellow-orange fruit. P. coccinea 'Lowboy' is 2-3 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide with orange fruit. P. angustifolia 'Gnome' is cold hardy, 4-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide with orange fruit. P. rogersiana 'Flava' is 10-12 feet tall and wide with bright yellow fruit. 'Tiny Tim', a hybrid, is 3 feet tall with small leaves, few thorns, and bright red fruit. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Pyrethropsis hosmariense (Moroccan daisy), perennial, less than 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with finely cut, silvery green leaves and bright white daisy flowers with bright yellow centers in fall or winter. Native to rocky, exposed sites in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco and Algeria. Sun, excellent drainage. Prefers a dryish winter. May be offered as Chrysanthemum, Leucanthemum, or Rhodanthemum. Sunset: 14-24

Pyrrosia species (felt fern), fern, less than 1 foot to 18 inches tall and 1-3 feet wide, with smooth, green, undivided but often lobed leaves, sometimes with undulating margins and often with reddish undersides. Spread slowly by rhizomes, which can adhere to a vertical surface such as a wall or tree trunk. Native to mountains of China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan, usually growing on rocks or trees. Many cultivars. Light shade or shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Quercus agrifolia (coast live oak), evergreen tree, 35-75 feet tall and 35-50 feet wide, dense and broadly rounded, with leathery, dark green leaves with spiny margins and small, reddish brown acorns. Native along the coast and in the coastal mountains from northern California to northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best in mild climates. Young trees do best in part shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Quercus berberidifolia (California scrub oak), evergreen shrub or small tree, variable, slow growing, usually a shrub 4-10 feet tall and wide, sometimes a 15- to 20-foot tree, with small, oval to elliptic, sometimes wavy-edged, leathery, dark green leaves, gray-green beneath, often with toothed or spiny margins. Native to dry, rocky slopes in coastal mountains and valleys from northern California to northern Baja California and in Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Q. dumosa. Sunset: 5,7-10,14-24

Quercus chrysolepis (canyon live oak), evergreen tree, variable, 30-60 feet tall and wide, rounded and wide spreading, with leathery, dark green leaves with smooth or spiny margins. Native to a wide range of elevations, soils, and moisture regimes from southwestern Oregon to Baja California and east into Nevada and Arizona. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-11,14-24

Quercus douglasii (blue oak), deciduous tree, slow growing to 30-60 feet tall and wide, low branching and wide spreading, with dark bluish green, slightly lobed and wavy-edged leaves that turn red and yellow in fall. Native to dry, rocky slopes in foothills surrounding California's Central Valley north to the Klamath Mountains and south to the Tehachapi Mountains. Drops some leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-11,14-24

Quercus dumosa (coastal sage scrub oak), Nuttall's scrub oak, evergreen shrub, slow growing to 3-10 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, upright or mounding, with leathery, oval to rounded, dark green leaves, usually with wavy and toothed or spiny margins. Native to sandy soils in chaparral right along the coast in southern California and northern Baja California. Sun, well-drained, sandy soils. Sunset: N/A

Quercus durata (leather oak), evergreen shrub or small tree, 3-15 feet tall and wide, with small, leathery, oval to elliptic, dark green leaves, paler and felted beneath, with margins rolled under, toothed, or spiny. Native to dry, rocky, serpentine soils in coastal mountains from northern to southern California and in foothills of the Sierra Nevada. Sun, most well-drained soils. May be offered as a subspecies of Q. dumosa. Sunset: 5,7-10,14-24

Quercus emoryi (Emory oak), evergreen tree, 30-60 feet tall and 40 feet wide, rounded and wide spreading, with large, leathery, oval to elliptic or broadly lance-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves, usually with wavy, toothed, or spiny margins. Native to dry foothills and slopes from central Arizona east to western Texas and south into northern Mexico. Drops some leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 10-13

Quercus engelmannii (mesa oak), evergreen tree, variable, slow growing to 40-50 feet tall and 60-90 feet wide, with bluish gray-green, oval to oblong leaves, usually with smooth margins. Native to grasslands and woodlands, often near streams or spring, in coastal mountains of southern California and northwestern Baja California. Drops some leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Quercus gambelii (Gambel oak), deciduous tree or large shrub, variable, 10-30 feet tall and wide, sometimes 50 feet tall in wetter locations, with deeply and irregularly lobed, dark green leaves, paler and felted beneath, and a usually rounded habit. Spreads by root sprouts as well as by seed and may form groves or thickets. Native to rocky soils in mountains from Utah and Colorado south through Arizona and New Mexico to northwestern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-3,10

Quercus garryana (Oregon white oak), deciduous tree, 40-90 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, or multitrunk and shrubby to 20 feet tall, with large, deeply lobed, glossy, dark green leaves and whitish gray bark. Native to both dry, rocky slopes and seasonally flooded riparian areas, mostly west of the Cascades, from southwestern British Columbia to the Tehachapi Mountains north of Los Angeles. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2a-11,14-23

Quercus ilex (holly oak), evergreen tree, 30-60 feet tall and wide, dense and rounded, with narrowly oval, leathery, dark green leaves, grayish white beneath, newer leaves with spiny margins. Native to the western Mediterranean region from Portugal to Greece and Morocco to Tunisia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Good seaside tree. Sunset: 4-24

Quercus kelloggii (California black oak), deciduous tree, upright to 30-70 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, rounded and low branching when given the space, with large, glossy, green leaves with deep, bristly tipped lobes and golden yellow and orange fall color. Native to coastal mountains from Oregon to southern California and from the Cascade Range through the Sierra Nevada to northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 6-7,9,14-21

Quercus lobata (valley oak), deciduous tree, fast growing to 50-90 feet tall and wide, with deeply lobed, aromatic, dark green leaves and dark brown to pale gray, ridged and furrowed bark. Native to the Central Valley and to foothills and valleys of coastal and inland mountains of California where access to surface or groundwater is year-round. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 3b-9,11-24

Quercus suber (cork oak), evergreen tree, 40-70 feet tall and wide, with leathery, oval, spine-tipped, dark green leaves, hairy and gray-white beneath, and thick, deeply fissured, spongy, gray bark. Native to the western Mediterranean region from Portugal to Italy and from Morocco to Tunisia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 5-7,8-16,18-24

Quercus tomentella (island oak), evergreen tree, 30-50 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, upright and pyramidal, with leathery, elliptical, dark green leaves with widely spaced teeth, densely hairy and paler beneath. Native to canyons and ridges on the Channel Islands in southern California and Guadalupe Island in Baja California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Best right along the coast in the fog belt. May be offered as a subspecies or variety of Q. chrysolepis. Sunset: 7-9,14-17,19-24

Quercus turbinella (shrub live oak), Sonora scrub oak, evergreen shrub, 6-15 feet tall and wide, larger in moist locations, stiffly branched, with small, leathery, oval to oblong, yellowish gray-green leaves with sharply spiny margins, new growth purplish red. Spreads by root sprouts and may form thickets. Native to sandy soils in desert mountains of southeastern California east to Colorado, western Texas, and northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Quercus wislizeni (interior live oak), evergreen tree, variable, to 30-70 feet tall and wide, or shrubby to 20 feet tall, with thick, leathery, glossy, green leaves with smooth or spiny margins. Native to dry valleys and foothills in the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada from southern Oregon to Baja California. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-16,18-21

Ranunculus californicus (California buttercup), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with bright green, lobed and divided basal leaves and glossy, clear yellow flowers on leafless stems in spring. Dormant and deciduous in summer. May self-sow. Native to seasonally moist sites, both along the coast and inland, from southern Oregon to norhwestern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Ranunculus cortusifolius (Canary buttercup), biennial or perennial from rhizomes, 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with large, rounded, lobed and scalloped, mid-green leaves and dense clusters of shiny, cup-shaped, bright yellow flowers on 3- to 4-foot, branching stems in spring. Summer dormant and deciduous, reviving with fall rains. Native to seasonally moist forest edges and openings on Madeira, the Azores, and the Canary Islands. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. Prefers a dry summer dormancy. Sunset: N/A

Ranunculus asiaticus (Persian ranunculus), perennial from tuber, to 2 feet tall and wide, with deeply divided, feathery, green leaves and white, pink, red, purple, yellow, or bicolored, cup-shaped, sometimes double flowers with ruffled petals in late winter or early spring. Deciduous and dormant in summer, when tubers should be kept dry. Native to much of the Mediterranean region. Many cultivars. Sun, well-drained, slightly acidic soils. Best near the coast. Sunset: all zones

Ratibida columnifera (Mexican hat), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with feathery, deeply cut, green leaves and daisy flowers with yellow, red, or red and yellow, drooping petals and a dark brown, columnar, central disk on 2- to 3-foot, leafless stems in late spring to fall. Self-sows freely. Native to prairies and plains from southern Canada through much of the United States and south through Texas into Mexico. Sun, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 1-24

Rhagodia spinescens (Australian saltbush), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, prostrate or mounding, and densely covered with small, oval to triangular, silvery gray-green leaves on upright, sometimes spine-tipped branches. Inconspicuous, greenish flowers in summer are followed by showy clusters of small, bright red berries. Climbs other vegetation and cascades over rocks and walls. Native to much of Australia, both along the coast and inland. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: N/A

Rhamnus alaternus (Italian buckthorn), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 12-15 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with glossy, dark green leaves, inconspicuous flowers, and red berrylike fruits that age to dark purple. Native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Greece and north to the western shores of the Black Sea. 'Variegata', 8-12 feet tall, has dark green leaves edged in creamy white. Considered a high risk for invasiveness in parts of California. Sun or shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 4-24

Rhamnus crocea (redberry), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and 6-7 feet wide, with small, leathery, oval to nearly round, dark green leaves with finely toothed margins on stiff branches often but not always tipped with thorns. Inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in late winter are followed by showy, bright red, berrylike fruit. Native to coastal mountains from northern California to Baja California. Cool sun or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Good for dryish shade. Sunset: 7,14-24

Rhamnus ilicifolia (hollyleaf redberry), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 8-10 feet tall and wide, with thick, glossy, green leaves with spiny margins, inconspicuous flowers, and bright red berrylike fruit  in fall. Native to rocky slopes and canyons in mountains of southern Oregon, California, Arizona, and Baja California. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as a subspecies of R. crocea. Sunset: 7-10,14-23

Rhaphiolepis Majestic Beauty™ (Majestic Beauty hawthorn), evergreen shrub or small tree, 12-20 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with large, leathery, dark green leaves, new growth often coppery, and clusters of small, star-shaped, lightly fragrant, pale pink flowers in spring. Hybrid of uncertain parentage, possibly a cross between R. umbellata and Eriobotrya. Registered cultivar name is 'Montic'. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation.  Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Rhaphiolepis indica and cultivars (India hawthorn), evergreen shrubs, 4-5 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves, new growth often coppery, and clusters of small, star-shaped, lightly fragrant, pink-tinged white flowers in spring. Native to southern China south to Cambodia and Vietnam. 'Ballerina' is 2-3 feet tall and 4 feet wide with deep pink flowers. 'Clara' is 3-5 feet tall and wide with white flowers. 'Springtime' is 5-6 feet tall and wide with pale pink flowers. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Rhaphiolepis umbellata and cultivars (Yeddo hawthorn), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 6-8 feet tall and wide, with leathery, dark green leaves and clusters of small, star-shaped, lightly fragrant, white flowers in spring. Leaves are smaller and darker green than those of R. indica and branches are more upright. Native to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and coastal mainland China. 'Minor' is only slightly smaller, 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-10,12-24
