Rhodocoma arida (rhodocoma), restio, 5-6 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with upright, blue-gray stems bearing inconspicuous flowers and decorative brown bracts in fall and winter. Native to rocky outcrops in the semi-arid Little Karoo, Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Rhododendron spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Rhodohypoxis species (rose grass), perennials from tubers, 2-6 inches tall and 10-12 inches wide, with narrowly lance-shaped to linear, mid-green leaves and multiple stems bearing small, star-shaped, pink, red, or white flowers in spring. Most common in cultivation are R. baurii selections and hybrids. Native to mid- to high elevations in the mountains of summer-rainfall eastern South Africa and Lesotho. Dozens of cultivars. Cool sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Need a dry winter dormancy. Good rock garden plants. Sunset: 4-7,14-24

Rhus aromatica (skunk bush), deciduous shrub, 2-4 or sometimes 10 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, with aromatic, three-lobed, mid-green leaves that turn red, orange, and reddish purple in fall. Catkins on male plants form in fall and persist through the winter. On female plants clusters of tiny, yellow flowers in early spring are followed by showy, red, berrylike fruit. Plants spread by suckering roots and may form thickets. Native to open woodlands and rocky outcrops in much of North America east of the Rocky Mountains. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as R. trilobata. Sunset: 1-3,10

Rhus integrifolia (lemonade berry), evergreen shrub, 3-12 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with leathery, dark green leaves with small, sharp marginal teeth, dense clusters of tiny, pink or white flowers in midwinter to spring, and red, berrylike fruits. Native to dry, open slopes along the coast from Santa Barbara County and the Channel Islands to northern Baja California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,14-17,19-24

Rhus lentii (pink flowering sumac), evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide, with grayish green, oval to rounded leaves with wavy margins and prominent pale yellow veins. Showy clusters of bright pink flowers in late winter or early spring are followed by red, berrylike fruit. Native to bluffs and canyons in coastal mainland Baja California and on Cedros Island. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Rhus microphylla (little-leaf sumac), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 4-12 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with leaves divided into small, glossy, leathery, bright green, oval to elliptic leaflets. Clusters of white flowers appear before the leaves in mid-spring and are followed in female plants by red-orange, berrylike fruit. Spreads by suckers Native to sandy or rocky soils on dry slopes and mesas from Arizona to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 10-13

Rhus ovata (sugar bush), evergreen shrub, 6-20 feet tall and wide, with leathery, dark green, oval leaves and clusters of small, pink-tinted, white flowers in midwinter to spring followed by sticky, red, berrylike fruits. Similar to R. integrifolia but with larger, darker green leaves and adapted to inland rather than coastal locations. Native to dry slopes and canyons in foothills and mountains of southern California, Arizona, and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 9-12,14-24

Rhus typhina (staghorn sumac), deciduous shrub, 15-25 feet tall and 20-30 feet wide, with large leaves divided into many dark green, lance-shaped leaflets that turn yellow, orange, and red in fall. Showy clusters of tiny, greenish yellow flowers in late spring to early summer are followed by upright, pyramidal clusters of bright red, berrylike fruit. Spreads by suckering roots and by seed; may form thickets. Native to southeastern Canada and the northeastern and midwestern United States. Compact cultivars are available. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 1-10,14-17,A1-3

Ribes aureum (golden currant), deciduous shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with lobed, maplelike, light green leaves that turn reddish purple in fall. Clusters of fragrant, bright yellow, tubular flowers in spring are followed by small, yellow or purple berries. Native to dry slopes and moist streambanks in much of North America. The variety gracillimum, native to foothills of the Transverse Ranges in southern California, is 3-6 feet tall and sprawling. Cool sun to part shade, most soils. Accepts periodic flooding. Sunset: 1-12,14-23,A2-3

Ribes californicum (hillside gooseberry), deciduous shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves with toothed lobes on stiff, spiny stems and pendant, tubular, white flowers with purplish red sepals in late winter or early spring followed by bristly red berries. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains from northern to southern California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Ribes indecorum (white flowering currant), deciduous shrub, 6-10 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, lobed and scalloped, dark green leaves and small, pendant clusters of fragrant, white flowers in late winter to early spring followed by red or orange berries. Native to coastal mountains from Santa Barbara County to northern Baja California. Part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 7-9,11,14-24

Ribes malvaceum (chaparral currant), deciduous shrub, 5-8 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with lobed, maplelike, gray-green, aromatic leaves that turn red in fall. Clusters of fragrant, pink, tubular flowers in winter to early spring are followed by small, red berries. Native to the Coast Ranges and Sierra Nevada foothills from the San Francisco Bay Area to northern Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 6-9,14-24

Ribes menziesii (canyon gooseberry), deciduous shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with lobed and scalloped, bright green leaves on spiny branches and pendant, tubular, white flowers with purple sepals in late winter and early spring followed by purple berries. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains from southwestern Oregon to southern California. Part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Ribes roezlii (Sierra gooseberry), deciduous shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with small, rounded and lobed, dark green leaves with scalloped margins on spiny stems. Small, pendant, tubular, white flowers surrounded by prominent burgundy sepals are followed by round, prickly, green fruits that mature to red. Native to dry or moist slopes in partly shaded woodlands and forest openings in mountains throughout much of California. Part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

photos.filename: Ribes sanguineum varieties and cultivars (red-flowering currant)
photos.caption: Ribes sanguineum varieties and cultivars (red-flowering currant)

plants.culturalInformation: Ribes sanguineum varieties and cultivars (red-flowering currant), deciduous shrubs, 6-12 feet tall and wide, spreading by rhizomes, with lobed, aromatic, maplelike leaves and small, tubular, red or pink flowers, followed by dark purple berries. Native along the coast and in coastal mountains from southern British Columbia to northern California and east to Idaho. 'Inverness White' is a white-flowered selection of the usually pink-flowered variety glutinosum, which may be offered as R. glutinosum. 'King Edward VII' is a red-flowering selection of the variety sanguineum. Part shade to shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Ribes speciosum (fuchsia-flowered gooseberry), semi-evergreen shrub, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with lobed, maplelike, bright green leaves on sharply spiny stems. Bright red, tubular, spring flowers with protruding red stamens are followed by small, red-orange berries. Native to shady, north-facing slopes or seasonally moist places along the coast from the San Francisco Bay Area to northern Baja California. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Ribes viburnifolium and cvs. (evergreen currant), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide, with glossy, red-tinted, dark green, aromatic, oval leaves on red stems. Clusters of reddish pink, star-shaped flowers in late winter and spring are followed by small, red berries. Native to Santa Catalina Island and the coastal mainland of southern California and northern Baja California. 'Spooner's Mesa' is a lower growing cultivar from San Diego County with larger leaves and shorter internodes yielding a denser plant. Part shade to shade, most well-drained soils. Good for dryish shade. Sunset: 5,7-9,14-17,19-24

Robinia pseudoacacia (black locust), deciduous tree, fast growing to 35-60 feet tall and 25-45 feet wide, with thorny branches bearing dark bluish green leaves divided into many oval leaflets and pendulous spikes of fragrant, creamy white pea flowers in spring or early summer. Flowers are followed by dark purplish brown, beanlike seedpods. Self-sows prolifically and spreads by suckering roots to form thickets. Can be weedy or invasive. Native to the eastern and central United States. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Romneya coulteri (Matilija poppy), perennial from rhizomes, upright to 6-10 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with bluish gray stems and leaves and large flowers with crinkly, white petals and bright yellow stamens in early summer. Spreads vigorously once established. Native to dry canyons in coastal mountains of southern California and Baja California. Dormant in late summer if grown dry. Full sun, excellent drainage. Can be cut back hard in late fall. Sunset: 4-12,14-24

Romneya trichocalyx (hairy Matilija poppy), perennial, 4-8 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes to form a large colony, with waxy, gray-green leaves divided into several lance-shaped lobes and large flowers with crinkly, white petals and bright yellow stamens. Native to dry slopes and canyons in coastal mountains of southern California and northern Baja California. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Similar to R. coulteri but with more bristly sepals. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Rosa 'Cecile Brunner' (Cecile Brunner rose), hybrid polyantha, variable, from a shrubby 3-6 feet tall and wide to climbing forms 10-20 feet tall. Pointed, mid-green leaves are borne on almost thornless, reddish stems. Showy clusters of small, fragrant, light pink, double flowers appear in late spring to early summer and intermittently until fall. Hybrid between a double-flowered form of R. multiflora and a hybrid tea rose. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils, good air circulation. Adaptable. Sunset: 4-24

Rosa banksiae (Lady Banks rose), evergreen shrub, climber to 20 feet or more, with glossy, green leaves on thornless stems and large clusters of small, usually fragrant flowers in early to mid-spring. Native to central and western China. 'Alba Plena' has scented, double white flowers. 'Lutea' has unscented, double yellow flowers. Sun, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Rosa californica (California wild rose), deciduous shrub, 3-10 feet tall and spreading widely by underground stems, with dark green leaves divided into coarsely toothed leaflets on prickly, arching stems. May form thickets. Pale pink to deep red, fragrant, single flowers in spring and summer are followed by bright red fruits. Native to cool, shaded canyons, along streams, and in seasonally moist places from southwestern Oregon to northern Baja California.  May drop leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun to shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: N/A

Rosa minutifolia (Baja wild rose), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 2-3 feet tall and wide, slowly thicket forming, with glossy, green leaves divided into tiny, toothed leaflets on intensely thorny branches. Pink, purplish pink, or sometimes white flowers in winter and early spring. Native to coastal bluffs and foothills in the summer fog zone of northern Baja California and southwestern San Diego County. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Best in coastal southern California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Rosa rubiginosa (sweet briar rose), deciduous shrub, 6-12 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with aromatic, dark green, finely toothed leaves on upright, arching, thorny stems. Fragrant, pink, single flowers with white centers in late spring or early summer are followed by persistent red-orange fruit. Native to open, sunny areas throughout much of Europe to western Asia. Suckers and forms thickets. Can be weedy or invasive. Sun, well-drained soils, good air circulation. May be offered as R. eglanteria. Sunset: 1-24,A2-3

Rosa rugosa (Japanese rose), deciduous shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with thick, almost leathery, wrinkled, dark green leaves on thorny stems and fragrant, pink or white flowers from spring to fall. Forms dense thickets and may spread widely by seed. Native to coastal northeastern China, Japan, Korea, and southeastern Siberia. Cultivars are available with single or double flowers in white to pink or purplish red. Sun to part shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Good coastal plant. Sunset: 1-24,A1-3

Rosmarinus cultivars (rosemary) evergreen shrubs, upright to sprawling or prostrate, with aromatic, needle-like, dark green leaves and small blue flowers in late winter through spring and often again in fall. Species is native to coastal cliffs and islands of the Mediterranean region from Spain to Greece and around the northern edge of the Black Sea. Upright cultivars, 5-8 feet tall, include 'Blue Spires', 'Spice Islands', and 'Tuscan Blue', all with dark blue flowers. Mid-height, semi-upright spreaders good for covering banks are 'Collingwood Ingram', 'Ken Taylor', and 'Mozart', all with deep blue flowers. Nearly flat spillers, good for draping over walls, include 'Huntington Carpet', with pale blue flowers, 'Irene' ('Renzels'), with lavender-blue flowers, and Prostratus Group, with pale lavender-blue flowers. 'Arp' and 'Madalene Hill' ('Hill Hardy', 'Madeline Hill'), both upright to 3 feet tall, are said to be especially hardy. Sun, well-drained soils. Tip prune as needed to maintain form. May be offered as Salvia rosmarinus. Sunset: 4-24

Rosmarinus officinalis cultivars (rosemary), evergreen shrubs, prostrate to mounding or upright and 6-8 feet tall, with aromatic, needlelike, dark green leaves and small blue flowers in late winter and spring and often again in fall. Species is native to coastal cliffs and islands from Spain to Greece and around the northern edge of the Black Sea. Many cultivars, differing mostly in habit and flower color. 'Huntington Carpet' is 1-2 feet tall and 4-8 feet wide, with pale blue flowers. 'Tuscan Blue' is 4-6 feet tall and wide with deep purplish blue flowers. 'Albiflorus' ('Albus') is 3-5 feet tall with white flowers. Sun, well-drained soils. Tip prune as needed to maintain form. May be offered as Salvia rosmarinus. Sunset: 4-24

Rubus parviflorus (thimbleberry), deciduous shrub, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with large, finely hairy, lobed and toothed, medium green leaves on arching, thornless stems. Clusters of fragrant, white flowers with yellow stamens in spring are followed by red fruits resembling raspberries. Spreads by rhizomes to form thickets. Native to moist and partly shaded woodland or forest edges from southeastern Alaska east to Ontario and south to California and northern Mexico. Cool sun to part shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Rubus spectabilis (salmonberry), deciduous shrub, 3-10 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes, with upright or arching, prickly stems bearing green leaves divided into three leaflets with toothed margins. Red or pinkish purple flowers in early spring to early summer are followed by yellow to red-orange fruits that resemble raspberries. May form dense thickets. Native to damp forests and along streams from southern Alaska to northwestern California and east to Idaho. Cool sun to light shade or shade, most soils. Sunset: N/A

Ruellia californica (rama parda), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with small, aromatic, oval to broadly lance-shaped, velvety, mid-green leaves on gray-white stems and lightly fragrant, trumpet-shaped, purple to purplish pink flowers nearly year round in warm climates. May drop leaves in summer if grown dry. Native to arroyos in the lower Sonoran desert of Baja California and Sonora, Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-13

Ruellia peninsularis (Baja ruellia), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with small, oval, glossy, green leaves and bluish purple, trumpet-shaped flowers in spring and early summer or almost year-round in mild-winter climates. Native to Baja California. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset:12-13,21-24

Ruscus species (butcher's broom), evergreen shrubs and subshrubs, 1-3 feet tall and spreading widely by rhizomes, with large, oval to lance-shaped, dull or glossy, dark green, sometimes spine-tipped, leaflike structures (cladodes). Inconspicuous, greenish flowers are followed by bright red or sometimes yellow, waxy, berrylike fruit. Spread widely by rhizomes and form colonies. Native to shady woodlands from western Europe to Turkey and Iran. Shade to part sun, most soils. Good for dry shade. Sunset: 4-24

Russelia equisetiformis (coral fountain), perennial or subshrub, 2-4 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with arching, rushlike, bright green stems that cascade over walls or planters. Leaves are few and inconspicuous. Masses of narrowly tubular, bright red flowers are borne at the tips of stems in spring and summer or almost year round in warm-winter climates. Native to Mexico and Guatemala. Sun or shade, most soils. Sunset: 13-14,17,19-24

Ruta graveolens (rue), perennial or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with upright stems bearing aromatic, bluish gray-green leaves divided into lobed, oblong to paddle-shaped leaflets and clusters of small, yellow flowers with green centers in summer. Native to dry, rocky slopes in southeastern Europe. Short-lived. Self-sows. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back in early spring to renew. Sunset: 2-24

Salvia 'Allen Chickering' (Allen Chickering sage), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with deeply wrinkled, aromatic, gray-green, linear leaves and spikes of lavender flowers in spring and summer. Hybrid of S. clevelandii and S. leucophylla, both native to southern California. Similar to 'Aromas', 'Pozo Blue', and 'Whirly Blue'. Sun, well-drained soils. Tip prune in late fall or winter; does not respond well to hard cutting back. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Salvia 'Aromas' (Aromas sage), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, gray-green, linear leaves and spikes of lavender flowers in late spring and summer. Hybrid of S. clevelandii and S. leucophylla, both native to southern California. Similar to 'Allen Chickering', 'Pozo Blue', and 'Whirly Blue'. Sun, well-drained soils. Tip prune in late fall or winter; does not respond well to hard cutting back. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Salvia 'Bee's Bliss' (Bee's Bliss sage), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with lightly hairy, silvery gray-green, aromatic leaves and long spikes of lavender-blue flowers in mid-spring and early summer. Hybrid of garden origin, believed to be a cross between S. leucophylla and either S. clevelandii or S. sonomensis. May drop leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade inland, fast drainage. Cut back in late fall to renew. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Salvia 'Dara's Choice' (Sonoma sage), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 1-2 feet tall and 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, grayish green, lance-shaped leaves and outstretched stems with widely spaced clusters of blue-violet, tubular flowers in spring and summer. Cascades over walls. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be between S. sonomensis and S. mellifera. Sun to light shade, afternoon shade in hot climates, fast drainage, good air circulation. Best near the coast. Sunset: 7,14-24

Salvia 'Gayle Nielsen' (Gayle Nielsen sage), evergreen shrub , 3-4 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, silvery gray-green leaves and short spikes of blue-violet flowers with reddish purple sepals in summer. Garden origin, likely a selection of S. dorrii but often offered as a hybrid with S. clevelandii. Sun to light shade, excellent drainage. Tip prune only. May be offered as S. Trident™. Sunset: N/A

Salvia 'Mrs. Beard' (Mrs. Beard sage), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, green to gray-green leaves and short spikes of pale lavender-blue flowers in spring. Hybrid of garden origin believed to be a cross between S. sonomensis and S. mellifera. Cool sun to light shade, afternoon shade inland, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Salvia apiana (white sage), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with large, velvety, gray-green, aromatic leaves that age to silvery white and tall spikes of lavender-tinged, white flowers in spring and summer. Native to dry, gravelly, exposed hillsides from Santa Barbara County south to northern Baja California. Sun, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 7-9,11,13-24

Salvia brandegeei (Santa Rosa Island sage), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 5-7 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped to linear, scalloped, dark green leaves and whorled clusters of bluish lavender, tubular flowers in early spring. Native to ocean-facing bluffs and canyons in northwestern Baja California and on Santa Rosa Island in southern California. Best near the coast. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 15-17,19-24

Salvia canariensis (Canary Island sage), evergreen shrub, 5-8 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, triangular, silvery gray-green leaves on upright stems and dense spikes of tubular flowers with bluish purple petals and reddish purple bracts in summer. Self-sows. Native to the Canary Islands. Sun, well-drained soils. Cut back in winter to renew. Sunset: N/A

Salvia chamaedryoides (blue sage), perennial, 1 foot tall and spreading to 2-4 feet wide, with small, silvery gray-green, aromatic leaves and small, bright blue flowers on tall stems in late spring and fall and intermittently in summer. Native to the high desert in mountains of eastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Sunset: 8-9,12,14-24

Salvia clevelandii and hybrids (Cleveland sage), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with felted, gray-green, rough-textured, aromatic leaves and tall spikes of blue-violet flowers in spring and summer. Native to dry chaparral and coastal sage scrub in southern California and northwestern Baja California. ‘Winnifred Gilman’, a selection of the species, is more compact and has especially rich violet flowers. ‘Allen Chickering’, ‘Aromas’, ‘Pozo Blue’, and ‘Whirly Blue’ are hybrids with S. leucophylla. Sun, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Salvia coahuilensis (Coahuila sage), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, linear, olive green leaves and purple, tubular flowers from early summer to fall. Native to the mountains of northeastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Cut back in late winter to renew. May be offered as a purple-flowered form of S. greggii. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Salvia coccinea (Texas sage), perennial, 2-3 feet tall and wide, variable, with heart-shaped or almost triangular, hairy, green leaves and widely spaced clusters of tubular, bright red-orange flowers on tall stems for much of the year where winters are mild. Native to or naturalized in much of tropical and subtropical America, from Mexico south to Brazil and east through the Caribbean and the southwestern United States to Florida. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be short lived but self-sows readily and can be invasive. Sunset: 12-24

Salvia darcyi (darcy sage), perennial, 2-4 feet tall and spreading by rooting stems, with aromatic, triangular, pale green leaves and tall spikes of bright red, tubular flowers in late spring to early summer and sometimes again in fall. Native to mid- to higher elevations in the mountains of northeastern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,12,14-24

Salvia dorrii (purple sage), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, with aromatic, silvery gray-green, broadly linear to oval leaves and pale to dark blue or purplish blue flowers with reddish purple bracts in spring. Native to dry, open slopes in high deserts of western North America from eastern Washington and Idaho to California and Arizona. Sun, excellent drainage. Tip prune only. Sunset: 2-3,10-13,18-19

Salvia greggii and hybrids (autumn sage), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and 4 feet wide, with small, narrow, light green, aromatic leaves and bright red, tubular flowers in summer and fall. Native to rocky slopes in mountains of southwestern Texas and northeastern Mexico. 'Alba' has white flowers. 'Salmon ' has pinkish orange flowers. 'Furman's Red' has magenta flowers. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Afternoon shade in hot-summer climates. Sunset: 8-24

Salvia lanceolata (lance-leaf sage), perennial or subshrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with small, aromatic, grayish green, lance-shaped leaves and short spikes of bicolored, purplish pink and rusty yellow, tubular flowers in spring and summer. Native to rocky or sandy soils along the west coast of Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good coastal plant. Sunset: N/A

photos.filename: Salvia leucantha and cvs. (Mexican bush sage)
photos.caption: Salvia leucantha and cvs. (Mexican bush sage)

plants.culturalInformation: Salvia leucantha and cultivars (Mexican bush sage), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, gray-green leaves and tall spikes of tiny white flowers with showy purple bracts in summer. Native to tropical and subtropical forests in central and eastern Mexico. 'Santa Barbara' is 30 inches tall and 4 feet wide with purple flowers and purple bracts. Cut back in late winter to renew. Sunset: 12-24

Salvia leucophylla and cultivars (purple sage), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, whitish gray, lance-shaped leaves, new growth green, and pinkish lavender, tubular flowers in spring and summer. Native to gravelly soils on hot, dry hillsides in coastal southern California and Baja California. 'Point Sal' is 2-3 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide. 'Amethyst Bluff' is 6-8 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide. 'Figueroa', with especially white leaves, is 4-6 feet tall and wide. Sun, fast drainage. Tip prune only. Sunset: 8-9,14-17,19-24

Salvia melissodora (grape-scented sage), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, oval, gray-green leaves, silvery beneath, and fragrant, tubular, lavender flowers in summer. Native to the mountains of southern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Salvia mellifera and cultivars (black sage), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with aromatic, wrinkled, lance-shaped, dark green leaves, paler beneath, and white, pale blue, or pale lavender flowers in late spring and early summer. Native to coastal bluffs and foothills from the San Francisco Bay Area to northern Baja California. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Salvia microphylla (cherry/Graham sage), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, small ovate green leaves with almost year-round red flowers. Native to southern Arizona and northern Mexico. Many hybrids and cultivars, including the popular ‘Hot Lips’ with bi-colored white and red flowers (or sometimes all white or all red at the same time, coloration may change based on temperature). Best appearance if sheared 2-3 times a year to remove spent blooms and keep shape full. Full sun, most soils but avoid waterlogging. Sunset zones: 7-24.

Salvia muelleri (autumn sage), evergreen shrub, 18 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, aromatic, glossy green leaves on dark purple stems and dark purple, tubular flowers in mid- to late summer. Similar to S. greggii but lower, more open, and more widely spreading. Native to the mountains of northeastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Cut back in early spring to renew. Sunset: N/A

Salvia munzii (San Miguel Mountain sage), evergreen shrub, 1-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with small, aromatic, dark green, linear leaves and upright spikes of tubular, blue flowers in spring or early summer. Native to coastal mountains of southern San Diego County and northern Baja California. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Drops leaves in late summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Salvia officinalis and cultivars (garden sage), perennial or short-lived shrub, 1-3 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, oval to oblong, gray-green leaves and short, upright spikes of small, lavender-blue flowers in late spring and summer. Native to rocky slopes around the Adriatic Sea from Italy to the Balkan Peninsula and Greece and naturalized in much of the Mediterranean region. Many cultivars, some with variegated or purplish leaves. Sun, most well-drained soils. Trim lightly in spring to maintain compact form. Sunset: 2-24

Salvia pachyphylla (rose sage), evergreen shrub or subshrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with aromatic, silvery gray-green leaves and dense spikes of tubular, purplish blue flowers with purple bracts in summer and fall. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in the mountains of southern California, northern Baja California, southern Nevada, and western Arizona. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Salvia regla (mountain sage), semi-evergreen or deciduous shrub, 5-8 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with aromatic, rounded to heart-shaped, glossy, green leaves and loose clusters of bright red or red-orange, tubular flowers in late summer and fall. Native to rocky, wooded slopes in the mountains of western Texas and northeastern Mexico. Part shade or afternoon shade, most well-drained soils. Prefers a dryish winter dormancy. Prune only when actively growing. Sunset: 7-10,14-24

Salvia reptans (west Texas cobalt sage), 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, narrowly lance-shaped, almost needlelike, green leaves and small clusters of deep blue, tubular flowers widely spaced along lax and floppy or upright stems in late summer and fall. Upright plants are often marketed as 'West Texas Form'. Native to dry, gravelly soils and seasonal washes in the arid mountains of western Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Salvia sclarea (clary sage), biennial or short-lived perennial, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with large, aromatic, broadly lance-shaped to oval, wrinkled, gray-green leaves with toothed margins and tall, widely branching spikes of tubular flowers with creamy white and lavender petals and white or purplish pink, papery bracts in late spring and summer. Native to the northwestern Mediterranean region. Self-sows prolifically and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 2-24

Salvia semiatrata (bicolor sage), perennial, 3-5 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, triangular, olive green, wrinkled leaves and bicolored, deep purple and pale lavender flowers with purplish red bracts in summer to fall and intermittently year round. Native to forest edges and exposed, rocky cliffs in the mountains of central Mexico. Cool sun, afternoon shade inland, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 16-17,21-24

Salvia sonomensis and cultivars (Sonoma sage), evergreen shrub, 12-18 inches tall and spreading 10-12 feet wide, with aromatic, gray-white, lightly hairy leaves and small, white to blue, lavender, or purple flowers on leafless stems in spring and summer. Native to dry slopes, usually shaded by larger shrubs, in the Coast Ranges and foothills of the Sierra Nevada. Cool sun to light shade or afternoon shade, most fast-draining soils. Best away from the immediate coast. Sunset: 7,9,14-24

Salvia spathacea and cultivars (hummingbird sage), perennial, 1-3 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes to 4-5 feet wide, with aromatic, lance-shaped, light green, wrinkled leaves and pale pink to dark rose flowers from late winter into summer. Native to lightly shaded slopes in the Coast Ranges from central to southern California. Good choice for dryish shade. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Salvia x jamensis cultivars (Jame sage), evergreen shrubs, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, glossy, oval, green leaves and tubular fall flowers in various shades and combinations of white, pink, yellow, or red. Natural hybrids found in northeastern Mexico near the town of Jame, where the parents, S. greggii and S. microphylla, share territory. Many cultivars. 'Sierra San Antonio' has pale yellow and pink flowers. 'Hot Lips' has red and white flowers. 'Lipstick' has pinkish red flowers. 'Ignition Purple' has bright purple flowers. Best in mild-winter, mild-summer climates. Sun to light shade, fast drainage, good air circulation. Sunset: 8-24

plants.botanicalName: Sambucus spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Sambucus species (California native and non-native), (elderberry), deciduous shrubs or small trees, fast growing, with leaves divided into dark or light green leaflets with serrated margins. Large, flat-topped clusters of white or creamy yellow, spring or mid-summer flowers are followed by red or blue-black, berrylike fruit. Most spread by suckers to form thickets. S. nigra, 10-20 feet tall and wide, is native to Europe, northern Africa, southwestern Asia, and western North America, including much of California. S. canadensis, 10-12 feet tall and wide and sometimes offered as a subspecies of S. nigra, is native to central and eastern North America. S. cerulea, 10-30 feet tall and wide and sometimes offered as a subspecies of S. nigra or as S. mexicana, is native from southern British Columbia south through the Rocky Mountains to California, western Texas, and northwestern Mexico. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained, moisture-retentive soils. Sunset: zones vary

Santolina species (lavender cotton), evergreen shrubs, 1-2 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with narrow, aromatic, dissected and lobed, green or gray leaves and small, rounded flowers in summer. S. chamaecyparissus, with gray leaves and bright yellow flowers, is native to dry, rocky slopes from Portugal to Italy and Croatia. S. rosmarinifolia, with green leaves and pale yellow flowers, is native to Portugal, Spain, and southern France. Full sun, good to excellent drainage. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Plants may need replacing every few years. Sunset: zones vary

Saponaria ocymoides (rock soapwort), perennial, 6-8 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with small, oval to lance-shaped, finely hairy, gray-green leaves on trailing, reddish stems and clusters of small, fragrant, bright pink flowers in early summer. Cascades over walls. Native to rocky slopes in the mountains of southern Europe from Spain to the Balkans. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Self-sows readily. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: 1-11,14-24

photos.filename: Saponaria × lempergii ‘Max Frei’ (hybrid soapwort), evergreen herbaceous perennial, 5 inches tall and spreading up to 2 feet wide, lance-shaped, hairy, dark green leaves and masses of pink flowers from summer into fall. Shear after bloom
photos.caption: Saponaria × lempergii ‘Max Frei’ (hybrid soapwort), evergreen herbaceous perennial, 5 inches tall and spreading up to 2 feet wide, lance-shaped, hairy, dark green leaves and masses of pink flowers from summer into fall. Shear after bloom to improve looks and for best rebloom. Stems are brittle, so keep away from foot traffic. Hybrid between two Mediterranean species. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 7-9, 14-24.

plants.culturalInformation: Sarcococca confusa (sweet box), evergreen shrub, slow growing to 3-5 feet tall and wide, with oval to lance-shaped, glossy, leathery, dark green leaves with wavy margins. Tiny, fragrant, creamy white flowers with protruding white stamens in winter are followed by blue-black, berrylike fruit. Provenance uncertain, believed to be native to western China, possibly a natural hybrid between varieties of S. ruscifolia and S. hookeriana or S. humilis. Part shade to shade, well-drained soils. Good for dryish shade. May be offered as S. ruscifolia. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

photos.filename: Sarcococca hookeriana var. humilis (dwarf sweet box)
photos.caption: Sarcococca hookeriana var. humilis (dwarf sweet box)

plants.culturalInformation: Sarcococca hookeriana var. humilis (dwarf sweet box), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and spreading slowly by rooting stems to 6-8 feet wide, with glossy, dark green, lance-shaped leaves and clusters of tiny, fragrant, white flowers in winter followed by berrylike, blue-black fruit. Native to the Himalayas from northeastern India to western China. Part to full shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 3-9,14-24

Sarcococca ruscifolia (fragrant sarcococca), evergreen shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with glossy, dark green, pointed oval leaves. Clusters of small, fragrant, white flowers in late winter are followed by small, red, berrylike fruits that age to black. Native to western and central China. Cool sun to part shade or shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Sasa species (bamboo), grass, fast growing and shrublike, 2-8 feet tall and spreading rapidly by rhizomes to form dense thickets. Stems are smooth and upright to arching, and leaves are large, ribbed, and broadly lance-shaped to oblong with finely toothed margins. In some species (e.g., S. veitchii) leaf margins gradually turn creamy white in winter, lending a distinctly variegated appearance. Flowering is infrequent and unpredictable, occurring at widely spaced intervals of many years. Native to eastern Asia from southeastern Russia to China, Korea, and Japan. Fairly cold hardy, the most northerly genus of bamboo. Sun or shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Saxifraga spp. (for some CA natives see Micranthes spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Scaevola aemula (fairy fan), perennial, variable, 6-12 or sometimes 2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with lance-shaped to oblong, toothed, lightly hairy, bright green leaves and purplish blue, fan-shaped flowers with white or yellow centers from late spring into fall. Spills over walls and the edges of containers. Native to sandy soils along the coast of eastern and southeastern Australia. Many cultivars with flowers in shades of blue, purple, white, or pink. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

plants.botanicalName: Schefflera elegantissima (Dizygotheca elegantissima) (shade in low desert)

plants.culturalInformation: Schinus molle (California pepper tree), evergreen tree, fast growing to 25-40 feet tall and wide, with bright green leaves divided into narrow leaflets on pendulous branches and rough, dark gray bark. Drooping clusters of tiny, creamy white summer flowers are followed by small, red berrylike fruit on female trees. Native to the southern Andes mountains from Peru to Bolivia, Chile, and Argentina. Leaf drop can be messy and discourages growth of plants beneath. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Schizachyrium scoparium (little bluestem), warm-season bunchgrass, upright or densely mounding to 1-3 feet tall and wide, with narrow leaves, intensely blue in spring, bluish green to green in summer, and bronzy green, orange, or coppery red in fall. Fluffy, silvery flowers on pink, 4- to 5-foot stems in late summer. Self-sows but not aggressively. Native to prairies and open woodlands in much of North America. Sun, most soils. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Sunset: 1-24

Scilla peruviana (giant scilla), perennial from bulb, less than 1 foot tall and wide, low mound of strap-shaped, green leaves and large, round-topped clusters of tiny, blue-violet, star-shaped flowers on 1-foot stems in spring and early summer. Spreads slowly as bulbs continue to multiply. Dormant after flowering if grown dry. Native to the western Mediterranean region from southwestern Europe to northwestern Africa. Sun to part shade, well-drained, gritty soil. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. Prefers a dry summer dormancy. May be offered as S. hughii. Sunset: 14-17,19-24

Scutellaria suffrutescens (pink Texas skullcap), perennial, 3-8 inches tall and 10-18 inches wide, with small, oval to rounded, gray-green leaves and small, tubular, bright reddish pink flowers from spring to fall. Native to rocky soils in the mountains of northern Mexico. May self-sow. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: 4-12,14-24

Searsia lancea (African sumac), evergreen tree, 20-30 feet tall and 20-35 feet wide, low branching and weeping, with aromatic, leathery, dark green leaves divided into three narrowly lance-shaped, willowlike leaflets. Inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in summer are followed by small, red or yellow, berrylike fruits on female trees. Native to South Africa from Zambia to the Western Cape. Sun, most soils, including poorly drained. Good tall hedge or screen. May be offered as Rhus. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Sedum species (sedum), succulents, mat-forming to upright, with fleshy stems and leaves in a wide range of colors and shapes and showy clusters of tiny, star-shaped flowers in spring or summer. Hundreds of cultivars, often offered with no information on species or native origin. Sun to part shade or afternoon shade, well-drained soils. Some species have been moved to the genus Hylotelephium. Sunset: zones vary

Sempervivum species (house leek), succulents, rosettes of leaves with pointed tips and star-shaped flowers. Each rosette flowers only once and then dies, replaced by offsets that can be removed and replanted or left to form a small colony. Native to mountains of the Mediterranean region. Most plants offered are cultivars. Cool sun to part shade or afternoon shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: 2-24

Senecio cineraria (dusty miller), perennial, less than 1 foot to 2 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with lance-shaped, deeply or shallowly dissected and lobed, silvery gray-green, felted leaves and rounded to flat-topped clusters of small, creamy white or yellow daisy flowers in summer. Native to seaside cliffs and rocky coastal sites in the Mediterranean region from Spain to western Turkey and from Morocco to Tunisia. Grown for foliage. Cultivars without flowers are available. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Jacobaea maritima. Sunset: 4-24

Senecio cylindricus (narrowleaf chalksticks), succulent, 1-2 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with upcurved, narrowly cylindrical or fingerlike, gray-green leaves and upright clusters of creamy white flowers in late spring and early summer. Stems spread out and root where they touch the ground. Native to coastal Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as a subspecies of S. talinoides or as S. vitalis. Sunset: N/A

Senecio mandraliscae (kleinia), succulent, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with cylindrical, upward curving, 3- to 4-inch-long, silvery blue-gray leaves coated with a powdery, white wax. In late summer, small, creamy white flowers on tall, thin stems rise a foot or more above the leaves. Species is native to Western Cape Province, South Africa; the plant commonly offered in nurseries may be a hybrid. Sun to light shade, fast-draining soils. May be offered as Kleinia or as a variety of Curio talinoides. Sunset: 12-13,16-17,21-24

Senecio serpens (blue chalksticks), succulent, 1 foot tall and spreading 2-3 feet wide, with short, upright, powdery blue-gray, fingerlike leaves and clusters of small, white flowers in summer and fall. Stems root as they spread out along the ground. Native to coastal Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Kleinia repens. Sunset: 16-17,21-24

Senecio viravira (dusty miller), perennial or subshrub, 3-5 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide, with finely divided, silvery gray-white leaves and loose clusters of small, creamy white, buttonlike flowers in summer and fall. Grown for foliage. Native to the mountains of central Argentina. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Trim lightly to maintain dense form. May be offered as S. leucostachys or as S. cineraria 'Candissimus'. Sunset: 4-24

Senna armata (spicy senna), deciduous shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with spiny branches bearing ephemeral, spine-tipped leaves divided into small, oval leaflets that drop soon after they appear. Small clusters of fragrant, yellow flowers in spring or early summer are followed by bean-like seedpods. Native to sandy or gravelly washes in deserts of southeastern California, Nevada, Arizona, and Baja California. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cassia. Sunset: N/A

Senna artemisioides (feathery cassia), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with light gray-green leaflike structures (phyllodes) divided into small, needlelike segments and clusters of fragrant, yellow pea flowers in late winter through spring or almost year round. Flowers are followed by lime green, beanlike seedpods that age to dark brown. Native to Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cassia. Sunset: 8-9,12-16,18-23

Senna nemophila (desert cassia), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 5-8 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into one to several pairs of narrowly linear, almost threadlike, mid-green leaflike structures (phyllodes). Masses of lightly fragrant, cup-shaped, bright yellow flowers appear in late winter or early spring, especially after rainfall, and are followed by green, beanlike seedpods that age to papery dark brown. Native to arid and semi-arid, inland regions of all of Australia's mainland states. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cassia. Sunset: 12-24

Senna phyllodinea (silverleaf cassia), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 4-6 feet tall and wide, with long, silvery gray-green, sickle-shaped leaf-like structures (phyllodes) and showy clusters of yellow, cup-shaped flowers in winter or early spring, especially after rains. Flowers are followed by green, bean-like seedpods that age to papery dark brown. Native to rocky soils in arid and semi-arid, inland regions of central Australia. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Cassia. Sunset: 13-16,19-20

Sidalcea malviflora (checkerbloom), perennial, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, basal clump of broadly rounded, lobed or scalloped, lightly hairy, dark green leaves and light to dark pink, cup-shaped flowers with white veining on 2- to 3-foot, leafy stems in spring and early summer. Self-sows readily. Native to seasonally moist meadows in coastal mountains and inland foothills from Washington to northern Baja California. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

Sideritis syriaca (sideritis), perennial, 12-18 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with linear, felted, gray-green to greenish white leaves and small clusters of tiny, pale yellow flowers on upright stems in summer. Native to rocky slopes at mid- to high elevations in the mountains of Greece and the Balkans. Sun, fast drainage. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Silene spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Silene species, California native and non-native (moss pink, campion, catchfly), annuals, biennials, and perennials, variable, with lance-shaped to linear, elliptic, or oblong, green to gray-green, sometimes hairy leaves, often forming a basal rosette. Tubular, white, pink, purple, or red flowers, most with widely flaring, often lobed petals and some with a distinctly inflated calyx, appear in spring or summer. Hundreds of species native to many habitats, from high alpine meadows to conifer forests and coastal cliffs, distributed throughout much of the world. Some spread by rhizomes or by seed and some, such as S. vulgaris and S. latifolia, can be invasive outside their natural range. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Simmondsia chinensis (jojoba), evergreen shrub, 3-8 feet tall and wide, with leathery, oval, bluish gray-green leaves on stiff branches. Tiny, greenish yellow flowers in late spring are followed by green, nutlike fruits on female plants if male plants are nearby. Native to rocky or sandy soils in coastal mountains and deserts of southern California and Baja California east into southern Arizona and northern Mexico. May drop leaves in summer if grown dry. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 7-24

Sisyrinchium bellum and cultivars (blue-eyed grass), perennial, 6-12 inches tall and wide, with narrow, green leaves resembling iris and purplish-blue flowers with yellow centers in spring. Summer dormant. Self-sows. Native to seasonally moist woodlands and grasslands from Oregon to northwestern Baja California. 'Album' has white flowers. 'Greyhound Rock' has pale blue flowers and gray-green leaves. 'Figueroa' has creamy variegation on the leaf margins. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Sisyrinchium striatum (yellow eyed grass), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 1 foot wide, with fans of upright, strap-shaped, dark grayish green leaves and upright spikes of creamy white or pale yellow, cup-shaped flowers with darker yellow centers in late spring. Flowers are followed by black seedpods. Spreads slowly by creeping rootstocks to form a large clump. May self-sow. Can be weedy or invasive in damp soils. Native to grasslands and open woodlands in the mountains of Chile and Argentina. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Solanum hindsianum (mariola), perennial or subshrub, 6-8 feet tall and 5-6 feet wide, with sometimes prickly, upright stems bearing oval to oblong or lance-shaped, felted, gray-green leaves, densely hairy beneath, and loose clusters of purple flowers with bright yellow stamens from fall to spring. Native to rocky or sandy soils in Baja California and Sonora, Mexico, and adjacent parts of southern Arizona. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Sunset: N/A

Solanum umbelliferum and cultivars (blue witch), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with pale green, oval to elliptic leaves and purplish blue flowers with bright yellow stamens in winter and spring followed by small, round, green fruits. Native to dry, rocky slopes and canyons from northern California to Baja California and east into Arizona. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: N/A

Solanum wendlandii (Costa Rican nightshade), semi-evergreen vine, 10-15 feet, with leaves divided into large, oval, glossy, mid-green leaflets with wavy margins and hooked prickles along the midrib beneath. Showy clusters of blue-purple flowers from spring to fall fade to lavender and then nearly white. Climbs by twining. Native from southern Mexico to Colombia. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 16,21-24

Solanum xanti and cultivars (blue witch), evergreen shrub, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with oval to oblong, green leaves and showy clusters of pale to dark purple flowers with bright yellow stamens in spring or early summer followed by round, green fruits. Native to rocky soils in mountains from southern Oregon to northern Baja California and east to Nevada and Arizona. 'Mountain Pride' has especially large, dark purple flowers. Sun to light shade, most well-drained soils. Drops leaves in summer if grown dry. Sunset: 7-9,11,14-24

Solidago velutina subsp. californica (California goldenrod), perennial, 1-4 feet tall and spreading by rhizomes, with oval to lance-shaped, gray-green leaves on upright stems and dense spikes of tiny, yellow flowers in summer and early fall. Native to both moist and dry soils in grasslands and open woodlands throughout much of California, southern Oregion, and northern Baja California. Self-sows and can be weedy. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Sollya heterophylla (Australian bluebell creeper), evergreen vining shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with glossy, oval to lance-shaped, bright green leaves on twining stems and small, bell-shaped, purplish blue flowers in summer. Flowers are followed by purplish blue, berrylike fruit. Creeps along the ground or climbs with support. May self-sow. Native to forest openings and open woodlands in southwestern Western Australia. Cool sun or part shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Billardiera. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Sophora secundiflora (Texas mountain laurel), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk or low branching, slow growing to 15-20 feet tall and 8-10 feet wide, with leathery, glossy, dark green leaves divided into multiple oblong leaflets with rounded tips. Drooping clusters of fragrant, bluish purple pea flowers in spring are followed by hard, pale brown seedpods containing decorative, bright orange seeds. Native to rocky slopes, often along streams, from south-central and western Texas west to southeastern New Mexico and south to central Mexico. White-flowered and gray-leaved cultivars are available. Sun to part shade, well-drained, alkaline soils. Sunset: 8-16,18-24

Sparaxis species (harlequin flower), perennials from corms, 12-16 inches tall and 1-2 feet wide, with strap-shaped, green leaves and star-shaped, white, pink, red, orange, or yellow spring flowers with contrasting centers often bicolored or edged in black. Summer dormant. Species are native to rocky or clayey slopes or flats in Western and Northern Cape provinces and the western Karoo, South Africa. S. tricolor, with red--orange flowers with yellow centers, is commonly available and often used in hybridization. S. bulbifera has white flowers sometimes tinged with yellow or purple. S. elegans has soft pinkish orange flowers with purple centers. Many cultivars, especially hybrids, often available as seed mixes. Sun, well-drained soils. Prefer a dry summer dormancy. Need moisture in winter to bloom well. Sunset: 9,12-24

plants.botanicalName: Sphaeralcea spp. (CA native and non-native spp.)
plants.culturalInformation: Sphaeralcea species (globe mallow), perennials, upright to mounding 2-4 feet tall and wide, with softly hairy, shallowly lobed or deeply cut, green or gray-green leaves and bowl-shaped, orange, red, or pale to bright pink flowers. Most are native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. Full sun, fast-draining soils, good air circulation. Cut back in late winter or early spring to renew. Best in hot-summer climates. Sunset: zones vary

plants.botanicalName: Spiraea spp. (CA native and non native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Sporobolus airoides (alkali sacaton), warm-season bunchgrass, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with narrow, arching, silvery gray-green leaves that age to light tan and airy, mid-summer flowers on 4-foot stems. Native to varied habitats in much of western North America, often where there is underground or seasonal moisture. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Sporobolus wrightii (big sacaton), warm-season bunchgrass, 4-5 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide, with dark gray-green leaves and flower spikes 5-6 feet tall in summer. Native to rocky slopes and dry lake beds from eastern California to Texas and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Cut back in early spring to renew. Sunset: 3b,7-16,18-24

Stachys bullata (hedge nettle), perennial, 1 foot tall and spreading by rhizomes to 3-6 feet wide, with aromatic, hairy, oval to triangular, mid-green leaves with scalloped margins. Whorls of tubular, pale pink to lavender flowers with intricate white markings are spaced intermittently on upright, 2-foot stems in spring and summer. Native to the summer fog zone in coastal mountains from the San Francisco Bay Area to southern California. Part shade to shade, most soils, including seasonally flooded. Good choice for shady rain gardens. May be offered as S. californica. Sunset: N/A

Stachys byzantina (lamb's ears), perennial,  6-8 inches tall and spreading 4-5 feet wide by rooting stems, with dense rosettes of thick, gray-green leaves so densely woolly that they appear silvery gray. Tall spikes of purplish pink flowers on tall stems in summer. Usually grown for foliage, some cultivars rarely flower. Native from Turkey to Iran. Cool sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as S. lanata. Sunset: 1-24

Stachys lanata and cultivars (lamb's ears), perennial, 6-12 inches tall and spreading by rooting stems, with thick, soft, felted, oblong, silvery gray leaves and tiny, pale purplish pink flowers on upright stems well above the leaves in late spring and early summer. Native to northern Turkey, the southern Caucasus, and Iran. Grown for foliage. Cultivars with few or no flowers are available. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as S. byzantina. Sunset: 1-24

plants.botanicalName: Stachys maxima (S. maxima and S. minor may be compact selections of S. officinalis)*

plants.culturalInformation: Sternbergia lutea (yellow autumn crocus), perennial from bulb, 6 inches tall and wide, with upright, linear or strap-shaped, glossy, dark green leaves that appear in fall along with or just after the bright yellow, bowl-shaped flowers on leafless stems. Dormant in summer. Spreads slowly by bulb offsets and may self-sow. Native to rocky soils in mountains from the Balearic Islands east to Turkey and northern Iran. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. Good rock garden plant. Sunset: 3-10,14-24

Stipa cernua (nodding needlegrass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with narrow, bluish green leaves and airy, purplish flowers on 2-foot, arching stems in spring. Native to coastal mountains of California and northern Baja California. Self-sows. Dormant or partially dormant in summer. Sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as Nassella. Sunset: 7-9,11,14-24

Stipa comata (needle and thread grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, grayish green leaves and airy, light tan flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems in early summer. Native to sandy or gravelly soils in many habitats, from grasslands to forests, in foothills and mountains of western and midwestern North America. May be offered as Hesperostipa. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Stipa hymenoides (Indian rice grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, bright green leaves and airy, greenish yellow flowers on 2- to 3-foot stems in early summer. Native to dry, sandy or gravelly soils east of the Cascades from British Columbia east to Manitoba and south to California, western Texas, and northern Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Oryzopsis or as Achnatherum. Sunset: 1-3,10-13

Stipa lepida (foothill needlegrass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, green leaves and airy, silvery gray flowers on 2- to 3-foot arching stems in early summer. Native to dry slopes in coastal mountains and Sierra Nevada foothills from northern California south into northern Baja California. Part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Nassella. Sunset: 7-9,11,14-24

Stipa pulchra (purple needlegrass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, bright green to grayish green leaves and airy, purplish flowers on 2- to 4-foot arching stems in early summer. Native from coastal northern California, the Central Valley, and the west-facing Sierra Nevada foothills south to northern Baja California. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Nassella. Sunset: 5-9,11,14-24

Stipa ramosissima (pillar of smoke), cool-season bunchgrass, 4-6 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with narrow, mid-green leaves on sturdy stems with whorled branches that resemble bamboo. Fine-textured, airy sprays of showy flowers emerge bronzy and age to creamy white and then smoky gray. Flowering may occur from late winter to fall or at almost any time of year. Self-sows. Native to woodland and forest openings and edges in eastern Australia, usually in moist locations. Sun or part shade, most well-drained soils, including both dry and periodically flooded. Cut back hard in late winter to renew. May be offered as Austrostipa. Sunset: 14-24

Stipa tenuissima (Mexican feather grass), cool-season bunchgrass, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, arching, bright green leaves that age to tan and a haze of tawny, extremely fine-textured flowers in summer. Native to western Texas and southern New Mexico south to central Mexico. Self-sows prolifically and considered a high risk for invasiveness in California. May be offered as Nassella. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 2b-24

Strelitzia regina var. juncea (narrow-leaved bird of paradise), perennial from rhizomes, with upright, rushlike, bluish gray-green, leafless petioles that appear to be stems. From late fall to early spring showy flowers with blue petals and orange sepals emerge one at a time from a large, sheathlike, pink-tinged bract (spathe) held at right angles near the top of each 6-foot stem. Spreads slowly to form a large clump. Native just inland from the south coast of Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as S. juncea. Sunset: N/A

Styphnolobium japonicum (pagoda tree), deciduous tree, upright and wide-spreading to 35-65 feet tall and wide, with leaves divided into oval, glossy, dark green leaflets and showy, pendulous clusters of fragrant, creamy white pea flowers in late summer. Flowers are followed by beanlike seedpods that may persist into winter. Fruit drop can be messy. Native to northeastern China and Korea. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Sophora japonica. Sunset: 2-24

Styrax redivivus (snowdrop bush), deciduous shrub, slow growing to 6-12 feet tall and wide , with thin, broadly oval to rounded, dark green leaves widely spaced on arching branches and pendulous clusters of bright white, waxy, bell-shaped flowers with yellow stamens in spring. Native to woodlands and shrublands in mountains and foothills from southwestern Oregon to southern California. Sun to bright shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. May be offered as a variety of S. officinalis, which is native to the Mediterranean region. Sunset: 4-9,14-21

Syagrus romanzoffiana (queen palm), palm, 30-60 feet tall and 15-25 feet wide, with an upright, columnar, gray trunk topped by a rosette of feathery, 10- to 15-foot long leaves divided into many glossy, dark green leaflets. Creamy white flowers in spring and summer are followed by drooping clusters of bright orange fruit. Dead fronds persist on the trunk unless removed. Native to northern Argentina, eastern Bolivia, and eastern Brazil. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. May be offered as Arecastrum. Sunset: 12-13,15-17,19-24

Symphoricarpos albus (snowberry), deciduous shrub, 3-6 feet tall and wide, with oval to rounded, sometimes lobed, bluish green leaves on upright or arching branches. Small clusters of tiny, bell-shaped, pink or pinkish white flowers in summer are followed by round, pale green, berrylike fruits that age to bright white and persist into winter. Spreads by rhizomes and may form dense thickets. Native to dry or moist slopes and open forests in mountains, foothills, and valleys from southeastern Alaska to southern California and across much of southern Canada and the northern United States. Cool sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 1-11,14-21,A3

Symphoricarpos mollis (creeping snowberry), deciduous vining shrub, 1-2 feet tall and slowly spreading by rooting stems to 4-5 feet wide, with rounded to oval, lobed, dark bluish green leaves and pink, bell-shaped flowers in spring. Flowers are followed by waxy, round, bright white fruit that persists into winter. Native to shady slopes and canyons in foothills and mountains throughout California north to southern British Columbia and east to Idaho, Nevada, and New Mexico. Cool sun to part shade or shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-10,14-24

Symphotrichum chilense (Pacific aster), perennial, 1-3 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly oval to lance-shaped, lightly hairy, green leaves and lavender or white, late-summer daisy flowers with yellow centers. Native from British Columbia to central California, especially along the coast. Spreads rapidly by rhizomes in moist locations. Sun to part shade, most soils. May be offered as Aster. Sunset: N/A

Syringa vulgaris (lilac), deciduous shrub, 8-15 feet tall and 6-12 feet wide, with dark green to bluish green, pointed oval leaves and showy clusters of small, fragrant, tubular, lavender flowers in late spring along with or preceding new leaves. Spreads by suckering roots and may form colonies. Native to rocky slopes and open woodlands of southeastern Europe, especially the Balkan peninsula. Hundreds of cultivars vary mostly in size and flower color, adding compact and dwarf plants, early, mid-season, and late blooming plants, and plants with single or double flowers in many shades of white, pink, magenta, purple, blue, and bicolored. Sun, well-drained, humusy soils, good air circulation. Need winter chill to flower well. Sunset: 1-11,14,A1-3

Tagetes lemmonii (mountain marigold), evergreen shrub, 4-6 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with finely dissected, medium green, aromatic leaves and flat-topped clusters of yellow-orange daisy flowers in fall and winter or intermittently year round. Native to canyons in mountains of southern Arizona and northern Mexico. 'Compacta' is 2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-10,12-24

Tagetes nelsonii (citrus scented marigold), perennial, 3-4 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with aromatic leaves divided into narrowly oval, red-tinged, dark green leaflets and flat-topped clusters of small, yellow-orange daisy flowers in late summer to fall. Native to Guatemala and southern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Tanacetum camphoratum (dune tansy), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and spreading slowly by rhizomes, with aromatic, hairy, oval to elliptic, gray-green leaves divided two or three times into feathery leaflets. Branched stems above the leaves bear flat-topped clusters of small, yellow, buttonlike flowerheads with tiny, densely packed disc flowers and much reduced ray flowers. Species is native to coastal sand dunes from southwestern British Columbia to northern California. The form known as camphor dune tansy, native to the San Francisco Bay Area, differs from the more widely distributed species in its lack of ray flowers. Sun to light shade, fast drainage. May be offered as T. bipinnatum. Sunset: N/A

Tanacetum parthenium (feverfew), perennial, to 1-2 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, pale yellowish green, deeply divided, feathery leaves and dense, flat-topped clusters of white daisy flowers with yellow centers in summer. Self-sows freely and can be weedy or invasive. Native to the mountains of the Balkan Peninsula. May be offered as Chrysanthemum or as Pyrethrum. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Tecoma Crimson Flare™ (yellow bells), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves divided into many lance-shaped leaflets. Showy clusters of trumpet-shaped, red flowers from spring to fall are followed by long, brown seedpods. Hybrid involving T. stans, which is native from southern Texas and southern Arizona south to Mexico and parts of Central and South America. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 12-13,21-24

Tecoma Sunrise™ (Sunrise tecoma), evergreen shrub, 6-8 feet tall and wide, with dark green leaves divided into many lance-shaped leaflets. Showy clusters of trumpet-shaped, yellow-orange flowers from coppery buds from spring to fall are followed by long, brown seedpods. Hybrid involving T. stans, which is native from southern Texas and southern Arizona south to Mexico and parts of Central and South America. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 12-13,21-24

Tecoma garrocha (Argentine tecoma), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, fast growing to 10-20 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with leaves divided into dark green, lance-shaped leaflets with serrated margins and clusters of deep yellowish or reddish orange, funnel-shaped flowers from spring to fall. Similar to T. stans but with orange flowers. Native to southern Bolivia and northwestern Argentina. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-13,21-24

Tecoma stans (yellow bells), evergreen shrub to small tree, 10-20 feet tall and 10-15 feet wide, with bright green leaves divided into many lance-shaped leaflets. Showy clusters of trumpet-shaped, yellow flowers from spring to fall are followed by long, brown seedpods. Native from southern Texas and southern Arizona south to Mexico and parts of Central and South America. Cultivars 6-8 feet tall are often available. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Needs summer heat. Can be weedy or invasive. Sunset: 12-13,21-24

Tecoma x alata 'Flaming Bells' (orange bells), evergreen shrub, 8-10 feet tall and 6-8 feet wide, with dark green leaves divided into many lance-shaped leaflets. Showy clusters of trumpet-shaped, yellow-orange flowers from coppery buds from spring to fall are followed by long, brown seedpods. Uncertain origin. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Needs summer heat. May be offered as T. x smithii, as T. fulva subsp. guarume. or as T. 'Orange Jubilee'. Sunset: 12-13,21,24

Tetraneuris acaulis (stemless four-nerve daisy), perennial, 6 inches tall and 12-18 inches wide, with a basal rosette or low mat of sometimes hairy, linear or grass-like, green to gray-green leaves and bright yellow daisy flowers on 10- to 12-inch leafless stems in winter and spring. Native to dry, rocky slopes and washes in central and southwestern North America. Sun, well-drained soils. Good rock garden plant. May be offered as Hymenoxys. Sunset: 1-3,7-14,18-24

Teucrium betonicum (Madeira germander), perennial, 3 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, heart-shaped, sage green leaves with scalloped margins and upright spikes of pinkish purple flowers in spring or early summer. Native to rocky soils and coastal bluffs on the island of Madeira off the coast of Morocco. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: N/A

Teucrium chamaedrys (germander), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, glossy, dark green, oval leaves with scalloped margins and upright spikes of pink to purplish flowers in spring or early summer. Native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Turkey. Sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as T. x lucidrys. Sunset: 2-24

Teucrium cossonii (Majorcan germander), perennial, 4-6 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrow, gray-green leaves, whitish beneath, and dense clusters of lavender flowers among the leaves in spring or early summer. Native to rocky soils on the Mediterranean island of Mallorca, Spain. Sun to light shade, perfect drainage. May be offered as T. majoricum. Sunset: 7-9,14-24

Teucrium fruticans (bush germander), perennial, 4-8 feet tall and wide, with small, aromatic, gray-green leaves on downy, white stems and tiny, lavender-blue flowers in spring or early summer. Native to rocky soils in the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Italy. 'Azureum' is 4-5 feet tall and wide with darker blue flowers. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Teucrium marum (cat thyme), evergreen shrub, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, with tiny, aromatic, silvery gray-green, oval leaves on downy, white stems and short, one-sided spikes of tiny reddish or purplish pink flowers in summer. Native to the Balearic Islands and naturalized in the western Mediterranean region. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 3-9,14-24

Teucrium x lucidrys (dwarf germander), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with small, glossy, dark green, aromatic  leaves and small, purplish pink, tubular flowers on upright stems in spring or early summer. Uncertain origin, believed to be either the same plant as T. chamaedrys, native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal to Turkey, or a hybrid between that plant and T. lucidum, native to the Alps from France to Italy. Sun to light shade, good drainage. May be offered as T. chamaedrys. Sunset: 2-24

Thymophylla pentachaeta (golden fleece), perennial or subshrub, 4-8 inches tall and wide, with green to grayish green leaves divided into stiff, linear, needle-like lobes and yellow daisy flowers in spring. Native to deserts from southern Utah to southeastern California and east to western Texas and Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Short-lived but self-sows. May be offered as Dyssodia. Sunset: 8-14,18-23

Thymus praecox (mother-of-thyme), 2-3 inches tall and spreading 1-3 feet wide, with tiny, aromatic, woolly, gray-green leaves and tiny, deep pink to purplish, tubular flowers in summer. Native to open, sandy or rocky soils in parts of western, southern, and central Europe. Subspecies arcticus may be offered as T. polytrichus subsp. britannicus. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24,A2-3

Thymus species and cultivars (thyme), perennials, a few inches to 1 foot tall and spreading 1-3 feet wide, with tiny, green to gray-green, aromatic leaves and masses of tiny flowers in spring or summer. Many named cultivars with varying leaf and flower colors. Sun to part shade, excellent drainage. Shear taller plants occasionally for best form and more flowers. Sunset: 1-24

plants.botanicalName: Tiarella species & cvs. (CA native and non-native species)

plants.culturalInformation: Tilia tomentosa (silver linden), deciduous tree, 50-70 feet tall and 30-50 feet wide, with glossy, broadly oval to triangular, dark green leaves with serrated margins, silvery white beneath, and pendulous clusters of fragrant, pale yellow flowers in late spring or early summer. Flowers are followed by nut-like fruit. Native to southeastern Europe and western Asia from the Balkans east to western Turkey. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-21

Tipuana tipu (tipu tree), semi-deciduous tree, fast growing to 30-50 feet tall and wide, sometimes much wider than tall, with light green leaves divided into many pairs of rounded oval leaflets. Clusters of yellow flowers in late spring or early summer are followed by winged seedpods. Roots can lift paving. Flower, fruit, and leaf drop can be messy. Native from Bolivia and southern Brazil to Argentina and Uruguay. Sun, well-drained soils.  Sunset: 13-16,18-24

Torreya californica (California nutmeg), evergreen tree, exceptionally slow growing to 40-75 feet tall and 15-30 feet wide, with needlelike, sharply pointed, dark green leaves on upwardly angled or horizontal branches. Male cones are tiny, creamy white, and grouped on the undersides of branches. Female cones are small and the seed is covered with an oval, light green skin (aril) streaked with dark green or purple. Native to varied habitats in mountains of coastal northern and central California and the west-facing Sierra Nevada foothills. Cool sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Trachycarpus fortunei (windmill palm), palm, 20-30 feet tall, with dark green, fan-shaped fronds on 2- to 3-foot stalks, drooping clusters of small, greenish yellow flowers, and dark blue fruit on female plants. Leaves drop and rough, fibrous leaf bases persist on the trunk. Native to mountains of central and southern China. 'Wagnerianus', dwarf Chusan palm, is 12-20 feet tall, with smaller leaves on shorter stalks. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Trichostema lanatum (woolly blue curls), evergreen shrub, 3-4 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with narrow, glossy, green leaves, woolly and white beneath, and foot-long spikes of blue flowers from woolly, purplish buds in late spring through summer. Native to dry slopes in coastal mountains of southern California and northern Baja California. Short lived and not always easy in cultivation. Sun to part shade, perfect drainage, no summer water. 'Midnight Magic', a hybrid of T. lanatum and T. purpusii, a species from Mexico, may be more adaptable to garden conditions. Sunset: 14-24

Trichostema parishii (mountain blue curls), evergreen shrub, 2-4 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, glossy green, narrowly linear leaves, woolly and white beneath, and long spikes of blue and pinkish purple flowers with hairy sepals and prominent purple stamens in spring. Native to the coastal mountains of southern California and Baja California. Cool sun or part shade, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Trillium chloropetalum (wake robin), perennial, 12-18 inches tall and spreading slowly to form a small clump, with a whorl of three large, wavy-edged, mid-green leaves usually marked with darker or lighter green blotches. A single dark red, purplish black, or white, fragrant flower with three upright petals rises from the center of each trio of leaves in spring. Dormant and deciduous by mid-summer. Native to shaded woodlands in northern and central California. Light shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-17

Triteleia hyacinthina (white brodiaea), perennial from corms, with one to a few grasslike, green leaves and a rounded cluster of several to many small, bowl-shaped, white flowers on a tall stem in spring. Native to seasonally damp grasslands and woodlands along the coast and in mountains from British Columbia to Idaho and south to central California. Summer dormant and deciduous. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Needs a dry summer dormancy and ample moisture in spring to bloom well. May be offered as Brodiaea. Sunset: 2-9,14-24

Triteleia laxa (Ithuriel's spear), perennial from corms, with one to a few grasslike leaves and a loose, open cluster of upfacing, trumpet-shaped, purplish blue flowers on tall, leafless stems in late spring or early summer. Native to sunny forest or woodland openings in central and northern California and southwestern Oregon. Commonly available as 'Queen Fabiola'.  Spreads slowly by offsets. Summer dormant. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. May be offered as Brodiaea. Sunset: 5-9,14-24

Triteleia peduncularis (long-rayed brodiaea), perennial from corms, with several strap-shaped green leaves and a rounded cluster of bowl-shaped, white flowers on a tall stem in spring and early summer. Native to seasonally damp grasslands in coastal and inland mountains of northern and central California. Summer dormant and deciduous. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Needs a dry summer dormancy and ample moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: N/A

Tritonia species (tritonia), perennials from corms, to 1 foot tall and wide, with fans of strap-shaped to lance-shaped, green leaves and spikes of fragrant, yellow or orange, funnel-shaped flowers in late spring or early summer. Deciduous and dormant after flowering. Most spread by offsets. Native to southern Africa, especially southern Western Cape Province, South Africa, mostly from winter-rainfall shrublands but some from summer-rainfall grasslands. T. crocata, from the southern Cape provinces, is the most commonly grown species. Sun, excellent drainage, good air circulation. Winter-growing species need a dry summer dormancy. Sunset: 9,13-24
