Tulbaghia violacea (society garlic), perennial, 10-12 inches tall and 1 foot wide, with aromatic, grasslike, pale bluish green leaves and tall stems bearing clusters of small, fragrant, lavender or sometimes white, tubular flowers with widely flared petals in summer and fall. Native to grasslands and forest edges, often along streams, from summer-rainfall KwaZulu-Natal to the semi-arid Little Karoo in Western Cape Province, South Africa. Sun to light shade, well-drained, humusy soils. Sunset: 13-24

Ulmus parvifolia (Chinese elm), evergreen tree, fast growing to 40-60 feet tall and wide, with multi-colored, mottled, exfoliating bark in mostly pastel shades of gray, brown, and orange or red and oval to elliptic, glossy, dark green leaves on pendulous branches. Small, inconspicuous, reddish green flowers in late summer are followed by papery, winged seeds. Native to China, Japan, Korea, and Vietnam. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 3-24

Umbellularia californica (California bay), evergreen tree, 20-50 feet tall and wide, with leathery, lance-shaped, dark green, aromatic leaves and clusters of tiny, yellowish flowers in spring followed by small, purplish, berrylike fruit. Native to coastal mountains of southwestern Oregon and northern California and the foothills of the Sierra Nevada. Leaf drop can be messy. Sun or shade, most soils. Adaptable. Sunset: 4-9,14-24

Ungnadia speciosa (Mexican buckeye), deciduous shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk, 15-20 feet tall and 8-12 feet wide, with dark green leaves that turn golden yellow in fall, clusters of fragrant, bright pink flowers in spring, and rounded, brown seedpods that hang on into winter. Native to streambanks and  canyons in southern New Mexico, western Texas, and northeastern Mexico. Sun, good drainage. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 10-13

plants.botanicalName: Vaccinium hybrids and cvs (CA native and non- native spp.)

plants.culturalInformation: Vachellia farnesiana (sweet acacia), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, 15-20 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with fine-textured, light green leaves divided into many feathery leaflets on branches armed with substantial spines. Small round clusters of fragrant, bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by dark purplish red, beanlike seedpods. Native origin uncertain but widely introduced and naturalized in many tropical and subtropical parts of the world, including southern North America. May form thickets and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as V. constricta or as Acacia farnesiana. Sunset: N/A

plants.botanicalName: Vachellia farnesiana var. farnsiana (Acacia farnesiana farnesiana)
plants.culturalInformation: Vachellia farnesiana var. farnesiana (desert sweet acacia), semi-evergreen shrub or small tree, 15-20 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with fine-textured, light green leaves divided into many feathery leaflets on branches armed with substantial spines. Small round clusters of fragrant, bright yellow flowers in spring are followed by dark purplish red, beanlike seedpods. Native origin uncertain but widely introduced and naturalized in many tropical and subtropical parts of the world, including southern North America. May form thickets and can be weedy or invasive. May be more cold hardy than the species. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as Acacia smallii. Sunset: 8-9,12-24

Vancouveria species (inside-out flower), perennials from rhizomes, 12-18 inches tall and wide, with green leaves divided into three leaflets and white or yellow flowers with prominent stamens and backward-pointing sepals in late spring or early summer. V. hexandra, with white flowers, is native to damp, shady forests along the coast from southwestern British Columbia to northwestern California. V. chrysantha, with yellow flowers, is native to dry habitats in coastal and inland mountains of southwestern Oregon and northwestern California. V. planipetala, with white flowers, is native to coastal mountain forests, especially redwood forests of southwestern Oregon and northwestern California. Part shade to shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Good for dryish shade. Sunset: zones vary

Vauquelinia californica (Arizona rosewood), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk, 8-20 feet tall and 6-15 feet wide, with leathery, lance-shaped, medium green leaves with finely toothed or serrated margins. Flat-topped clusters of creamy white flowers in spring are followed by persistent woody seed capsules. Native to dry slopes and canyons in southern Arizona, New Mexico, and northwestern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Best inland. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 10-13

Vauquelinia corymbosa var. heterodon (narrow-leaf rosewood), evergreen shrub or small tree, usually multitrunk, 12-20 feet tall and 8-15 feet wide, with long, narrow, leathery, dark green leaves with finely toothed or serrated margins, flat-topped clusters of creamy white flowers in late spring and summer, and persistent woody seed capsules. Native to western Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun to part shade, most well-drained soils. Needs summer heat. Sunset: 10-13

Veltheimia bracteata (forest lily), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with large, glossy, dark green, broadly strap-shaped leaves with wavy margins and dense spikes of pendulous, tubular, light pink flowers on 1- to 2-foot stems in late winter and early spring. Flowers are followed by large, papery, three-winged seed capsules. Dormant in summer if grown dry. Native to rocky, forested or shrubby slopes along the coast in Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. Part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 13,16-24

Verbascum bombyciferum (silver mullein), biennial or short-lived perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide, rosette of large, broad, felted, silvery gray-green, wavy-edged leaves. In mid-summer of the second year a 4- to 6-foot, upright, velvety, branching stem bears several spikes of yellow, bowl-shaped flowers. Self-sows freely. Native to the mountains of northwestern Turkey. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-11,14-24

Verbena bonariensis (verbena), perennial, 2-4 feet tall and 1-3 feet wide, with narrow, toothed, dark green leaves, widely spaced on upright stems, and rounded clusters of tiny purple flowers from spring to fall. Native to Brazil and Argentina. Self-sows, sometimes aggressively. High risk of invasiveness in California, especially in moist soils. Sunset: 8-24

Verbena gooddingii (Goodding's verbena), perennial, 18 inches tall and 2-3 feet wide, with finely dissected, light green leaves and small, rounded clusters of tiny, lightly fragrant, pinkish lavender flowers in late winter or spring. Self-sows. Native to sandy or rocky soils in deserts of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. Sun to part shade, fast drainage. May be offered as Glandularia. Sunset: 7-24

Verbena hybrids (garden verbena), perennials, a few inches to 2 feet tall and 1-4 feet wide, with oblong, green to gray-green leaves with serrated margins and showy, flat-topped clusters of tiny, tubular flowers in spring through early fall. Hundreds of named cultivars with flowers in various shades of red, pink, purple, blue, or white. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as V. x hybrida or as V. x hortensis. Sunset: 8-24

Verbena rigida (vervain), perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, with rough-textured, dark green leaves with widely spaced, sharply pointed, marginal teeth and tight clusters of tiny lavender flowers on tall stems in spring through early fall. Native to Brazil, Bolivia, and Argentina. Spreads by rhizomes, especially in moist soils. Sun to part shade, good drainage, good air circulation. Cut back hard after flowering to renew. May be offered as a variety of V. bonariensis or as V. venosa. Sunset: 3-24

Verbena stricta (hoary vervain), perennial, 2-4 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide, with hairy, oval, coarsely toothed, gray-green leaves on hairy stems and narrow spikes of small, tightly packed, blue-purple flowers in summer. Short-lived but self-sows. Native to eastern and central North America from Ontario to Montana and south to New Mexico and Texas. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 2-24

Verticordia plumosa (pink lace), evergreen shrub, 3-5 feet tall and 2-3 feet wide, with narrowly linear to needle-like, green leaves and tight clusters of fragrant, pink, lavender, or white daisy flowers in late winter to spring. Native to seasonally wet habitats near the coast of southwestern Western Australia. 'Pink Lace' is 1-3 feet tall and wide. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 16-17,22-24

Vitex agnus-castus (chaste tree), deciduous shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with grayish green, aromatic leaves divided into oval to lance-shaped leaflets and showy, upright spikes of small, fragrant, lavender-blue or purplish flowers from summer to fall. Native to streambanks and other damp places in southern Europe and western Asia. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most soils. Sunset: 4-24

Vitex rotundifolia (beach vitex), deciduous shrub, 1-3 feet tall and spreading rapidly 15-20 feet wide or more, with aromatic, round to broadly oval, bluish green leaves, silvery gray beneath. Branching spikes of small, purplish blue flowers throughout much of the year are followed by round, purplish black, berrylike fruits. Native to coastal dunes from northern Australia to eastern and southeastern Asia and islands of the Pacific, including Hawaii. Spreads by rooting stems and by seed and can be invasive in coastal habitats. Sun, well-drained soils. May be offered as V. trifolia subsp. litoralis.  Sunset: 13-24

Vitex trifolia 'Purpurea' (Arabian lilac), evergreen shrub, fast growing to 10-15 feet tall and wide, with aromatic, oval to lance-shaped, grayish green leaves, purplish beneath, and long spikes of small, purple flowers in summer through fall followed by small, purplish black, berrylike fruits. Native to coastal areas from eastern Africa east through Asia and south to Australia. Sun, most well-drained soils. Best near the coast. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive. May be offered as variety purpurea or as V. 'Fascination'. Sunset N/A

Vitis 'Roger's Red' (Roger's Red grape), deciduous vine, fast-growing to 30 feet or more, with large, soft, slightly lobed and serrated leaves that turn brilliant red-orange in fall and small, purple fruit. Climbs by tendrils that attach tightly to nearby shrubs and trees. Hybrid between V. californica and the wine grape cultivar V. vinifera 'Alicante Bouschet'. Prune at any time to control spread. Berries are attractive to many birds. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-24

Vitis californica (California wild grape), deciduous vine, fast growing to 30 feet or more, with large, soft, heart-shaped to rounded and slightly lobed, green leaves that turn bright red and yellow in fall. Climbs by tendrils that attach tightly to anything they encounter. Fruits are small and sour but attractive to many birds. Native to seasonally damp places in coastal mountains of southwestern Oregon and northern California, the Sacramento Valley, and the foothills of the Transverse Ranges. 'Walker Ridge' is smaller, to 10 feet. Prune at any time to control spread. Sun to part shade, most soils. Sunset: 4-24

Vitis girdiana (desert grape), deciduous vine, fast growing and climbing by tendrils to 30 feet or more, with heart-shaped to rounded, slightly lobed and serrated, green leaves that turn bright red and yellow in fall. Inconspicuous flowers in spring are followed by dark blue fruits. Stems, leaf undersides, and new leaves are covered in white hairs, giving the plant a silvery gray appearance. Native to deserts and mountains of southern California and Baja California, often along streams. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: N/A

Vitis vinifera (European grape), deciduous vine, fast growing and climbing by tendrils to 30 feet or more, with heart-shaped to rounded, slightly lobed and serrated, green leaves and inconspicuous flowers in spring followed by dark blue fruits. Native to the Mediterranean region and southwestern Asia, from Portugal and Morocco to the Caucasus and Iran, usually along streams. Purple-leaved cultivars are available. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,14-23

Washingtonia filifera (California fan palm), palm, 30-60 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with an upright, columnar trunk topped by a rosette of 3- to 6-foot long, waxy, fan-shaped, dark grayish green leaves on spiny petioles. Drooping clusters of creamy white, tubular flowers in spring or early summer are followed by small, reddish black fruits. Dead fronds remain attached to the trunk, forming a dense, brown thatch or skirt. Native to seeps, springs, or streams in deserts of southeastern California and Baja California, with scattered populations in Arizona and southern Nevada. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: 8-9,11-24

Washingtonia robusta (Mexican fan palm), palm, 60-80 feet tall and 10-12 feet wide, with an upright, columnar trunk topped by a rosette of 3- to 5-foot long, waxy, fan-shaped, dark green leaves with long, spiny petioles. Large, showy clusters of creamy white, tubular flowers in summer are followed by tiny, black fruits. Self-sows and can be weedy or invasive in moist soils. Dead fronds remain attached to the trunk, forming a dense, brown thatch or skirt. Native to Baja California and Sonora, Mexico. Sun, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 11-24

Watsonia species (watsonia), perennials from corms, 2-3 feet tall and wide, with fans of sword-shaped to strap-shaped, mid-green leaves and tall spikes of fragrant, trumpet-shaped flowers on 3- to 6-foot stems in mid- to late spring. Summer dormant and deciduous. Native to sandy soils and rocky slopes in both winter- and summer-rainfall parts of southern Africa, especially Western Cape Province, South Africa. Many cultivars. Most plants offered are hybrids with red, pink, or peach colored flowers. Can be weedy or invasive. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,12-24

Westringia 'Wynyabbie Gem' (Wynabbie Gem westringia), evergreen shrub, 6 feet tall and wide, with narrowly linear, gray-green leaves and small, lavender flowers almost year round in mild climates. Hybrid between W. fruticosa, native to sandy soils in southeastern Australia,  and W. eremicola, an inland species also from southeastern Australia. 'Wynyabbie Highlight', a sport of 'Wynyabbie Gem', has variegated leaves. Sun to part shade, good drainage. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

photos.filename: Westringia fruticosa hybrids and cultivars (coast rosemary)
photos.caption: Westringia fruticosa hybrids and cultivars (coast rosemary)

plants.culturalInformation: Westringia fruticosa hybrids and cultivars (coast rosemary), evergreen shrubs, 4-6 feet tall and 5-10 feet wide, with small, dark gray-green, narrowly linear leaves and small, white flowers almost year-round. Native to sandy soils along the coast in New South Wales, Australia. 'Smokey' and 'Morning Light' have variegated leaves. 'Wynyabbie Gem', a hybrid with W. eremicola, an inland species from southeastern Australia, has lavender flowers. Grey Box™ ('WES04'), with gray-green leaves and white flowers, is 3 feet tall and wide. Sun to light shade, good drainage. Good seaside plants. May be offered as W. rosmariniformis. Sunset: 8-9,14-24

Wyethia angustifolia (narrowleaf mule ears), perennial, 1 foot tall and 1-2 feet wide, low rosette of long, lance-shaped, green leaves and large, bright yellow sunflowers on leafless, 2-foot stems in spring. Dies back to the ground in winter. Native to grassy slopes and forest openings, often along streams, from southwestern Washington to central California and from the coast to the northern Sierra Nevada foothills. Sun, most soils. Sunset: N/A

x Amarygia hybrids (amarygia), perennials from bulbs, 1 foot tall and 2 feet wide, with medium green, strap-shaped leaves that emerge in late fall or winter and die back in late spring. Clusters of large, trumpet-shaped flowers atop 2- to 3-foot leafless stems appear in late summer or fall. Hybrids between Amaryllis and Brunsvigia that extend the color range from the pinks of amaryllis flowers to pure white and red. Summer dormant and deciduous. Sun, most soils. Sunset: N/A

x Chitalpa tashkentensis (chitalpa), deciduous tree, 20-30 feet tall and wide, usually multitrunk, with dark green, lance-shaped leaves and showy clusters of funnel-shaped, wavy-edged, white, pink, or lavender flowers from late spring into fall. Hybrid between Chilopsis linearis, desert willow, and Catalpa bignonioides, southern catalpa. 'Pink Dawn' and Summer Bells™ ('Minsum') have pale pink flowers. 'Morning Cloud' has white flowers. Flower and leaf drop can be messy. Sun, most well-drained soils.  Sunset: 3-24

x Halimiocistus sahucii (hybrid rockrose), evergreen shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, with linear, dark green leaves and masses of small, white flowers with yellow centers in spring and summer. Hybrid between white-flowered Halimium umbellatum and Cistus salviifolius, both native to the Mediterranean region. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: 4-24

Xanthorrhoea species (grass tree), perennial, 2- to 4-foot rosette of stiff, narrow, grasslike, blue-green leaves radiating out from a slowly forming stem or trunk to 8 feet tall. At maturity, but not every year, thousands of tiny, white, star-shaped flowers are produced on a 4- to 12-foot stalk in spring. Slow growing and long lived. Native to coastal southwestern Western Australia. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 12-24

Xerophyllum tenax (bear grass), perennial, 3-foot-tall and wide rosette of tough, fibrous, grasslike, olive green leaves on a slowly growing, sometimes branching trunk to 6-8 feet tall. After about 10 years, a 6-foot central stalk rises up bearing a dense, broad head of creamy white flowers in spring. Spreads by rhizomes and by seed. Rosette dies after flowering and is replaced by offsets that sprout from the rhizomes. Native to rocky mountain slopes from southeastern British Columbia south to central California and east to Idaho and Montana. Sun to light shade, well-drained soils. Not at its best in southern California. Sunset: 1-7,14-17

Xylococcus bicolor (mission manzanita), evergreen shrub to small tree, usually multitrunk, slow growing to 10-20 feet tall and wide, with small, oval, glossy, dark green leaves, paler and felted beneath. Pendant clusters of small, urn-shaped, pink to white flowers in spring are followed by red, berrylike fruits. Native to dry, rocky slopes in foothills of coastal mountains in southern California and Baja California. Sun, excellent drainage. Sunset: N/A

Xylosma congesta (shiny xylosma), evergreen shrub or small tree, 8-18 feet tall and wide, with arching branches densely covered with oval to broadly lance-shaped, glossy, bright green leaves, bronzy when new. Tiny, inconspicuous, greenish yellow flowers in late summer are followed by dark red, berrylike fruit that ripens to black. Native to China. 'Compacta' is 6-8 feet tall and wide. Sun to part shade, most soils. Good hedge or screen. May be offered as X. congestum or as Croton congestus. Sunset: 8-24

Yucca aloifolia (Spanish bayonet), succulent, 2-4 feet tall and wide rosette of stiff, sword-shaped, sharply tipped, green leaves with finely serrated margins and pendulous, bell-shaped, creamy white flowers on a 2-foot stalk in spring or summer. Slowly forms a branched or unbranched stem or trunk 6-15 feet tall and offsets to form a small colony. Native to sand dunes or sandy soils along the coast from North Carolina south to Florida and west along the Gulf Coast to Texas and Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. Sunset: 7-24

Yucca baccata (banana yucca), succulent, 3 feet tall and 5 feet wide, stemless or short-stemmed rosette of rigid, spine-tipped, bluish green, strap-shaped leaves and purple-tinged, creamy white flowers on a 3- to 6-foot stalk in spring or early summer. Rosettes may not flower every year. Offsets form large clusters. Native to arid and semi-arid grasslands and woodlands from southeastern California north to Utah and south to western Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 1-3,7,9-14,18-24

Yucca brevifolia (Joshua tree), succulent, slow growing to 20-40 feet tall and 10-20 feet wide, with stiff, linear, dark green leaves with sharply pointed tips clustered in rosettes at branch ends. Showy clusters of white spring flowers appear only in years of adequate rainfall and are followed by oval, greenish brown fruits. Native to deserts of southeastern California, western Arizona, southwestern Utah, southern Nevada, and northern Baja California. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 7,9-16,18-23

Yucca elata (soaptree yucca), succulent, rosette of bluish gray-green, strap-shaped leaves 3-4 feet long with shredding, greenish white margins, slowly developing a branched or unbranched, trunklike stem 8-15 feet tall. Creamy white flowers on a 3- to 6-foot stalk in spring or summer but not every year. Native to the deserts of Arizona to Texas and northern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 7-24

Yucca elephantipes (giant yucca), succulent, 2-3 feet tall and wide rosette of flexible, sword-shaped, pale green leaves with soft tips and pendulous, bell-shaped, creamy white flowers on a 3- to 6-foot stalk in spring or summer. Slowly forms multiple branching trunks 15-30 feet tall and may spread 15-25 feet wide. Native to Mexico and Guatemala. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as Y. gigantea. Sunset: 16-17,19-24

Yucca filamentosa and cultivars (Adam's needle), succulent, 2-4 feet tall and wide rosette of stiff, sword-shaped, spine-tipped, grayish green leaves with white, threadlike filaments along the margins and pendulous, bell-shaped, creamy white flowers on a 5- to 8-foot stalk in late spring or summer. Offsets to form a small colony. Native to sandy or rocky soils from southern Virginia south to Florida and west to southern Texas. Sun, most well-drained soils. Sunset: 1-24

Yucca gloriosa (Spanish dagger), succulent, 2-4 feet tall and wide, rosette of stiff, sword-shaped, spine-tipped, dark green leaves and pendulous, bell-shaped, pink-tinged white flowers with purple-tipped petals in summer. May slowly form a 6- to 8-foot stem or trunk and offset to form a small colony. Native along the coast from North Carolina to northeastern Florida. Variegated cultivars are available. Sun to part shade, afternoon shade in hot-summer climates, well-drained soils. Good seaside plant. May be offered as a form of or hybrid with Y. elephantipes. Sunset: 7-9,12-24

Yucca linearifolia (linear-leaf yucca), succulent, spherical rosette to 2-3 feet tall and wide, with narrow, strap-shaped, green leaves, slowly forming a 4- to 6-foot trunklike stem. Creamy white flowers on a 3-foot stalk in spring. Native to the Chihuahuan Desert of northeastern Mexico and southwestern Texas. Sun, fast drainage. May be offered as Y. rostrata var. linearis. Sunset: N/A

Yucca rigida (blue yucca), succulent, 3-4 feet tall and wide rosette of stiff, sword-shaped, spine-tipped, blue-gray leaves and pendulous, bell-shaped, white flowers just above the leaves in spring. Slowly forms a 10-to 12-foot, branched or unbranched stem or trunk. Native to north-central Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Sunset: 11-13

Yucca rostrata (beaked yucca), succulent rosette, 4-6 feet tall and wide, with stiff, narrow, sharply pointed, silvery gray-blue leaves, slowly forming a thick trunk 10-12 feet tall. Creamy white flowers are borne on a 4-foot stalk in spring or early summer, but rosettes may not flower every year. Native to rocky slopes and ridges in southwestern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. Sunset: 7-24

Yucca schidigera (Mojave yucca), succulent rosette, 3-4 feet tall and wide, with thick, rigid, yellow-green to blue-green, sword-shaped leaves with marginal fibers and a sharp terminal spine. Slowly forms a trunk or several trunks 5-15 feet tall. Creamy white flowers are borne on a 1- to 4-foot stalk in spring or early summer, but rosettes may not flower every year. Native to dry, rocky slopes and flats in southern California and northern Baja California east to New Mexico. Sun, fast drainage. May be offered as a subspecies of Y. filifera. Sunset: 7-16,18-24

plants.botanicalName: Zantedeschia spp. & hybrids SHADE IN DESERT

plants.culturalInformation: Zephyranthes candida (zephyr lily), perennial from bulb, 1 foot tall and wide, spreading by offsets to form dense colonies, with narrow, upright, rushlike, glossy green leaves and tubular, white flowers with golden yellow stamens in late summer and fall. Native to seasonal wetlands and marshes from northeastern Argentina and Paraguay to southern Brazil and Uruguay. Sun to part shade, humusy, well-drained soils. Sunset: 4-9,12-24

Zephyranthes species (zephyr flower), perennials from bulbs, 1-2 feet tall and wide, with narrow, grasslike, mid-green to dark green leaves and tall stems, each bearing a large, funnel-shaped, upward-pointing, white, yellow, or pink flower in spring, summer, or fall, especially following rains. Native to southeastern North America and parts of Central and South America. Sun, well-drained soils. Sunset: zones vary

Zinnia grandiflora (prairie zinnia), perennial, 4-8 inches tall and slowly spreading by rhizomes to 1-2 feet wide, with tiny, needle-like, green leaves and masses of bright yellow flowers on leafy stems in summer. Native to dry, sandy or gravelly soils in mountains of southern Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, and Mexico. Sun to part shade, well-drained soils. Needs moisture in spring to bloom well. Sunset: 2-24

Aquilegia eximia (serpentine columbine), a mounding evergreen herbaceous perennial, 18 inches tall and wide, with lobed, gray-green leaves, and large orange-red lantern-shaped flowers on long stalks above the main plant from late spring to early fall. Attractive to hummingbirds. Native endemic to California in woodland, chaparral, and riparian habitats along the western edge of the state. Sun in cool coastal areas, light to full shade inland where bloom is best under deciduous trees where winter sun is available. Most soils. Sunset zones: 4-7, 9, 14-24.

photos.filename: Buddleja ‘Podaras #8’ (Flutterby Petite® Blue Heaven butterfly bush)
photos.caption: Buddleja ‘Podaras #8’ (Flutterby Petite® Blue Heaven butterfly bush)

plants.commonName: Flutterby Petite Blue Heaven butterfly bush
plants.culturalInformation: Buddleja ‘Podaras #8’ (Flutterby Petite® Blue Heaven butterfly bush), semi-deciduous, dense shrub, 4.5 feet tall and wide, lavender colored flowers from June through fall with peak bloom from August to September. Hybrid of B. davidii x B. alternifolia. Best appearance if cut back by half in late winter or early spring. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 2-24; H1

Buddleia 'Hinebud2' (Purple Splendor butterfly bush), semi-deciduous shrub, 4.5 feet tall and up to 6 feet wide, bright green leaves and vivid violet blooms from spring through fall with heaviest bloom June to August. Best appearance if cut back by half in late winter or early spring and deadheaded after the first large flush of bloom. Complex hybrid of six different species. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 2-24; H1.

photos.filename: Buddleja 'Podaras #13' (Flutterby Petite® Tutti Fruitti butterfly bush)
photos.caption: Buddleja 'Podaras #13' (Flutterby Petite® Tutti Fruitti butterfly bush)

plants.commonName: Flutterby Petite  Tutti Fruitti Pink butterfly bush
plants.culturalInformation: Buddleja 'Podaras #13' (Flutterby Petite® Tutti Fruitti butterfly bush), semi-deciduous shrub that forms a loose, rounded mound 2.5 feet high and 4.5 wide, long, pointed leaves are gray underneath and may fold up in high heat. Bright violet blooms begin in late April and continue through fall with a lighter pinkish violet color in higher heat. Best appearance if cut back by half in late winter or early spring and deadheaded after the first large flush of bloom. Cool sun on coast, or may appreciate afternoon shade in hot, inland areas. Hybrid of (B. davidii x B. alternifolia) x B. davidii. Most soils. Sunset zones: 2-24; H1.

plants.botanicalName: Ceanothus thysiflorus var. griseus  'MATCEA01' (Ceanothus griseus var. horizontalis 'Highlights') (part shade)
plants.culturalInformation: Ceanothus thyrsiflorus var. griseus ‘MATCEA01’ (Highlights™ ceanothus), mounding shrub 3-4 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide with bright, shiny green ovate leaves with a chartreuse green leaf margin. The amount of variegation varies slightly from leaf to leaf. Light, lilac purple to denim blue flowers will appear in mid-spring. Highlights was a sport found in a crop of plants at Matsuda’s Nursery, sometimes sold as Ceanothus griseus var. horizontalis ‘Highlights’. Cool coastal sun or part shade in inland regions. Sunset Zones: 5-9 (with protection), 14-24.

Delosperma cooperi (hardy ice plant), mat forming succulent perennial with narrow bright green leaves borne on burgundy colored stems, 3-4 inches tall and 1-3 feet wide. Bright purple ray-type flowers emerge in early summer and continue until fall. Native to South Africa. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 2-24.?

Dianthus 'KLEDG10119' (Everlast™ Orchid dianthus), a small evergreen perennial with narrow blue-grey to blue-green leaves growing to 8-12" tall, and to 24" wide. In the spring orchid pink muli-petaled flowers with fringed edges emerge, flowers have a "spiced" scent. Flowers are not self cleaning and remain on the plant, fading to a straw yellow color. Plants bloom from spring to fall with the heaviest periods of bloom in late spring and early fall. Shear plants to remove spent flowers and maintain appearance during the growing season. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 1-24

Distylium 'Vintage Jade' (Vintage Jade Distylium), evergreen mounding shrub 3-4 feet tall and wide with ovate green leaves and coppery green new growth. In late winter or early spring, small, unshowy, dark red flowers appear in the leaf axils. Distylium is native to the southeastern United States. 'Vintage Jade' was developed by Plant Introductions Inc. and the University of Georgia. Part shade/afternoon shade in inland regions. Most soils, Sunset Zones: 4-12, 14-16, 18-21.

Epilobium canum 'Sidewinder' (Sidewinder California fuchsia), low and wide-spreading perennial or subshrub, 2 feet tall spreading to 7 feet within 2 years. Medium green leaves and vivid orange-red flowers begin blooming in June or earlier and continue through fall, making it one of the most long-blooming cultivars. For best appearance, cut back annually in late winter. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 2-11, 14-24.

photos.filename: Epilobium canum 'Sierra Salmon' (Sierra Salmon California fuchsia)
photos.caption: Epilobium canum 'Sierra Salmon' (Sierra Salmon California fuchsia)

plants.culturalInformation: Epilobium canum 'Sierra Salmon' (Sierra Salmon California fuchsia), upright perennial or subshrub, 2.5 feet tall by 4.5 feet wide, light gray foliage and pale salmon flowers beginning in September. Pale foliage and short bloom period make it best used in planting combinations as a foliage accent. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 2-11, 14-24.

Eucomis 'Leia' (Leia pineapple lily), bulb, winter dormant, clump forming, up to 1 foot tall and wide, with succulent strap-like leaves forming a rosette. Flowering stems emerge in the summer bearing clusters of pink flowers whorled around the stalk, the stem is topped with green, leaf-like bracts, resembling a pineapple. A hybrid of Eucomis vandermerwei and Eucomis zambesiaca. Sun to part shade, part shade recommended in inland regions. Most soils. Sunset: 4-9, 14-24; H1, H2.

Geranium 'Gerwat' (Rozanne geranium), mounding perennial 16 inches tall to 3 feet wide with marbled green leaves containing 5 deep lobes. Flowers in shades of violet blue beginning in spring, peaking in summer, and continuing through fall. Cool coastal sun or part shade inland for best appearance. Most soils. Sunset zones: 2-11, 14-24.

Geranium × cantabrigiense 'Biokovo' (Biokovo geranium or cranesbill), mounding evergreen perennial 13 inches tall and 18 inches wide with palmately lobed aromatic foliage. Over time it can form a groundcover as stems run along the surface of the ground and root into the native soil. Simple flowers with 5 white to light pink petals and pink anthers and stamens, the main crop of flowers occurs in late spring with light flowering through fall. This cultivar was discovered growing in the Biokovo Mountains in southern Croatia. Part shade to shade, most soils. Sunset Zones 1-24.

Helleborus 'Red Lady' (Red Lady Lenten rose)- clumping evergreen perennial, 12-18 inches tall and wide with leathery, palmately lobed leaves. Outward facing, showy burgundy sepals surround the small flowers in terminal clusters from late winter to early spring. Flowers remain attractive for weeks after fading to green, but deadheading may prolong bloom time. Annual removal of old leaves keeps clumps looking fresh and clean. Well suited to dappled shade under deciduous trees where winter sun helps promote late winter/early spring bloom. Parents from Greece, Turkey, Caucasus. Most soils. Sunset zones: 2b-10, 14-24.

Heuchera 'Rosada' (Rosada coral bells), mounding, herbaceous, evergreen perennial 12 inches tall and wide with lobed leaves. Believed to be a spontaneous hybrid of H. maxima and H. sanguinea. Rosy pink flowers on branched stalks in spring. Not fussy about soil. Sun in cool coastal areas, prefers some shade inland. Sunset zones: 9, 14-24.

Kniphofia 'Christmas Cheer’ (‘Christmas Cheer’ red hot poker), evergreen rhizomatous perennial, reaching 2-3 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide with up to 2-inch wide, strap-like “v” shaped leaves tapering to a soft point. Conical spikes made up of tightly packed individual tubular flowers emerge in the winter and continue blooming until spring, new flowers open with a bright orange coloration fading to? yellow as they age creating an ombre effect which gives rise to the common name red hot poker. Flower spikes can rise to 4-6 feet tall. Cut back in or early spring after flowering to refresh foliage and remove old flower spikes. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 7-9, 12-24.

photos.filename: Kniphofia uvaria 'Elvira' (Elvira red hot poker plant)
photos.caption: Kniphofia uvaria 'Elvira' (Elvira red hot poker plant)

photos.filename: Kniphofia uvaria 'Elvira' (Elvira red hot poker plant)
photos.caption: Kniphofia uvaria 'Elvira' (Elvira red hot poker plant)

plants.culturalInformation: Kniphofia uvaria 'Elvira' (Elvira red hot poker plant), evergreen, rhizomatous perennial, thin, strap-shaped leaves 1 foot long forming clumps 1-1.5 feet wide, cylindrical spikes of small, red-orange closely spaced, tubular flowers on upright stems 1-2 feet long in summer. Flowers are held well above the leaves and buds open from the bottom of the spike to the top, changing color as they mature. Native to the South African Cape region. Appearance improved by cutting back in late winter to refresh foliage and remove old flower spikes. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 2-9, 14-24.

Lippia interspecific hybrids (Kurapia and cvs.), dense groundcover forms a mat 1-2 inches high and reaching 5-10 feet wide in a year, widely spreading stems covered with small oval leaves. Tiny verbena flowers in shades of white to pink cover the mats beginning April and continuing through the summer and on the outer edges in fall. Bees and butterflies are highly attracted to these flowers. May be mowed to remove flowers if undesirable. Good on slopes. May die back some in winter in colder locations but recovers the following spring. Sun to light shade. Most soils. Sunset zones:8-24; H1, H2.

photos.filename: Lomandra fluviatilis 'AU807' (Shara river lomandra, Lomandra Shara)
photos.caption: Lomandra fluviatilis 'AU807' (Shara river lomandra, Lomandra Shara)

plants.culturalInformation: Lomandra fluviatilis 'AU807' (Shara river lomandra, Lomandra Shara), grass-like perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 4-4.5 feet wide with narrow, green leaves with forked brown tips. Older foliage will remain and turn a straw yellow to light parchment tan providing a contrast with the remainder of the foliage. Clusters of straw yellow, spikey flowers will emerge in the spring, blooms are held at the foliage canopy, flowers, and stem age to a parchment brown. Lomandra fluviatilis is native to southeastern Australia. Full sun. Sunset Zone: 8,9,12-24

Lomandra longifolia 'LM300' (Breeze™ dwarf mat rush), grass-like perennial, 2-3 feet tall and 3-5 feet wide with narrow, fine green leaves with short brown forked tips. Small clusters of yellow flowers surrounded by prickles appear at the base in spring, the flowers fade to brown as they age. Lomandra longifolia grows in eastern Australia, 'LM300' is a sport of Lomandra longifolia ‘Katrinus’ found growing in an Australian nursery. Part shade is recommended inland. Sunset Zones 8, 9, 12-24.?

photos.filename: Lomandra longifolia 'Lomlon' (Lime Tuff dwarf mat rush) (sun)
photos.caption: Lomandra longifolia 'Lomlon' (Lime Tuff dwarf mat rush) (sun)

photos.filename: Lomandra longifolia 'Lomlon' (Lime Tuff dwarf mat rush) (shade)
photos.caption: Lomandra longifolia 'Lomlon' (Lime Tuff dwarf mat rush) (shade)

plants.culturalInformation: Lomandra longifolia 'Lomlon' (Lime Tuff dwarf mat rush), grass-like perennial in the Asparagaceae, 3 feet high and 31 inches wide with narrow, strap-shaped, bright pale green leaves with forked tips. In sun it takes on an upright structural form, in shade the form will be laxer and fountain-form and up to 3 feet wide. Spiky flowers on stalks that do not rise as high as the foliage. Unfussy about soil or sun exposure. Does not require pruning but takes late winter shearing to remove old foliage and flower stalks. Has been sold as Bushland Green and Lime Tough. Sun or shade, most soils. Sunset zones: 8, 9, 14-24.

Lomandra longifolia ‘Roma13’ (Platinum Beauty™ lomandra), grass-like perennial growing 2-3 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide. Narrow green leaves with creamy white variegation along the leaf margin originate at the base of the plant and culminate in small brown leaf tips, often with two forked points, only noticeable at short distances. Small clusters of yellow flowers surrounded by prickles appear at the base in spring, the flowers fade to brown as they age. Lomandra longifolia is native to Australia. Part Shade. Sunset Zones 8, 9, 12-24.

Lonicera periclymenum 'Inov86' (Peaches and Cream honeysuckle), compact shrub form of common honeysuckle, 2 feet high and 3-4 feet wide with dark green leaves. May to July, dense display of large fragrant compound inflorescences of large flowers that emerge from dark purple-red buds that turn dark pink and white when fully open and a creamy yellow-orange as they mature. Intermittent flowering until fall with red berries, pink flower buds and white flowers displayed simultaneously. Disease-resistant. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 1-24.

Muhlenbergia reverchonii 'PUND01S’ (Undaunted™ Ruby Muhly grass), perennial grass with fine green leaves growing 18-24 inches tall and 3-3.5 feet wide. In late summer, flower stalks emerge to cover the plant with loose panicles of bright ruby colored flowers which slowly age to a tawny straw-yellow color. Undaunted™ was developed from collections of Muhlenbergia reverchonii by Lauren Springer-Ogden and Scott Ogden from populations growing in northern Texas. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 7-24.

photos.filename: Osmanthus heterophyllus 'Purpureus’ (Purple leaf false holly) (early spring)
photos.caption: Osmanthus heterophyllus 'Purpureus’ (Purple leaf false holly) (early spring)

plants.culturalInformation: Osmanthus heterophyllus 'Purpureus’ (Purple leaf false holly), also called holly olive and sweet olive, slow-growing evergreen shrub 10-15 feet tall and 6-10 feet wide with spiny, shiny, holly-like leaves and small white, intensely fragrant flowers in late summer to late fall once mature. New foliage is deep burgundy and stays darker longer with more sun. Responds well to pruning. Part shade, most soils. Sunset zones: 4-10, 14-24.

Ozothamnus leptophyllus 'Silver Cape’ (Silver Cape ozothamnus), evergreen shrub 2-3 feet tall and wide with small grey-blue leaves, new growth has white stems that turn brown and woody with age. The flowers consist of small puffs of white anthers and are not significant. 'Silver Cape’ developed by Lindsey Hatch in New Zealand, where Ozothamnus leptophyllus is native. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 14-24.?

photos.filename: Penstemon heterophyllus 'Margarita BOP’ (Margarita BOP foothill penstemon)
photos.caption: Penstemon heterophyllus 'Margarita BOP’ (Margarita BOP foothill penstemon)

photos.filename: Penstemon heterophyllus 'Margarita BOP’ (Margarita BOP foothill penstemon)
photos.caption: Penstemon heterophyllus 'Margarita BOP’ (Margarita BOP foothill penstemon)

plants.culturalInformation: Penstemon heterophyllus 'Margarita BOP’ (Margarita BOP foothill penstemon), evergreen perennial or sub-shrub, 1-2 feet tall and 2-4 feet wide with smooth, dark green narrow leaves. Can survive with virtually no summer water once established. Blooms summer to fall. Best appearance if cut back to rejuvenate after bloom slows in late summer or early fall. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 7-24.

Phlox cvs. (Paparazzi series) are low growing perennials 6-12 inches tall and 12-18 inches wide with narrow green foliage and stems. Six-petaled, pinwheel type flowers appear in the spring in shades of pink, violet, purple, and white depending on the cultivar. The Paparazzi series is developed from several different Phlox species including Phlox divaricata, P. subulata, and P. stolonifera. Full sun to part shade inland. Sunset Zones: 1-17.

Rhododendron hybrid and cvs. (Encore™ azalea series), evergreen shrubs with small pubescent leaves. Cultivars classified as “dwarf” reach 2-3 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide, while “intermediate” cultivars reach 4-5 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide. Heavy flowering occurs in spring, with occasional flowering in summer, fall, and winter; flower colors vary. Part shade to shade, tolerates most soils, though prefers acidic soils. Sunset: 7-9, 14-24. (Zone info taken from Southern R. indica hybrids.)

Rosa ‘KORbatam’ (Winter Sun™ Eleganza® rose) a hybrid tea rose with green leaflets, growing 3-4 feet tall and 4 feet wide. The pale, butter-yellow, high-centered flowers start in spring and continue to fall. If not dead-headed, Winter Sun will prolifically form green hips which change to orange-red in late summer to fall. Developed by Kordes Roses. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Korbin’ (Iceberg rose), semi-evergreen floribunda shrub rose, 4-6 feet tall and 5 feet wide, clusters of white fragrant flowers from April through December. Good self-cleaner. Disease-free except in damp coastal sites where powdery mildew can be a problem. Takes high heat and neglect, but best year-to-year appearance and a 4-foot height is maintained with annual mid-winter pruning to 1/3 its height and occasional removal of oldest canes. Introduced in 1958 by German breeder Kordes. One of the most reliable landscape roses for decades. Most soils. Sunset zones: 2b-24.

Rosa ‘KORelamba’ (Bordeaux™ Cityscape® rose), shrub with deep green leaves, 4 feet tall and 5 feet wide. Crimson red, multi-petaled, slightly fragrant flowers appear in spring and continue until frost, occasionally flowers will fully open to reveal centers filled with yellow stamens. Developed by Kordes Roses. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘KORfloci01’ (Cream Veranda® rose), deciduous shrub growing to 2 feet tall and wide with green leaflets. Creamy, peach-pink, fragrant, multi-petaled cupped blooms appear in spring and continue until frost. Developed by Kordes Roses. Full Sun, most soils. Sunset Zones:4-24.

Rosa ‘KORsixkono’ (Kardinal Kolorscape® rose), deciduous shrub growing to 3-4 feet tall and 4 feet wide with green leaflets and prickles on the stem. Vibrant red semi-double blooms, opening fully as they age to reveal a center of yellow stamens. Flowering begins in early spring and continues until fall. Developed by Kordes Roses. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘KORsteimm’ (Lone Star® rose), shrub with dark green leaves, 5 feet tall and wide. Light yellow, multi-petaled, slightly fragrant flowers appear in spring and continue until fall. Developed by Kordes Roses. Full Sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘KORvodacom’ (Plum Perfect™ Sunbelt® rose), a semi-deciduous shrub 3-4 feet tall and wide with light green leaflets with narrow red margins and deep wine purple new growth. Tyrian purple multi-petaled blooms emerge in late spring, spent blooms shatter and form hips, not a heavy rebloomer. Developed by Kordes Roses. Full sun though may appreciate some afternoon shade in hot inland areas, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meiradriflora’ (Coral Drift® rose), semi-deciduous, low-growing shrub, 18-24 inches tall and 4-5 feet wide, with small green leaflets. Part of the Drift® series of groundcover roses, coral pink semi-double blooms in clusters appear in spring and flowering continues until fall, blooms turn to a light sepia color before petals shatter and fall off the plant. Developed by Meilland International. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meigalpio’ (Red Drift® rose), semi-deciduous, low-growing shrub, 18 inches tall and 4 feet wide with small green leaflets. The red semi-double blooms turn to a light sepia color before petals shatter and fall off the plant, clusters of blooms appear in spring and flowering continues until frost. Part of the Drift® series of groundcover roses developed by Meilland International. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meijocos’ (Pink Drift® rose), semi-deciduous, low-growing shrub, 18 inches tall and 4.5-5 feet wide, with small green leaflets. The pink single blooms with bright yellow stamens fade to white as they age before the petals shatter and fall off the plant, clusters of blooms appear in spring and flowering continues until frost. Part of the Drift® series of groundcover roses developed by Meilland International. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meikokan’ (Tequila Supreme® rose), semi-deciduous shrub rose 3-4 feet tall and 5 feet wide with green leaflets. The coloration of the semi-double, ruffled petals ranges from vivid peach, to orange and pink. Tequila Supreme starts blooming in spring and continues until fall. Developed by Meilland International. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meiradena’ (Icecap™ rose), semi-deciduous shrub with green leaflets 3-4 feet tall and 5 feet wide. The creamy white semi-double blooms fade to a sepia color before the petals shatter. Icecap blooms heavily in the spring and will continue to cycle in and out of bloom through the remainder of the season. Developed by Meilland International. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meisentmil’ (Lemon Drift® rose), semi-deciduous, low-growing shrub, 18 inches tall and 3-4 feet wide with small green leaflets. The creamy yellow, semi-double, open-faced blooms turn to ivory and white before self-cleaning; clusters of blooms appear in spring and flowering continues until frost. Part of the Drift® series of groundcover roses developed by Meilland International. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Meizorland’ (White Drift® rose), semi-deciduous, low-growing shrub 18-24 inches tall and 4-5 feet wide with small green leaflets. Small white blooms have a rosette form and an ivory-pinkish hue. Clusters of blooms appear in spring and flowering continues until frost, spent blooms quickly self-clean. Part of the Drift® series of groundcover roses developed by Meilland International and Will Radler. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Radcon’ (Pink Knock Out® rose), semi-deciduous shrub rose 3-4 feet tall and 5 feet wide with deep green leaflets covering stems. Bright pink semi-double blooms fade to light pink and parchment tan as the flowers age. Heavy flushes of bloom appear in late spring, mid-summer, and late summer, though the plant always has some flowers from spring until frost. Part of the Knock Out® series of roses developed by Will Radler. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Radgor’ (Peachy Knock Out® rose), semi-deciduous shrub, 3 feet tall and 4 feet wide with blue-green leaflets covering stems. Pink double blooms with yellow centers open with light yellow stamens giving an overall appearance of peachy color beginning in spring continuing until frost. Blooms fade to white before the petals shatter and fall off the plant. Part of the Knock Out® series of roses developed by Will Radler. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Radsunny’ (Sunny Knock Out® rose), semi-deciduous shrub, 3 feet tall and 4.5 feet wide with deep green leaflets covering stems. Clusters of pale yellow, semi-double blooms appear in spring and continue until frost. Blooms fade to white before the petals shatter and fall off the plant. Part of the Knock Out® series of roses developed by Will Radler. Full Sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

Rosa ‘Radtko’ ( Double Knock Out® rose), semi-deciduous shrub 3 feet tall and 4 feet wide with deep green leaflets covering stems. Double cherry-red flowers appear in spring with heavy repeat flowering continuing until frost. Petals fade to pale pink and eventually parchment tan before the petals shatter and fall off the plant. Part of the Knock Out® series of roses developed by Will Radler. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones: 4-24.

photos.filename: Ruellia simplex 'R10-108' Mayan White (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia)
photos.caption: Ruellia simplex 'R10-108' Mayan White (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia)

photos.filename: Ruellia simplex 'R10-105-Q54' Mayan Pink (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia)
photos.caption: Ruellia simplex 'R10-105-Q54' Mayan Pink (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia)

photos.filename: Ruellia simplex 'R10-102' Mayan Purple (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia)
photos.caption: Ruellia simplex 'R10-102' Mayan Purple (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia)

plants.culturalInformation: Ruellia simplex cvs. (Mayan™ series Mexican petunia), deciduous perennial, thick fleshy stems with pronounced nodes and two long, narrow, dark green leaves with lighter green undersides produced at each node. Spreads by underground stems. Plants have a tropical appearance with single trumpet shaped flowers in either white, pink, or purple borne from late spring to winter. Dwarf cultivars are suitable for pots. Mayan™ purple 30 inches high spreading to 6 feet wide; Mayan™ pink grows to 16 inches high and 19 inches wide; Mayan™ white reaches 28 inches high and 4 feet wide. Plants may die or lose leaves in response to cold. Bred at the University of Florida to be non-invasive by means of sterile flowers. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 8, 9, 12-24; H1, H2.

Sambucus nigra ‘Eiffel 1’ (Black Tower elderberry), upright, columnar form of this deciduous shrub, 6-8 feet tall and 3-4 feet wide with woody stems and compound pinnate leaves that emerge green and turn green-black to purple-black as they age. Cymes of white flowers with a pinkish hue appear in late spring, fruit may develop later in the summer. Sambucus nigra is native to Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, this hybrid was developed by Kenneth Richard Tobutt in the UK. Prune each year when dormant. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 2-9, 14-17.

Teucrium chamaedrys ‘Nanum’ (dwarf germander), low-growing dense groundcover 6 inches tall spreading 2-3 feet wide in time. Small, dark green leaves, lavender flowers in late spring. Native to the Mediterranean, sometimes sold as ‘Prostratum’. Spreads by underground stems. Full sun, tolerates light shade, most soils. Sunset zones: 2-24.

Tulbaghia ‘Ashanti’ (Ashanti society garlic), clumping grass-like perennial, 1-2 feet tall and 1-2 feet wide with narrow, fleshy leaves with a light garlic-like scent. Pale lavender-pink star-shaped flowers appear in the spring with blooms continuing until fall. A hybrid of Tulbaghia violacea and T. cominsii, both from South Africa. Full sun. Sunset Zones: 8, 9, 13-24; H1, H2.

Vitex agnus-castus ‘PIIVAC-I’ (Delta Blues™ chastetree), large deciduous shrub 8-10 feet tall and wide with green, palmately-compound leaves with 5-7 leaflets. This dwarf cultivar of the species has violet blue flowers that begin blooming in mid-summer and continuing to fall. Vitex agnus-castus is native to the Mediterranean regions and parts of Asia. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 4-24: H1, H2.

Westringia fruticosa ‘NFL25’ (Mundi coast rosemary), ground-hugging evergreen shrub 1-2 feet tall and 4-6 feet wide with very small, narrow, deep green leaves. Small white flowers appear in early spring. Westringia fruticosa is native to eastern Australia. Full sun, most soils. Sunset Zones 8, 9, 14-24.

Abelia × grandiflora 'Wevo1' (Bella Donna abelia), evergreen shrub, 24-36 inches high and 28-38 inches wide with light green ovate leaves that have a white margin and occasional white streaks through the center. White trumpet-shaped flowers with a mild sweet fragrance are borne in the spring and summer. Abelia × grandiflora is a cross between Abelia chinensis and Abelia uniflora. Part Shade in inland regions. Sunset Zones 4-24; H1, H2.

Abelia × grandiflora ‘Abelops’ (Sunshine Daydream Abelia), low-growing shrub 2-4 feet tall and wide with tri-color variegated lance shaped leaves on deep red stems. Tall stems may emerge from center and arch over creating a fountain-form effect, these may be pruned out for a lower, more compact appearance. Fragrant flowers appear from summer through fall, begin white and fade to pale rosy edges. Foliage is pest and disease free. High dappled shade, or morning sun with afternoon shade. Most soils. Sunset zones: 4-24, 28-35.

photos.filename: Nandina domestica dwarf cultivars (dwarf heavenly bamboo)
photos.caption: Nandina domestica dwarf cultivars (dwarf heavenly bamboo)

plants.culturalInformation: Nandina domestica dwarf cultivars (dwarf heavenly bamboo), evergreen shrub 12-18 inches after two years, eventually reaching 2-4 feet tall and wide. 'Lemon-Lime’ has bright chartreuse green new growth forming an attractive contrast to darker green older growth. 'Sunset Boulevard’ has contrasting new growth in copper, orange, and bright green colors. Part shade is recommended in inland climates, ideal exposure is morning sun and afternoon shade to prevent sunburn but still allow colors to develop. Nandina domestica is from China and Japan. Sunset Zones 3 (with protection), 4-24: H1, H2.

Saponaria x lempergii 'Max Frei'.filename: Saponaria × lempergii ‘Max Frei’ (hybrid soapwort), evergreen herbaceous perennial, 5 inches tall and spreading up to 2 feet wide, lance-shaped, hairy, dark green leaves and masses of pink flowers from summer into fall. Shear after bloom
Saponaria x lempergii 'Max Frei'.caption: Saponaria × lempergii ‘Max Frei’ (hybrid soapwort), evergreen herbaceous perennial, 5 inches tall and spreading up to 2 feet wide, lance-shaped, hairy, dark green leaves and masses of pink flowers from summer into fall. Shear after bloom to improve looks and for best rebloom. Stems are brittle, so keep away from foot traffic. Hybrid between two Mediterranean species. Full sun, most soils. Sunset zones: 7-9, 14-24.
